fields.headline: Flower caught in three minds
fields.standfirst: The Zimbabwe captain carries on juggling with Stewart's old dilemma
fields.trailText: David Hopps As the Nottingham Test approaches, Zimbabwe captain Andy Flower is juggling with the same dilemma that once vexed Alec Stewart.
fields.body:
Andy Flower's troubled state of mind in the build-up to the Nottingham Test, which starts tomorrow, was encapsulated in his dress for his opening television interview: a batting helmet complete with grille, plus arm-guard and pads. It was as if he intended to be fully protected against the burst of verbal bouncers that have assaulted him since Zimbabwe's capitulation at Lord's.

It was not just the margin of England's victory - by an innings and 209 runs - that so dismayed Flower. Neither was it the fact that Zimbabwe had so patently frozen in their first Test appearance at Lord's. It was that his own wicketkeeping display had fallen massively below the standards he regards as acceptable.

As if that was not enough, everywhere the Zimbabwe captain looked yesterday he discovered a fast bowler grunting about some ailment or other. Henry Olonga's ankle problem is once again likely to rob Zimbabwe of their most compulsive force, while Bryan Strang, Mpumelelo Mbangwa and Brian Murphy all have niggles. That leaves Heath Streak on his own, which is pretty much how it seemed to be for most of the Lord's test.

In the immediate aftermath of Lord's, Flower hinted broadly at a wicketkeeping debut for Tatenda Taibu, the tiny 17-year-old schoolboy, a product of Zimbabwe's development scheme. The name Tatenda means "thank you" in Shona, and everybody thrilled by the prospect of one of the unlikeliest Test debuts for years was ready to express their gratitude.

Since then reality has intruded. Taibu had an uncomfortable time last week against Yorkshire on a Headingley greentop, failing twice with the bat and keeping gingerly.

Flower's protective instincts make sense. "To be honest, I don't think Taibu's debut is going to happen, I don't think that it is the right time for him to play," he said. "I think I have to sort out my own game to help things click back into place. I kept pretty well as captain in the West Indies, so I know I can do both jobs."

A few yards away Alec Stewart, five years Flower's senior and a man who regularly grappled with the demands of top-order batsman, captain and wicketkeeper, was approaching his 97th test with his usual zest. Few internationals survive deep into their mid 30s without an exemplary attitude. Stewart's is as good as it gets.

"I wondered how long Alec would manage to combine the jobs but it didn't seem to affect him," Flower said. Once the series is over, he will seek him out and, this being cricket, insights will be shared.

There was some advice, though, to be going along with. "As long as you separate out the job of captaincy and concentrate on your keeping, then there is not a problem," Stewart said. "It is important to focus on your wicketkeeping because it is such a vital component in the field. The keeper is the centre of attention. If you have a good game, it lifts everybody. Have a bad half-hour and it can feed through.

"Andy is a top-class cricketer and his record with the bat while captain has been very good. It is important to lean on your vice-captain a lot, by asking him to translate messages or check fielding angles.

"They said that Andy dropped two easy catches at Lord's. But the edge from Mark Ramprakash was not as straightforward as it looked. The ball can snake and wobble around after it bounces; this one definitely dipped on him."

Stewart is a cricketing obsessive. It would be virtually impossible to exhaust him if he was asked to operate the PA system and supply the catering. He must be unbearable on holiday, asking his two kids for a knock-up within minutes of arriving on the beach. If Flower proves incapable of combining both jobs in the long term, it would not be an offence against nature.

Meanwhile, encouraged by his 100 at Lord's and by the central contracts system that will allow him to devise his own fitness and recuperation regimes away from the demands of county cricket, Stewart feels so sparky that he is even daring to wonder whether he might still be around for the next World Cup in South Africa in three years' time.

"It is not how old you are, it is how you are playing that counts," he said. "I've played solid cricket since 1981 and it has never crossed my mind to take a winter off."

fields.headline: Calypso comes to the rescue
fields.trailText: Paul Weaver Cricket died a few days ago. Or so it seemed. But when the West Indians fly into Gatwick, there will be a feeling of sunshine everywhere whatever the weather.
fields.body:
Cricket died a few days ago. Or so it seemed. A combination of heavy rain, bad light and a Siberian ice blast had driven every player from every field in the country. The traffic on the M25 was motionless for miles, as if in mourning, and the only cricket news on the radio was about corruption, match-fixing, taped conversations and delayed reports.

Everyone, fearing he might be exposed as an innocent, has become a cynic instead. And, just as it was when Ben Johnson's stunning burst in the 100 metres in the Seoul Olympics was exposed as being less than legitimate, nothing is trusted any more. Seeing is no longer believing.

But the cricket season starts this morning, when the West Indians fly into Gatwick, and, whatever the weather, there will be a feeling of sunshine everywhere.

West Indies are the world's most wonderful cricketers, the Brazil of the flannelled game, and, even though they are not at their best at the moment, their recent victories over Zimbabwe and Pakistan should help pull the game out of its malady.

Think of Lord's in 1950, Edgbaston in 1957, Lord's again in 1963, the Oval in 1966 and 1976 and Headingley in 1991, and cricket already feels alive and well.

This is the centenary year of the first tour of England by West Indian cricketers. Then there were five black players in the party of 15 and one newspaper was worried by the "slipshod and lazy" approach of the tourists.

The Boy's Own Paper talked of the "great novelty of the presence of coloured men playing on a cricket field in England" while expressing concern that they might take the field "without boots and in very sparse attire".

Even then, though, the West Indians showed an unusual exuberance for the game, even when they were being hopelessly outplayed.

In June 1900 they played Gloucestershire at Bristol. Gilbert Jessop went in to bat at 2.30pm and was out at 3.30. In exactly an hour he scored 157 and put on 201 for the sixth wicket with Charlie Townsend.

Jessop reached 50 in 20 minutes, 83 out of 105 in 30 minutes, 102 in 43 minutes and then added another 55 in 17 minutes. The Bristol Times and Mirror reported: "Nobody enjoyed this wonderful spell of phenomenal scoring more than the coloured men in the ranks of the visitors.

"They were hugely delighted. One of them would sit down and literally shake with laughter after a big hit. When 50 was signalled as Jessop's score this particular player turned round and asked one of the spectators: 'Has he been in 10 minutes yet?' His behaviour was typical of that of his colleagues."

The West Indies captain Aucher Warner said: "When Jessop hit six fours in a single over the coloured members in the side sat down on the ground and shouted with laughter at the unfortunate bowler's discomfiture."

.When the West Indians returned in 1906 their games were given first-class status and in 1928 they made their first test tour. They were beaten 3-0 and fared little better in 1933 and 1939. Then, in 1950, the world changed. They came to England with Sonny Ramadhin and Alf Valentine and the three Ws - Worrell, Weekes and Walcott - and won 3-1.

It was the same year that England's footballers were beaten by the United States in the World Cup and three years before Hungary's "Magical Magyars" beat England 6-3 at Wembley. It was the end of the Empire.

fields.headline: Underlined in music
fields.trailText:
Birmingham Contemporary Music Group/Adès

CBSO Centre, Birmingham

****
fields.body:
Composers have written songs without words, so why not opera without words? From one angle, that is how John Woolrich's new piece Bitter Fruit could be viewed. It is a three-act stage work, with a continuous musical score, lasting longer than Berg's Wozzeck and most of Janacek's operas; but apart from a few sexual grunts and groans at the final climax (two couples caught grotesquely in the act), the characters remain completely silent.

But Woolrich's score does not simply mime opera: there is little instrumental "singing" in the conventional sense. It mixes Birtwistle-like angry expressionism with the weird, mechanical-toy style Woolrich has made his own. And yet there is pathos: the violent, sad fairy tale of the gifted, Caliban-like Feast (a reworking of the Greek Hephaestus myth), alternately rejected and duped by his cruel aristocratic parents, invites our pity - the emotion acutely but unsentimentally underlined by the music.

Woolrich's invention never flags. It was no surprise to discover that the score came first, and that Trestle Theatre Company's Toby Wilsher designed both the story and the production to fit what Woolrich had already written. On the whole, action and music work very effectively together. The only problems relate not to the fairy-tale plot, but to the sub-plot. Bitter Fruit is a masque, with the characters played by the Greek gods. We sense that all is not well behind the scenes - rivalries, resentments, a complicated web of desire and frustration. But it is as hard to follow these as it is easy to chart the central drama. Toby Wilsher may have seen this as a virtue: leave the audience to work out what the back-stage shenanigans mean. But often this peripheral business is just confusing. And when, at the end, the masks are dropped and the gods' private drama spills on to the stage, it is hard to make out who exactly is doing what, to whom, and why. Woolrich builds the final revenge climax splendidly; but at the high point, Wilsher pulls the rug out from under his feet.

But until that final parting of the ways, Bitter Fruit makes a compelling and very entertaining music-theatrical fable. Trestle Theatre brought the action to life vividly, and Birmingham Contemporary Music Group, under its director Thomas Adès, did the same and more for Woolrich's music - it is rare to hear a first performance that sounds so assured and enthusiastic. But those are the qualities we are learning to expect from BCMG.

fields.headline: Commerzbank tries to steady Jupiter
fields.standfirst:
Committee set up in attempt to keep senior players after chief executive quits
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Committee set up in attempt to keep senior players after chief executive quits
fields.body:
Commerzbank was last night locked in bonus and pay negotiations with its senior Jupiter fund managers after the sudden departure of John Duffield, the high profile chief executive of the fund management operation.

Steve Glynn, the head of retail marketing at Jupiter, said conversations had just begun about "incentivising and motivating" important fund managers in order to prevent any mass departures from the business, which manages funds of some £14bn for thousands of small investors and major institutions. While the fund management unit bought by Commerzbank bank in 1995 would do little other than to confirm the departure of the chief executive, industry sources believe that any many as nine of the 12 board members of Jupiter were also leaving.

Commerzbank yesterday put in place a new executive committee to run the Jupiter operation, naming Edward Bonham Carter, the brother of actress Helena, and Jonathan Carey as joint chief executives.

Alan Miller, the head of specialist funds, and Martin Schueller, the head of interna tional business development, were named as the remaining two members of the fund manager's executive committee.

The departure of Mr Duffield follows negotiations about the new structure of the operation after Commerzbank took full ownership of the business in April - when it paid £500m for the remaining 25% owned by the Jupiter fund managers. Mr Duffield was said to have made £175m from that sale.

Mr Glynn stressed that no fund managers had left the business. It was unclear whether Mr Duffield, who is believed to be in his 60s, in tended to set up a rival operation or whether he would receive any pay-off from the German bank.

Perpetual, one of Jupiter's closest rivals, last night said it was "by no means" certain it would end up being put on the market after appointing Merrill Lynch and Cazenove to advise it on its "strategic options".

Amvescap, the largest fund management group listed on the stock market, is thought to still be interested in the operation but had been knocked out of negotiations, which were never confirmed, after buying Trimark of Canada.

Roger Cornick, the deputy chairman of Perpetual, said the operation, 45% controlled by founder Martin Arbib and his family, remained in takeover negotiations.

However, he indicated that the process was likely to take "months rather than weeks" and may not even result in the sale of the business. "A strategic review means just that," Mr Cornick said.

The shares rose by £1 to £38.50, but remained well below the £45 a share many industry sources believe Mr Arbib hopes to receive for the business he founded and which grew on the back of the personal equity plan industry.

fields.headline: Mike Phillips's top 10 crime novels
fields.trailText: Mike Phillips's latest book, A Shadow of Myself, is published by HarperCollins
fields.body:
Mike Phillips's latest book, A Shadow of Myself, is published by HarperCollins.
Buy A Shadow of Myself at Amazon.co.uk

1. A Coffin for Demetrios by Eric Ambler
Extraordinary originality for a time when the anodyne Agatha Christie was a bestseller. Still fresh as new, it is a political satire and a travelogue round eastern Europe as well as a gripping thriller.

2. Name of the Rose by Umberto Eco
Like walking a maze through history. Wonderful characters and an intricate, coruscatingly brilliant plot.

3. Gorky Park by Martin Cruz Smith
Displays an amazing grasp of the social geography of cold war Russia, predicting the issue of organised crime in the east.

4. The Miracle Game by Josef Skvorecky
Funny, original, acute outline of Czech society. It argues the social construction of 'crime' and its role as an instrument of political power.

5. The Secret Agent by Joseph Conrad
Bitter satire about a corrupt society. There's not been anything better about terrorism and the state.

6. Red Harvest by Dashiell Hammett
Often imitated but no one has done it better. Chandler was cuter but he lacked Hammett's knowledge, passion and political bite. In his hands Hammett's satirical lambasting of California society eventually became an endlessly cliched formula.

7. The Woman in White by Wilkie Collins
Union of gothic horror, mystery, and the leisurely detail of 19th century characterisation, along with a pre-cinematic approach to narration. Reading it again is a surprising pleasure.

8. The Way We Die Now by Charles Willeford
One of the few American crime writers to avoid propagating a rightwing agenda.This book is exceptional in focusing on the cruel exploitation and murder of migrant workers in Southern farms.

9. Murder in the Central Committee by Manuel Vazquez Montalban
Neglected Spanish master.

10. Brighton Rock by Graham Greene
Greene's entertainments look better now than most of his pretentious and overpraised 'serious novels'. One of the few British crime novels of the time which matched the modernist tone of the Americans, while remaining completely authentic.

fields.headline: Bring on the stadium
fields.trailText:
Jack Lukeman

Renfrew Ferry, Glasgow

***
fields.body:
Not that long ago 26-year-old Jack Lukeman was an apprentice motor mechanic who would bounce his considerable voice off the walls of his boss's garage, an impromptu rehearsal room in County Kildare. Now he is a genuine pop phenomenon, just about to play three consecutive sell-outs at Dublin's Point Stadium. He needs only to cough to fill auditoria across the Republic and, seemingly, New York and Paris.

But Lukeman is little known in Britain: he made his Scottish debut at the quietest gig of the buzzing Big Big Country Festival. Seventy people (at a push) on Glasgow's permanently docked Renfrew Ferry is not a stadium crowd, yet the four-piece band, behind a battery of guitars and keyboards, played a huge, florid introduction as Lukeman made his dramatic entrance wearing thin sunglasses, even thinner trademark goatee and a frock-coat.

Everything about this melodramatic show was big. Lukeman is obviously used to massive crowds and immediate singalongs, so his stagecraft seemed slightly preposterous in the circumstances, as if U2 had played a Clydeside pub in full stadium mode.

The opening Georgie Boy, co-written with guitarist David Constantine, was characteristic of Lukeman's high-flown songs, treading the Bohemian path of Jacques Brel and Scott Walker and filled with romance and yearning. Lukeman looks almost human when he takes off his coat and shades and calms down enough to sing rather than strut. And he does have a phenomenal voice, close to Scott Walker's in its tone, control and huge range.

If only the show were less overwrought. My advice? Crank down the presentation, sit on a stool now and again and let the fabulous voice work for itself.

fields.headline: Wish you were here?
fields.standfirst: Unemployment in Newbury is so low that some firms pay £2,000 to staff who bring a friend on board and shelf-stackers are paid twice the minimum wage. A worker's paradise? Not exactly, says Oliver Burkeman
fields.trailText: Unemployment in Newbury is so low that some firms pay £2,000 to staff who bring a friend on board and shelf-stackers are paid twice the minimum wage. A worker's paradise? Not exactly
fields.body:
High-flying executives and dot.com climbers in some parts of the country would kill for the perks that come with Niki Evans's job. Share options, two mobile phones, free travel to work and a fat pension are all hers for the taking, together with special deals on cars, televisions, hi-fi equipment, sports clubs, food outlets and clothes shops. But Evans, 29, isn't working at the pulsating hub of the new economy, or doing something lucrative, incomprehensible and soul-destroying in a merchant bank. She is a secretary in a moderately sized home counties market town. And her 3,500-plus fellow employees all get similar privileges.

This isn't some thinktank's idea of utopia. And whatever Evans's employer, Vodafone, might say, it's not really generosity, either: even the market leader has to keep an eye out for the next set of head-frying rumours or a vertiginous plunge in tech stocks, and generosity doesn't come cheap. There is a far more hard-headed reason: full employment. This is Newbury in Berkshire, home of the lowest unemployment rate in the country: 1%, compared to a national average of 4% and a high in South Tyneside and Haringey in London of 12.3%. Only Basingstoke in Hampshire - and some small tourist resorts during the high season - can match it.

For most economists, Newbury's rate counts as full employment - and even with the muscle that comes from being the biggest employer in town, Vodafone clearly figures some sweeteners are necessary just to hang on to the workers they already have, never mind the 100-plus Newbury-based vacancies on their books at any one time. Staff who recruit friends to fill empty positions can claim bonuses of between £200 and £2,000, depending on the seniority of the job. Some of the perks are available at the company's other UK sites, but nowhere are they more essential than in Newbury. "We run into brick walls," says Mike Caldwell, Vodafone's head of corporate communications, "where we've just employed all of the secretaries, all of the drivers, or whatever, that there are in the area."

A little further down the food chain, employers are even more desperate to seduce the limited workforce. Every other shop advertises multiple vacancies, while such recruitment agencies as manage to scrape a living cram their windows with ads for temporary data inputters and filing clerks subtly reworded to make them sound like once-in-a-lifetime career opportunities. Acres of classifieds in the Newbury Weekly News offer cleaning and shelf-stack ing jobs at twice the minimum wage and beyond.

"You've got two types of people in Newbury," says Debbie Twyning, manager of the Fabric Land store in the town centre, who is currently struggling to fill two positions. "Those who are in jobs - and those who don't want them." It is, without doubt, the employees who call the shots in Newbury. But they call them in a way that might surprise some traditional economists.

Certainly, Newbury's exceptional circumstances turn the usual experience of wage-slavery on its head. The job search is viewed as a bizarre and alien ritual: leaving her last job, Evans took one day off work to fire off applications and had a sheaf of offers - two from the same company - within a week.

Her colleague, Michelle Burgess, 23, didn't even make it that far: she was scooped up by Vodafone straight from sixth form and sponsored through university to a job at the other end.

"It's a nightmare," says Pauline Evans, managing director of Profile Recruitment, in the morgue-like silence of her agency's office. Companies hold bidding wars for temporary staff; permanent admin posts for moderately skilled second-jobbers kick off at £13,000. "Between four and five o'clock yesterday we took orders for 13 temporary staff. We filled two. The people just are not there."

But not everything is working the way economic theory suggests it should. Workers in areas of full employment are supposed to be hawkish, fickle creatures, flitting from job to job in search of higher salaries or better perks. Turnover should be high, and wages should be spiralling as workers holding all the cards bargain with eager-to-please employers. But it's not turning out that way.

For a start, loyalty - supposedly a key casualty of full employment and the knowledge economy alike - isn't dead. Talk to just about any Newbury employee and the responses are the same: security and satisfaction, an employer's reputation and the workplace culture rate far higher than minor increases in pay.

"Money's the least of it for me," is one typical comment. "Enjoying the job is what matters. And 95% of my job is enjoyable. Money's just a bonus on top." According to Thames Valley Enterprise, wages are increasing at around 7% annually - the national average is not much lower, at around 5% - and turnover in jobs is not exceptionally high; at Vodafone it is only around 8%. Caldwell hasn't had a leaving do in his department for five years.

Another surprisingly beleaguered resident of this paradise on earth is Gordon Bull, principal of Newbury College, the local further and adult education provider. Of all people, his role - feeding a ravenous job market - should be a cinch. But quite apart from his own staff retention woes, Bull has another worry. His younger, full-time students - especially those training in the technology sector - keep getting lured off their courses and into jobs. "There's a huge temptation to give up studies and go and get a job," says Bull, sipping coffee in his office and frowning. "My worry is that while that might make them happy now, what will it mean for their futures? There's an enormous pressure, and some of the local employers do try to tempt the good ones away."

And while it might elicit little sympathy in South Tyneside or Haringey, there's a further concern: the agony of choice. "Students are faced with a huge amount of options," Bull says. "It's not a question of what's on offer - there's a huge amount on offer - it's a question of what people should go for. That can be just as demanding."

There are some unemployed people in Newbury - 523 registered claimants throughout the parliamentary constituency at last count - but 519 of them aren't in the Newbury Jobcentre this wet weekday afternoon. Three advisers serve three of the jobseekers; a fourth has the hundreds of job ads on display to himself. There will, of course, be others - the unemployed not registered as such - yet the Jobcentre's near-emptiness is still something of a social triumph.

But economics may, after all, have the last laugh: this glorious state of affairs may not last forever. The real problem with full employment, critics argue, is that it impedes competitiveness and obstructs growth; while Vodafone is here for the duration, other companies may eventually give up and move away, shedding local jobs. It hasn't happened yet, but it's on the horizon.

"I know of three companies that are moving out or closing at the end of this year," says Pauline Evans. "I'm beginning to suspect that it's now so tight in Newbury that people will start to relocate whole companies. The companies will vote with their feet. Anyone who wants to start a business in Newbury today is daft."

fields.headline: Buyers queue for Scottish Provident
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Scottish Provident, the Edinburgh-based mutual insurer, has received a number of approaches from potential buyers but intends to talk to other bidders before deciding whether to untap windfalls for its policyholders.
fields.body:
Scottish Provident, the Edinburgh-based mutual insurer, has received a number of approaches from potential buyers but intends to talk to other bidders before deciding whether to untap windfalls for its policyholders.

As Standard Life stepped up its fight against carpetbaggers calling for its demutualisation, Scottish Provident - which has appointed Robert Fleming to conduct a "rigorous review" of all its options - admitted it was not "wedded to mutuality for its own sake".

However, Scottish Provident tried to play down speculation that the outcome of the review was a foregone conclusion which would lead to demutualisation. Chairman John Foden said at the insurer's annual meeting that he hoped the review would be completed by late summer. The objective of the review was to "increase value for members".

"I must reiterate that the board will take an objective view and has no favoured position," Mr Foden said.

His comments contrasted with those from Standard Life, whose management is fiercely opposed to demutualiation and yesterday took the gamble of urging policyholders to take the "principled" decision to vote to stay a mutual while conceding that some of them would be better off opting for a windfall.

Europe's largest mutual life insurer is fighting an attempt by rebel members to force a float and pay windfalls they say will average £5,000-£6,300.

fields.headline: Forever grunge
fields.standfirst:
Pearl Jam
Wembley Arena
***
fields.trailText:
Pearl Jam
Wembley Arena
***
fields.body:
In the US, Pearl Jam are held up as everything a big rock band should be: unswervingly dedicated to their brooding art, with a complementary streak of good-eggness that has seen them take on the ticket agencies over booking fees. They have never achieved iconic status here, and are losing ground to younger depressives such as Korn, but they are revered enough to have sold out an arena tour after a four-year absence, during which they reverted to the self-fulfilling pessimism that characterised their landmark debut, Ten.

The new album, Binaural, is full of what sound like petulant adolescent jottings, with leader Eddie Vedder intoning such non-observations as "It's nothing like a poem/Putting in, inputting in/Don't feel like methadone". That is from the single Nothing as it Seems, and there is a lot more where that came from, emanating from an eternal teen hell where nobody understands them and every day is a bad hair day.

The whole deal, including Vedder's feel-my-pain groaning, makes a certain amount of sense live, enveloping Wembley in a enjoyably indulgent fug of teen angst. Sometimes it is hard to believe that the newly shorn Eddie and colleagues are well into their 30s, such is their self-absorption. To watch them, backlit on a bare stage, is to be transported back to 1991, when the Seattle fivesome represented the only serious competition for Nirvana's grunge crown. They haven't changed all that much since, either in terms of presentation - no visuals, no video screens, no way for the back rows to enjoy guitarist Stone Gossard's cleavage-exposing shorts - or musical aesthetic.

Simplicity turns out to be a virtue, however: the songs take centre stage. Pearl Jam have two live modes - melancholically soaring and melancholically listless - and are equally impressive whether rocking the joint with the classic Even Flow or hypnotically daydreaming on Nothing as it Seems. Given to Fly, a recent minor hit, is post-grunge at its sulky best, and at its squalling apex, the front of the house rhythmically undulates, crowd-surfers offering themselves up to Vedder like so many sacrificial lambs. He's too wrapped up in some private emotion to respond, and through much of the 26-song set seems to be somewhere else entirely. Perhaps he's communing with the spirit of old rival Kurt Cobain, who would have to admit that, for old grungeheads, Pearl Jam have still got it.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: <A HREF="http://www.workunlimited.co.uk/">Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stephen Bates, 48 Financial director
fields.body:
Stephen Bates, 48 Financial director

If you're working your way up within a company, gauge the personality of a future boss from a distance. I used to work for a multinational where the chief executive was particularly difficult. By the time I got a job reporting directly to him, I had spent the previous six months watching how he worked and learning to read him. He hated competition so I made a point of showing him how my skills complemented the way he worked. He had a short attention span so I learned to develop concise written solutions to problems. I worked successfully with him for years.

Suzanne Chambers, 28 IT manager

I had a boss who hired me because I was a workhorse, but then found me threatening because I got on better with everyone and did a good job. She would set me up by putting me in charge of projects she knew would present problems, or she'd take credit for my work. How did I deal with her? I didn't bitch about her behind her back and I was measured and friendly to her face. She didn't have that many friends in the organisation so it didn't take people long to realise my worth - despite her.

Claire Baker, 35 Marketing manager

I had a boss who was quite mad. He never made notes, and made huge pronouncements only to forget them the next day. I'd work like a dog on a project which he would completely forget about. Or he'd criticise me for doing something he'd asked me to do. So I kept records of everything and ignored his sillier suggestions. We redesigned the company logo just before he went on holiday and he asked me to fax him in India with the final design. I ignored him - it would have taken too long. When he came back he'd forgotten all about it.

Sarah Johnson, 39 Fundraiser

My boss would have meetings with potential sponsors without telling me. He'd spend £130 on lunch for three and - because he saw himself as a VIP - he'd never take any notes. He'd agree for me to do things without telling me and I'd find the correspondence 10 months later. In the end I tactfully drew up a list of the things I thought I was employed to do. I showed it to him and asked him to add anything he wanted, or to cross out anything that he thought was his job, not mine. He seemed happy with the list. Afterwards, when he stepped over the mark I had proof.

Amanda Baker, 42 Events manager

I was the only employee in a new business. My boss would phone me at 11pm with some non-urgent query, or ask me to do cold-calling for new business, which I hated. I had to be firm with her, as if she were a spoilt child. I'd say she'd gone too far; she'd be contrite, then do it all again. She bought a dog and asked me to look after it at work. I said I was not her dog's PA and she'd have to make other arrangements. She never suggested bringing the dog to work again.

fields.headline: House prices fall slightly
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: House prices have fallen this month for the first time since August 1998, according to figures released yesterday, adding weight to suggestions that the property market is slowing down.
fields.body:
House prices have fallen this month for the first time since August 1998, according to figures released yesterday, adding weight to suggestions that the property market is slowing down.

The cost of an average home fell 0.4% in May, according to the Nationwide building society's survey. It believes consumer confidence in London and the south-east, the region which led the upturn, may have been dented by a combination of the recent stock market turmoil, fears of higher interest rates and the abolition last month of mortgage interest tax relief (Miras).

Its figures coincided with Land Registry data published today which showed that several towns and cities in the south, including Bath, Brighton and Bournemouth, have overtaken Greater London and with price rises of up to 38% in 12 months.

According to the Nationwide, while the cost of the average home rose £113 to £81,006 this month, on a seasonally adjusted basis they fell 0.4%, compared with the increases of 2.3% and 1.6% achieved in March and April respectively.

The figures come after figures issued on Friday showed that mortgage lending by the high street banks fell in April to £5.8bn from £6.5bn the previous month.

They also coincide with a warning from the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development that interest rates will have to go up to prevent a surge in inflation above the Bank of England's 2.5% target.

"With little slack in the labour market, a buoyant housing market, a widening external trade deficit and domestically generated inflation running above 2.5%, the bank faces the difficult task of cooling domestic demand while hoping this does not put too much further upward pres sures on the exchange rate," the think tank warned.

Quarterly figures for England and Wales published by the Land Registry show that the price of a typical home has risen 16.8% in a year, the highest figure since its records began in 1995. The figures compare prices in January 1 to March 31 this year with the same period last year. For England and Wales as a whole, the average price tag is now £99,295. Greater London tops the regional table with an average price of £163,317, while the figure for the north of England is £59,343.

fields.headline: Freeserve rises 24% on T-Online buy rumour
fields.standfirst:
City reads Telekom's refusal to deny speculation as confirmation of British ISP bid

E-finance: special report
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Deutsche Telekom and its majority-owned subsidiary, T-Online, yesterday proved that silence can be golden when their refusal to deny rumours that the latter is preparing a £6.5bn bid for Freeserve prompted a 24% surge in the internet service provider's share price.
fields.body:
Deutsche Telekom and its majority-owned subsidiary, T-Online, yesterday proved that silence can be golden when their refusal to deny rumours that the latter is preparing a £6.5bn bid for Freeserve prompted a 24% surge in the internet service provider's share price.

Dealers returned to their desks in London after the bank holiday weekend to find Freeserve shares marked up sharply on speculation that a 650p per share bid from Germany's largest internet outfit was imminent.

Although both German companies refused to comment on the reports, Deutsche senior vice-president Thomas Winkler added fuel to the fire by confirming that T-Online was searching for acquisitions, saying: "We are not a sitting duck - we want to take active part in the consolidation process."

Freeserve has been the centre of intense takeover speculation since the start of this month, when it was revealed that retailer Dixons had appointed investment bank Goldman Sachs to review the future of its 80% holding in the company.

Analysts believe that Freeserve -the only leading domestic European internet service provider not owned by a telecoms company - is most likely to be sold to the Deutsche-backed T-Online.

Cable company NTL, British Telecommunications and Energis have both been mentioned as possible counter-bidders but T-Online is seen as favourite to strike a deal.

Peter Misek, an internet analyst at Chase H&Q, said a deal between Freeserve and T-Online would give both a much needed pan-European presence, generate significant cost savings across a number of technology platforms and allow the combine a critical mass of users. "It's a deal that makes a lot of sense," he said.

Analysts believe that BT, which also recently announced a restructuring, is seen as having enough to do without entering an auction for Freeserve, while it is unclear whether NTL shareholders would be prepared to fund such a large bid.

Dixons has promised not to sell any of its shares before June 27 - Freeserve's first anniversary as a public company and the date that it reports its full-year results. But observers believe the stock exchange may be ready to wave through a bid before then, providing it represents a healthy premium for Freeserve shareholders.

Although Freeserve shares have traded as high as 950p this year they tumbled in the sell-off of tech stocks. Analysts believe that a bid of about 650p could secure a deal in light of recent turbulence. Last night Freeserve shares closed up 95p at 487p, with Dixons shares up 28.5p at 302p.

webTitle: Heroic Adams takes it at the wire

fields.headline: Heroic Adams takes it at the wire
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan 269 & 219
West Indies 273 & 216-9
West Indies win by one wicket
Scoreboard
fields.trailText:
Pakistan 269 & 219

West Indies 273 & 216-9

West Indies win by one wicket
fields.byline: BC Pires  at St John's, Antigua
fields.body:
The concept of tense final moments was stretched slowly to nerve-racking final hours on the last day of the third Test yesterday. With only 72 runs needed for victory at 10.05am, it was not until 2.20pm that Jimmy Adams, playing a captain's innings worth far more than his final 48, hit the single to get past the target of 215 and win the series.

The Antiguan governor-general Sir James Beethoven Carlisle knighted Sir Vivian Richards in front of the pavilion that bears his name during the luncheon interval but the royal performance came from Adams, who took the score from 169 to 216 with four bowlers, one of whom was Courtney Walsh.

When Wavell Hinds pulled a high Wasim Akram delivery on to his wicket on the last ball of the fourth day, the match turned in favour of Pakistan, as Hinds himself acknowledged in his speech accepting the man of the series award.

Adams, playing with intense concentration and patience, shielded the vulnerable West Indian lower order from the fierce bowling of the man of the match Wasim Akram who, in ideal swing bowler's conditions, nearly turned Adams' Caribbean monarchy into an Islamic republic. The match seemed to be Pakistan's when Walsh, the holder of the record for the number of Test wickets (449) and the number of Test ducks (36) came to the crease with 19 runs still needed and Wasim on fire.

Pakistan ought to have won at least twice. Television replays showed that Walsh should have been out off bat and pad on the second ball he faced with the score on 200.

Four runs later both Adams and Walsh ought to have been run out by the length of the pitch. With both men in the striker's crease, the wicket-keeper Moin Khan took the bails off at that end. Adams began scampering back to the bowler's end and saw the ball beat him to Mushtaq Saqlain's hands but Saqlain spilled the ball, allowing Adams to get in.

Amazingly the same thing had happened with Adams and Curtly Ambrose with the score on 188 for seven. That such an incident could take place twice was indicative of the tension; even the final drinks break came four runs from the end.

The first West Indies wicket to go was the young Guyanese Ramnaresh Sarwan who, in his second test, faced 24 balls for his six runs but was lbw to Wasim 55 from the target. Ridley Jacobs was run out for five with 47 to get, while Ambrose, in what looks to be his last match at his home ground, managed eight, the highest score of the lower order. He later confirmed his retirement after the England tour.

webTitle: Thomson rides in with a charge to square Zimbabwe's shoulders

fields.headline: Thomson rides in with a charge to square Zimbabwe's shoulders
fields.standfirst: Frank Keating  finds bowling coach upbeat before second Test
fields.trailText: Frank Keating finds Zimbabwe's bowling coach upbeat before the second Test
fields.body:
By far the gloomiest of the many sombre and soggy clouds which swirled and circled over St John's Wood throughout the first Test between England and Zimbabwe was the cruelly unshifting one which settled from the very start over the hapless visitors' dressing-room balcony. Stygian in both portent and outcome, it was, nevertheless, illuminated at regular intervals by the appearance of an optimistic beacon of luminous good cheer in the shape and dazzle of the visiting coach's hairdo.

It could only be Thommo.

Once the most feared and famed of fast bowlers, the Australian Jeff Thomson is a peripatetic cricketing nomad dispensing solid technical sense and earthy four-lettered wisdom to any player or team in need of a lift either spiritual or temporal. And up on that Lord's balcony last week, for crestfallen Zimbabwe, their assistant coach's great busby of a coiffure confidently glowed not so much a silver lining but one of leonine orangey-gold. If any team needs some colourful good cheer it is Zimbabwe and Thomson takes them to Trent Bridge today thoroughly determined to help them put Lord's behind them.

"There are a heap of lessons to be learned from Lord's," says Thomson, "and a heap of pride to be restored. I'm just praying we're mentally tough enough to come back after such a thrashing. Sure, we know we lack strength in depth but do we also lack strength of will, mental discipline and application? We're going to find out this week at Nottingham, aren't we?"

He will not find an excuse in Zimbabwe's political turmoils at home. Nor, as cricketing mentor, should he. But it is hard for a neutral to dismiss them. A year ago these same tourists were strutting, keen and slickly athletic, through the early rounds of the World Cup. Twelve months on and they have not displayed any of that bright-eyed readiness for battle; all 1999's dagger-sharpness in the field is sadly blunt and careworn. Those broad shoulders are hunched and rounded now, the competitive edge all ragged. Since arriving this time, they have looked wary and worried, fretful for home. And no wonder.

Zimbabwe cricket is strapped for cash. Thomson boosts his coach's wages with journalism and broadcasting - and his style is as directly unsettling as his toe-crunching yorker used to be. The day after Zimbabwe's Lord's surrender his poor team must have cringed doubly on reading their coach's slating censure in his column in London's Evening Standard. As intros go, this was pure Thommo.

"We lost the toss, lost three wickets for nothing before I'd blinked, lost the plot with the rest of the batting, lost any chance to put England under a bit of pressure through not supporting Heath Streak, lost two TV replay decisions and eventually lost by an innings and more than I care to remember. I think the only thing we didn't lose was our way back to the hotel each evening," he wrote.

In fact, as senior bowling coach only recently introduced to his charges, Thomson has no reason to upbraid himself. The burly Streak was simply terrific at Lord's and the tenderfoot Pommie Mbangwa showed willing promise (Mbangwa's 10-wicket haul against Yorkshire's stiffs this weekend has further fired his potential). But the catching and wicket-keeping was dire, and the batting flaccid. With the luck of the toss Zimbabwe's bowlers could cash in at Nottingham. "Sure," Thomson says, "but even then our batsmen have to make at least 350 in their first knock for us to be remotely competitive." It must be a strain for a merciless old Pommie basher to be back over here in the also-rans frame.

The last time Thomson played a test at Trent Bridge was in 1977 - Geoffrey Boycott's "comeback" test and Ian Botham's auspicious first - and, when he came into bat at No10 just before tea on the first day and in the middle of Beefy's first "five-for", he was greeted with noisy acclaim from the rafters. Announced all over Fleet Street's back pages that morning had been his "heroic", "noble", "honourable" decision not to take Kerry Packer's upcoming sackfuls of shillings.

For a brief period English cricket had thought that Packer was being thwarted at last by an upright moral crusader - until the truth emerged a few weeks later that it was Thommo's employers at the time, Queensland radio station 4IP, who were refusing to let him work, even in a fast-bowling capacity, for a deadly media rival from Sydney. Still, for those few days at Nottingham, the sudden darling of the English establishment bathed warmly in the unlikely approbation, bowled very fast and took three good wickets.

In 1981 Thommo briefly joined Middlesex and few in England can have bowled more venomously quick. It was fascinating to hear on Test Match Special in one of the many breaks for rain at Lord's earlier this month the recall of Vic Marks and our own Mike Selvey of a Lord's morning that June 6 when Somerset's Viv Richards smouldered in to take on the terrifyingly fast Thomson. Blast and withering counter-blast for an hour or so, it was, by both accounts, a truly epic and breathtaking contest, a championship rumble, a cricketing Ali v Frazier.

Thomson toured England again in 1985 and he took the wickets he needed to post his 200 for all Tests and his 100th v England. The double century had cost this utterly dynamic, uncomplicated cricketer just 28 runs each. In all, he took 675 wickets at 26.

He retired, he said, to fish and surf, "to enjoy the bush and the ocean" - and, when he got restless, "perhaps a bit of coaching here and there". Which is why, nearing 50, he and his luminous beacon of a hairdo is back at Trent Bridge. "Only hard work can put matters right for Zim - and there isn't long till Thursday."

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Glamorgan Dragons, the Benson & Hedges Cup finalists, yesterday made it two wins in two days when they saw off Derbyshire Scorpions in their National League second division match at Sophia Gardens.
fields.body:
Glamorgan Dragons, the Benson & Hedges Cup finalists, yesterday made it two wins in two days when they saw off Derbyshire Scorpions in their National League second division match at Sophia Gardens.

The former Australia opener Matthew Elliott made the lion's share of the runs, 88 helping his side to a six-wicket win with 12 balls to spare, only their second National League win this season.

Derbyshire, playing on the pitch where they disposed of Surrey in the B&H Cup semi-final, opted to field and soon had Matt Cassar and Michael Di Venuto struggling with the low bounce.

Di Venuto was out in the 12th over, hitting all around Owen Parkin with the score on 48, and Cassar followed for 29 seven overs later.

Robert Croft soon had Mathew Dowman caught behind for 25 and Derbyshire were struggling on 107 for three in the 30th over. Steve Titchard (33) and Rob Bailey (39) offered some resistance, however, putting on 63 in 13 overs before the former Northamptonshire captain fell to a fine catch by Darren Thomas at midwicket. He hit two of only four boundaries in the Derby innings as they reached 185 in their 45 overs.

The visitors' Tim Munton, with a spell of one for 28, managed to exert a firm grip but after the pinch-hitting Croft was removed by Dominic Cork for 19 and Michael Powell departed for a single, Elliott and Matthew Maynard put on 92 in 22 overs before Maynard flicked a catch to square leg when on 40.

Elliott managed seven fours and a six before a fine throw from Cork curtailed his input, but the intervention came too late for the visitors.

fields.headline: Cunliffe courage earns third final
fields.standfirst:
Gloucestershire 220-6
Lancashire 205-9
Gloucestershire win by 15 runs
fields.trailText:
Gloucestershire 220-6
Lancashire 205-9
Gloucestershire win by 15 runs
fields.body:
As Gloucestershire triumphed in both one-day finals last summer, there was a sense that however well they had played it was all a bit of an aberration. Such a grudging assessment will have to be reappraised today after they secured a third successive date at Lord's, where they will meet Glamorgan in the Benson and Hedges version. And they overcame the undisputed masters of limited-overs cricket, Lancashire, to achieve it.

Under the shrewd, understated captaincy of Mark Alleyne, Gloucestershire have become a side that consistently does the simple things well. A county with few acknowledged stars and, until eight months ago, modest success, has developed an impressive mental toughness. Lancashire, set 221 and fortunate to fall 15 runs short, were well beaten.

Gloucestershire's determination was exemplified by Rob Cunliffe, who was chosen only half-an-hour before the start because of injury to Ian Harvey. He battled gamely for 71 from 113 balls, and needed a hospital x-ray on a bruised toe after being hit twice by Andy Flintoff. "It's not broken, so I should be fit for Lord's," Cunliffe said.

His county have been short of top-order runs all season but their one-day confidence remained undimmed, and in Cunliffe they had a batsman whose peculiar career summed up their predilections. His Benson&Hedges average, at more than 50, is twice his record in the championship.

Tim Hancock began blisteringly, then fell leg-glancing, magnificently snapped up by Warren Hegg; Matt Windows busied himself in mid-innings and Alleyne's 32 from 28 balls provided late impetus.

For one Lancastrian, defeat seemed unthinkable. Neil Fairbrother had never lost a semi-final in a 19-year career and needed only one more Lord's appearance to surpass the record of 10 finals he shares with Kent's Derek Underwood.

It was Fairbrother's 74, from 102 balls, which kept Lancashire vaguely in touch. He began cagily, entering at 19 for three. A bail fell off as he scored his first run but replays showed it was only the wind. With Michael Atherton labouring for 79 balls over 27, runs were scarce.

Fairbrother needed a runner for the second half of his innings after straining a calf. With 58 needed in less than five overs, he swung Jon Lewis to Windows at long-on and, despite one or two late bowling tremors from Jamie Averis, the match was won.

On a pitch that restricted stroke play, Gloucestershire's 220 for six was a decent total; the new-ball pair of Lewis and Mike Smith, by removing Mike Watkinson, John Crawley and Andy Flintoff within 10 overs, made it formidable.

This is a distinct new-ball pairing, and not just in terms of left-arm and right-arm. Smith, who took two wickets in the final over to finish with four for 27, bowled his inswing with serenity, curving one back to hit Crawley's leg stump and causing Flintoff to drag on, pulling. Lewis The Lip rarely delivers a ball without effing and blinding, presumably to disguise the fact that he rarely gets it above 80mph.

Watkinson, bowled through the gate, was Lewis's victim. Now Lancashire's second XI coach, "Winker" made his first appearance of the season, at 38, in a semi-final. This provided the chance to study a bowling action that mutates annually. He is currently in his Armpit Period, in which he seems to tear out a chunk of body hair while delivering the ball. Long before the end, all Lancashire was tearing its hair out.

fields.headline: United close on £9.5m Barthez
fields.trailText: Sir Alex Ferguson's pursuit of Fabien Barthez moved closer to a conclusion last night when the French international goalkeeper arrived at Manchester United for talks about a £9.5m move from Monaco.
fields.body:
Sir Alex Ferguson's pursuit of Fabien Barthez moved closer to a conclusion last night when the French international goalkeeper arrived at Manchester United for talks about a £9.5m move from Monaco.

Barthez has been granted special leave from France's Euro 2000 preparations to finalise a move to Old Trafford that would make him the most expensive goalkeeper in British football while underlining the doubts over Mark Bosnich's future.

Ferguson spent several hours in negotiations with Barthez and his advisers last night and the early indications point to the 28-year-old signing a six-year contract within the next 48 hours.

"It's true to say that discussions are ongoing with the player," said United's spokesman Ken Ramsden. "Nothing has been decided yet but we hope to make progress on Tuesday."

Less than a fortnight has passed since Barthez publicly stated his desire to stay at Monaco, but the lure of joining the world's richest club has apparently been too great for a player whose curriculum vitae already boasts a World Cup winner's medal.

Ferguson has been monitoring his situation ever since it became apparent that Massimo Taibi's career at Old Trafford was destined only for a place in the club's hall of infamy.

The United manager has had little in the way of positive feedback in the past month, with reports in Monaco stating that Barcelona had been prime movers in attempting to entice Barthez away from the principality. But United are willing to meet Monaco's asking price of some 100m francs and it is highly improbable that Barthez will leave Old Trafford without having negotiated a deal second only to Roy Keane's.

Having seen an £18.5m deal for PSV Eindhoven's Ruud van Nistelrooy literally brought to its knees, Ferguson is intent on consolidating United's position as the powerhouse of English football with several new additions.

webTitle: Rampant England back with a chance

fields.headline: Rampant England back with a chance
fields.standfirst:
England Under-21 6
Lampard 28
Jeffers 45
Cort 66
King 73
Mills 77
Campbell 90

Turkey Under-21 0
fields.trailText: There is hope after all for England in the Under-21 European Championship. This comprehensive rout of Turkey, after their lame defeat against Italy at the weekend, leaves them an outside chance of reaching the final this Sunday. They need to beat the hosts Slovakia on Thursday and hope Italy fail to beat the Turks.
fields.body:
There is hope after all for England in the Under-21 European Championship. This comprehensive rout of Turkey, after their lame defeat against Italy at the weekend, leaves them an outside chance of reaching the final this Sunday. They need to beat the hosts Slovakia on Thursday and hope Italy fail to beat the Turks.

It was a match that confounded expectations as the feared-for fan trouble never emerged and England, so lacklustre a few days ago, found their scoring boots.

Three goals in 11 second-half minutes from Carl Cort, Ledley King and Danny Mills saw off what had been an emerging Turkish threat. King got his first goal for England at this level when he headed in after 73 minutes and with 77 minutes gone Mills tapped-in from close range. With the clock showing 90 minutes Andy Campbell scored the sixth.

Any fear of violence after the recent clashes between Leeds and Arsenal supporters and their Galatasaray counterparts never even threatened to materialise.

Uefa had taken every precaution in case of confrontations but the tanks and water cannons were totally surplus to requirements. There were scarcely more than 200 fans and the chance of any Slovakian neutrals swelling the attendance was ruined by the hosts playing Italy at the same time.

Those who did make it saw England, after a long spell of pressure, get the goal they needed after 27 minutes when Johnson's corner was headed past Aktas by Lampard for his ninth goal at this level.

England then got a second to put them fully in charge when Lampard hit a long pass to Francis Jeffers and the Everton striker took full advantage of Aktas being way off his line and to find the open net from 30 yards.

Despite taking such a comfortable lead England showed worrying lapses of concentration after the break which saw the Turks nearly score twice in the space of six minutes. But Cort then put the tie out of their reach on 66 minutes when he headed past Aktas from close range.

England Under-21 (3-5-2): Weaver (Manchester City); Carragher (Liverpool), Young, King (both Tottenham); Johnson (Derby, Harley (Chelsea, 79min)), Dunn (Blackburn), Lampard (West Ham), Murphy (Liverpool, Thompson (Liverpool, 78)), Mills (Leeds); Cort (Wimbledon), Jeffers (Everton, Campbell (Middlesbrough, 76)).

Turkey Under-21 (3-5-2): Aktas; Gulduren, Ozturk, Ozbey; Kahveci, Dokme, Basturk, Gunes, Ak, Albayrak (Akin, 65), Dursun.

Referee: S Bré (France).

webTitle: McPhail makes bow in clash of the Celts

fields.headline: McPhail makes bow in clash of the Celts
fields.trailText: The Republic of Ireland and Scotland launch their World Cup qualification preparations at Lansdowne Road tonight when the two Celtic nations clash for the first time in 13 years.
fields.body:
The Republic of Ireland and Scotland launch their World Cup qualification preparations at Lansdowne Road tonight when the two Celtic nations clash for the first time in 13 years.

The respective managers Mick McCarthy and Craig Brown, making a virtue of their Euro 2000 disappointments, hail the occasion as a valuable chance to try out new players and combinations.

Nevertheless the Republic are missing the injured Roy Keane, Gary Kelly, Ian Harte, Kenny Cunningham, Mark Kinsella and Rory Delap. The Scots are without the injured David Weir, Colin Hendrie, Jackie McNamara, Tom Boyd, Paul Ritchie and Calum Davidson.

The Leeds midfielder Stephen McPhail will win his first cap for the Republic while the Hearts defender Gary Naysmith looks certain to make his debut for the Scots.

Neither manager will name his starting line-up until just prior to the 7.30pm kick-off. But Brown made it clear he wants to try out an Old Firm midfield partnership of Barry Ferguson (Rangers) and Paul Lambert (Celtic).

The Fulham defender Terry Phelan is expected to return to the Irish defence after a three-year exile. He broke his Miami holiday after just five days when receiving a late call-up from McCarthy.

Republic of Ireland (probable; 4-4-2): Kelly (Blackburn); Carr (Tottenham), Breen (Coventry), Dunne (Everton), Phelan (Fulham); Kennedy (Manchester City), McAteer (Blackburn), McPhail (Leeds), Kilbane (Sunderland); Keane (Coventry), Quinn (Sunderland).

Scotland (probable; 3-4-3): Sullivan (Tottenham); O'Neil (Wolfsburg), Elliott (Leicester), Dailly (Blackburn); Burley (Derby), Ferguson (Rangers), Lambert (Celtic), Naysmith (Hearts); Hutchison (Everton), Gallacher (Newcastle), Dodds (Rangers).

Referee: V Pereira (Portugal).

webTitle: Bird's eye view ends without tears

fields.headline: Bird's eye view ends without tears
fields.standfirst: The celebrated umpire breaks with tradition as his beloved Barnsley fail
fields.trailText: The celebrated umpire Dickie Bird breaks with tradition as his beloved Barnsley fail
fields.body:
For some reason one expected Dickie Bird to be wearing a suit with clumps of white heather growing from it, his pockets bulging with horseshoes and a Watership Down-size collection of rabbit feet.

But the man famous for his range of nervous tics when standing as an umpire turned out to be, touch wood, not the slightest bit superstitious. He did not even have the most famous forefinger in cricket tucked underneath his middle finger as he watched his beloved Barnsley from the Royal Box, though he admitted that from first whistle to last he had a stomach which reminded him of visits to India. "Curdled" was the way he described it.

Bird was a special guest of Nationwide but he is no celebrity, fair-weather, wheel-him-out-for-Wembley fan. He is a season-ticket holder and has been as regular at Oakwell as any other supporter required to make regular trips to Australia, India and Pakistan as a member of the International Cricket Council's ambassadors panel.

True to style, the people's umpire travelled to London not in the comfort of a first-class rail carriage but as the meat in the sandwich of a few dozen noisy fans on a Barnsley Chronicle-sponsored bus, having swapped his white cap for a red-and-white scarf. "It was greet", he said, especially when supporters chanted his name and "Barnsley, Barnsley's favourite son".

The town bigwigs have presumably been chanting something similar in the council chamber since, on Thursday week, after a Barnsley-style slap-up meal, they are to award him the freedom of the borough. He says: "I have received awards from all over the world but this one means more to me than any of them because it is from my own people. It is a fantastic honour."

His verdict on Barnsley's 4-2 defeat by Ipswich? "I said to Parky" - Barnsley's other favourite son, Michael Parkinson, who was also a guest in the Royal Box - "we had no midfield," said the man who signed amateur forms for Barnsley as a promising inside-forward at the age of 15. Bird signed on the same day as his school pal Tommy Taylor, who was to die in the Munich air crash.

He says: "My dad and Tommy's dad worked on the same coal seam at Monk Bretton colliery. I've seen every England centre-forward from Tommy Lawton to Alan Shearer and my mate Tommy was the best of them all. If he were playing in the current Manchester United side he would score 50 goals a season."

The normally emotional Dickie destroyed another myth by failing to shed a tear at the final whistle, instead joining in the celebrations of Ipswich fans. "They deserved it," he said, but I think Dave Bassett will bring us up next season."

fields.headline: McManaman the catalyst for attack
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan will make at least three changes at Wembley tomorrow night when he uses England's friendly against Ukraine to sort out the remaining doubts in his final squad of 22 for the European Championship.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan will make at least three changes at Wembley tomorrow night when he uses England's friendly against Ukraine to sort out the remaining doubts in his final squad of 22 for the European Championship.

Steve McManaman is set to return to the side after his night of triumph for Real Madrid last Wednesday, Tony Adams will come into the back four provided Keegan is satisfied this will not risk his aggravating recent back trouble and England's coach is thinking of starting the game with Robbie Fowler alongside Alan Shearer.

Dennis Wise is the man most likely to make way for McManaman, Martin Keown or Sol Campbell would step aside for Adams, and Michael Owen, who confirmed his sharpness with Saturday's goal against Brazil, would stand down to give Fowler his chance.

Steven Gerrard and Keiron Dyer may play part of the match in midfield while those on the fringe, such as Nick Barmby, Gareth Barry, Rio Ferdinand and Andy Cole, will learn at some stage tomorrow if they have made the cut for Euro 2000.

Because of this, along with the fact that he is announcing the squad about an hour after the match, Keegan has decided against revealing his side today.

"By announcing it publicly I would show my hand completely and I don't want to do that. I want to go to the players first and I also have to wait to see how Jamie Redknapp and Ray Parlour are because they deserve that." Knee injuries could rule both out anyway.

The in-form McManaman will be the focus of attention tomorrow and, from what Keegan said yesterday, the player will be asked to run at opponents much as he did for Real Madrid last week. "I think the role I have for him will give him the chance to show what he's good at," Keegan said, "but it will also be a position which we need to address.

"You can read into that what you want. Everyone is talking about the left side. It doesn't have to be the left but I've got to find a place in there for him and, the way he is playing, bring the very best out of him. Sometimes you have to ask people to adjust a little."

Keegan confirmed he will go for a more out-and-out attacking performance. "Against Brazil we did a good job," he said, "but there were things we could and should have done a lot better. Now I want to see us set about a team more and I think we can against Ukraine."

Meanwhile Portugal's coach Humberto Coelho was unimpressed by England in their 1-1 draw with Brazil.

"I wouldn't say that England's display worried me. I am convinced we have the weapons needed to beat them - and we will use them. The English are going to have problems against us. We can give them a surprise.

"I didn't see England create as many attacking moves as I'd have liked against Brazil, although the Brazilians are not a side you can relax against.

"Alan Shearer certainly seems to tempt opponents into making contact in the penalty area. We might do better to let him receive the ball rather trying to dispossess him straight away.

"It was vital for me to be at Wembley but England didn't play their usual way ... We will remain alert. My assistant Agostinho Oliveira will watch them against Ukraine, who are a different type of opposition to Brazil, and this will enable us to put together more data."

Keegan's team start in Group A against Portugal in Eindhoven on June 12.
