webTitle: Ben Elton live on our talkboards

fields.headline: Ben Elton live on our talkboards
fields.standfirst: Ben Elton was live on Film Unlimited on Friday 26 May. During his hour online, he fielded questions about his new movie, Maybe Baby, his hugely successful career as a stand-up comedian and scriptwriter, his future projects, and, of course, a little bit of politics. Sadly he only had time to address a selection of the questions that poured in; what follows is an edited transcript of the questions that Ben was able to answer
fields.trailText: Ben Elton was live on Film Unlimited on Friday 26 May. During his hour online, he fielded questions about his new movie, Maybe Baby, his hugely successful career as a stand-up comedian and scriptwriter, his future projects, and, of course, a little bit of politics. Sadly he only had time to address a selection of the questions that poured in; what follows is an edited transcript of the questions that Ben was able to answer
fields.body:
naomi2
Stand-up comedy, scriptwriter, novelist, playwright, film director. Which do you enjoy most and which do you think you're best at?

BenElton
Everything I do is based on the scripts I write. So first and foremost I'm a writer. But directing your own film script is the best way to be a writer because you get to write in three dimensions.

Idlewriter
As a performer myself I was wondering how you found the enthusiasm to deliver your set when you're on a long tour. Is it hard not to just "go through the motions"? and, If there was one piece of advice you could give a new comic what would it be?

BenElton
I would advise you not to be idle. the only way to write good gags is to work very hard at it. Your first good idea just occurs to you. Every other idea has to be dragged screaming from somewhere inside.

Tally43
Dear Ben, Why have you stopped doing 'political comedy'? Why has everyone pretty much stopped doing it? do you think your Thatcher bashing in the 80s made any difference - or was she and her government just an easy target and an easy laugh? Do you think comedians have a duty to raise the public's awareness of 'issues' or are they just there to amuse? . PS be honest... don't you miss her just a little bit?

BenElton
I do not miss Thatch in the slightest and yes, she was a very easy target for a comedian, but not for many disadvantaged people. I never did political comedy for the sake of it, I just wrote what I felt then, as I do now. If I was on live TV weekly, as I was with Saturday Live, I'm sure I would draw on the issues of the day just as I did then, although I would say that we live in considerably less edgy and confrontational times than when I started out as a comedian. Mrs Thatcher's greatest achievement was to shatter the Liberal Left post-war consensus in our society and replace it with a Liberal Right consensus. That happened in the 80s and they were tough times. (PS By greatest I mean biggest not best.) I do not think comedians or any artists have a duty to do anything other than express themselves to the best of their abilities. But sometimes 'issues' can be very amusing.

pie3
What made you think of Hugh Laurie as the romantic lead? Couldn't you afford Hugh Grant?

BenElton
Even if I could have afforded Hugh Grant, I always wanted Hugh Laurie. Hugh Laurie has a tremendous depth and integrity which makes his comedy all the richer. I think he is a brilliant screen actor, as they do in Hollywood where he is being offered increasingly exciting roles. Perhaps we are not best at promoting our own talent in this country, but I certainly got the bloke I wanted.

gillianmar
Why do think the UK with such a wealth of talent in novel/screen writing and acting make such weak movies? Someone once put this down to American kids having access to cinecameras/video cameras in their youth and British kids venting their creativity by picking up a guitar and getting into bands instead. What do you think?

BenElton
Well, I'm not going to comment on the standards of British films as you have done, except to say that mine is brilliant. However I think the point you make about different influences in youth is an excellent one. Certainly the fact that our pop and rock industry is so good perhaps influences kids' dreams. I would add that British TV is also a world-beater and many of the artists who in America would go into film, in Britain find it easier to get into TV. We don't really have a film indstury in Britain as such but for our size we certainly have the greatest TV industry in the world.

blackbird21
Ben, do you, Rik, Ade, Alexi, Rowan etc ever get together for boys nights out? If so is it a case of cocktails at Soho house or a couple of pints and a curry in Brick Lane?

BenElton
I don't really know Alexei, but Rik Ade and Rowan are all very good friends of mine. Ro doesn't really go to the pub so we might go to a restaurant, very possibly a curry. Rik, Ade and I love a pub. I was in one with Ade only a couple of days ago. I like champagne too.

Alderslade
The inevitable Blackadder question. For the Dome BA it seemed Rowan's portrayal had a bit of Raymond Fowler in it saying 'sorry' allot and 'Ding Dong' and on the whole a devious but not a full on BA portrayal Can we expect him to be back to his verbally explosive best in the middle aged Blackadder that you and Richard have suggested could happen in 10 years or so? How likely is another series/one off? How did you find directing for the first time? How much more enjoyable was it directing your friends than say an ego inflated Hollywood actor? or would you have preferred the greater challenge of the latter?

BenElton
Some of the people acting in my film are old friends but of course I asked them to do it not for that reason but because of what fine performers they are. Personally I don't think actors, even in Hollywood, are usually quite as you describe. I find them a pretty reasonable bunch. Certainly working with the cream of the new British acting talent didn't lead me to think they'd all become ego-inflated actors when they get famous. Basically I'm trying to say I had a great time with my cast and I don't know any of the sort of actors you are describing. Do you?

Julie30
If you could have written one other classic comedy series from Dads Army, Fawlty Towers or Ab Fab which would it have been?

Tamara
Dear Ben, Blackadder is the funniest TV comedy ever written. When are you going to write another series? And, more importantly, when are you going to write another series? Please write another series.

BenElton
I love you for your question. However you are wrong. Fawlty Towers is the funniest TV series ever written. Can you please write to John Cleese and ask him when he's going to do another series. You can say I asked you too, because he's quite scarey. As to the Blackadder, Richard and I often talk about it and we did do a bit of nonsense for the Dome. There are no immediate plans for anything else, but never say never again eh?

RussellCrowe
Ben, did you like Gladiator? Have you ever considered doing a Blackadder prequel series set in Ancient Rome?

BenElton
If it's really you, good on you mate! I'm an honorary half Aussie and I love your work. Right back to Romper Stomper, which was so hugely powerful. I have not seen Gladiator because of babies and work, but get this cyber fans! - Ridley invited me to a private screening. How cool is that? I am absolutely thrilled at what a huge success it is, and if you're not Russell, I'm still thrilled.

fiveonions
Did you enjoy your experience of directing? Do you have something else lined up? I read that your film is based on your real-life experiences. Does your wife mind?

BenElton
- Dear Five or should I call you Mr Onion? Yes, being a movie director was the best job I ever had. I do have something else lined up, it's called the rest of my life. The movie is a total fiction but when it came to municipal masturbation, I did my own research. My wife was very happy that I should make this movie - she thinks it's funny.

SpankTM
How are plans for the movie of Popcorn progressing? Are the rumours true about Joel Schumacher being attached to the project, or do you have a proper director now?

BenElton
Ooh spank put the knife back in the cutlery drawer. Joel was attached to Popcorn a while back, but Batman Forever went on forever and our 'window' closed. Popcorn is still very much alive as a movie project. I will contact you to ask your opinion on any future directors.

Idlewriter
Ben do you have any plans to write your Autobiography yet? Although there's still a long way to go, there are people who've only been famous for 5 minutes who've penned theirs (and ended up with a slim volume). I'm sure yours would be far more interesting and weighty!

BenElton
Sometimes I think it would be fun - I've been involved in some quite interesting things. In fact I did get excited about an idea to write a book called Seven Nine Nine Seven which would be my impressions of the Tory years during which I basically grew up. But a very funny book called Things Can Only Get Better beat me to it. My problem with writing biog would be talking about my friends, so I don't think I will.

Mismo
Now that Tony Robinson is on the NEC, do you think he will work towards conciliation between the disaffected members and those at the top of the Labour party? And will you therefore get Mark Seddon to play Baldrick in any future Blackadders?

BenElton
I never talk politics with Baldrick.

tonyblair2
You managed to get that old stager Hugh Laurie a part. Did you try to get his old stablemate Emma Thompson a part? If not why not? I think she'd be great in the next Ben Elton comedy. No more serious parts for our Emma. Is New Labour just like the yoof of yesterday? Is Elvis Costello a friend of yours? Is he bigger than you?

BenElton
Great question. I think you must be my publicist. Emma IS in Maybe Baby. She was kind enough to agree to do a small but brilliantly written role playing a mad new-age loony friend who suggests that Hugh and Joely go bonking on lay lines to get a baby. She's brilliant in the movie as she always is.

tonyblair2
Yes, but is that because she's an old mate of Hugh's or because she's a great comedienne? If you see her, tell her the only movie I've ever fallen asleep during was Branagh's Henry V. I'm downloading Ride of the Valkyries now. Do you have any dodgy musical tastes? eg Paul Weller, Jam Tarts, Ed Kuepper, Jackson Browne. The only guy I've seen quicker than you was Spike. Asynchronous crowd laughter. Half the audience was laughing at the previous joke as he launched into the next one. 'course he was an old gaffer even then. When will you quit stand up? If ever? Seinfeld was a complete toss show. Something trivial goes wrong and they whinge about it for the next twenty minutes. Which was your favourite Fawlty Towers scene?

withnail20
Hello Ben. First I'd like to say that I am a fan of your work - I thought The Young Ones and Blackadder were fantastic and I've enjoyed several of your novels. Good luck with "Maybe Baby".
But I also have to say that I am fairly horrified at the prospect of this musical you have co-written with Andrew Lloyd Webber about the troubles in the North of Ireland. Isn't this the same Lloyd Webber who was an active supporter of Thatcher's Government in the 80's? Thatcher's Governments behaviour in dealing with my country was nothing less than shameful - she stubbornly stood by and watched 10 hunger strikers die, including Bobby Sands MP - this was a government propped up by the financial and vocal support of the likes of Lloyd Webber. A musical on this subject co-written by Lloyd Webber will be met with nothing but disdain by the Republican community not only in the North of Ireland but in every corner of this island. I just can't understand how you can reconcile your political beliefs with writing a musical with this man.

BenElton
I am writing a musical with a composer of popular music, not with a political activist. The musical is a love story trying to deal with the emotions of non-political young people who live in a highly politicised and violent environment through a coincidence of birth. It is not written for the Republican or the Unionist community, or any other community, it is written for individuals who seek an hour or two's diversion from the cares of their lives. I am an entertainer who loves popular musicals. Andrew is also an entertainer. Of course there are people whose politics are so objectionable that I would not find it possible to work with them. Beyond the fact that Andrew publicly supported the Tories in the 80s, I know nothing of his politics. We don't discuss it. If I were to refuse to talk to Tories, I would narrow my social and professional scope considerably. If you judge all your relationships on a person's voting intentions, I think you miss out on the varieties of life. Your question was very emotional and very loaded. I do not think that Andrew Lloyd-Webber murdered Bobby Sands. But thank you for writing. Also, on the subject , Andrew lives in Ireland and I've been to a couple of pubs with him and they seem to be happy to serve him.

withnail20
Ben - If Lloyd Webber simply voted for the Tories what you say would be fine. He didn't. He was involved in promoting and funding a Government that damaged not just my country but yours also. He had hands on involvement - he even composed music for them, for God's sake! "There are people whose politics are so objectionable that I would not find it possible to work with them", you said. Surely this qualifies.

BenElton
I suppose this is the problem with interviews. Here I am trying to promote my movie, but I'm discussing Andrew's politics. Still, for what it's worth, I have no idea whether he gave money to the Tories - I've never asked him. As to promoting them, I suppose he did so in the way I'm seen to have promoted Labour in that at election time I was happy to say who I was voting for. The composing is really why I wanted to write back to you because he did mention it to me saying that he'd actually written a tune for John Major, not Thatch. You and I would of course not dream of doing either, but for what it's worth, John Major had a very different take on the tragedy in Northern Ireland to Mrs Thatcher. I know you think I'm copping out when I say Look I'm an entertainer, I'm not an expert on Irish politics or any politics, but I'm going to say it anyway. I am happy with the decisions I take in my life because to the best of my ability I follow my conscience. If my conscience disappoints you I am sorry, but it is the work that matters and the musical is about the power of love. Naff? I've just had kids, there is no greater power.

withnail20
Ben - He did give money to the Tories. Ask him.

Idlewriter
Ok, trivial question: Were you pretty "peeved" when Chris Evans nailed down your jacket recently on TFI Friday? You didn't look best pleased.

BenElton
This is amazing. I cannot believe how many people thought that was my jacket. It was their bloody jacket for God's sake which they asked me to wear for the gag. I never thought people would believe it. Maybe it's because I looked so damn good in it.

victorla
You will probably hate this question (I've seen you attacking a poor fellow for asking a similar one on TV), but do you think being successful (economically and career-wise) made you less critical of the establishment? Would you give up your (well earned) creature-comforts for a more egalitarian world?

BenElton
Dear victorla, I do not know what 'the Establishment' is, but I don't think that my attitude towards living in Britain has changed with my success. I still hope for a fairer society although that will never mean everything the same for every body. I am not, and have never been, a communist. I am a welfare state Labour-supporter who thinks that Clement Atlee's post-war administration is the greatest in our history. I would be happy to pay higher taxes to see a greater commitment of resources to the community, and I think this should be done through government not through charity, although of course I do a lot of work for 'charidee' but I don't like to talk about it, even in cyberspace. There is such a thing as society - we all live there.

miner49er
You're probably bored of being asked about Blackadder, but here goes... a) What is your ever favourite episode? (the Lord Flasheart one in series 4 perhaps?) b) What - in your opinion - was the funniest Blackadder series? 2,3 or 4? I'd say 2 just nicks it...

BenElton
It's so nice that people love the Adder so much. It's different for me and I have to admit I probably haven't seen an episode for ten years. But series 2 would be my favourite because it was the first one I co-wrote. And the first episode which was called Bells but should really have been called 'Bob' will always have a special place in my heart.

Lianne88
Ben, you were brought up in East London, you've got a great sense of humour, you're loud and vocal about your opinions (and neuroses), is it any wonder people keep on mistaking you for a nice Jewish boy?

BenElton
Nice funny question, being serious for a moment, to me, being Jewish is a matter of faith. I see it as a religion not a race. Personally I subscribe to no organised religion, but I am certainly a nice boy.

Lianne88
Thanks for the reply - a little confused by the cryptic tone, but keeps us guessing here at www.totallyjewish.com!! Whether or not you see it as a faith, you must agree that Jewish people are blessed with the ability to laugh at themselves - Woody Allen, Jackie Mason, Neil Simon, Phil Silvers, etc. Ever been inspired/influenced by any of them?
p.s. how do you like your chicken soup?

BenjaminP
As a teenager I was entranced with your lengthy diatribes on your television shows. how much of those rambles were scripted? such pace would suggest that there was a definite outline to your performances. Do you ever feel slightly caught up in the successful entertainers' high life and crave a quick hack through the countryside to counter-act the madness. As a singer sometimes at the mercy of the 'machine' in this business we call show I often crave a more grounding and earthy surrounding to retain my sanity.

BenElton
All my routines are scripted, that's why they're funny. Good stuff doesn't come easily, but the greatest joy of all is to create an improvisation out of that script live on stage. but you have to improvise from strength. It would be an insult to the audience to just wander on and waffle. Yes I love to go walking in the countryside, but I did so long before I was a fabulous and glamorous celebrity.

Seona
Do you think you'll ever escape the public perception of you as a mouthy bloke in a shiny suit ranting about Thatcher?

BenElton
No.

achwong
Are you glad Maybe Baby is all over, or are you raring to do another film comedy again? Will Phantom be your first 'serious' ie non-comedic project? Or can we expect to see the Phantom suddenly stopping for a five-minute routine about teacups on motorway service stations? :-)

BenElton
Maybe Baby is not over because now we have world distribution, even in US ! So I must carry on doing things like this to flog it. But as I have said, I loved directing a movie and can think of nothing better than having the chance to do it again.

kdalt
I loved the Young Ones and Filthy Rich and Catflap. However I can't understand why you would write such an inoffensive innocuous comedy like The Thin Blue Line? Also don't you think that comedies like Seinfeld are far funnier than anything Britain now produces

BenElton
Dear K, I can't understand why you can't understand somebody doing something inoffensive and innocuous. If that was all anybody ever did, there would be no more war, and we would all be happy pixies. As far as I'm concerned, TBL was very funny, which was its sole ambition. However, actually I think it dealt with a number of issues relevant to policing - race, drugs, police violence, in quite an interesting way. Perhaps you didn't get past the first episode about buying a birthday present for the Queen. Regarding Seinfeld. It is a brilliant show, as are most of the American sitcoms we see on BBC2 and Channel 4. However, there are many many crap sitcoms that we don't see. The constantly stated idea that their comedies are funnier than ours is based on the strangest evidence. We see all our stuff, and the best of theirs. They think our stuff is better than theirs for exactly the same reason. In America they ask me 'Why can't we have more comedies like you have?' There's only ever a few decent shows. In the last 5 years or so, the Americans have produced the likes of Seinfeld, Larry Sanders, Frasier and Friends. All brilliant. We produced The Royle Family, Ab Fab, The Alan Patridge sitcom - all equally brilliant. I think it's not about nationality, but about quality, and we do pretty well.

A000457
Do you get embarrassed when people mention previous work of yours which you'd hoped had been forgotten by all and sundry? By the way, any chance of another series of Filthy, Rich and Catflap?

BenElton
I have to say the we all loved Filthy Rich and Catflap too. The critics loathed it, but the BBC were happy to go with it again. I don't know what got in the way - booze, babies and hair loss probably. But FR&C is about horrible old blokes, so maybe we're just growing into the project.

MsMonkey
You are a nice boy, Ben...I still have pleasant memory of you admiring my tattoo at a party many moons ago...(It was in Notting Hill of all places, the party, not my tatto - but it's okay, this isn't one of those, do you remember me queries!) I haven't really got a question, just to say great to see such a nice guy continuing to do so well for himself!

kdalt
As an aspiring comedy writer I used the line "he drinks like a mad viking celebrating his birthday on a bank holiday weekend". Is this too Blackadderish would I be sued by yourself and Richard Curtis?

sgoodas
kdalt: It is precisely that type of 'comedy writing' ie, uninspired and based on past comedies that lies behind the current malaise in TV sitcoms.

tonyblair2
MsMonkey: Ben is a star. A bright wit, who I'm sure has had his share of difficult times. Where is your tattoo? I think the Hollywood couple for an Elton movie would be Mandy Patinkin and Madonna. And congrats on your twins.

easthamd
Benny, where do you think comedy as a genre will go over the next few years, more shock, or more will things cycle around to carry-on type stuff, for young people who don't remember the stuff when it was originally out? or will it just be more have-I got news - All over type light entertainment? No pressure, take your time....

BenElton
I never ask myself where any art form is going. All art is an improvisation if you try to plan it, it doesn't tend to work. Which is why spin-offs and sequels are rarely as good as originals. I'll be able to tell you where my comedy has gone when I've been there.

SRGarland
Dear Ben Elton, This is a question I've been wanting to ask you for some years now. Identify the plot outline. A handful of green activists, one of them a traumatised Viet Nam veteran, race across a consummately described desert committing acts of eco-terrorism in a grassroots fight against the environmental atrocities committed by global corporations. Ring any bells? Well it's not your "Stark" that I'm summarising. It's The Monkeywench Gang by Edward Abbey, which preceded your efforts by about fifteen years. Time to confess to a bit of literary recycling, Ben? And as for Russell Crowe's (indeed) suggestions regarding a Roman farce do the words Up Pompeii or A funny thing happened on the way to the forum sound familiar?

BenElton
I have never read the Monkeywrench Gang, and had not even heard of it at the time when I wrote Stark. I have heard of it since - not through being accused of plagiarism though, merely from people interested in green-orientated literature recommending a like-minded book. Maybe now I will read it just to see.

achwong
Has anyone here seen Maybe Baby yet? :-) And where is Ben anyway? :)

BenElton
Many people have seen the film. We tested it in Britain and the USA and got a very very encouraging reaction. Also I took it to the American film market in an effort to get overseas distribution which is not at all common for a small-budget British picture. I am delighted to say that there was real excitement and the film has been acquired for screening all over the world. the fact that we have an American distributor is hugely good news for us, particularly considering the baffling absence of any Americans in the cast. The people who are getting behind it over there are the same team that put Four Weddings on the map, so fingers crossed eh mate? As for real people seeing the film, we start here in Britain, as we always intended to. It opens nationwide on June 2nd, and of course I hope you will all drag yourselves away from your keyboards to look at a 'real' screen.
Thanks a lot to everyone who's written in. It's been great inter-reacting with you. bye bye.

hmulley
Dear Ben - Fancy a pint in the Riverside Inn? All the cool kids are doing it.

Anthony12
Why not Ben? Nice people...(I'm sure the missus wouldn't mind just the one...)

withnail20
Cheerio. Keep writing. Except for musicals, that is.

tonyblair2
MsMonkey: Now Ben's gone we can chat. If Maybe Baby gets to Korea I can tell everyone I chatted to Ben and a lady who showed him her tattoo. My ex-wife had twins this month. IVF does work.

Anthony12
I'm off to the Riverside Inn,....who knows...maybe...

If I was on live TV weekly, as I was with Saturday Live, I'm sure I would draw on the issues of the day just as I did then, although I would say that we live in considerably less edgy and confrontational times than when I started out as a comedian. Mrs Thatcher's greatest achievement was to shatter the Liberal Left post-war consensus in our society and replace it with a Liberal Right consensus. That happened in the 80s and they were tough times. (PS By greatest I mean biggest not best.) I do not think comedians or any artists have a duty to do anything other than express themselves to the best of their abilities. But sometimes 'issues' can be very amusing. pie3 What made you think of Hugh Laurie as the romantic lead? Couldn't you afford Hugh Grant? BenElton Even if I could have afforded Hugh Grant, I always wanted Hugh Laurie. Hugh Laurie has a tremendous depth and integrity which makes his comedy all the richer. I think he is a brilliant screen actor, as they do in Hollywood where he is being offered increasingly exciting roles. Perhaps we are not best at promoting our own talent in this country, but I certainly got the bloke I wanted. gillianmar Why do think the UK with such a wealth of talent in novel/screen writing and acting make such weak movies? Someone once put this down to American kids having access to cinecameras/video cameras in their youth and British kids venting their creativity by picking up a guitar and getting into bands instead. What do you think? BenElton Well, I'm not going to comment on the standards of British films as you have done, except to say that mine is brilliant. However I think the point you make about different influences in youth is an excellent one. Certainly the fact that our pop and rock industry is so good perhaps influences kids' dreams. I would add that British TV is also a world-beater and many of the artists who in America would go into film, in Britain find it easier to get into TV. We don't really have a film indstury in Britain as such but for our size we certainly have the greatest TV industry in the world. blackbird21 Ben, do you, Rik, Ade, Alexi, Rowan etc ever get together for boys nights out? If so is it a case of cocktails at Soho house or a couple of pints and a curry in Brick Lane? BenElton I don't really know Alexei, but Rik Ade and Rowan are all very good friends of mine. Ro doesn't really go to the pub so we might go to a restaurant, very possibly a curry. Rik, Ade and I love a pub. I was in one with Ade only a couple of days ago. I like champagne too. Alderslade The inevitable Blackadder question. For the Dome BA it seemed Rowan's portrayal had a bit of Raymond Fowler in it saying 'sorry' allot and 'Ding Dong' and on the whole a devious but not a full on BA portrayal Can we expect him to be back to his verbally explosive best in the middle aged Blackadder that you and Richard have suggested could happen in 10 years or so? How likely is another series/one off? How did you find directing for the first time? How much more enjoyable was it directing your friends than say an ego inflated Hollywood actor? or would you have preferred the greater challenge of the latter? BenElton Some of the people acting in my film are old friends but of course I asked them to do it not for that reason but because of what fine performers they are. Personally I don't think actors, even in Hollywood, are usually quite as you describe. I find them a pretty reasonable bunch. Certainly working with the cream of the new British acting talent didn't lead me to think they'd all become ego-inflated actors when they get famous. Basically I'm trying to say I had a great time with my cast and I don't know any of the sort of actors you are describing. Do you? Julie30 If you could have written one other classic comedy series from Dads Army, Fawlty Towers or Ab Fab which would it have been? Tamara Dear Ben, Blackadder is the funniest TV comedy ever written. When are you going to write another series? And, more importantly, when are you going to write another series? Please write another series. BenElton I love you for your question. However you are wrong. Fawlty Towers is the funniest TV series ever written. Can you please write to John Cleese and ask him when he's going to do another series. You can say I asked you too, because he's quite scarey. As to the Blackadder, Richard and I often talk about it and we did do a bit of nonsense for the Dome. There are no immediate plans for anything else, but never say never again eh? RussellCrowe Ben, did you like Gladiator? Have you ever considered doing a Blackadder prequel series set in Ancient Rome? BenElton If it's really you, good on you mate! I'm an honorary half Aussie and I love your work. Right back to Romper Stomper, which was so hugely powerful. I have not seen Gladiator because of babies and work, but get this cyber fans! - Ridley invited me to a private screening. How cool is that? I am absolutely thrilled at what a huge success it is, and if you're not Russell, I'm still thrilled. fiveonions Did you enjoy your experience of directing? Do you have something else lined up? I read that your film is based on your real-life experiences. Does your wife mind? BenElton - Dear Five or should I call you Mr Onion? Yes, being a movie director was the best job I ever had. I do have something else lined up, it's called the rest of my life. The movie is a total fiction but when it came to municipal masturbation, I did my own research. My wife was very happy that I should make this movie - she thinks it's funny. SpankTM How are plans for the movie of Popcorn progressing? Are the rumours true about Joel Schumacher being attached to the project, or do you have a proper director now? BenElton Ooh spank put the knife back in the cutlery drawer. Joel was attached to Popcorn a while back, but Batman Forever went on forever and our 'window' closed. Popcorn is still very much alive as a movie project. I will contact you to ask your opinion on any future directors. Idlewriter Ben do you have any plans to write your Autobiography yet? Although there's still a long way to go, there are people who've only been famous for 5 minutes who've penned theirs (and ended up with a slim volume). I'm sure yours would be far more interesting and weighty! BenElton Sometimes I think it would be fun - I've been involved in some quite interesting things. In fact I did get excited about an idea to write a book called Seven Nine Nine Seven which would be my impressions of the Tory years during which I basically grew up. But a very funny book called Things Can Only Get Better beat me to it. My problem with writing biog would be talking about my friends, so I don't think I will. Mismo Now that Tony Robinson is on the NEC, do you think he will work towards conciliation between the disaffected members and those at the top of the Labour party? And will you therefore get Mark Seddon to play Baldrick in any future Blackadders? BenElton I never talk politics with Baldrick. tonyblair2 You managed to get that old stager Hugh Laurie a part. Did you try to get his old stablemate Emma Thompson a part? If not why not? I think she'd be great in the next Ben Elton comedy. No more serious parts for our Emma. Is New Labour just like the yoof of yesterday? Is Elvis Costello a friend of yours? Is he bigger than you? BenElton Great question. I think you must be my publicist. Emma IS in Maybe Baby. She was kind enough to agree to do a small but brilliantly written role playing a mad new-age loony friend who suggests that Hugh and Joely go bonking on lay lines to get a baby. She's brilliant in the movie as she always is. tonyblair2 Yes, but is that because she's an old mate of Hugh's or because she's a great comedienne? If you see her, tell her the only movie I've ever fallen asleep during was Branagh's Henry V. I'm downloading Ride of the Valkyries now. Do you have any dodgy musical tastes? eg Paul Weller, Jam Tarts, Ed Kuepper, Jackson Browne. The only guy I've seen quicker than you was Spike. Asynchronous crowd laughter. Half the audience was laughing at the previous joke as he launched into the next one. 'course he was an old gaffer even then. When will you quit stand up? If ever? Seinfeld was a complete toss show. Something trivial goes wrong and they whinge about it for the next twenty minutes. Which was your favourite Fawlty Towers scene? withnail20 Hello Ben. First I'd like to say that I am a fan of your work - I thought The Young Ones and Blackadder were fantastic and I've enjoyed several of your novels. Good luck with "Maybe Baby". But I also have to say that I am fairly horrified at the prospect of this musical you have co-written with Andrew Lloyd Webber about the troubles in the North of Ireland. Isn't this the same Lloyd Webber who was an active supporter of Thatcher's Government in the 80's? Thatcher's Governments behaviour in dealing with my country was nothing less than shameful - she stubbornly stood by and watched 10 hunger strikers die, including Bobby Sands MP - this was a government propped up by the financial and vocal support of the likes of Lloyd Webber. A musical on this subject co-written by Lloyd Webber will be met with nothing but disdain by the Republican community not only in the North of Ireland but in every corner of this island. I just can't understand how you can reconcile your political beliefs with writing a musical with this man. BenElton I am writing a musical with a composer of popular music, not with a political activist. The musical is a love story trying to deal with the emotions of non-political young people who live in a highly politicised and violent environment through a coincidence of birth. It is not written for the Republican or the Unionist community, or any other community, it is written for individuals who seek an hour or two's diversion from the cares of their lives. I am an entertainer who loves popular musicals. Andrew is also an entertainer. Of course there are people whose politics are so objectionable that I would not find it possible to work with them. Beyond the fact that Andrew publicly supported the Tories in the 80s, I know nothing of his politics. We don't discuss it. If I were to refuse to talk to Tories, I would narrow my social and professional scope considerably. If you judge all your relationships on a person's voting intentions, I think you miss out on the varieties of life. Your question was very emotional and very loaded. I do not think that Andrew Lloyd-Webber murdered Bobby Sands. But thank you for writing. Also, on the subject , Andrew lives in Ireland and I've been to a couple of pubs with him and they seem to be happy to serve him. withnail20 Ben - If Lloyd Webber simply voted for the Tories what you say would be fine. He didn't. He was involved in promoting and funding a Government that damaged not just my country but yours also. He had hands on involvement - he even composed music for them, for God's sake! "There are people whose politics are so objectionable that I would not find it possible to work with them", you said. Surely this qualifies. BenElton I suppose this is the problem with interviews. Here I am trying to promote my movie, but I'm discussing Andrew's politics. Still, for what it's worth, I have no idea whether he gave money to the Tories - I've never asked him. As to promoting them, I suppose he did so in the way I'm seen to have promoted Labour in that at election time I was happy to say who I was voting for. The composing is really why I wanted to write back to you because he did mention it to me saying that he'd actually written a tune for John Major, not Thatch. You and I would of course not dream of doing either, but for what it's worth, John Major had a very different take on the tragedy in Northern Ireland to Mrs Thatcher. I know you think I'm copping out when I say Look I'm an entertainer, I'm not an expert on Irish politics or any politics, but I'm going to say it anyway. I am happy with the decisions I take in my life because to the best of my ability I follow my conscience. If my conscience disappoints you I am sorry, but it is the work that matters and the musical is about the power of love. Naff? I've just had kids, there is no greater power. withnail20 Ben - He did give money to the Tories. Ask him. Idlewriter Ok, trivial question: Were you pretty "peeved" when Chris Evans nailed down your jacket recently on TFI Friday? You didn't look best pleased. BenElton This is amazing. I cannot believe how many people thought that was my jacket. It was their bloody jacket for God's sake which they asked me to wear for the gag. I never thought people would believe it. Maybe it's because I looked so damn good in it. victorla You will probably hate this question (I've seen you attacking a poor fellow for asking a similar one on TV), but do you think being successful (economically and career-wise) made you less critical of the establishment? Would you give up your (well earned) creature-comforts for a more egalitarian world? BenElton Dear victorla, I do not know what 'the Establishment' is, but I don't think that my attitude towards living in Britain has changed with my success. I still hope for a fairer society although that will never mean everything the same for every body. I am not, and have never been, a communist. I am a welfare state Labour-supporter who thinks that Clement Atlee's post-war administration is the greatest in our history. I would be happy to pay higher taxes to see a greater commitment of resources to the community, and I think this should be done through government not through charity, although of course I do a lot of work for 'charidee' but I don't like to talk about it, even in cyberspace. There is such a thing as society - we all live there. miner49er You're probably bored of being asked about Blackadder, but here goes... a) What is your ever favourite episode? (the Lord Flasheart one in series 4 perhaps?) b) What - in your opinion - was the funniest Blackadder series? 2,3 or 4? I'd say 2 just nicks it... BenElton It's so nice that people love the Adder so much. It's different for me and I have to admit I probably haven't seen an episode for ten years. But series 2 would be my favourite because it was the first one I co-wrote. And the first episode which was called Bells but should really have been called 'Bob' will always have a special place in my heart. Lianne88 Ben, you were brought up in East London, you've got a great sense of humour, you're loud and vocal about your opinions (and neuroses), is it any wonder people keep on mistaking you for a nice Jewish boy? BenElton Nice funny question, being serious for a moment, to me, being Jewish is a matter of faith. I see it as a religion not a race. Personally I subscribe to no organised religion, but I am certainly a nice boy. Lianne88 Thanks for the reply - a little confused by the cryptic tone, but keeps us guessing here at www.totallyjewish.com!! Whether or not you see it as a faith, you must agree that Jewish people are blessed with the ability to laugh at themselves - Woody Allen, Jackie Mason, Neil Simon, Phil Silvers, etc. Ever been inspired/influenced by any of them? p.s. how do you like your chicken soup? BenjaminP As a teenager I was entranced with your lengthy diatribes on your television shows. how much of those rambles were scripted? such pace would suggest that there was a definite outline to your performances. Do you ever feel slightly caught up in the successful entertainers' high life and crave a quick hack through the countryside to counter-act the madness. As a singer sometimes at the mercy of the 'machine' in this business we call show I often crave a more grounding and earthy surrounding to retain my sanity. BenElton All my routines are scripted, that's why they're funny. Good stuff doesn't come easily, but the greatest joy of all is to create an improvisation out of that script live on stage. but you have to improvise from strength. It would be an insult to the audience to just wander on and waffle. Yes I love to go walking in the countryside, but I did so long before I was a fabulous and glamorous celebrity. Seona Do you think you'll ever escape the public perception of you as a mouthy bloke in a shiny suit ranting about Thatcher? BenElton No. achwong Are you glad Maybe Baby is all over, or are you raring to do another film comedy again? Will Phantom be your first 'serious' ie non-comedic project? Or can we expect to see the Phantom suddenly stopping for a five-minute routine about teacups on motorway service stations? :-) BenElton Maybe Baby is not over because now we have world distribution, even in US ! So I must carry on doing things like this to flog it. But as I have said, I loved directing a movie and can think of nothing better than having the chance to do it again. kdalt I loved the Young Ones and Filthy Rich and Catflap. However I can't understand why you would write such an inoffensive innocuous comedy like The Thin Blue Line? Also don't you think that comedies like Seinfeld are far funnier than anything Britain now produces BenElton Dear K, I can't understand why you can't understand somebody doing something inoffensive and innocuous. If that was all anybody ever did, there would be no more war, and we would all be happy pixies. As far as I'm concerned, TBL was very funny, which was its sole ambition. However, actually I think it dealt with a number of issues relevant to policing - race, drugs, police violence, in quite an interesting way. Perhaps you didn't get past the first episode about buying a birthday present for the Queen. Regarding Seinfeld. It is a brilliant show, as are most of the American sitcoms we see on BBC2 and Channel 4. However, there are many many crap sitcoms that we don't see. The constantly stated idea that their comedies are funnier than ours is based on the strangest evidence. We see all our stuff, and the best of theirs. They think our stuff is better than theirs for exactly the same reason. In America they ask me 'Why can't we have more comedies like you have?' There's only ever a few decent shows. In the last 5 years or so, the Americans have produced the likes of Seinfeld, Larry Sanders, Frasier and Friends. All brilliant. We produced The Royle Family, Ab Fab, The Alan Patridge sitcom - all equally brilliant. I think it's not about nationality, but about quality, and we do pretty well. A000457 Do you get embarrassed when people mention previous work of yours which you'd hoped had been forgotten by all and sundry? By the way, any chance of another series of Filthy, Rich and Catflap? BenElton I have to say the we all loved Filthy Rich and Catflap too. The critics loathed it, but the BBC were happy to go with it again. I don't know what got in the way - booze, babies and hair loss probably. But FR&C is about horrible old blokes, so maybe we're just growing into the project. MsMonkey You are a nice boy, Ben...I still have pleasant memory of you admiring my tattoo at a party many moons ago...(It was in Notting Hill of all places, the party, not my tatto - but it's okay, this isn't one of those, do you remember me queries!) I haven't really got a question, just to say great to see such a nice guy continuing to do so well for himself! kdalt As an aspiring comedy writer I used the line "he drinks like a mad viking celebrating his birthday on a bank holiday weekend". Is this too Blackadderish would I be sued by yourself and Richard Curtis? sgoodas kdalt: It is precisely that type of 'comedy writing' ie, uninspired and based on past comedies that lies behind the current malaise in TV sitcoms. tonyblair2 MsMonkey: Ben is a star. A bright wit, who I'm sure has had his share of difficult times. Where is your tattoo? I think the Hollywood couple for an Elton movie would be Mandy Patinkin and Madonna. And congrats on your twins. easthamd Benny, where do you think comedy as a genre will go over the next few years, more shock, or more will things cycle around to carry-on type stuff, for young people who don't remember the stuff when it was originally out? or will it just be more have-I got news - All over type light entertainment? No pressure, take your time.... BenElton I never ask myself where any art form is going. All art is an improvisation if you try to plan it, it doesn't tend to work. Which is why spin-offs and sequels are rarely as good as originals. I'll be able to tell you where my comedy has gone when I've been there. SRGarland Dear Ben Elton, This is a question I've been wanting to ask you for some years now. Identify the plot outline. A handful of green activists, one of them a traumatised Viet Nam veteran, race across a consummately described desert committing acts of eco-terrorism in a grassroots fight against the environmental atrocities committed by global corporations. Ring any bells? Well it's not your "Stark" that I'm summarising. It's The Monkeywench Gang by Edward Abbey, which preceded your efforts by about fifteen years. Time to confess to a bit of literary recycling, Ben? And as for Russell Crowe's (indeed) suggestions regarding a Roman farce do the words Up Pompeii or A funny thing happened on the way to the forum sound familiar? BenElton I have never read the Monkeywrench Gang, and had not even heard of it at the time when I wrote Stark. I have heard of it since - not through being accused of plagiarism though, merely from people interested in green-orientated literature recommending a like-minded book. Maybe now I will read it just to see. achwong Has anyone here seen Maybe Baby yet? :-) And where is Ben anyway? :) BenElton Many people have seen the film. We tested it in Britain and the USA and got a very very encouraging reaction. Also I took it to the American film market in an effort to get overseas distribution which is not at all common for a small-budget British picture. I am delighted to say that there was real excitement and the film has been acquired for screening all over the world. the fact that we have an American distributor is hugely good news for us, particularly considering the baffling absence of any Americans in the cast. The people who are getting behind it over there are the same team that put Four Weddings on the map, so fingers crossed eh mate? As for real people seeing the film, we start here in Britain, as we always intended to. It opens nationwide on June 2nd, and of course I hope you will all drag yourselves away from your keyboards to look at a 'real' screen. Thanks a lot to everyone who's written in. It's been great inter-reacting with you. bye bye. hmulley Dear Ben - Fancy a pint in the Riverside Inn? All the cool kids are doing it. Anthony12 Why not Ben? Nice people...(I'm sure the missus wouldn't mind just the one...) withnail20 Cheerio. Keep writing. Except for musicals, that is. tonyblair2 MsMonkey: Now Ben's gone we can chat. If Maybe Baby gets to Korea I can tell everyone I chatted to Ben and a lady who showed him her tattoo. My ex-wife had twins this month. IVF does work. Anthony12 I'm off to the Riverside Inn,....who knows...maybe...

fields.headline: Back to work at Stormont
fields.trailText:
30/05/2000: David Trimble went back to his day job
                                                                  this morning. But as the Northern Ireland
                                                                  executive got back to work, there were
                                                                  rumbles of continuing dissent - and an
                                                                  even more ominous crackling of gunfire in
                                                                  the background.
fields.body:
David Trimble went back to his day job this morning. But as the Northern Ireland executive got back to work, there were rumbles of continuing dissent - and an even more ominous crackling of gunfire in the background.

The resumption of devolved government has come as a relief to most of the main parties in Ulster, and no doubt to its long-suffering people. But one of the most important power-brokers in the province, Ian Paisley, is refusing to give his blessing to the latest attempt to make the Good Friday peace accords work.

Two leading members of his Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) were absent from their government departments this morning. Peter Robinson, the minister for regional development, and Nigel Dodds, minister for social development, are said to be keen to resume their ministerial careers - though they are still refusing to attend cabinet meetings which include members of Sinn Fein.

But Mr Paisley has apparently set his mind against further power-sharing. His party council meets tonight to take a final decision. If the vote goes against participation, the two seats will be allocated to Mr Trimble's Ulster Unionist party, and to the moderate Alliance party.

The latest phase of power-sharing will no doubt survive a boycott by the DUP, though the new government will dismiss the Paisleyite faction at its peril.

Mr Trimble was on mischievous form on this morning's Radio Four Today programme, when he compared the DUP to an autocratic East European party, conducting its business behind closed doors. "We wait to see whether there's a puff of white smoke coming out from wherever they go into conference," he said - a throwaway gibe calculated to enrage Mr Paisley, who loathes all things papal.

Northern Ireland's First Minister has already bitterly offended his Sinn Fein colleagues, by remarking that the republican party has still be politically "house-trained".

With political nerves still scraped raw by the disputes of recent weeks, Mr Trimble would be well advised to suppress his predilection for cheap taunts, and instead brace himself for the coming storms. For it is clear that the Northern Ireland executive cannot expect plain sailing.

Its most immediate problem, as it returns to the bread-and-butter business of running the province, is to put behind it the corrosive row over IRA disarmament. But with the first weapons inspections due in a matter of days, the issue will remain at the forefront of public and political attention.

Then there is the continuing mutual recrimination between the Unionists and Sinn Fein over the vexed issues of police reform, and the flying of national flags over public buildings. The Unionists want to retain the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary and the right to fly the Union flag - symbols of British rule vehemently rejected by republicans and for that matter the moderate nationalists of the Social Democratic and Labour Party.

John Taylor, the Ulster Unionist deputy leader, has raised the political temperature over the weekend by hinting that Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson has offered concessions to the party, to entice it back into power-sharing. If that is so, we could see yet another breakdown of the fragile devolution experiment.

A threat literally more deadly than any of the political shadow boxing, lurks on the streets of Northern Ireland. Recent days have brought a spate of shooting incidents in the murderous feud between two of the most ruthless loyalist paramilitary gangs, the Ulster Volunteer Force and a breakaway faction, the Loyalist Volunteer Force. A third group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, is said to be getting involved in the brutal dispute.

Even more chilling, the IRA has offered grim evidence that it too is still in business. It is hotly suspected of murdering a leading loyalist over the weekend. Eddie McCoy, gunned down in a Belfast suburban bar, was targeted not for his paramilitary activity, but for his alleged involvement in drug dealing.

The IRA long ago declared war on drug dealers; a war which has claimed at least 11 lives during the organisation's so-called ceasefire. There could be no clearer evidence that the republican group remains armed and belligerent.

webTitle: IRA suspected of murder as powers devolved to Ulster

fields.headline: IRA suspected of murder as powers devolved to Ulster
fields.trailText: 30/05/2000: Detectives were last night investigating                                                                    whether there was IRA involvement in the                                                                    shooting dead of a suspected drugs                                                                    dealer near Belfast, an execution                                                                    exacerbating Ulster Unionist jitters as                                                                    they again joined government with                                                                    republicans. Powers were devolved to                                                                    Northern Ireland at midnight.
fields.body:
Detectives were last night investigating whether there was IRA involvement in the shooting dead of a suspected drugs dealer near Belfast, an execution exacerbating Ulster Unionist jitters as they again joined government with republicans. Powers were devolved to Northern Ireland at midnight.

Edmund McCoy, 28, a Catholic, died at the Royal Victoria hospital in west Belfast yesterday, hours before the inclusive power-sharing executive took control from Westminster for the second time in seven months. He was shot in a pub in Dunmurry, just outside south Belfast, on Sunday evening.

Senior IRA figures are believed to have threatened Mr McCoy, a father-of-one, with assassination last year over his drug-dealing activities. He left his home, close to Dunmurry, soon afterwards, but is thought recently to have returned to the area, close to republican west Belfast.

Police, who rejected a sectarian motive, believed the murder was drugs-related. They were unable to say who was responsible, but refused to rule out terrorist involvement.

Hugh Lewsley, SDLP councillor in nearby Twinbrook, in west Belfast, said he was convinced that the IRA was responsible. So was Vincent McKenna, director of the Human Rights Bureau.

But the burned out car used in the attack was found in Derriaghy, a loyalist area, and police are also investigating whether Mr McCoy was a victim of a gangland feud.

webTitle: O'Neill move to Celtic in the balance

fields.headline: O'Neill move to Celtic in the balance
fields.trailText: Martin O'Neill's move to Celtic from Leicester appeared to hit a hitch this afternoon.
fields.body:
Martin O'Neill's move to Celtic from Leicester appeared to hit a hitch this afternoon.

O'Neill had indicated this morning that he had decided to join the Parkhead club and was due to inform Leicester chairman John Elsom of that decision. But O'Neill is believed to be holding talks at Filbert Street with Elsom this afternoon, and there could be a last-ditch bid by the Foxes to persuade him to have a change of heart.

A Leicester spokesman told Football Unlimited that no announcement would be made on O'Neill's future until tomorrow.

O'Neill had spent the last 24 hours agonising over his decision after a meeting on Sunday evening with Leicester chairman John Elsom, financial director Steve Kind and football secretary Andrew Neville. Yesterday, sources close to Filbert Street were insisting it was 50-50 as to whether O'Neill would join Celtic to try to overturn the dominance of Rangers.

But earlier today, O'Neill, who learnt his managerial trade at Grantham, Shepshed, Wycombe and Norwich, looked like he had decided to take the plunge and attempt to succeed in one of football's most pressurised posts - until the hitch this afternoon.

fields.headline: Bullying
fields.trailText: Bullying is an issue which affects most of us at some stage in our lives - and not necessarily only at school. Tackling bullying requires careful and sensitive handling in order not to aggravate the problem. The following books look at some of the many forms bullying can take, the possible repercussions and some of the ways in which it can be addressed.
fields.body:
Bullying is an issue which affects most of us at some stage in our lives - and not necessarily only at school. Tackling bullying requires careful and sensitive handling in order not to aggravate the problem. The following books look at some of the many forms bullying can take, the possible repercussions and some of the ways in which it can be addressed.

Hugo and the Bully Frogs by Francesca Simon and Caroline Jayne Church (David and Charles, £4.99, 3-7) is a gentle, light-hearted tale, suggesting that neither suffering in silence nor physical retaliation need be the only options. The bully frogs' victim is Hugo, a small frog - with a proportionately small croak. Following some sage advice from a judicious duck, however, Hugo discovers a new talent (for quacking!) which proves enough to send his surprised bullies packing.

A tendency to bully is often a sign that the bully has insecurities of his or her own. In Bullysaurus Under The Sea (Damon Burnard, Hodder, £3.50, 6+), harmonious island life is shattered by the arrival of a large, noisy dinosaur. In this case, it becomes apparent that the bully just needs to be urged to explore other ways of using his particular skills, in order for peace to be restored.

Physical attributes often provide bullies with ammunition. In Elizabeth Laird's Secret Friends (Hodder, £1.99, 8-11), Rafaella's prominent ears are the cause of her unhappiness, and lead to tragic consequences. Picked on by the rest of the school, only one girl is willing to be friends with Rafaella, and only if they keep it a secret. It is moving and well illustrated and offers a painful reminder that the possible impact of mindless "teasing" should never be underestimated.

Bullies generally target those who are smaller, weaker, less confident - or just plain different. In Stiks and Stoans by Andrew Matthews (Mammoth, £4.99, 9+), the victim is dyslexic and overweight. Ella's increasing unhappiness at the hands of a group of schoolboys is described through diary entries, interspersed with narration by Liam, a new boy at school. Liam's situation illustrates just how easy it is to ignore bullying, or even join in, to safeguard one's own acceptance by one's peers.

It is a sad fact that a bully can find almost any excuse to single out a potential victim. What's Your Problem? (Sherry Ashworth, Livewire, £4.99, 11+) provides a terrifying reminder of just how little ammunition a proficient bully needs. Jac is a confident teenager in the middle of her GCSEs when she has to move schools. Her public school history provides the initial material for ringleader Lisa, but this is then followed by the sort of general "bitchiness" at which teenage girls really excel. Jac's self-confidence and happiness gradually crumble as the cruelty intensifies, until she is finally forced to take action and stand up to the bully.

Finally, on the non-fiction front, Rosemary Stones' Don't Pick On Me (Piccadilly, £5.99, 7-12) provides plenty of valuable material for understanding and handling bullying. It could prove helpful for use with almost any age.

 For a full list of books on bullying call Book Trust on 0906 5161193 (calls cost £1.50 a minute). If you are being bullied, Childline (0800 1111) is a freephone number and open 24 hours a day.

fields.headline: States of mind
fields.standfirst: It was a 'scandal' that a Tyneside pupil had to go to Harvard instead of Oxford, according to Gordon Brown. But what's wrong with studying in the States? British students at Stanford University, California, give their side of the story
fields.trailText: It was a 'scandal' that a Tyneside pupil had to go to Harvard instead of Oxford, according to Gordon Brown. But what's wrong with studying in the States? British students at Stanford University, California, give their side of the story
fields.body:
Alex Newall majors in product design as an engineer

I played for the England Women's Volleyball team and was looking for ways to continue playing at a high level. The options in England at the time were limited - there has been a programme started at Loughborough University - since I left. I was looking at my options, given I still wanted to play volleyball, and America came up in the conversation.

The dilemma is about finding a university over here that is not only good for sports (so many have full-time programmes), but that is also not detrimental for the rest of my life. Fortunately for me, Stanford recruited me because they fit both of my requirements: a National Championship Volleyball team and one of the best academic places around.

I'm the youngest of three - my brother and sister stayed in England and went to Loughborough and Nottingham respectively. It took a few years of persuasion to get my mother to let me travel halfway around the globe for university.

I also really liked the academic set up. I've always known I wanted to go into engineering, but it had always felt like the natural path just because I was good at maths and physics, not because it was the right move.

I really liked the fact that here you can try everything until you find the right degree for you, as well as taking lots of other classes for interest.

I am going to leave here with my engineering degree in product design (part of the mechanical engineering department, but with a consumer-orientated focus), with minors (a field of study in which you fulfil about a third of a degree) in psychology and international relations. I'm also a university interpreter for American sign language.

I could not imagine being able to do so many different things at a university in England!

Well, Stanford is often seen to be on a par with Oxford and Cambridge, so for here I would definitely say you need to be able to hold your own academically. But to be honest the work load is comparable to tough A levels.

Most people here are amazing, but it's easier for people from England to get in because they like international students, and your A levels prepare you better, but it's a tough process.

The maths side of the Sat I found not that much harder than GCSE, so for someone like me, studying maths and further maths A levels, that was obviously a doddle.

But I had to swallow an American dictionary before I had a hope at the English part of the exams!

Most universities here aren't as hard to get into, though, and I would say that anyone who is able to go to a university in England is more than qualified to be studying at some American university.

My course is great. I get to take psychology, art, history of design, engineering and product design classes. The options for degrees are so open. If you don't like any of the options, you can make up your own interdisciplinary major!

Product design is everything I had wanted to study. We look at products and we learn how to design something. How to research what people need (vs what they think they need!), what the manufacturing limitations are and how to create the perfect product. One of the professors is one of the best renowned product designers in the world. He is an entrepreneur who founded Ideo, the largest produce design company around.

That is the best thing about Stanford. You are getting taught by people whose books you read in other classes. My psychology prof is Philip Zimbardo, who told me about some LWT programme he helped on which is going to be broadcast in the autumn. It's so amazing!

Yes, I get homesick. I really miss my family. But they come and visit, which helps. And when I go home in the summer I can talk about things - and they know about it!

I most of all miss England. English mannerisms and phrases. I've been here three years, completely changed my vocabulary, lost a lot of my English accent - and I still get laughed at sometimes for saying something they don't understand.

It's tough. I know we always joke about it being a different language but, seriously, for my first couple of months no one had a clue what I was talking about most of the time. I got extremely used to this blank look that would develop on people's faces when I talked to them which would make me sad because they obviously had no idea what I was babbling on about.

No one has heard of The Magic Roundabout or anything I grew up on. The only British programmes they know are ones like Are You Being Served? which I haven't seen for years!

It gets very sad sometimes, and all you want is a piece of Cadbury's chocolate or a pint of John Smiths!

As for the money, I came out here on an athletics scholarship, so it hasn't been that bad. When you are on scholarship they pay for everything apart from your flights home.

Time for class. Off to enjoy the Californian weather. Yes, it's a hard life!!!

Matt Craven is in his third year as an economics major

I was attracted by the greater academic freedom offered by Stanford. My degree will be in economics, but along the way I have taken courses in computer science, philosophy and political science. I think a broad education is very important and Stanford offered me that better than a UK university could. I was also attracted by the location in Silicon Valley, the climate and a general desire to study abroad.

Being admitted to Stanford is almost as difficult as being admitted to Oxford or Cambridge. Stanford only admits about 13% of students who apply. I turned down a place at Cambridge to come here.

The courses are difficult and they make us work hard. I probably spend 40 to 50 hours a week on academics (classes and homework) and I work less than most. I don't get homesick. This is partly because I made a lot of good friends here very quickly, and partly just because of my personality. I'm in my third year and this is really my home now.

Phil Rowe is honing his golf while studying psychology

The reason that I came to Stanford was because of my sport - golf. After leaving Truro School I took a year out, but decided in the end not to turn pro at that stage.

I went to Exeter University and had a great year, but I was having a lot of trouble fitting in the golf and academic work. I was contacted by coaches from universities in the US and put in touch with the golf coach at Stanford.

I had a national collge entry test and scored 1,300, which is below average for Stanford but not a bad total. It is tough to fit in sport and academic work, but the teachers are flexible at exam times - they are used to having athletes at college in the States. I am coming home to play in the British amateur at Liverpool [this week] but they will fax or email me the exam papers and I will have to take them just after I finish my round.

You do a whole range of subjects. I have done three classes in psychology and hope to major in that. You choose your classes to fit your timetable - my coach requires us to practise at certain times of the day, so I arranged classes to have mornings free one term and afternoons free the next. (We also do fitness workouts - last term I had to be in the gym every morning at 7am.)

My number-one priority is the golf team at Stanford, and I have had to turn down England international matches because I am in the United States.

I have missed my friends at home, but at the same time I have made a lot of friends here, including my roommate, who is an American footballer.

The cost is $35,000 a year which is way beyond my family's capabilities; but I am lucky because I have a golf scholarship which covers almost everything.

fields.headline: Unequal footings
fields.standfirst: Vice chancellors are a key target of anger at inequality, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Vice chancellors are a key target of anger at inequality, says Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
Ministers are stepping up pressure for reforms at Britain's elite universities. They want to see an end to the inequalities that still blight the entire higher education system, from the appointment of academic heads to the recruitment of students. Selection procedures for vice-chancellors are set to come under the spotlight, after education secretary David Blunkett slammed universities for the small number of women and people with ethnic-minority backgrounds who are appointed senior academic managers.

Last week MPs announced an inquiry into the admissions procedures of top universities after the chancellor Gordon Brown said it was scandalous that Oxford University had rejected the Tyneside comprehensive sixth-former Laura Spence, who then won an exclusive Harvard scholarship.

Presenting evidence to the House of Commons education committee, Blunkett complained that there are only five women vice-chancellors, and no vice-chancellors from ethnic minority groups in the UK. He called on old universities in particular to review their "quaint" ways of appointing heads. The selection procedures adopted by university councils are often shrouded in secrecy.

The call comes as headhunters are scrambling around universities for replacements for nearly half of the Russell group - the country's 19 most powerful university heads - who are standing down over the next year. Last week Newcastle University announced Prof Christopher Edwards, currently principal of the Imperial College school of medicine, as its next vice-chancellor. Glaxo Wellcome chief executive Sir Richard Sykes, meanwhile, is widely tipped as the next rector at Imperial College.

These appointments will mean that the group, which represents the large research universities, will remain an all-white-male affair. But some Bristol academics claim their university hopes to appoint the first black vice-chancellor when Sir John Kingman stands down next year.

Concerns over the powerful influence wielded by the Russell group, meanwhile, are likely to be reawakened when it announces plans to finally come out from the shadows. Up to now an informal lobbying group, it is now establishing its own secretariat and convenor. Its first convenor will be Oxford University's vice-chancellor, Dr Colin Lucas.

The move has been partly prompted by the debate over top-up fees, brought to light by a proposals put forward by the Nottingham University vice-chancellor, Sir Colin Campbell, earlier in the year. Many vice-chancellors in the group want to distance themselves from Campbell's more radical views, and agreed to appoint one formal spokesman for the group. The group has commissioned a team of economists to consider the implications of giving universities the freedom to charge top-up fees and control their student intakes.

Top-up fees remain another running sore between Blunkett and the Russell group heads. He has bowed to pressure to allow a debate on introducing fees after the next election.

A "no-surprise agreement" now exists between the different university factions and the committee of vice-chancellors and principals, whereby no proposals are made public without notifying other groups. The House of Commons education committee, though, is likely to focus on Russell-group institutions in its inquiry into admissions. The MPs will explore radical solutions to improve the low uptake of state-school students on degree courses. Universities could be forced to employ recruitment agencies to attract pupils from poorer backgrounds. Another suggestion is to set quotas for universities under which they would have to accept a certain percentage of students from the state sector. fields.bodyText: Ministers are stepping up pressure for reforms at Britain's elite universities. They want to see an end to the inequalities that still blight the entire higher education system, from the appointment of academic heads to the recruitment of students. Selection procedures for vice-chancellors are set to come under the spotlight, after education secretary David Blunkett slammed universities for the small number of women and people with ethnic-minority backgrounds who are appointed senior academic managers. Last week MPs announced an inquiry into the admissions procedures of top universities after the chancellor Gordon Brown said it was scandalous that Oxford University had rejected the Tyneside comprehensive sixth-former Laura Spence, who then won an exclusive Harvard scholarship. Presenting evidence to the House of Commons education committee, Blunkett complained that there are only five women vice-chancellors, and no vice-chancellors from ethnic minority groups in the UK. He called on old universities in particular to review their "quaint" ways of appointing heads. The selection procedures adopted by university councils are often shrouded in secrecy. The call comes as headhunters are scrambling around universities for replacements for nearly half of the Russell group - the country's 19 most powerful university heads - who are standing down over the next year. Last week Newcastle University announced Prof Christopher Edwards, currently principal of the Imperial College school of medicine, as its next vice-chancellor. Glaxo Wellcome chief executive Sir Richard Sykes, meanwhile, is widely tipped as the next rector at Imperial College. These appointments will mean that the group, which represents the large research universities, will remain an all-white-male affair. But some Bristol academics claim their university hopes to appoint the first black vice-chancellor when Sir John Kingman stands down next year.
