fields.headline: Perfect exits
fields.standfirst: Imagine our top football managers quitting en masse, then translate that into university heads. Radical reforms are due and a new guard awaits. Report by Lee Elliot Major
fields.trailText: Imagine our top football managers quitting en masse, then translate that into university heads. Radical reforms are due and a new guard awaits. Report by Lee Elliot Major
fields.body:
There is one give-away sign that a university vice-chancellor is planning to stand down: a sudden hike in their five figure salary in the annual university report. As with successful football managers and business chief executives, academic leaders can now negotiate one final lucrative contract before retiring from the pressurised world of managing a large institution.

There is also a perfect time to leave. Ignore all the conciliatory language you hear from academics about the importance of teaching students and working with industry. Research is what matters. The more academic and esoteric the better. And with all the kudos and money it brings, the Research Assessment Exercise is the only competition worth entering in the academic world.

The canny university head bows out just after the last university department makes its submissions to the exercise, but before the results are announced six months later. The official reason for this is that it gives a successor time to stamp their personality on the institution and take their own gambles in the academic transfer market in preparation for the next assessment in four years' time. But among the university council circuit, everyone knows the real reason: if the results go well, credit can still be taken; if they go badly, blame can be avoided.

Take Professor Sir Gareth Roberts for example. According to the most recent records, Sheffield University's vice-chancellor enjoyed a whopping 8.5% pay increase in 1998. Another 6.3% rise in 1999 took his total salary to £136,000. Not bad for a sector where the average lecturer's salary is £27,000, and funding per student has fallen by more than 40% over the last 20 years. Last December Roberts announced he was leaving the university after 10 enjoyable years. The date? - April 31 2001, the last day for entries to the 2001 assessment.

Then there is Sir Brian Follett, the vice-chancellor of Warwick University. Consecutive pay rises of 5.8% and 4.8% in the last two years have catapulted his salary to £114,412. Last month the university announced that he is standing down after eight years in post - at the end of next April.

In any normal academic year, these moves would be part of the usual sea sonal patterns among the academic elite that trace a steady turnover of the top university positions. But what distinguishes the coming year is the scale of the impending retirements. Half of the Russell group - the country's 19 most powerful university heads - will be gone by the time the research assessment results are unveiled at the end of 2001.

Newcastle's vice-chancellor, James Wright, leaves at the end of the year. Imperial College's rector, Lord Oxburgh, leaves on March 31 2001. Bristol's Sir John Kingman, will leave before August 31 2001. Birmingham and Cardiff heads Maxwell Irvine and Sir Brian Smith retire at the end of September 2001. And rumours are rife that the Manchester vice-chancellor, Sir Martin Harris, will be next to join the list, though he denies them.

The mass exodus has prompted a crisis among academic headhunters, who are scrambling around for potential successors. Some fear that there isn't enough talent around to fill the empty seats at the high table. "There are lots of senior people untested at this level," bemoaned one vice-chancellor. "You can't just recruit a vice-chancellor from a smaller uni versity - it would be like giving first division football managers a place in the premier league." It is as if the managers of Manchester United, Liverpool, Leeds, Arsenal and Chelsea all resigned at the same time.

And all this comes at a time when the academic sector is bracing itself for radical reforms. In private the prime minister's advisers are resigned to the fact that universities must be freed from current state controls if they are to prosper as businesses in the increasingly global market place for students and research grants. In the not too distant future, tuition fees and student numbers, as well as professorial salaries, will be determined by market forces, not nationally set quotas.

Roberts has been tempted away from Sheffield by one of the best post-VC jobs in the business: president of Wolfson College, Oxford. This is ideal for those who fancy a step down to a less pressurised academic life. But it also allows time for maintaining a national presence by serving on various national committees and inquiries. In semi-retirement, Roberts is likely only to enhance his reputation as the networker supreme, continuing to advise the government on science, biotechnology, university funding and researchers' careers.

Next year will see another vice-chancellor leave to snap up arguably the most attractive job of all: chief executive of the Higher Education Funding Council for England. Three heads consistently emerge as possible candidates: Manchester's Sir Martin Harris; Southampton's Howard Newby; and Sir David Watson, director of Brighton University. Watson started as the outside bet. But there is now a whisper that education ministers want to appoint a well respected figure from the new university sector. Watson fits the bill perfectly.

Job offers are not the reason for all the moves, though. Many heads are simply retiring. Some, it is claimed, have been pushed. But they are all members of the original set who eight years ago first started meeting at the dusty old rooms of the Russell Hotel in London. The group united the heads of the large redbrick and Oxbridge universities at a time when their research budgets looked to be under threat. The former polytechnics had become universities in 1992, doubling the number of institutions fighting for a share of the funding council's £600m research budget.

It soon emerged that the group was lobbying funding chiefs to ensure that 75% of research grants remained in the 20 oldest and largest universities. This was the most exclusive academic elite of clubs. And yet there was no trace of its existence - no official papers or spokesmen - only adding to its mystique and reputation. The legend of the Russell group was born.

And the break-up of the group comes when it is now at the very height of its power. In the early days it was a squabble over research funds. Now the talk concerns much wider topics: student top-up fees and global education markets. And for the first time the group appears genuinely to have the government's ear.

When the education secretary, David Blunkett, hinted that during a second parliamentary term ministers might allow universities to charge their own fees, the group took the unprecedented step of commissioning an economic study into the impacts of deregulating fees and student intakes. The prime minister's education adviser, Andrew Adonis, has privately urged the group to openly explore such issues, which not so long ago were off-limits even under the Tory government. Cleverly, the Russell group heads argue that fees make social and economic sense: why should the state subsidise the education of middle-class students who then earn high wages?

These views may become more extreme if the academic old guard make way for a new era of hard-nosed businesspeople in top academic positions. The Russell group packs a powerful punch. Director of the London School of Economics and New Labour insider Anthony Giddens has proved a useful addition as discussions with government have intensified. Add to this the clout of Sir Richard Sykes, Glaxo Wellcome's chief executive, who is widely tipped to become the new rector of Imperial College, and the group appears even more formidable.

Hiring business leaders, though, would buck a long-standing trend. In a book out later this year Kingston's vice-chancellor, Peter Scott, concludes that the backgrounds of university heads have hardly changed over the years. "Vice-chancellors are drawn from almost precisely the same background now as they were 30 years ago," he says. "There are few people who haven't been academics."

Yet Sykes' experience of merger talks and global competition could be invaluable in the new job. Recent signs that Birmingham and Aston universities are finally to merge suggest that further academic mergers are in the pipeline. St Andrews and Dundee, Warwick and Leicester, and even a University of Yorkshire have been rumoured. But by far the boldest proposals have come from former University College, London provost Sir Derek Roberts. Before retiring last year, he suggested that UCL, Imperial and LSE merge to form a university that would be a giant by any standards.

Whatever their backgrounds, the new breed of VCs are likely to live a very different life to their predecessors. The Russell group itself is to be transformed, taking on a more formal role with its own secretariat and convener. Oxford's vice-chancellor, Colin Lucas, will shortly be announced as the first to officially chair the group.

Contracts are likely to become shorter and less secure in an increasingly pressurised environment. Heads may even be judged as much on teaching income and student intakes as on the latest research assessment grades.

And you can say goodbye to the days when you could detect the tell-tale signs that a vice-chancellor was about to hand in their notice.

webTitle: Fijian coup leaders force appointment of interim prime minister

fields.headline: Fijian coup leaders force appointment of interim prime minister
fields.standfirst: The new military government in Fiji has appointed an interim prime minister  whose wife is among some 30 hostages held by coup leader George Speight
fields.trailText: The new military government in Fiji has appointed an interim prime minister  whose wife is among some 30 hostages held by coup leader George Speight
fields.body:
Ratu Epeli Nailatikau, son-in-law of yesterday's deposed President Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara has today been appointed an interim prime minister. But Mr Nailatikau's wife, Adi Nailatikau Mara, is among the hostages being held in the Parliament complex by troops loyal to George Speight.

Mrs Nailatikau was tourism minister in a government lead by the country's first ethnic Indian prime minister Mahendra Chaudhry. Mr Speight, in collusion with Fiji's elite counter-revolutionary warfare squadron, seized Mr Chaudhry and his government on May 19, claiming power in the name of indigenous Fijians.

Mr Nailatikau was Fiji's army commander until he was overthrown in a military coup in 1987. Formerly Fiji's high commissioner to Britain, who returned home to Fiji last year was appointed as the top official in the foreign affairs department.

The military took power yesterday amid growing lawlessness that saw the looting of Indian shops, the smashing up of a local TV station and the fatal shooting of a policeman. Commodore Frank Bainimarama, head of the armed forces, has denied that his men were negotiating with Mr Speight: "We can't be seen to negotiate with George Speight because we must maintain the credibility of the military. We've been known all over the world for our peacekeeping."

He said he had not been able to see Mr Chaudhry yet, but asked if the ousted prime minster was safe, he replied: "I believe he is." Cmdr Bainimarama said it had been hard to ask president Mara to stand aside and allow the military to take over. "We did what we did to ensure there was no civil war."

He conceded that president Mara had been reluctant to hand over power. "You must understand that his excellency the president is the president of Fiji. He cannot fully endorse the RFMF [the military] taking away his authority."

Cmdr Bainimarama acknowledged: "We have indirectly acceded to [Speight's] demands by taking over the country (from Mara), abrogating the constitution, and we have put in place an amnesty. But I must make it clear we are not doing this for him [Speight]. We are doing it for Fiji...to ensure that we bring some semblance of normality back to the country, to take out fear."

Don McKinnon, Commonwealth secretary-general acknowledged that there was little the Commonwealth could do to force Fiji to abandon its return to a race-based constitution. Commodore Frank Bainimarama, Fiji's military leader, has revoked a multi-racial constitution, in the hope of returning to a 1990 constitutional policy that favours indigenous Fijians and bars ethnic Indians from the positions of president and prime minister. Mr McKinnon said the secretariat of the Commonwealth, which includes Britain and its former colonies, would meet next week.

In throwing out Fiji's multi-racial constitution, the Fijian military met one of the main demands of Mr Speight, a failed businessman who seized the government and claimed power on behalf of indigenous Fijians. Mr McKinnon steered clear of criticising the Fijian authorities, saying they were overwhelmingly concerned for the safety of the hostages.

The issue explained

fields.headline: Labour's £28bn spending spree
fields.standfirst:
Cash aimed at both heartlands and middle England

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott will today seek to rally the Labour heartlands and middle England behind the slogan "opportunity for all" and a promise by Gordon Brown to inject a further £28bn into public spending over the next four years - on top of the £13bn already earmarked for the NHS.
fields.body:
John Prescott will today seek to rally the Labour heartlands and middle England behind the slogan "opportunity for all" and a promise by Gordon Brown to inject a further £28bn into public spending over the next four years - on top of the £13bn already earmarked for the NHS.

Brushing aside fears that New Labour offers different promises to different classes and regions, Mr Prescott will insist: "The Labour party is, always was and always will be the party that fights for a better chance for the majority. The Tory party is, always was and always will be the party that stands up for a privileged few."

The extra money is expected to be targeted at key policy areas including crime reduction measures, the welfare of poorer children, combating under-achievement in schools, and improvements to the road and rail infrastructure.

Behind the confident ministerial rhetoric the government is poised to admit that many of the performance targets it set for health, education and other public policies barely two years ago were too ambitious, too precise, too vague or almost meaningless.

Some, such as the drive to cut NHS waiting lists, had the "perverse effect" of driving up waiting times. Targets for improved exam league tables forced some schools to expel more disruptive pupils - just when other targets called for fewer expulsions.

When the chancellor unveils his second three-year comprehensive spending review in July he will introduce a simplified system of performance targets, or public service agreements, in Whitehall jargon: 200 instead of the 600 launched in 1998.

The change is designed to ensure that "hard core" problem areas do not get left behind as standards rise for the comfortable majority, majorities that exist in most cities and regions, not just the affluent south which has problem areas too, ministers say.

Under a scheme devised by the Treasury's senior official, Sir Andrew Turnbull, there will be two sets of targets: one for annual average improvements in national policy areas as different as GCSE results and cancer cures; plus a second set of minimum performance increases, to be called "floor targets", which must be met "in every part of the country".

With Tony Blair on quasi-paternity leave at Chequers the deputy prime minister will raise the government's banner in Gillingham, Kent, today.

Mr Prescott will back Mr Brown's attack on unjustified privilege at Oxford and Cambridge. The whole country will benefit if "employment, economic, educational and social barriers to opportunity that still exist in Britain today" are broken down, he will say.

Citing action for pensioners, education and regional development agencies - his own brainchild - Mr Prescott will insist: "These measures we are putting through benefit not just the heartlands, not just middle England, because the two are united by common instincts, common values and a common desire to remove the barriers that hold people back."

As for the July spending review, it will be presented in terms of "opportunity for all", the theme ministers intend to deploy in the election run-up, as they accuse the Conservatives of elitism.

Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, gave a hint of how the Tories will attack Labour's huge spending plans, an extra £40bn by 2004, by saying there is little to show for it.

"Gordon Brown's extra taxes are bad enough but what makes people angry is that the things they care about, like schools, hospitals and law and order, are not getting any better. This is a government that taxes more but delivers less," said Mr Portillo.

After three years of trying to impose solutions from Whitehall across traditional departmental barriers, ministers are aware how intractable some policy problems and neighbourhoods are.

The new floor targets model, due to come into effect in 2001-02, means that the worst-performing schools, hospitals or crime-ridden police authorities will be required to raise their game by a specified minimum, instead of being allowed to hide behind the average rise achieved by more successful rivals.

Failure will not be punished by loss of funds but by more central intervention, including sackings as a last resort. Targets as different as adult literacy, GCSE results, train punctuality and rates of cancer cure are in Whitehall's sights.

Those who show they can deliver the goods will get more money and less government interference.

Mr Brown's team is still negotiating bilaterally with individual spending ministers, while Mr Blair's policy unit staff ride shotgun, ready to advise the prime minister that his arbitration is necessary.

However, Treasury officials now believe that the downward pressure on social security spending will allow them to add around £28bn to spending ministries other than health by 2003-04. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has already been promised £13bn for the NHS over four years - 35% in real terms.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, has already been promised £13bn for the NHS over four years - 35% in real terms.

fields.headline: Class warfare or what?
fields.standfirst: Political editor Michael White wonders if the latest row over university selection is about more than just getting rid of elitism in this country
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 1.45pm: Political editor Michael White wonders if the latest row over university selection is about more than just getting rid of elitism in this country
fields.body:
Ministers seem to have taken a lot of stick from Conservative newspapers since Gordon Brown unleashed the latest Labour assault on the citadels of privilege that he detects at Oxford and Cambridge Universities.

It is not simply a question of whether Mr Brown and his cabinet allies are right or wrong, they are probably both. Do they know what they are doing as John Prescott piles in behind Robin Cook, Margaret Jay and other colleagues?

The short answer is, yes, they are adamant that they do know. They intend to fight the coming election on an "opportunities for all" slogan and to paint William Hague's Tory team as promoting an exclusive brand of elitism which favours those who have already got a firm foot on the ladder.

This is tricky territory for both sides. As most voters know, Tony Blair's parents (his father, Leo Senior, was illegitimate) came up the hard way, prospered and sent their children to private schools. All three became lawyers and young Tony went from Fettes - Scotland's Eton - to Oxford where he was a rebel of the rock'n'roll kind, not an Oxford Union politico.

William Hague's family were Yorkshire business types. He was sent away to school, didn't like it, then went to the local grammar which had recently turned comprehensive. He went to Oxford too, was president of the union and got a first at the college - Magdalen - which rejected Laura Spence, the Tyneside teenager whose case fired up Mr Brown.

So was Gordon Brown wrong to say Ms Spence had been a victim of the "old boy networks"? Oxford was quick to parade its own efforts to widen the net. The five medical students who got the places Laura didn't included a majority of women and ethnic minorities.

All true, but Brown and co are playing politics. They seek to turn the tables on Mr Hague for his populist attacks on law and order, on asylum and taxation, intending to fight populist fire with populist fire.

Brown, a thoughtful man who got to Edinburgh University from his local grammar school at 16 and was a famous student radical in his time, has a more ambitious agenda. A bookish policy wonk, he has spent many summers at Harvard - America's richest and most prestigious college - and seen it transformed from what he calls "a finishing school for elites" into a far more diverse place.

Why? Because 25 years ago, the college decided not to pick and choose between those who apply, rich or poor, deprived or late developers, but to go out and actively find clever students, the best. It takes time and money - Harvard has plenty and employs up to 50 talent spotters. Yale, Princeton and other US Ivy League colleges now do the same. David Lammy, the 27-year-old black barrister who has just been picked to fight Bernie Grant's Tottenham seat for Labour, is one such lucky Harvard man.

This is where Brown scores. It is not just Oxbridge which is open to attack in Britain. The top 10 universities, which include Edinburgh - more exclusive now than in the chancellor's day, full of posh English refugees from Oxbridge - the London School of Economics, University College London, Imperial and Warwick, are all open to criticism for not taking deprived students: fewer than 5% in fact. UMIST in Manchester, ministers say, takes 30%.

Mr Brown's July spending review will offer the top ten more money to go out and find the best. No wonder the rightwing press is screaming; its editors and their readers realise that the more meritocratic the system, the fewer the places at Oxbridge for borderline cases from the private schools which cost up to £14,000 a year.

Yes, they're bright kids too, but are they the brightest? And do cultural biases work against them as Oxbridge pays lip-service to inverted snobbery, or does familiarity and confidence ease in more than their fair share? The figures support the Labour case: 7% at private schools, yet 45%-55% of the Oxbridge places.

Yet Labour still runs a risk. After all, say the Liberal Democrats, why did they impose tuition fees at £1,000 a year, plus student loans which can intimidate students from poor backgrounds, unused to debts that can reach £15,000 by graduation? And why did Labour abolish the assisted places scheme for poor kids and is spending less on education per head than the Tories did in office, Hague's party asks?

All good questions, but Labour will press ahead. It deplores talk of "class warfare", but that is the sub-text of its message to the Labour heartlands and to Middle England: we represent the hard-working majority, the Tories don't, ministers will say. As with the row over fox-hunting, voters will soon decide who they think is right, when election day dawns.

fields.headline: Not so black and white
fields.standfirst:
Some 'racist attacks' turn out to be hoaxes - that should not deflect attention from the real story of increases in such crimes across the country

Race issues in the UK: special report
Macpherson report - one year on: special report
fields.trailText: Of all the things attributed to the publication in February of Sir William Macpherson's report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, this has to be the most perverse.
fields.body:
Of all the things attributed to the publication in February of Sir William Macpherson's report into the murder of Stephen Lawrence, this has to be the most perverse.

Recently there have been a number of well-publicised "racist attacks". But if the police are now right, we were duped. After exhaustive inquiries, detectives concluded the incidents were hoaxes. In some cases, alleged victims were not attacked at all. Some so-called victims have been charged by the police and their stories will emerge in court, where they will be devoured by tub-thumpers who rail that race relations "are not so bad".

Yet the alleged fakers should not be ignored. Take Gurpal Virdi, the Sikh police sergeant who claimed he received racist hate mail from white colleagues. Mr Virdi, an officer stationed in west London, alleged he was victimised for challenging colleagues who took a less than rigorous interest in race crimes. His fight, however, appears to have been a figment of his imagination.

Mr Virdi was sacked by the Metropolitan police in March after an internal inquiry decided he had sent the hate mail to himself and other black and Asian staff. The hearing concluded that Mr Virdi was motivated by frustration - he had been turned down for promotion - and that he had tried to cover his tracks by incriminating a white woman colleague. Mr Virdi says he was framed.

The case of Ashia Hansen is stranger still. When the Daily Express broke the story that Chris Cotter, the athlete's on-off boyfriend, had been stabbed outside her home in Birmingham and that she had received hate mail, detectives thought they were dealing with a racially- motivated attack.

Now Mr Cotter has been remanded in custody charged with staging the whole incident in order to sell the story. Two other men have been charged with causing Mr Cotter grievous bodily harm, though it appears the wounds he received from them were unintentionally vicious.

Last month a teenager claimed that four white men soaked him in petrol and set him alight, shouting "You smelly Paki". The 17-year-old, who lives in a village in Oxfordshire, suffered terrible burns to his face and arms. The pictures told one story and he told another. It was one which echoed the circumstances of the horrendous death of the black musician Michael Menson, whose murderers were jailed in January.

According to detectives, nothing happened. First they announced the incident was not being treated as racially motivated. Then the teenager was "invited" in for questioning. The police theory goes something like this: the youth accidentally set himself alight when he tried to set fire to a car with lighter fluid, and concocted the story to get himself out of trouble. There was a similar case in the West Midlands. Last week, Ashley Kane, from Kings Heath, Birmingham, was charged with wasting police time by claiming he was set on fire by a gang of racists. Mr Kane's possible motive for apparently making up the story becomes a little clearer when you consider the second charge against him - attempting to defraud an insurance company of £3,500 for damage to his car, a VW Golf, which was set on fire in the alleged attack.

There has been a spate of these unresolved incidents. But whatever the truth in each case, as a phenomenon they are not significant. They are probably no more than an unfortunate curiosity of the post-Macpherson back lash, and should not deflect the police, politicians or commentators from the task ahead. The nature of that task is illustrated by the graphic: what is the cause of such disproportion in arrest rates?

The real story for the Metropolitan police is not that Gurpal Virdi was sacked but that the number of race hate crimes in the capital is now running at an average of 63 a day. The total number in the 12 months to April this year was 23,346, more than for the whole of England in the 12 months to 1999. Scotland Yard does not record the number of malicious racial reports, but when asked, sources at the Met could not think of a single incident in recent memory.

The Thames Valley force, which covers Oxfordshire, recorded 999 racially motivated crimes last year, up from 486 in 1998. Inspector Simon Pont, who heads the community and race relations team, said the recent hoax involving the teenager was the only one he had ever come across.

The West Midlands force will tell you a similar story. Recorded racial crime has gone up by 50% in the last two years. Every study suggests racial crime has been massively under-reported. But even recorded "racial incidents" are acknowledged to have doubled in the past decade. Now that the police are taking race crimes seriously - thanks in no small measure to Macpherson - is it such a surprise that a few individuals have tried to take advantage?

Those who have been proved to have faked racial abuse deserve the highest condemnation. Their deception wastes police time and money. They are also guilty of engineering a shameful distraction. By exploiting sensitivity about race, they encourage claims that Macpherson went far too far and that Sir William - demonised in some papers, particularly the Daily Telegraph - dangerously exaggerated Britain's multi-cultural problems and branded the police, with high-minded carelessness, as institutionally racist.

Nick Hopkins is our crime correspondent

nick.hopkins@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Gifted, black... and gone
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: This month has seen the publication of two major books by leading black British intellectuals, Paul Gilroy's polemic Between Camps and Caryl Phillips's reflective travelogue, The Atlantic Sound.
fields.body:
This month has seen the publication of two major books by leading black British intellectuals, Paul Gilroy's polemic Between Camps and Caryl Phillips's reflective travelogue, The Atlantic Sound. The books, like their authors, are very different but Gilroy and Phillips have at least one thing in common: prestigious professorial posts at American universities - Gilroy at Yale, since quitting as a professor at Goldsmith's College in London last year, and Phillips at Columbia.

They are not alone: other key black or Asian scholars and artists with teaching posts in the US include the academics Homi Bhabha and Kobena Mercer, the writers Fred D'Aguiar and Merle Collins, the filmmaker Isaac Julien and the artist Winston Branch. This might be a success story: Britain's brightest and most creative wooed by a superpower with whose wealth and resources we cannot compete. But many don't see it that way.

Phillips, who insists he has "never left" his primary source of creativity thanks to air miles, says: "Tertiary education in Britain doesn't value the people who work in it, so there's a leakage to the US." He doesn't see this as a particularly black problem; white writers and academics are drawn west just as strongly, he says.

But Professor Lola Young of Middlesex University, who wrote recently in this newspaper that "black intellectuals . . . often have a hard time getting their work taken seriously", believes the lack of recognition has another dimension. "Britain is still in thrall to America," she says. "The media are more likely to seek African-American feminists, say, as cultural commmentators than black British intellectuals."

While the word "intellectual" is often accompanied by a sneer, some claim that turns to open scorn for those who theorise about race. Gilroy, who claims many in Britain see the term "black intellectual" as "oxymoronic", says: "Even to be interested in race, let alone to assert its centrality to British nationalism, is to sacrifice the right to be taken seriously."

Edward Said, in his 1992 Reith lectures, saw one task of the intellectual as "to break down the stereotypes and reductive categories that are so limiting to human thought and communication". While academic writing can be abstruse, its ideas have a way of filtering into society; the current film of Mansfield Park would be impossible without Said's thought on Jane Austen's links to Caribbean slavery. Yet how are debates on, say, political asylum or institutional racism to be raised above the level of tabloid journalism if those doing rigorous, long-term thinking on such issues are derided?

Heidi Safia Mirza, professor of racial equality studies at Middlesex, says: "There's no critical capacity to talk about race issues here; we have no such intellectual tradition. We talk in very regressive ways; 19th-century ideas about genes and blood are at the heart of a lot of 'commonsense' thinking, which is not challenged in schools."

The result, says Gilroy, is that "political and policy debate gets jammed". He accuses the government of unleashing a lethal xenophobia partly by paying no heed to historical links between race, nationalism and immigration.

Few would see US race politics as more healthy, but the ubiquity of African-American thinkers such as Skip Gates, Cornell West and Patricia Williams as media pundits is in marked contrast to Britain, where, as Gilroy says: "It's incredible that Sivanandan and Stuart Hall have had to wait till now to be admitted to the magic circle of media commentators."

The writer Ferdinand Dennis, who has coedited a new anthology of three generations of black and Asian writers and intellectuals, says: "It's easier to get attention if we're victims and beaten up by racist thugs, when they can pour liberal sympathy on us, than if we're reflecting on our own experience here."

Kobena Mercer at Cornell University, who works in diaspora studies, says there is a longer tradition of debating race issues in the US. "Universities reflect the history of race relations in the two countries; because the US was a segregated society, official institutions have had to deal with race in a way they haven't in Britain.

It's hard for me to find an institutional niche home in Britain, partly because my work cuts across disciplines, and I've found an audience here. But the tradeoff is that while America recognises work like mine as a legitimate area of study, the culture is still dealing with a legacy of segregation."

Julien, who teaches a semester a year at Harvard, agrees: "London's wonderful on a cultural and social level; there's a certain fluidity, mobility, ease. And for people of colour, there's no question that Britain is the best place in Europe. But institutionally, especially in London, there's a real resistance. A retrospective show is opening at the Bard museum in New York, and in Sydney and Sweden, but it can't find a place at the Tate or the Hayward. On the one hand you have artistic recognition of Chris Ofili and Steve McQueen [who won the Turner prize in successive years], and on the other there's still institutional disrespect."

There is an unwritten code, Julien suggests, of not drawing attention to race: "Assimilation is about repudiating one's racial status, proving yourself beyond it. In a way the US is race obsessed - but at least they recognise there's a problem."

Yet the very friction of institutional battles can sustain some. David Dabydeen, professor of Caribbean studies at Warwick University, who has taught in Virginia, says: "It's much more challenging and energising to be in Britain than America. I didn't feel there was anything to kick against there; the fights in the 60s - for intellectual parity and seeing African culture and history as worthy of the academy - were largely won. In England, they still have to be."

But while Gilroy intends to return to Britain he warns of a knock-on effect for future generations: "If you want to make younger black people interested in education and the arts, you need black folks visibly successful outside music and sport, instead of saying you have to go somewhere else to succeed."

 Between Camps is published by Allen Lane, £22.50. The Atlantic Sound is published by Faber and Faber, £16.99.

In a way the US is race obsessed - but at least they recognise there's a problem." Yet the very friction of institutional battles can sustain some. David Dabydeen, professor of Caribbean studies at Warwick University, who has taught in Virginia, says: "It's much more challenging and energising to be in Britain than America. I didn't feel there was anything to kick against there; the fights in the 60s - for intellectual parity and seeing African culture and history as worthy of the academy - were largely won. In England, they still have to be." But while Gilroy intends to return to Britain he warns of a knock-on effect for future generations: "If you want to make younger black people interested in education and the arts, you need black folks visibly successful outside music and sport, instead of saying you have to go somewhere else to succeed."  Between Camps is published by Allen Lane, £22.50. The Atlantic Sound is published by Faber and Faber, £16.99.

fields.headline: Foxy, Fab and Forthright
fields.trailText: MARTIN AT THE CROSSROADS
fields.body:
MARTIN AT THE CROSSROADS

With ITV executives desperately looking for something to fill a Home and Away-sized hole in their schedules, they could do worse than attempt an embarrassingly low-budget dramatisation of the goings-on at Leicester City. There's the gang of four, the improbable Worthington Cup victories, the arrival of Stanley Victor Collymore ("But... we thought you were dead!!?") and, to cap it all off, the tragic departure of Martin O'Neill.

Or not. You see, while early this morning O'Neill was still mulling over the offer of the Celtic manager's job, and at lunchtime he had agreed to leave Leicester for Glasgow, by tea-time Leicester were saying that nothing had been decided and that nothing will be decided today. The club refused to confirm to the Fiver whether or not O'Neill is still in discussions with the Foxy Foxes (it must have been our tone of voice), but it is widely believed that chairman John Elsom is this evening making one last attempt to keep the Irishman at the club. Stapling his feet to the boardroom floor is probably Elsom's best bet.

So any managerial move remains uncertain. Which means the jury hasn't even had a chance to be out over whether O'Neill has the right pedigree for Parkhead. One thing that does seem unlikely, however, is that Foxy record signing Darren Eadie is the sort of player 60,000 baying season-ticket holders have in mind when it comes to regenerating what is currently the ailing manufacturing arm of the Old Firm. As Benny from Crossroads might have put it: "Ooh, Miss Diane."

FAB BLAB

After the Greg van Rusedski farce temporarily turned Manchester United into the laughing stock of world football, the last thing you'd expect the Old Trafford club to do is announce another big-money transfer before they've dotted all the "i"s and crossed all the "t"s. For example, say they were trying to sign French World Cup-winning goalkeeper Fabien Barthez from Monaco for £10m. They'd keep well schtum until everything was sorted, right?

"I can confirm that we are in discussions with Fabien Barthez and we would expect an early conclusion to it," United's excited money man Peter Kenyon predictably blabbed this morning, tempting fate in the way only true masochists can. "The medical has still to take place but we're getting close and I think later today we should be able to make an announcement," he continued in a carelessly carefree manner, filing the Monaco keeper's Keane-esque wage demands under "don't care" and his doctor's report under "medicine schmedicine".

Of course, the Fiver is probably just being uncharacteristically dour and cynical. After all, it's more than likely that nothing will go wrong and the 28-year-old keeper will join United, forcing the never-popular Mark Bosnich to waddle off to Spanish champions Deportivo La Coruna. But we're not counting any chickens, because we're still waiting for this announcement we've been promised. And has anyone had a look at the state of his knees yet?

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"We are applying the law that states that a player will be punished severely for striking a referee, only this time it is reverse. It's a very strange situation and this is not the kind of publicity we want." Alexander Rego of the Macau FA after referee Choi Kuok-kun was banned for life for laying into a player during a friendly.

KEN YOU CREDIT IT?

It must be a tough time for Kuddly Ken Bates. With no incendiary programme notes to write, and with a good couple of months until this winter's fur coats are unveiled, Chelsea's chairman must have a lot of time on his hands. It's no surprise therefore to find him ranting his head off to Chelsea Clubcall about anything and everyone. With a special degree of attention lavished upon Aston Villa.

Reminiscing about the Blues' fantastic Cup final achievement of yesterweek, Kuddly charitably recalled: "I must confess that halfway through the first-half I decided that they were like some two-bob team hoping to get through on penalties." You may remember that Leicester City had committed the same horror against Chelsea earlier in the competition, but Villa compounded that folly by being stupid as well. "Of course, their attempts to mark us down on that pitch in that weather wore them out," observed the much-loved chairman. "They started to lose their puff. They thought our old ones would lose their puff but they didn't."

So ner. But as far as Ken is concerned, Villa are not alone in making unfounded assumptions. In fact, there's been a conspiracy at work for some time now. "There has always been an anti-Chelsea bias going right back to the 1970s because we had our fans strutting down the Kings Road and Carnaby Street and the swinging sixties and all that kind of stuff," said Ken. "That bias has continued to this day and perhaps even more now because I dare to defend Chelsea and stand up for us." But thank God you do Ken. Thank God you do.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Ugo Ehiogu has been told that he can leave Aston Villa by John Gregory. The talented defender is reportedly a target for both Leeds and Manchester United.

Arsenal could be ready to bring Kasey Keller back to Britain. The former Leicester keeper has had a mixed time with Spanish club Rayo Vallecano this season, and is available for £2m.

Liverpool are believed to have completed the signing of Leicester's reserve keeper Pegguy Arphexad on a free transfer.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Michael Owen and Dennis Wise have been pulled out of tomorrow night's Wembley friendly against Ukraine. The pair have been withdrawn as a precaution by Kelvin Koogan because of "slight" back injuries. Steven Gerrard and Steve McManaman will definitely play.

England will wear white for both their Euro 2000 group A games against Portugal and Romania and red for their final group match against Germany.

Gabriel Batistuta, 31, has completed a £22m move from Fiorentina to Roma.

Wembley Stadium's funders are threatening to pull the plug on the proposed redevelopment unless the cap on events is withdrawn by Brent Council. Planning officers have suggested that a limit of 22 sporting events and 15 non-sporting events should be imposed until a £36m upgrade to Wembley Park tube station is completed. But Chase Manhattan bank are worried that they would not be able to safeguard their investment should Wembley run into financial difficulties.

Borussia Dortmund have appointed former German international Matthias Sammer as coach. The 32-year-old replaces Udo Lattek, who was installed as a stop-gap manager last month and quit last week.

Former Blackburn manager Brian Kidd has joined Leeds to oversee youth development at the English premier league club.

Leicester's Muzzy Izzet and Rangers midfielder Tugay have been named in Turkey's squad for Euro 2000. Aston Villa-bound Luc Nilis has been named in Belgium's squad.

A computer crash has wiped scores of season ticket holders from Aberdeen's records. Details of around 160 tickets sold on Wednesday and Thursday last week have been lost, and supporters who made purchases on those days are advised to ring the Pittodrie ticket office on 01224 650444 to avoid their tickets being sold to other fans.

Roberto Carlos has signed a new five-year, £10m contract with Real Madrid. The contract has a buy-out clause of £50m.

Roy Hodgson looks set to be installed as the new manager of Danish first division side FC Copenhagen.

St Johnstone have completed the signing of AB Copenhagen winger Tommy Lovenkrands on a three-year deal.

Former Dunfermline boss Dick Campbell has returned to management by taking the reins at Brechin City.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Sky Sports 1: International Football Live (7pm, 12midnight)
Republic of Ireland v Scotland. Bespoke title sequence probably features animated leprechaun doing highland fling.

Sky Sports 3: Premiership Shorts (10.55pm)
Will be longer next year.

British Eurosport: Football (7.15pm)
Go on, surprise us.

Football (7.45pm)
If you want England to get through to the final of the U-21s, you'd better hope Italy, who beat England, lose to Turkey, who lost 6-0 to England. Hmm.

fields.headline: UK agrees to Euro-bugging
fields.standfirst:
Civil liberties watchdog voices unease as Straw signs anti-crime pact to allow EU-wide phone tapping

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Britain signed up to greater cooperation with its EU partners yesterday, with agreements to share criminal intelligence and to allow UK immigration officials to operate in France.
fields.body:
Britain signed up to greater cooperation with its EU partners yesterday, with agreements to share criminal intelligence and to allow UK immigration officials to operate in France.

EU ministers signed the mutual legal assistance convention, which allows for cooperation on criminal investigations. It gives German police, for example, the right to tap the telephone of a suspect living in Britain, or vice versa.

Jack Straw, the home secretary, and Jean-Pierre Chevènement, his French counterpart, finalised details of a treaty permitting British immigration officers to check passengers before they board the Eurostar at Paris's Gare du Nord and other stations in France.

With controversy over illegal immigrants and asylum seekers in recent months, the cross-Channel rail link has become a popular route for refugees, especially Albanians and Somalians, seeking a new life in Britain.

Under the agreement, signed in Brussels, French officials will be able to operate reciprocally at Waterloo and Ashford. British immigration officers already operate on Eurostar trains from Belgium.

On a wider issue, EU interior ministers approved Britain's request to join the Schengen information system, a Strasbourg-based database with over 14m records on fugitives, stolen vehicles and firearms.

But Britain is staying outside the wider Schengen agreement, which loosened border controls between several EU states. Other EU states had been unhappy with this à la carte approach, but reluctantly concluded that it was better to have Britain only partly in than completely outside - a solution which cannot be replicated over the bigger issue of the euro.

The British government says the EU anti-crime convention is intended to cope with the growth of cross-border crime and make it easier to obtain evidence abroad for use in British courts.

But there are worries that what began as judicial cooperation has ended with tighter operational coordination between unaccountable and self-regulating police and security forces. "It's a massive extension of powers," warned Tony Bunyan of Statewatch, the civil liberties watchdog. "If you don't define which crimes this applies to - say drug dealing or child pornography - those powers could easily be abused."

Worries about the Schengen information system focus on a lack of adequate data-protection provisions and a limited scope for judicial review.

Mr Straw sought to emphasise the positive aspects of the government's involvement in EU cooperation on crime, justice and home affairs. "There are clear benefits to engaging with our European partners," he said. "We have been able to protect our borders while joining in measures which will enable us better to tackle cross-border crime."

He said later he had reassured colleagues that Britain's involvement in the Echelon surveillance system, a US-led economic espionage network, did not breach accepted EU standards on the interception of communications.

Portugal, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency, had raised concerns, originating in the European parliament, that Echelon's satellites and listening posts were being used to spy on European companies.

"All interception in the UK takes place under a strict legal framework," Mr Straw insisted.

Officials said it would take about a year for the Anglo-French treaty on Eurostar checks to be ratified - too late to stop football hooligans heading to the Euro 2000 competition next month.

But Mr Straw told BBC radio that the government would "continue to look at whether it is possible, even at this late stage, to introduce emergency legislation to stop hooligans travelling".

The Belgian and Dutch governments, members of the Schengen border pact, confirmed that they would reinstate frontier controls for the duration of Euro 2000.

A continent sans frontières

Under the original 1985 Schengen pact, a group of European Union states agreed to the gradual abolition of border controls and new measures on cross-border policing. All EU member states except Britain and Ireland are members.

London and Dublin have opted out of sections of the agreement removing frontier controls.

Britain now opts into the Schengen information system. UK police and law enforcement agencies will have access to a network of computer databases to help track down stolen vehicles or firearms, or suspects who have fled abroad.

The Schengen information system has 45,000 access points. By the end of 1997 it had 14m records.

webTitle: Head teachers' leader calls for end to Ofsted inspections

fields.headline: Head teachers' leader calls for end to Ofsted inspections
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The new leader of the National Association of Head Teachers today compared Ofsted inspections to the Spanish inquisition and said they should be scrapped.
fields.body:
The new leader of the National Association of Head Teachers today compared Ofsted inspections to the Spanish inquisition and said they should be scrapped.

"Let's call a halt to the current inspection system because we think it's causing schools an awful lot of anxiety," Mick Brookes, the association's incoming president, told reporters. "Every now and again I see some schools are being pasted because they have had a difficult experience with the Ofsted inspectors. My experience of going to those schools and helping them through case work is it doesn't do them any good."

Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, said he was "deeply concerned" if anything went wrong during an inspection. But he said he felt "an appalling sense of deja vu" when he heard Mr Brookes's comments.

"The same expression was used five to six years ago when I started as chief inspector," said Mr Woodhead. "You have got the teaching unions repeatedly, year after year, wanting to try to remove Ofsted."

It was important to distinguish between a legitimate expression of concern over inspections that have gone wrong and the NAHT's demand to outlaw Ofsted. "In my humble opinion, there should be nowhere to hide for head teachers," said Mr Woodhead.

Up to 30% of inspections were monitored. "If we find through those processes any inspector who is not doing the job as we expect them to do it, then we get rid of them," he added. Nearly 90% of inspections were judged positively.

In another development, the union today published advice for its members on the issue of exclusions and raised a number of concerns about the practice.

It said head teachers must reserve the right to exclude pupils where the health, safety, welfare or education of others is threatened, even if this goes against government guidance or appeal panel decisions.

The union is concerned that the reinstatement of pupils by Independent Appeal Panels, often on the advice of local education authorities, is causing extreme difficulties for schools. It highlights cases where pupils who have threatened fellow students with knives have been reinstated against the wishes of governors, head teachers and school staff.

NAHT general secretary David Hart said: "The exclusions process is falling into disrepute. There are whole areas of misconduct, such as drug dealing and serious bullying, that call for drastic action, but which government guidance treats inadequately. The reduction in the number of permanent exclusions may look superficially impressive. But it has been obtained at the expense of heads and their staff. They are being forced to keep pupils whose actions damage the education of fellow students."

Mr Hart told a news conference that within the last few weeks two secondary school head teachers in London had been forced to take back pupils who had threatened other children with knives in school.

"It was part of an ongoing vendetta between the perpetrator and pupils concerned," he said. In one case it was a carving knife that was wielded by an older student at a younger student."

In one of the schools, Mr Hart said, there was a possibility that a teacher would refuse to teach the pupil involved. Both cases have been reported to the education secretary and Mr Hart said the incidents left pupils desperately frightened.

Mr Hart also highlighted the issue of using reasonable force to restrain violent pupils. A number of the association's 40 members who were currently suspended were cases relating to allegations of improper restraint in special schools.

He said: "That's a matter of great concern to us. These schools are operating in a very difficult situation. They are being unfairly accused of misapplying a policy which is very difficult to apply and often has to be applied in a split second to prevent damage to pupils and staff."

webTitle: Real hope in ending the Eritrea-Ethopia bloodbath

fields.headline: Real hope in ending the Eritrea-Ethopia bloodbath
fields.standfirst: Hours after Addis Ababa announced a partial withdrawal from Eritrean territory, peace talks in Algiers hope to bring the two-year border war to an end
fields.trailText: Hours after Addis Ababa announced a partial withdrawal from Eritrean territory, peace talks in Algiers hope to bring the two-year border war to an end
fields.body:
Ahmed Ouyahia, the Algerian justice minister, will mediate between poverty stricten Eritrea and Ethiopia, at war since May 1998. Haile Woldensae, the Eritrean foreign minister, is leading his country's delegation in peace efforts sponsored by the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), and backed by the US and the EU.

The planned four day talks were due to start yesterday but were delayed by 24 hours after Seyoum Mesfin, the Ethiopian foreign minister failed to appear. The peace effort follows recent Ethiopian offensives reminiscent of the bloodiest parts of the first world war.

Ethiopia said its army had withdrawn from western Eritrea after accomplishing certain military objectives, claiming its forces had killed, wounded or captured a sufficient number of Eritrean soldiers thereby stunting Eritrea's ability to wage war.

Fighting still continues in southern Eritrea where Ethiopia claims its enemy is holding pockets of Ethiopian land along a 600-mile frontier. On the central front, Ethiopian troops are believed to have pushed to within 60 miles of the Eritrean capital Asmara. The latest offensive has brought the Eritrean economy to a standstill as the UN struggles to cope with an exodus to Sudan of wide-reaching humanitarian implication.

webTitle: EC investigates claim that German PO is overcharging

fields.headline: EC investigates claim that German PO is overcharging
fields.standfirst: Delivery delays cause anger in Britain and raise competition questions
fields.trailText: The Post Office had cause for celebration last night after the European commission disclosed it had launched an investigation into claims that Germany's Deutsche Post is overcharging for certain letters sent from Britain and deliberately delaying their delivery.
fields.body:
The Post Office had cause for celebration last night after the European commission disclosed it had launched an investigation into claims that Germany's Deutsche Post is overcharging for certain letters sent from Britain and deliberately delaying their delivery.

The move comes ahead of radical proposals due to be endorsed in Brussels today to liberalise substantially Europe's postal sector and gradually open it up to full competition by chipping away at monopoly providers. These proposals are likely to be less popular with the Royal Mail.

The dispute between the Post Office and Deutsche Post raises serious questions, however, about how advanced competition in Europe really is.

Postal charges in Germany are among the highest in Europe and have prompted companies based there to dispatch huge quantities of letters to Britain electronically or by other means where they are then remailed to Germany.

The canny German and international firms concerned, mostly banks and credit card companies, are saving millions of pounds by doing this because international postal rates in Britain are considerably cheaper than German domestic rates.

However, the Post Office, which is pulling down significant extra revenue as a result, claims that a disgruntled Deutsche Post has started hitting back by charging the full German price on such letters and deliberately holding them up to discourage the practice.

This kind of behaviour must, it argues, be in breach of EU fair competition rules since Deutsche Post is clearly taking advantage of its dominant position.

Brussels, which is already looking into claims that Deutsche Post is illegally cross-subsidising some of its commercial services, obviously suspects the German firm has at least a case to answer.

"We sent a letter to Deutsche Post last week asking it to respond to allegations made by the Post Office and others," an EC spokeswoman said. Although companies have complained about this issue before, this is the first time, she added, that a postal service from another member state has become involved.

"Among the allegations is that Deutsche Post is charging the full stamp price and delaying delivering letters with a view to damaging the practice of remailing," she said.

The inquiry is a victory for proponents of liberalisation who were disappointed in February when the European Court of Justice ruled that Deutsche Post was perfectly in its rights to levy an extra charge for remailed letters, although not the full domestic price.

Europe's £53bn postal market is, in any case, due for an overhaul and the commission is expected to say today that EU-wide competition for letters weighing more than 50 grammes should be introduced from 2003 onwards. This would be certain to anger the Post Office which has argued strongly that the 350 gramme threshold should not be lowered beyond 150 grammes.

In November Post Office chief executive John Roberts warned the commission not to go too far: "There should not be 'a leap of faith' in making changes to monopolies otherwise there would be a threat to the continued provision of an affordable universal service ... with the inevitable risk of postage price rises and lower quality of service."

The Post Office is already under pressure from the government to surrender part of its monopoly and under present plans would only retain exclusivity on letters and parcels under 50p compared to £1 presently. The Post Office - which employs around 200,000 people and enjoys annual revenues in excess of £7bn - has sought to ready itself for liberalisation by expanding internationally through a series of acquisitions and joint ventures.

webTitle: 'Sometimes people just stop fancying each other'

fields.headline: 'Sometimes people just stop fancying each other'
fields.standfirst: So Viagra doesn't work on females. But with 43% of women saying they don't enjoy sex, the drug companies are still frantically searching for treatments. Are drugs really the answer though, asks  Lucy Atkins
fields.trailText: So Viagra doesn't work on females. But with 43% of women saying they don't enjoy sex, the drug companies are still frantically searching for treatments. Are drugs really the answer though?
fields.body:
"I feel like less than a woman," says 34-year-old Marian Jones. Since having her second child four years ago, Marian has lost all desire for sex. "I feel guilty every time I say no. I slink into bed after he's gone to sleep... I can't bear to be touched." So her marriage is a disaster?

"He's my soulmate," she says. "I just feel no sexual desire for him, or anyone else." She is is not alone. Recent surveys show that around 43% of women have a "sexual dysfunction". This doesn't mean we're all fantasising about dogs, dressing as nuns or doing odd things with the Hoover nozzle.

It means that nearly half of us are complaining of nightly headaches, or faking orgasms, or finding sex painful, or simply lying there, one eye on the clock, feeling nothing much at all. So why is it happening to so many women? The answer isn't straightforward.

The medical term is "female sexual dysfunction", a complex area roughly divided into four basic conditions: low sex drive or an aversion to sex; an inability to get aroused; an inability to orgasm; and pain during sex.

None of these sounds too unusual: you're unlikely to feel like love's young dream, say, after giving birth or consuming 16 tequila slammers. But these normal sexual hiccups become dysfunctional when they're recurrent, persistent and cause personal distress.

There can be obvious physical causes: the menopause or a hysterectomy can disrupt the production of the hormones oestrogen and testosterone, both key components in desire. Other factors, like heart disease, diabetes, childbirth and breastfeeding can mess up your sexual functions too. But in many cases for youthful, otherwise healthy people like Marian, the cause isn't clear.

The bad news is that, unlike 12m men worldwide, Marian can't just pop a pill, sit back and feel the heat rise. Last week Dr Rosemary Basson, associate professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, presented the findings of her study into whether Viagra works for women.

The short answer is "no" (at least, not usually). Basson focused on premenopausal women - average age 37 - who were experiencing FSD. Viagra worked about as well as a placebo pill, but the drug might help certain sub-groups (namely some menopausal women).

"We're continuing our research," says Heather Van Ness, a rep for Pfizer, which makes Viagra. "We feel this [area] is significantly more complicated than erectile dysfunction."

It's perhaps odd that Viagra won't work widely on women. Arousal in both sexes works in a similar way: we all have smooth muscle tissue in our genitals that engorges with blood when we're aroused. Viagra works by stimulating this blood supply. Researchers hoped the drug might relax the tissue in the clitoris, allow it to swell, and bingo: goodbye dysfunction; hello boys.

It didn't. So if fixing the blood supply to our clitorises won't make us sexy, what will? Dr Michael Crowe, a consultant psychiatrist and head of the couple and sexual clinic at London's Maudsley hospital believes the pharmaceutical solution is too simplistic: "Women's sexuality is more complicated and multidimensional than men's. The physical and emotional are connected in a way that makes them inseparable."

But it seems we're often being treated according to a male pattern of stimulation - arousal - satisfaction. This is certainly what Dr Laura Berman and her sister Jennifer (a urologist) believe is wrong with FSD treatments today. Together they run the women's sexual health clinic in Boston, where all patients are initially given both a physical and a psychological consultation.

"Women experience sexuality differently from men," says Laura Berman. "For women, sexuality involves many components - both emotional and physical - which happen simultaneously."

Our tendency to lie back and think of England doesn't help . "All too often, whatever the root cause," says Laura Berman, "women don't let their partners know how to satisfy them sexually. We pretend to be aroused, or to reach orgasm and then find ourselves either having to live with a permanently unhappy sex life, or let the other person know."

By this time, sex has usually become fraught or non-existent and the relationship is under severe strain. The realization of the scale of female dissatisfaction has galvanised drug companies. They've also noticed that a generation of "baby boomers" is about to hit the menopause - several million solvent women who believe in (and will pay for) their right to sexual pleasure.

Since Pfizer made more than $1bn in the US and more than £8m in Britain in the first year alone, the potential gain is massive. Dr Riley says: "It's a new field, but everyone is racing to catch up."

There are many different drugs in development, but research can be roughly divided into two areas: hormone treatments (usually oestrogen, testosterone, or a combination of both, administered by injection, pill, patch or cream) and "vasodilators" (drugs like Viagra, that dilate blood vessels and increase blood flow to the genitals).

This month the US food and drug administration approved a device optimistically named "Eros" - a vacuum pump that increases the blood supply to the clitoris. The next wave of treatments, says Dr Martin Cole, the recently retired head of the sex education institute in Birmingham, is based around the brain chemicals of seratonin, dopamine and drenaline.

"Once we fully understand the role of the brain chemicals in arousal and response," says Cole, "we'll have some amazing treatments." But maybe medication is missing the point. "Sometimes, people just do stop fancying each other," Cole suggests. "The best sex therapy under those circumstances might be to point out that sex is just one part of a relationship jigsaw, and it doesn't have to be the most important part." After all, if nearly half of us don't like sex, then FSD is almost normal, isn't it? A bit like cellulite or PMT?

"Absolutely not," says Laura Berman. "Addressing female sexual dysfunction is the final frontier of the women's movement." We need to "take responsibility for our sexual satisfaction" and "feel that we're entitled to it".

We can start by explaining to our partners exactly what, how, where, when we want it. This won't solve all problems - those rooted in a physical condition will need medication too - but taking control of your sex life has to be a good start.

fields.headline: Warning: your pants can kill
fields.standfirst: Each year a government report chronicles the bizarre accidents that take place in our homes.  Brian Logan  offers a guide to the heart-stopping dangers of trousers, sticky tape and flowerpots
fields.trailText: Each year a government report chronicles the bizarre accidents that take place in our homes. Brian Logan offers a guide to the heart-stopping dangers of trousers, sticky tape and flowerpots
fields.body:
Have you ever wondered how many people are injured climbing ladders," asks the department of trade and industry, "or attend casualty as a result of burning themselves on the barbecue?" If, like me, you answer "No, not really", you should be ashamed of yourself.

For home is where heart-stopping hazards lurk behind every door and at the bottom of the wardrobe - or so the department's "home accident surveillance system" (HASS) would have us believe. You will know what the HASS report is, even if you think you don't. It's the one cited at the tail end of those silly-season news items about the statistical dangers of DIY (7,402 Britons injured by hammer blows in 1998) and of letting little Johnny paddle in the chip pan.

The report makes sombre reading unless you've got a sense of humour, in which case it's a right wheeze. It is published annually - the latest emerged this spring - as a clarion call to we, the vulnerable public, to take seriously the presence of peril in our own homes. "You're regulated at work," says Jane Eason at the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA), "and you pay attention when driving. But when you get home you relax and let your guard down."

A fatal mistake, and one which the government is anxious to rectify - not least because accidents in the home cost the nation £25,000m per year, or three millennium domes. Dr Kim Howells, minister for consumer and corporate affairs, whose department seeks the eradication of the slippery floor and the swallowed sellotape, says: "We are investing a great deal of time and energy in reducing accidents in the future." It gives a whole new dimension to the term "nanny state".

Is it, after all, the government's role to cater for the 6,152 people hospitalised in 1998 having been daft enough to collide, injuriously, with their dog? Then there's the 5,937 burned by cups of tea, and the 5,781 victims of "unspecified hot water" - which does, admittedly, sound pretty scary. The HASS report and its attendant flurry of press releases are full of bathetic warnings of kitchen-table catastrophe. "Tin cans pose a risk to the unwary," we read - so take note, for "there are nearly 6,000 accidents a year. The DTI is working closely with industry to tackle this."

The report is no less fascinating for what it doesn't say. "Apart from 1993, when considerably fewer people choked on fish bones, choking accidents have been on the rise," it tells us, but offers no clue as to what made 1993 such a well-filleted year. And while the data asserts that, while 130,675 were hospitalised after falling over their carpets, only 67,574 keeled over on concrete, it's left to us to adduce that the sensible precaution would be to swap our shagpiles for cement.

Admitting that some of HASS's extrapolations - from data gathered from 18 A&E units in England and Wales - seem bizarre, Eason says that "you do read that report and think: my God, how on Earth do you get injured by that?" With her help, however, the Guardian is pleased to offer up - in the very sober spirit of accident prevention - a thumbnail guide to those least suspected of domestic threats.

Trousers: That favourite pair of comfy cords could be your nemesis: trousers account for thousands of tumbles per year. "You might be getting on a bit," says Eason sympathetically, "you catch your foot in your trouser leg" - and let's draw a veil over what, painfully, happens next.

Slippers: Don't panic, but slipper-related incidents account for some 27,000 visits to A&E per year. "You lose the tread on the sole," Eason explains, "but don't replace the slippers as readily as you would a normal pair of shoes." Apply such treacherous footwear to a well-buffed linoleum and "the old Carry On scenario", as Eason calls it, must unavoidably ensue.

DIY: "It's getting more and more popular, now that so many people watch programmes such as Changing Rooms." Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen is responsible, in other words, for the quarter of a million DIY casualties per year - which is as good a reason as any to unscrew that wobbly shelf and, if you see him, apply it sharply to his jaw. Eason's advice: "People have to be able to admit when they can't do something. They should call in the experts and" - in hapless recognition of the extent of their talents - "make them a cup of tea."

Flowerpots (left lying about): Bill and Ben will never seem the same again.

Underpants: Never underestimate how perilous pants can be. "You get changed, you get into bed, you may leave your underpants on the floor," says Eason, and I can almost see the vultures gathering above the scene. "You've got a polished floor, you get up in the morning, and . . . " - crash! The worst kind of brief encounter.

Eason calls home accidents "the hidden epidemic" and it's easy to see why. After a conversation with her, you feel like wearing protective clothing on the trip from the living room to the loo. In fact, Eason says, it's about being vigilant: "We're asking people, once they get in, to have a quick look around and check that things are fairly tidy." For, as HASS reports: "The majority [of accidents] appear to be caused by people's actions rather than faulty products."

It's the kids we should really fear for, says RoSPA. Mums and dads are encouraged "to get down on the floor and look around the room from the child's perspective at how many objects might be dangerous if children got their hands on them". "You'd be amazed," says Eason.

But she knows that trying to prevent accidents, at an institutional level, is like trying to prevent the wind: 22 years of HASS reports haven't dented the domestic accident figures (1993 and fishbones notwithstanding). We'll never be persuaded to be on-guard in our own homes, and it would be a worse world if we were. Rakes will continue to languish on the lawn, prongs up. Blu-tac will ever adhere to walls well within reach of little clamorous hands. "But if," says Eason, "by convincing even two or three people to take that extra precaution, we can save them from accidents, then the job's been worth doing."

As Kim Howells intones, in the introduction to the report, "no matter how valuable the data, we must never forget that it relates to real people who have suffered personal distress or discomfort". The problem is, we do forget that, all too readily. The curse of this research is that it relates to situations forever undermined by comedy sketches - all those saucepans stuck on heads in doctors' waiting rooms - and You've Been Framed. The familiarity of the dangers make us doubt or deny them. We deflect responsibility with ridicule. 24,000 injured by doors? 43,000 falls from ladders? The scourge of the threadbare sock? It's the price we pay for the jealously-guarded right to be complacent in our own homes.
