Flowerpots (left lying about): Bill and Ben will never seem the same again. Underpants: Never underestimate how perilous pants can be. "You get changed, you get into bed, you may leave your underpants on the floor," says Eason, and I can almost see the vultures gathering above the scene. "You've got a polished floor, you get up in the morning, and . . . " - crash! The worst kind of brief encounter. Eason calls home accidents "the hidden epidemic" and it's easy to see why. After a conversation with her, you feel like wearing protective clothing on the trip from the living room to the loo. In fact, Eason says, it's about being vigilant: "We're asking people, once they get in, to have a quick look around and check that things are fairly tidy." For, as HASS reports: "The majority [of accidents] appear to be caused by people's actions rather than faulty products." It's the kids we should really fear for, says RoSPA. Mums and dads are encouraged "to get down on the floor and look around the room from the child's perspective at how many objects might be dangerous if children got their hands on them". "You'd be amazed," says Eason. But she knows that trying to prevent accidents, at an institutional level, is like trying to prevent the wind: 22 years of HASS reports haven't dented the domestic accident figures (1993 and fishbones notwithstanding). We'll never be persuaded to be on-guard in our own homes, and it would be a worse world if we were. Rakes will continue to languish on the lawn, prongs up. Blu-tac will ever adhere to walls well within reach of little clamorous hands. "But if," says Eason, "by convincing even two or three people to take that extra precaution, we can save them from accidents, then the job's been worth doing." As Kim Howells intones, in the introduction to the report, "no matter how valuable the data, we must never forget that it relates to real people who have suffered personal distress or discomfort". The problem is, we do forget that, all too readily. The curse of this research is that it relates to situations forever undermined by comedy sketches - all those saucepans stuck on heads in doctors' waiting rooms - and You've Been Framed. The familiarity of the dangers make us doubt or deny them. We deflect responsibility with ridicule. 24,000 injured by doors? 43,000 falls from ladders? The scourge of the threadbare sock? It's the price we pay for the jealously-guarded right to be complacent in our own homes.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: A few years ago I had a nasty cyst removed from my chest - just above where my cleavage would start, if I had one.
fields.body:
Scar tissue

Q A few years ago I had a nasty cyst removed from my chest - just above where my cleavage would start, if I had one. The small operation to cut out the cyst went well but I was left with a horrible heaped up scar which my GP said is called keloid. I've been told that any treatment to remove it may result in worse scarring. Is there really nothing to be done?

A Keloid is an inherited tendency to overhealing of cuts. When wounds heal you produce too much fibrous tissue, causing raised scars that can itch or be uncomfortable. Treatments include injecting steroid into the scar, laser, pressure, or freezing with liquid nitrogen. None is guaranteed to work and nearly half of the scars will recur.

There are great hopes for a newer treatment using sheets of silicone gel (Cics-Care), which is like sticky-back plastic as featured on Blue Peter in the late 60s and can be bought over the counter. It probably works by sealing moisture into the scar, which makes it flatter and softer. Cut the self-adhesive sheet to fit the scar. Stick it on and leave for four hours a day, building up to 24 hours as soon as you can. Each piece can be left on for up to a month, though it should be cleaned twice a day. Continue treatment for two to four months.

For further advice contact the Scar Information Service (0845 120 0022).

Eczema distress

Q I've developed the most irritating dermatitis on my hands. They're so dry, red and itchy that I'm constantly clawing away at them and they have developed weeping blisters on their backs that my GP said was infection from all the scratching. That calmed down with antibiotics but my hands are still so painful sometimes that I can hardly hold a cup. I use a strong steroid cream (Betnovate) but it doesn't seem to help any more. Any ideas?

A Dermatitis (or eczema - two different words for the same thing) is dry, irritated, itchy skin. When confined to the hands, it's almost always because you're in contact with something that your skin is sensitive to.

Common culprits are water, chemicals and rubber. I had one patient who developed awful skin rashes on his hands when he switched jobs to work as a technician in a hospital medical unit. Allergy testing (injecting tiny amounts of substances just under his skin, then noting the reaction) showed he was allergic to a cleansing solution used for the medical instruments. Wearing rubber gloves didn't help - he was allergic to rubber too. PVC gloves helped a bit, but ultimately he moved to a different
department and his hands healed. Try avoiding water and corrosive chemicals, and wear PVC not rubber gloves. But if it persists, why not ask to be referred for allergy testing?

Does he need more iron?

Q My toddler's a poor eater and never eats meat. Does he need iron supplements?

A If your son has lots of energy, seems well and looks around the same size as other kids his age, he's probably getting enough iron. Only a blood test will confirm whether or not he lacks iron and it may be worth requesting if you're concerned about his growth or development.

Your health visitor can give specific advice about iron-rich foods - red meat's got lots but broccoli and dried apricots have some too and may be more acceptable to him. Avoid tea with meals as it binds to iron and prevents its absorption. Giving iron supplements to non-deficient children is potentially harmful and can slow their growth. Drops containing vitamins A, C and D for children aged one to five are a good idea while he's faddy with food. Vitamin C will help him absorb more iron from Hula Hoops and Ribena while you keep plugging the meat and two veg.

Will I get my hair back?

Q I had a bad nervous breakdown last year from which I've made a slow but steady recovery. Though I'm only 37, my hair went from thick dark brown with a few grey hairs, to sparse white hair like an old man. Will it ever return to its former colour and texture?

A It's great to hear that you've made such a good recovery. Any severe stress, physical or mental, can make your hair fall out. Coloured hairs, like your brown ones, are shed first whereas the white hairs are sturdier and less likely to fall out. So, seemingly overnight, your hair goes from looking predominantly brown, to white. The good news is that hair often grows again and with any luck it will be brown not white.

fields.headline: The diabetes timebomb
fields.standfirst: Can it really be true that 1m people in this country are suffering from a potentially life-threatening condition without knowing it?  Oliver Burkeman investigates
fields.trailText: Can it really be true that 1m people in this country are suffering from a potentially life-threatening condition without knowing it?
fields.body:
The average British person's near-total ignorance of their state of health is, of course, a cherished component of the national psyche - as essential as a fixation with climatic conditions, or never getting to the finals at Wimbledon. Every so often, though, comes statistical confirmation of the true depths of our ignorance - and the results still have the power to shock.

So it was with yesterday's report from the British Diabetic Association, revealing that an estimated 1m Britons suffer from diabetes without knowing it. As any of the 1.4m diabetics who do know of their condition will testify, this is not the sort of condition it's advisable to ignore: blindness, strokes, kidney damage and heart disease can result if it is not kept under control, and amputations can be required.

But that is not the limit of our ignorance: it also extends, the BDA says, to those at high risk of developing the disorder, three quarters of whom were not aware of the dangers, according to the survey of 2,135 people.

Almost all of the "missing million" will be suffering from type II diabetes, in which the body's natural mechanisms for regulating levels of sugar in the blood - normally controlled by insulin produced in the pancreas - become overwhelmed, usually because of obesity. Strict dietary controls and increased exercise are often enough to control the problem, and most sufferers can avoid the numerous daily insulin injections which are a depressing fact of life for type I diabetics.

But the popular perception that type II is less serious than type I - which usually develops in childhood when the body's immune system launches an assault against its own insulin-producing cells - is false. Left unattended, type II diabetes can be just as problematic. Although less common than among type-I diabetics, insufficient levels of glucose in the blood can prompt hypoglycaemic episodes, or "hypos", characterised by dizziness, confusion or aggression. Without prompt treatment, coma can ensue.

"This is an alarming state of affairs: these findings underline the myth many people believe - that dia betes can be a mild condition," said Paul Streets, chief executive of the BDA, which is to rebrand itself as Diabetes UK early next month. "It is not. Diabetes is one of the most serious health issues facing the UK today, and if society keeps on ignoring its importance we will be facing a potential health timebomb."

It is an overused term, but if any contemporary medical problem deserves the timebomb label, it is diabetes. Cases are expected to skyrocket, by 2010, to 3m in Britain and 220m worldwide. Already, the BDA estimates, the NHS spends £4.9bn on treatment annually; at any one time, diabetics occupy between 6% and 16% of Britain's hospital beds.

High-sugar, high-fat, low-fibre western diets must probably shoulder much of the blame for the proliferation of type II cases; some nutritionists blame the carbohydrates with which processed foods are stuffed, and which the pancreas strains to metabolise. But perhaps even more worryingly, the incidence of type I diabetes is increasing too, and the age at which children are affected is falling. And here - apart from some much-contested reports linking the disorder to the MMR vaccine - the causes are far more mysterious.

Indeed, the medical establishment's attitude towards the disorder can sometimes seem to rival levels of ignorance in the population as a whole. In April this year, an Audit Commission report exposed astonishing variations in the quality of care around the UK, with some doctors failing to undertake the basic checks that can prevent eye and liver-related complications. A third of hospital wards lacked adequate guidelines for managing the problem, the commission found.

At the forefront of medical science, breakthroughs are announced almost monthly, but diabetics are well used to riding the rollercoaster of hope and disappointment which has characterised the field ever since the first injections of insulin into humans, in 1924.

A couple of years ago, the headlines were full of Rezulin, a tradename for troglitazone, which helps reawaken type II diabetics' sensitivity to insulin - but it was withdrawn in the UK amid fears over side-effects. (A rival drug, Avandia, is now available.) Insulin nose sprays, insulin tablets, pumps which drip insulin gradually into the bloodstream, and insulin inhalers have all enjoyed brief moments of celebrity, but regulating dosage has proved difficult.

Two weeks ago came potentially the most promising news yet, when James Shapiro, a British surgeon from the University of Alberta in Canada, announced that he had managed to transfer the cells which generate insulin in non-diabetics into the bodies of severe type I sufferers who had previously been "crashing their cars, falling off horses or burning themselves while cooking". All, according to Shapiro, were now able to live normally, so long as they took immunosuppressant drugs to prevent their bodies rejecting the cells.

But it will take more than headlines to convince those who live with the problem that a solution really is around the corner.

"My daughter has had diabetes since she was five. That was 25 years ago, and I've listened to this for 25 years, which does make one a bit cynical," says Jenny Hirst, co-chair of the Insulin Dependent Diabetes Trust, formed in 1994 in protest at the BDA's controversial decision to withhold a report on the alleged dangers of synthetic insulin, used by some diabetics as an alternative to traditional insulin derived from animals.

"Take this latest announcement. The test subjects all had extremely severe diabetes, untreatable with insulin. But if you're an average sufferer, the choice is: do you want to go on immunosuppressants for the rest of your life, or do you want to carry on taking insulin? That's not much of a choice, and I think many will prefer to continue with the regime they know."

Basic screening procedures, rather than futuristic contraptions and cutting-edge innovation, may prove more effective weapons in the short term. Campaigners propose a national programme of urine tests for over-40s visiting their GPs - a low-cost exercise similar to blood-pressure monitoring programmes that would help identify those at risk at an early stage. That, and far more strenuous health education efforts. The existence of hundreds of thousands of unwitting sufferers, says Hirst, "has been known for years. It's just extremely sad that we don't seem to have made any progress."

Untreated diabetes: what to look for

The symptoms

Early symptoms of untreated diabetes include:

 increased thirst

 frequent need to go to the toilet

 extreme tiredness

 weight loss

 blurred vision

 genital itching

 tingling or numbness in hands or

feet

 cuts and bruises that are slow to

heal

 erection impairment in men and

unusual vaginal dryness in

women.

The risk groups

Those most at risk of type II diabetes belong to two or more of the following groups:

 the over-40s

 the overweight

 those with a family history of the

condition

 Asian and AfroCaribbean people.

Further information

The British Diabetic Association (Diabetes UK): 020-7323 1531
diabetes.org.uk

Insulin Dependent Diabetes Trust
iddtinternational.org

So, seemingly overnight, your hair goes from looking predominantly brown, to white. The good news is that hair often grows again and with any luck it will be brown not white.

webTitle: Atlantis back home after 'super' Space Station mission

fields.headline: Atlantis back home after 'super' Space Station mission
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
International Space Station homepage
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Atlantis and its crew swooped through the pre-dawn darkness Monday and ended a triumphant repair mission to the International Space Station.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Atlantis and its crew swooped through the pre-dawn darkness Monday and ended a triumphant repair mission to the International Space Station.

Within moments of touchdown, the seven astronauts were basking in praise.

"Just a super mission," congratulated Mission Control.

Infrared cameras tracked Atlantis on the final approach; the shuttle resembled a ghost ship in the grainy, black and white pictures. The view switched to inside the cockpit just before the 2:20am (06.20 GMT) landing, and the floodlighted runway and centre line were easily distinguishable from the pilots' seats.

It was only the 14th time in 98 flights that a space shuttle landed in darkness. The crosswind ended up being well within safety limits, despite Nasa's earlier concerns.

The astronauts' handiwork, the rejuvenated space station, had passed over the Kennedy Space Center just 10 minutes earlier, and was crossing the North Atlantic when Atlantis touched down.

All four newly installed batteries were working fine and providing full electrical power to the space station.

"I know it's bad hours for the arrival, but we are certainly glad to be back home," commander James Halsell Jr said.

Halsell and his crew immediately inspected scratches and dents in the thermal tiles covering the bottom of each shuttle wing. The scrapes happened during lift-off May 19 and were noticed when Nasa reviewed video of the launch. Engineers suspect the wings were hit by chunks of ice that fell off the external fuel tank. The ice sometimes forms because of the supercold liquid fuel inside.

Halsell said the damage turned out to be "nothing extraordinary," even though Nasa had him take special precautions in preparing for landing.

Besides replacing bad batteries, the six Americans and one Russian furnished the 1 1/2-year-old space station with a new antenna, construction crane, fire extinguishers, smoke detectors and fans. They also boosted the complex into an orbit more than 230 miles high, 30 miles higher than before.

Halsell said it was sometimes stressful trying to squeeze everything into the six days that the spacecraft were docked. But he noted with visible pride that the outcome was "a resounding success and something of a resurgence for the international space station program."

Now that it's back in top form, the space station will fly solo until July. That's when Russia's long delayed service module is supposed to arrive. Once that happens, space station compartments will start soaring and astronauts and cosmonauts will begin moving in.

After more than two years of delay, the service module finally appears to be ready, said Nasa Administrator Daniel Goldin. The space agency wants Russian space officials to launch a few more Proton rockets, however, before committing to the all-important service module flight.

A pair of Proton launch accidents last year put the service module flight on hold. The module, a propulsion tug as well as crew quarters, was already running late because of Russia's money crunch.

"Until it goes up, we won't know," Goldin said. As a precaution, Nasa is working on substitute modules to keep the space station program on track.

Goldin said the crew's extensive training paid off on this 10-day mission. But he noted: "There's a bit of luck, too."

Nasa hopes to have Atlantis ready for another space station visit, with another US-Russian crew, in September.

webTitle: Ms Su shows the party way to say 'I miss you'

fields.headline: Ms Su shows the party way to say 'I miss you'
fields.trailText: Advice on how to bring the romance back into marriage is not normally dispensed by the Communist party of China. Traditonally it has been more concerned to offer instruction in socialist morality.
fields.body:
Advice on how to bring the romance back into marriage is not normally dispensed by the Communist party of China. Traditonally it has been more concerned to offer instruction in socialist morality.

But a party website opened in Shanghai yesterday pays more attention to life style than political style, representing a new effort to attract the attention of the city's sophisticated and upwardly mobile younger generation.

One click in a section called "women's chat" reveals the Thoughts of Ms Su on "how to treat your husband like a sweetheart". Having a baby is a great joy, she writes, but they should be aware of the risk of turning into "sexless slaves".

Remember, she says, that "you are not just your child's mother but your husband's lover as well". It is essential to kindle some "romantic sparks" from time to time.

Ms Su illustrates her theme with an appropriate anecdote. Her husband often has to go to another town for work. Once she phoned ahead to the hotel where he was staying, asking them to put a drink and flowers from her in his room. By return came an invitation from her husband to join her for the next weekend. She quickly overcame a pang of remorse at leaving her child behind: it was more important to be a "good wife".

The approach to nannu guanxi (relations between the sexes) carries a whiff of gender inequality: the husband always seems to go out to work while his wife stays at home. But in a party which not so long ago frowned on sexual enjoyment, the homely hints are a great leap bedwards.

webTitle: Power duo join utility web launch

fields.headline: Power duo join utility web launch
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: National Grid and ScottishPower have joined a group of 12 leading European utilities to form an e-business industry procurement exchange.
fields.body:
National Grid and ScottishPower have joined a group of 12 leading European utilities to form an e-business industry procurement exchange.

An independent company will be created to own and operate the exchange. Initially around 80% of the equity will be owned by the founding partners, who also include Northern Electric, United Utilities, Edf of France and RWE in Germany.

Ken Vowles, executive director of ScottishPower's UK power operation said last night: "These leading European utilities have come together to improve performance, productivity and capital efficiency."

He described it as "an exciting example of the application of the internet to promote efficiency in an industry and throughout the supply chain."

The founding partners are estimated to spend upwards of £20bn collectively each year on procurement. The exchange will provide an elec tronic marketplace open to buyers and sellers in the utilities industry. The intital focus will be on the European electricity and water industries.

The founding partners will work together to make the exchange attractive for all companies by establishing a collaborative platform for all industry participants.

In the first phase, the focus will be on catalogue purchasing, auctioning of goods and also procurement management information. Any supplier can participate. The approach is aimed at benefiting suppliers, giving them greater market reach and reducing transaction costs.

Members of the new procurement exchange claim that "a robust, scalable, open and independent technology platform will be chosen after a thorough evaluation of alternative providers."

The consortium plans to begin internet-based trading by late summer. The partners will use the exchange for a substantial proportion of their procurement.

fields.headline: No 1639: David Scott
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: For the second time in his life, ex-astronaut David Scott is over the moon - well, his bride-to-be is Anna Ford
fields.body:
Age: 67.

Official title: Colonel.

Former employer: Nasa.

Appearance: Stocky, with a strangely bulbous head. Oh, hang on - that's a spacesuit.

Claim to fame: Until yesterday, Col Scott's most bankable dinner-party anecdotes were his 1971 moonwalk as commander of Apollo 15, and his 1966 mission alongside Neil Armstrong to carry out the first link-up between two spacecraft.

It doesn't get much better than that. Few things, it's true, can rival a leisurely afternoon stroll along the final frontier. But he's discovered one.

He's discovered the secret of life itself? Or invented time travel? Even better than that. Col Scott has sabotaged the pathetic fantasies of a million pub bores by winning the heart of that paragon of newsreaderly poise, Anna Ford.

One small step for man, one giant poke in the eye for lots of other middle-aged men? Precisely. The two announced yesterday that they plan to marry.

Quite a catch. Let's not forget that Ford was labelled the most beautiful woman in the world by no other touchstone of aesthetic wisdom than Mr Peter Jay himself. Auberon Waugh reportedly said the sight of her made him kiss the screen of his television, but don't linger on that image.

I mean, marrying an astronaut is quite a catch. That too: this certainly looks like a match made in heaven. Or on the far side of the stratosphere, at any rate.

And they're over the moon, I suppose. "David and I are together and very happy and we want to spend our future together," Ford says.

Still, it's an unlikely pairing. TVam's most talented wine-thrower first met her rocket man when he was ITN's space adviser and she a newsreader there. They hooked up again last year and things just, um, blasted off.

Do say: "Beam me up, Scotty"

Not to be confused with: Scott of the Antarctic; Scott off Neighbours; Buzz Aldrin.

webTitle: Shuttle ends successful repair visit to Space Station

fields.headline: Shuttle ends successful repair visit to Space Station
fields.standfirst:
Nasa Human Spaceflight
International Space Station homepage
Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: The Atlantis astronauts glided to a smooth predawn landing Monday, leaving the refurbished International Space Station behind in orbit and setting the stage for a flurry of upcoming assembly missions.
fields.body:
The Atlantis astronauts glided to a smooth predawn landing Monday, leaving the refurbished International Space Station behind in orbit and setting the stage for a flurry of upcoming assembly missions.

With Commander James Halsell Jr. and pilot Scott Horowitz at the controls, Atlantis dropped out of a pitch-black sky and floated to a tire-smoking touchdown at 2:20am.

It was the 14th night landing by a shuttle and the ninth at Kennedy Space Center. But Halsell had no problems handling a 10-knot crosswind, bringing Atlantis to a stop on the centreline of the brightly lit runway.

"Jim, congratulations to you and the crew on just a super mission to the international space station," astronaut Rick Sturckow radioed from mission control after Atlantis rolled to a halt.

"Smiles around the cabin here; appreciate your help," Halsell replied.

During six days docked to the international space station, the Atlantis astronauts replaced four of six batteries in the Russian Zarya module, installed new fans and smoke detectors, delivered fresh water for future use and replaced a faulty radio antenna.

They also installed a Russian cargo boom on the station's hull, replaced a Russian telemetry transmitter and made a variety of other repairs and upgrades.

The work, in effect, extended the Russian-built, Nasa-financed module's expired warranty through the end of the year, giving program managers confidence the station can continue operating safely even if a key Russian command module scheduled for launch in July is delayed again.

The Zvezda module, which will provide the station's propulsion and initial crew quarters, is running two years behind schedule because of Russian funding problems and trouble with the Proton rocket needed to launch it.

But the module is virtually complete; the Proton has been cleared for flight, and space station planners are hopeful Zvezda will finally get into orbit in July.

Once Zvezda is attached to the two modules already in space - Zarya and a multi-hatch US module called Unity - Nasa will be clear to launch a steady stream of shuttles carrying supplies, equipment and new modules.

If all goes well, stabilising gyroscopes will be delivered in late September or early October, huge solar arrays will be installed in November and the US laboratory module, Destiny, will arrive in January to serve as the scientific heart of the orbiting complex.

A Russian Soyuz rocket is scheduled for launch in late October to ferry the station's first full-time crew into orbit. From that point forward, the station will be permanently staffed with rotating crews of astronauts and cosmonauts.

"Once we get into the fall, it's off to the races," said shuttle program manager Ronald Dittemore.

But it will not be easy. James Van Laak, manager of space station integration and operations, said the station project represents "one of the greatest engineering challenges humankind has ever undertaken."

fields.headline: Prescott hammers 'the privileged few'
fields.trailText: John Prescott today launched Labour's pre-election onslaught on its own  heartlands, unveiling a £28bn package of spending plans themed with the words  Opportunity For All.
fields.body:
John Prescott today launched Labour's pre-election onslaught on its own heartlands, unveiling a £28bn package of spending plans themed with the words Opportunity For All.

The slogan is likely to be repeated endlessly in the coming months, as the government moves to shore up support in traditional Labour strongholds, and in the more precariously held areas captured from the Conservatives in 1997.

The deputy prime minister's speech ranged far beyond his sprawling responsibilities as minister in charge of the environment, transport and the regions.

Outlining Chancellor Gordon Brown's forthcoming comprehensive spending review, Mr Prescott said the government's mission was to deliver opportunity and security in a changing world.

"That is what we're all about, about giving to the majority of people the life chances taken for granted by the privileged few," he said.

Mr Prescott, who clearly relishes standing in for Tony Blair while the prime minister is on temporary child-minding duties, launched a withering attack on Tory promises of increased pensions.

He also made a spirited grab for headlines by reopening the controversy over Oxbridge elitism.

Labour ministers believe they are on to a winner over the case of Newcastle school leaver Laura Spence, eagerly accepted by Harvard University after being turned down by Oxford.

Now the government is working on a modest package of incentives for Oxbridge colleges to increase their intake of state school pupils.

"Nobody should be surprised if the spending review widens opportunity in our universities, or provides the resources for schools to combat underachievement, wherever it may exist, in the heartlands or middle England," said Mr Prescott.

GOOD FORM

fields.body:
GOOD FORM
Rahul Dravid Kent

As the weather begins to warms up, so too does Dravid's bat. After three mediocre knocks at the end of April, a big score against the Zimbabweans saw him click into gear, and he followed that up with over 100 runs in the Championship at The Oval a week later. With three not-outs to his name, his average in all competitions is fractionally short of 100 - not quite challenging Michael Bevan at the top of the overseas players league, but a sound investment by Kent nonetheless.

fields.headline: Pork
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the battle to sell British pork on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the battle to sell British pork on the net
fields.body:
1. In the bid to save their bacon, Britain's pig industry goes on the offensive today with the launch of the second phase of a controversial advertising campaign.

2. The new poster in the £4.6m operation shows a sow suckling her young under the slogan: "After she's fed them, she could be fed to them." It follows the first advert, depicting a pig inches away from the edge of the page beneath a caption explaining that these few inches are "the longest walk some pigs can ever look forward to".

3. The ads are referring to foreigners' pig-rearing habits - and Denmark and Holland aren't happy. "Deeply misconceived" is the verdict of the Danish pig industry.

4. Agriculture minister Nick Brown is unrepentant, calling the Meat and Livestock Commission and Ministry of Agriculture campaign "tough, focused and absolutely right".

5. It highlights the fact that British pigs aren't fed meat, enjoy spacious accommodation and are independently audited (although it omits to mention that some farmers stuff their pigs with antibiotics).

6. Britain's beleaguered pig farmers need all the help they can get. Every pig reared in Britain is losing them between £5 and £10. Prices collapsed in 1996 and have not recovered since (although they have almost reached break-even point in recent months). One in three British pig farms has gone out of business since 1994.

7. It is partly because Britain's pig industry is governed by stringent regulations, enabling mass-produced foreign meat to be imported and sold for less by profit-seeking supermarkets.

8. Pigs may be relatively well treated in British sties, but they still get a raw deal from all of us. Language and literature has always done pigs down.

9. Do you sweat like a pig? Did you pig out last night? Are you as fat as a pig? You might be, but pigs are naturally lean (we overfeed them) and are unable to sweat. The reason they are mucky is because they roll around to cool down; their personal hygiene is immaculate as they refuse to excrete where they eat.

10. And there are many more examples of pigs getting a bad press: Wilbur, in Charlotte's Web, was a simpleton; Major, Snowball, Napoleon and Squealer may have been clever, but soon turned Commie in Animal Farm; and the one occasion when an unashamedly heroic pig, Babe, took centre stage, the little runt spoke in a squeaky American accent.

fields.headline: Keep section 28 says Scots poll
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Scots have come out heavily in favour of keeping Section 28, the law barring the promotion of homosexuality in schools, according to the results today of a privately-funded postal referendum.
fields.body:
Scots have come out heavily in favour of keeping Section 28, the law barring the promotion of homosexuality in schools, according to the results today of a privately-funded postal referendum.

The referendum figures, announced in Edinburgh, said 1,094,440 people voted in favour of keeping the clause - which the Scottish executive intends to repeal - compared to 166,406 voting to scrap it.

Of 3,970,712 papers posted out, a total of 1,260,846 valid votes were cast - 86.8% in favour of keeping Section 28, and 13.2% in favour of repeal, said John Cowdall, "returning officer" for the poll bankrolled by Stagecoach tycoon Brian Souter, who has campaigned vigorously in favour of retaining the clause.

The total number of ballot papers returned to Mr Cowdall was 1,272,202 - representing a poll of 32.04% on the electoral register.

Stagecoach tycoon Mr Souter and Jack Irvine, director of the Keep the Clause campaign, said they welcomed the result as the "clear and unequivocal verdict of the Scottish people", but the low turnout was hailed by the pro-repeal camp, which said it showed the majority of people in Scotland favoured reform.

Rozanne Foyer, assistant secretary of the Scottish Trades Union Congress, said: "We have been utterly opposed to this ballot from the very beginning, as it has been nothing more than a cynical attempt to undermine our democratic processes and its execution has been insecure, unfair and ill thought-out.

"However, we have been very encouraged that despite the fact Keep the Clause spent huge sums of money on inciting homophobia, spreading misinformation and stirring up false concerns and fears among Scotland's parents, the vast majority of people who were balloted have rejected the Keep the Clause message, by either not participating in this flawed exercise or by voting for repeal."

Ms Foyer claimed Mr Souter's campaign had been "killed off" by the low turnout. "We now look forward to focusing on the real debate around Section 28 and the many other extremely important parts of this bill, which will take place in the Scottish parliament in the coming weeks."

webTitle: 30 May: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: 30 May: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText:
In brief and the latest casting news

Garbo bust gets the boot, M:I 2 confirms box-office success, Clooney's latest is panned by web reviewer, and on the casting couch Heather Graham and Juliette Binoche
fields.body:
 Stockholm's arts authority have ordered that a bust of Greta Garbo be removed from a city park, claiming that the bronze likeness was not good enough for public display. The allegedly shoddy bust by German artist Julia Erbe was scrutinised by experts who refused to grant approval for it to be erected as a work of art. The residents' association that set up the bust on Sodermalm Island, where the actress was born in 1905, has said it will fight the order in court. In the meantime, the bust will be mothballed out of sight - a fitting fate for an actress who famously longed to be alone.

 Mission: Impossible 2 has defied its reviewers and gone straight in at number one at the US box office when it opened over the Memorial Day weekend (see Friday's report). Official figures show the film, released on a record 3,653 screens, has reaped an estimated $88m. Disney's Dinosaur was pushed into second place with $18m, while Jackie Chan's comic Wild West foray, Shanghai Noon, rustled up an estimated $16m. The opening figures for Tom Cruise's latest hit eclipse that of the first Mission: Impossible, which pulled in $74m in its inaugural weekend.

 A cheeky film fan who sneaked into a private screening of the forthcoming George Clooney pic, The Perfect Storm, has suggested that the Hollywood heart-throb should have remained in his scrubs in ER. The review, which appeared on the Coming Attractions website, remarked that the film makes you "wait 2 hours and 10 minutes for something interesting to happen, but fails to deliver anything."

 New Line Cinema have announced it will provide a home for Darryl Quarle's horror script Stray Dawgz which already has a commitment from Ice Cube to star and Gregory Dark to direct. The story centres on a parolee who discovers that he is the ancestor of a line of werewolf hunters and is forced to save his sister from a new breed of werewolf that is threatening to take over San Francisco. Tsk - it never rains, but it pours, eh?

Casting couch

 Palme d'Or-winning Chinese film-maker Chen Kaige (of Farewell My Concubine fame) is teaming up with Hollywood star Heather Graham to make his English-language directing debut with the erotic thriller Killing Me Softly. Based on the novel by English husband and wife team Nicci Gerrard and Sean French (known collectively as Nicci French), the film tells the tale of a London research scientist who opts out of her comfortable, but ordinary relationship with a nice boyfriend and into a dangerously obsessive bond with a handsome and mysterious mountaineer.

 Juliette Binoche is in negotiations to star in The Assumption of a Virgin by Brazilian director Walter (Central Station) Salles. The actress who has also signed to play opposite Johnny Depp in Lasse Hallstrom's upcoming picture for Miramax, Chocolat, is due to start shooting the Salles pic this year, with Anthony Minghella producing. The French press has suggested that Al Pacino and Robert De Niro are two leads being considered to play opposite her.

fields.headline: Ipswich finally break free
fields.standfirst:
Minute-by-minute match report
Why play-offs are the new Cup finals
fields.trailText: It has taken five years, 401 points and enough tears to irrigate most of East Anglia but Ipswich are back in the Premiership at last.
fields.body:
It has taken five years, 401 points and enough tears to irrigate most of East Anglia but Ipswich are back in the Premiership at last. Even the most one-eyed Norwich City supporter might grudgingly accept that they deserve it.

After three years of play-off pain, this was fourth time lucky. And as Ipswich paraded the trophy, taking sporting applause from Barnsley's fans, the booming music was appropriate: "I get knocked down but I get up again." At Portman Road the hope is that, having finally got up, they will not be knocked straight back down.

As ever Ipswich made their fans suffer, falling behind and making the game safe only at the death. But they merited this victory after a dramatic 90 minutes that had everything: six goals, a penalty save by Richard Wright and a fantastic late stop by the same goalkeeper to prevent Barnsley making it 3-3. If Wright spends his summer anywhere other than at Euro 2000 it will be a travesty.

George Burley spent the aftermath in the bath with his suit on. But still the manager was wearing a grin wider than the Wembley pitch. He won the FA Cup here with Ipswich in 1978 but this, he insisted, surpassed it. "You can imagine the heartache after missing out so often," he said. "It means the world to me to take the club back."

They return playing the stylish football that made the team of Burley's era, under Bobby Robson, so successful. And they seem to have a backbone too, for this side four times came from behind to beat Bolton in the semi-final and recovered a deficit here as well.

But the jump from play-offs to Premiership is not easy, as the last three winners - Watford, Charlton and Crystal Palace - will testify. They lasted only one season in the top flight. Burley is confident Ipswich's fate will be different.

"Of course we will need help," he said. "Of course we will look to bring one or two in. Of course it will be difficult; it's a massive challenge. But we think we can survive. The vast majority of this squad can play in the Premiership."

The hug Burley gave his chairman David Sheepshanks as he picked up the trophy may have included a whispered request for financial assistance. The defence needs strengthening but there is talent to work with. Wright said afterwards that he wants to stay and in front of him there were some fine performances.

Jim Magilton and Matt Holland were neat in midfield, and Marcus Stewart was a handful up front. But the man of the match was Tony Mowbray, 37 in November but defiant in defence and scorer of his side's first goal. At the start of the season the player-coach said he would play only in an emergency. Some 38 appearances later it is fair to assume Ipswich must have suffered their biggest crisis since the boardroom ran out of claret.

Mowbray's header from Magilton's cross deservedly clawed his side back into the game after Barnsley had taken a sixth-minute lead, Craig Hignett's shot from 30 yards cannoning off the crossbar and going in off the diving Wright's arm.

If it seemed then that Ipswich's bad luck would continue, the feeling grew when David Johnson was forced off injured and Wright was adjudged to have upended Hignett in the area at the end of a first half Burley's team had increasingly controlled. Darren Barnard, though, saw his shot beaten out by the keeper. Ipswich rarely looked back.

"It would have been a great psychological advantage to go in 2-1 up," said Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett. "But you can't make Darren the scapegoat. Overall Ipswich deserved it."

Richard Naylor ran on to Stewart's flick and beat Kevin Miller to make it 2-1 and, when Stewart headed in Jamie Clapham's cross, the game seemed over. But Barnsley were given a second penalty when Mowbray tugged Georgi Hristov's shirt, Hignett tucked it away and only Wright's reflexes denied Hristov an equaliser before Naylor sent through Martin Reuser for No4. "I think he can be another Gordon Banks," Burley said of Wright. "I can see him going on." At long last Ipswich have done the same.

The defence needs strengthening but there is talent to work with. Wright said afterwards that he wants to stay and in front of him there were some fine performances. Jim Magilton and Matt Holland were neat in midfield, and Marcus Stewart was a handful up front. But the man of the match was Tony Mowbray, 37 in November but defiant in defence and scorer of his side's first goal. At the start of the season the player-coach said he would play only in an emergency. Some 38 appearances later it is fair to assume Ipswich must have suffered their biggest crisis since the boardroom ran out of claret. Mowbray's header from Magilton's cross deservedly clawed his side back into the game after Barnsley had taken a sixth-minute lead, Craig Hignett's shot from 30 yards cannoning off the crossbar and going in off the diving Wright's arm. If it seemed then that Ipswich's bad luck would continue, the feeling grew when David Johnson was forced off injured and Wright was adjudged to have upended Hignett in the area at the end of a first half Burley's team had increasingly controlled. Darren Barnard, though, saw his shot beaten out by the keeper. Ipswich rarely looked back. "It would have been a great psychological advantage to go in 2-1 up," said Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett. "But you can't make Darren the scapegoat. Overall Ipswich deserved it." Richard Naylor ran on to Stewart's flick and beat Kevin Miller to make it 2-1 and, when Stewart headed in Jamie Clapham's cross, the game seemed over. But Barnsley were given a second penalty when Mowbray tugged Georgi Hristov's shirt, Hignett tucked it away and only Wright's reflexes denied Hristov an equaliser before Naylor sent through Martin Reuser for No4. "I think he can be another Gordon Banks," Burley said of Wright. "I can see him going on." At long last Ipswich have done the same. Ipswich Town (3-5-2): R Wright; McGreal, Mowbray, Venus; Croft, J Wright (Wilnis, 90), Magilton, Holland, Clapham; Stewart (Reuser, 83), Johnson (Naylor, 22). Referee: T Heilbron (Newton Aycliffe).

webTitle: Indonesian leader caught in vice of violence

fields.headline: Indonesian leader caught in vice of violence
fields.standfirst:
Hidden forces stir Indonesian violence

Indonesia: special report
fields.trailText: The former Indonesian dictator Suharto was put under house arrest yesterday to speed up the investigation of his alleged corruption and placate mounting public anger with President Abdurrahman Wahid at the slow pace of the inquiry.
fields.body:
The former Indonesian dictator Suharto was put under house arrest yesterday to speed up the investigation of his alleged corruption and placate mounting public anger with President Abdurrahman Wahid at the slow pace of the inquiry.

His detention coincides with rising sectarian tension, which is thought to be part of a concerted campaign to discredit Mr Wahid and provide an excuse to oust him at a special session of parliament in August.

Mr Suharto's status has been changed from city arrest to house arrest for two weeks "to ensure a conducive environment for the corruption investigation and also taking into account his poor health", the attorney general's office said.

Prosecutors hope to put Mr Suharto, 78, on trial by the middle of August, charged with embezzling billions of pounds during his 32 years in power until he was toppled by a student-led reform movement in May 1998.

Their investigation is being hampered by his deteriorating health. He suffered a stroke last year and was in hospital with intestinal trouble.

His lawyers and family say he has difficulty talking and is losing his memory. Doctors have had to halt many recent questioning sessions because his blood pressure started rising suddenly.

Yesterday's move is seen mainly as a sop to the increasingly militant student-led protests demanding an immediate trial.

Police and demonstrators regularly engage in running battles near Mr Suharto's home in central Jakarta. On Friday parts of Jakarta were reduced to chaos as hundreds of people attacked police stations and burned passing army vehicles. The police did nothing, saying they did not want to provoke total disorder.

On Sunday a nail bomb exploded in a packed church in Medan, Indonesia's third biggest city, injuring several dozen people in the congregation. The timer failed in another bomb in the city's largest church, and the police found a third bomb during a sweep of all the city's places of worship.

A fourth bomb exploded in a restaurant early yesterday, injuring four people.

Religious leaders and government officials said they were intended to foment sectarian violence between Muslims and Christians. Almost 90% of Indonesia's 210m people follow Islam.

In the past fortnight the sectarian conflict which began in the eastern Moluccas 18 months ago has reached a new level of intensity with the arrival of 2,000 Muslims proclaiming a holy war against Christians. They have made several attacks in the region, in which more than 70 people have died.

Christians and Muslims have been fighting in Poso, central Sulawesi, for the past week. The police say the clashes are spreading to neighbouring districts.

Hasyim Muzadi, chairman of Indonesia's biggest Muslim organisation, Nahdlatul Ulama, said the sectarian tension was a "systematic and well coordinated" attempt to undermine Mr Wahid.

"A series of troubles and now an explosion in a church in Medan will eventually lead to an attempt to topple the government," he said.

Despite having no concrete evidence, most people blame Mr Suharto, his family and cronies for the tension.

"They are bitter about what is happening to the old man and are bitter because they are no longer in power," an official in the presidential palace said.

Most people believe that Mr Wahid's position is currently secure but that a lot can happen in the 10 weeks before the special parliamentary session.

Mr Wahid is not helping himself, however. He is seen as failing to see through much-needed economic reforms and appointing friends and family to influential positions.

The Jakarta stock market fell to a one-year low yesterday because of the the growing concern, and the currency fell more than 3%.

fields.headline: Fiji
fields.standfirst:
Almost two weeks after George Speight took the entire government hostage, efforts are still going on to resolve the political crisis. Mark Tran explains Fiji's descent into political turmoil
Fiji coup: special report
fields.trailText: Almost two weeks after George Speight took the entire government hostage, efforts are still going on to resolve the political crisis. We explain Fiji's descent into political turmoil.
fields.body:
What is the latest in the crisis?
The country's military leaders, who declared martial law yesterday, have named Ratu Epeli Nailatikau as interim prime minister. In a small country where everyone knows everybody else, Mr Nailatikau's wife, Adi Koila Mara, the tourism minister, is one of the 30 hostages held by Mr Speight since the May 19 coup.

What are Mr Speight's demands?
What rankled Mr Speight was the fact that Fiji's prime minister is Mahendra Chaudhry, the first ethnic Indian to hold the post. In other demands, Mr Speight sought the resignation of Rau Sir Kamisese Mara, who was considered too soft towards the Indian minority, the appointment of an indigenous government, and a new constitution allowing only Fijians to hold the posts of prime minister and president. Mr Chaudhry was sacked by president Mara last week, who now remains on a Fijian navy off-shore patrol boat.

Who is George Speight?
He is essentially a businessman but is also the son of an opposition MP, Sam Speight. His father, a senior government member and an architect of the 1987 coup, was brought to power on the coat-tails of Sitiveni Rabuka, whose administration lost power a year ago. Mr Speight was chairman of two Fijian firms involved in the country's lucrative $60m mahogany timber trade. Mr Speight was sacked by Mr Chaudhry after last years landslide victory over Mr Rabuka.

Is there anyone behind Mr Speight?
Mr Speight always seemed a rather implausible coup leader, and sure enough reports emerged today that the real coup leader is a former special services soldier loyal to former prime minister Rabuka. APF, the French news agency, has reported that the actual leader is Colonel Ilisoni Ligairi, 60, who received training in the UK. He is in charge of the counter revolutionary warfare unit (CRWU) which Mr Speight used to seize Fiji's parliament. The CRWU, considered Fiji's version of the Special Air Service, frequently operates with special forces from Britain, Australia and New Zealand.

Has there been any violence?
On Sunday, Mr Speight's supporters smashed up the local TV station, forcing it off the air, and surrounded the Centra hotel, where most foreign journalists covering the coup were staying. One policeman was shot dead, prompting the army to declare martial law.

Didn't analysts think the coup was going to peter out quickly?
That was the initial thinking. But the longer the coup went on, the more support Mr Speight received from the Fijian population until Fiji's traditional chiefs eventually gave their blessing to the coup, calling for Mr Chaudhry to be replaced by an indigenous Fijian. The chiefs, who wield enormous influence, agreed to all of Mr Speight's demands, including a pardon for all those involved in the coup.

What will be the effect on the island's Indian population?
Fiji is bracing itself for a mass Indian emigration similar to that after the 1987 coup. Indians started coming to Fiji as labourers on sugar plantations at the end of the 19th century, when Fiji was a British colony. By 1970, when Fiji became independent, ethnic Indians were in a majority. But after the 1987 coup, many Indians - especially professionals - left the country, and now 51% of the 800,000 population are indigenous Fijians. Indians form 44% of the population.

What was the political background to the latest events?
The Fijian-dominated Alliance Party led by now former president Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara dominated Fijian politics after independence. But elections in April 1987 saw the Alliance Party supplanted by a multi-racial coalition which divided ministerial jobs evenly between Fijians and Indians, to the consternation of hard-line indigenous nationalists. After colonel Rabuka took power in the 1987 coup, he declared Fiji a republic and the country was expelled from the Commonwealth. Fiji rejoined the Commonwealth in 1997, but it now faces expulsion once again.

fields.headline: Top tips for football widows
fields.trailText: Would you rather spend June with Rupert Everett or David Beckham? Either option sounds palatable, but Hollywood is counting on British women choosing glossy celluloid locks over twinkling toes. They have held back the release dates of dozens of so-called chick-flicks until the start of Euro 2000, in order to cash in on the "fed-up female factor".
fields.body:
Would you rather spend June with Rupert Everett or David Beckham? Either option sounds palatable, but Hollywood is counting on British women choosing glossy celluloid locks over twinkling toes. They have held back the release dates of dozens of so-called chick-flicks until the start of Euro 2000, in order to cash in on the "fed-up female factor".

It would be hateful to let them win. Many of the films on offer have been flops in America - Ben Affleck's Deception for example - and the moguls see football widows as easy box-office prey. If footie is not your thing, refuse to hide away at the pictures. Instead of glossy Rupert, try gritty Nasser. Instead of popcorn, cake. Replace love on the silver-screen with life, death (well, groin strains), money-laundering, argy-bargy and seduction on the cricket field.

Here are ten top tips for virgin cricket-watchers who do take the plunge this June:

1. Equip yourself with a pair of binoculars. Not only do they make it far easier to decipher what is going off out there but they also allow you to keep a close eye on that really rather cute fielder. And don't worry about being labelled a sexist. When cricketers sit on the dressing room balcony with binoculars glued to their eyes, they aren't looking for their grandmothers.

2. Don't wash your hair. There is absolutely no need to put on any make-up or make any sort of effort whatsoever in order to attend a cricket match. If it looks like it is going to rain, pack that anorak - with pride.

3. If on the other hand you want to be a screen starlet, and it looks like the sun will shine, wear a bikini top. Cameramen (they usually are men) are suckers for expansive bosoms so you will be beamed live into a million homes. Oh and if you streak, The Sun will offer you a lot of money to pose on page three.

4. If going to a Test match take a walkman and tune into Test Match Special (Radio 4, 198 LW) as soon as you arrive. Friendly voices will give you an idea of what is going on and entertain you when it rains. They will also point you in the direction of the man dressed as a carrot.

5. Bring a Thermos flask of coffee. Cricket grounds sell lousy stuff: Nescafe, if you're lucky; bog-brush turds if you're not.

6. Carry a newspaper, or two, or a beach bonkbuster. The joy of cricket is that you can drift in and out of the game as you fancy. No-one, except perhaps Bob Woolmer and his computerised companion, pays attention to every single ball of a match. In fact, at any given moment probably a quarter of the crowd is asleep.

7. Wear sunglasses. Essential for the usual reasons and also useful for staring - has that woman really got a moustache? - or pretending to have dozed off when the man you are sitting next to reveals his "really interesting" theory on the Duckworth/Lewis method.

8. Keep an eye on the scoreboard. If someone has 48 or 98 try not to go to the loo. You are guaranteed to miss something vital when you do go, but at least this way you are cutting your losses.

9. Wear something with an elasticated waistband (see tip 2). You will be amazed at just how much one woman can consume in seven sedentary hours. Pork pies, quiches, salmon, chips, cake, strawberries, doughnuts and crisps make for tasty hors d'oeuvres.

10. Enjoy. This is the most wonderful game in the world. And even if you hate every horrible second of it you can always get darling Rupert out on video as soon as you've bowled home.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. Her Women's Page appears on wisden.com and CricketUnlimited every Tuesday.

webTitle: Festen director to shoot first English-language film

fields.headline: Festen director to shoot first English-language film
fields.trailText: German company Senator Film has announced it is to co-produce Danish director Thomas Vinterberg's $10m English-language debut, It's All About Love. The UK's FilmFour and Italy's Key Films are also co-producing the project, set to shoot in New York next spring.
fields.body:
German company Senator Film has announced it is to co-produce Danish director Thomas Vinterberg's $10m English-language debut, It's All About Love. The UK's FilmFour and Italy's Key Films are also co-producing the project, set to shoot in New York next spring.

The film is being produced by Birgitte Hald of Denmark's Nimbus Film who also oversaw Vinterberg's acclaimed Dogme title, Festen (The Celebration).

"As with The Celebration, we have insisted on full creative control for Thomas, yet still people have shared our vision and wanted to come on board," said Hald. "We are now getting offers from the rest of Europe as well."

Scripted by Vinterberg and regular collaborator Mogens Rukov, It's All About Love is the story of two separated lovers who are reunited in New York and travel across America in an attempt to rebuild their relationship.

Vinterberg made his name as a leading light in Denmark's Dogme movement alongside the more established Lars Von Trier. Both Vinterberg's Festen and Von Trier's The Idiots subscribed to Dogme's spartan "vow of chastity" which involved shooting on hand-held cameras with natural sound in undecorated locations. Vinterberg's second film, though, puts the Dogme business behind him, with a plot set in a reimagined, futuristic USA that's suffering from a global deep-freeze.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Which Danish workhorse could be off to manage Wimbledon? And which clubs are leading the chase for Ugo Ehiogu?
fields.trailText: Which Danish workhorse could be off to manage Wimbledon? And which clubs are leading the chase for Ugo Ehiogu?
fields.body:
Gianfranco Zola has hinted he will be off to Napoli. According to the Daily Mail, Fenerbahce have already offered the striker £1.5m for one season, but their vice-president Mahmut Usiu revealed: "He has told us that should Napoli be promoted, he would give it strong consideration."

The former Arsenal work-horse John Jensen has emerged as a 'shock contender' for the Wimbledon job, reports the Mirror. Caretaker boss Terry Burton remains the odds-on favourite for the job, but ex-Danish Jensen has impressed as a rookie coach, having steered minnows Hefolge to the Danish title.

The Mirror also claims that Arsenal have made an approach for Rayo Vallecano keeper Kasey Keller. The former Leicester keeper made a bright start with Rayo, but spent the second half of the season on the bench after losing his place through injury and will be available for around £2m.

Leeds have bid £3m for Brann Bergen's 23-year-old striker Torstein Helstad, who has scored eight goals in ten matches this season, reports Teamtalk.

Teamtalk also claims that Leeds and Manchester United are leading the race for Aston Villa defender Ugo Ehiogu - who has been told he can leave by John Gregory.

Meanwhile Paul Merson's future will be decided later this week when his agent Steve Kutner meets Aston Villa chairman Doug Ellis. Kutner said: "He wants to stay with Villa and we are not talking to other clubs at the moment. But Paul is on holiday, John Gregory is away and I will talk to the chairman."

Planet Football is claiming that Robert Pires's move to Arsenal is far from a done deal - and the 27 year-old winger is more likely to move to Lyon or Lens.

fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Engineer  Marcus Franz, 28, describes why he is taking part in a Christian festival
fields.trailText: Engineer Marcus Franz, 28, describes why he is taking part in a Christian festival
fields.body:
Meine Eltern sind neuapostolisch. Doch obwohl ich in eine Familie mit diesem Glauben hineingeboren bin, habe ich nie daran gezweifelt, daß es das richtige ist. Was mich davon überzeugt hat, daß es Gott gibt, ist einfach zu erklären: ich erlebe es jedesmal im Gottesdienst und auch im täglichen Leben.

Das ist kaum in Worte zu fassen, ich denke, man muß es spüren. Wenn ich Gott zum Beispiel im Gebet um etwas bitte, dann merke ich, daß ich Hilfe bekomme. Das bedeutet natürlich nicht, daß ich gleich einen Sechser im Lotto habe, nur weil ich Gott zum Beispiel bei einem finanziellen Engpaß um Hilfe gebeten habe. Die Hilfe ist anderer Art, nicht nur auf das Materielle ausgerichtet. Aber sie ist doch da.

Man ist aber auch immer selbst gefordert, diese Beziehung zu Gott aufrecht zu erhalten. Das ist wie mit dem Verhältnis zu Vater, Mutter oder meiner Freundin. Man muß diese Liebe pflegen, aber man weiß: du bist nie allein.

Ich bin froh, daß auch in der heutigen Zeit viele so denken. Bei Jugendtagen der Neuapostolischen Kirche erlebt man in einer Menge von vier- oder fünftausend jungen, ganz unterschiedlichen Menschen, wie sie der Glaube an Gott verbindet. Sie verfolgen ja alle das gleiche Ziel: Bei der Rückkehr von Jesus dabei zu sein. Das bedeutet natürlich nicht, daß ich irgendwie lebensmüde wäre. Im Gegenteil. Erfolg und Freude sind mir auch wichtig. Aber ich ordne sie diesem wichtigsten Ziel unter.

Beängstigend finde ich, daß immer mehr junge Menschen aus den christlichen Kirchen austreten, weil sie nichts von Gott wissen wollen. In meinem Glauben ist das zum Glück anders.

webTitle: Toy Story: most clubbers prefer it

fields.headline: Toy Story: most clubbers prefer it
fields.trailText: Clubbers who want to put their feet up and watch a film after a hard night on the dancefloor would rather watch family favourite Toy Story than any other movie, a survey conducted to promote Sky Digital revealed today.
fields.body:
Clubbers who want to put their feet up and watch a film after a hard night on the dancefloor would rather watch family favourite Toy Story than any other movie, a survey conducted to promote Sky Digital revealed today.

The original animated adventures of astronaut Buzz Lightyear and cowboy Woody (released in the UK in 1996) came top of a poll for those viewers wanting to chill out after staggering home from their favourite nightclub.

Science-fiction stalwarts Star Wars and 2001: A Space Odyssey came in at number two and three respectively, hotly followed by the more predictable youth flicks Trainspotting and Pulp Fiction.

In all, 1,000 regular UK club-goers were interviewed for the survey which was carried out to coincide with the national TV premiere of last year's cult clubbing movie Human Traffic.

But if pollsters were expecting to find clubbers wanting brash, hip movies to come down to, they had another thing coming. Analysing the poll results, psychotherapist Sidney Crown said: "When people are physically exhausted, they very often revert to warm fantasies that are reminiscent of childhood. Toy Story is the ultimate childhood fantasy that appeals to both children and adults The fantasy theme continues with Star Wars and 2001: A Space Odyssey, as people will immerse themselves in a world of make-believe."

Rounding out the post-clubbing top ten was Ridley Scott's Blade Runner, the 60s-set comedy Withnail & I, the spoof rockumentray This is Spinal Tap, Martin Scorsese's Goodfellas and the Vietnam classic Apocalypse Now.

fields.headline: Jordan to direct Borgia biopic
fields.trailText: Neil Jordan will write and direct a film on the notorious Italian noblewoman Lucrezia Borgia, it was confirmed yesterday. The film will be backed by DreamWorks and overseen by one of its semi-independent production arms, ImageMovies, which is part-owned by director Robert Zemeckis. The role of Lucrezia has yet to be cast, but Jordan is believed to have completed a first draft of the script and the film is expected to begin shooting before the end of the year.
fields.body:
Neil Jordan will write and direct a film on the notorious Italian noblewoman Lucrezia Borgia, it was confirmed yesterday. The film will be backed by DreamWorks and overseen by one of its semi-independent production arms, ImageMovies, which is part-owned by director Robert Zemeckis. The role of Lucrezia has yet to be cast, but Jordan is believed to have completed a first draft of the script and the film is expected to begin shooting before the end of the year.

Lucrezia Borgia, who lived from 1480-1519, is regarded as the most glamorous and vindictive member of the Borgia clan, a family which dominated Renaissance Italy in the 15th and 16th centuries. The daughter of a corrupt pope, her crash-course lifestyle took in accusations of incest, a trio of marriages and an infamous orgy at the Vatican. Surprisingly, the Borgias' story - a Dallas in period costume - has thus far failed to incite much interest in Hollywood, though they did inspire a BBC TV series in the 70s.

Jordan's sprawling tale of political intrigue in period Italy is likely to require a hefty budget, but the Irish-born film-maker is currently seen as a bankable bet again, after a wobbly patch a few years back when his paranormal thriller In Dreams bombed at the box office. His last picture, an adaptation of Graham Greene's The End of the Affair, did decent business and won a Best Actress Oscar nomination for Julianne Moore.

fields.headline: French buy £27bn Orange
fields.trailText: France Telecom completed the takeover of mobile phone company Orange for almost £27bn, it was announced this morning.
fields.body:
France Telecom completed the takeover of mobile phone company Orange for almost £27bn, it was announced this morning.

Orange will be merged with France Telecom's other mobile phone operations and headed by Hans Snook, Orange's current chief executive. The merger will create a group with around 30 million subscribers by the end of the year and revenues of £4.9bn.

Vodafone became the owner of Orange as part of its near £100bn takeover of the German telecoms company Mannesmann. It was required to sell Orange in order to win approval from European regulators for the Mannesmann deal and will retain the rest of the German company's phone business.

By taking over Orange, France Telecom will also gain one of the much sought-after third generation mobile phone licences recently auctioned off by the UK government.

The company will also take on the £4.1 billion cost of that licence, which will gives Orange the ability to offer a raft of new services including email and Internet access to mobile handsets.

The merged mobile phone operation will be listed on the London, Paris and New York Stock Exchanges by early next year.

Michel Bon, chairman and chief executive of France Telecom, said: "The acquisition of Orange and the creation of New Orange is a major step in France Telecom's international strategy to become a European leader and global player."

France Telecom said it anticipated floating between 10% and 15% of its enlarged mobile business depending on market conditions later in the year. It will use the proceeds from the float to buy back the shares given to Vodafone as part of the Orange sale.

webTitle: Chirac's support fails to boost lucklustre euro

fields.headline: Chirac's support fails to boost lucklustre euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's big guns yesterday launched a now-familiar bank-holiday salvo to support the euro, but - even with British and US markets closed - the ailing single currency barely responded.
fields.body:
Europe's big guns yesterday launched a now-familiar bank-holiday salvo to support the euro, but - even with British and US markets closed - the ailing single currency barely responded.

Meanwhile, official data showed the euro-zone countries still failing to reap the full benefits of the sliding euro, with the current account surplus £2.1bn lower in March than 12 months earlier.

French president Jacques Chirac led the attempt to rally the euro, with an address in Paris that promised to use the French presidency of the European Union, which begins at the end of next month, to push ahead with structural reform the euro-zone countries.

Ominously for those trying to persuade the British to adopt the single currency, he added that budgetary "co-ordination" was vital to stem the euro's slide.

"[We]...have to ensure that the means are there for better coordination on budgetary policies and that we strengthen the instruments and procedure of economic decision-making," he said.

He was speaking to an audience of the world's central bankers to celebrate the bicentenary of the Bank of France.

Meanwhile, Ernst Welteke, head of Germany's former central bank, the Bundesbank, who was also in Paris yesterday, said prospects for price stability in the euro-zone were good, but admitted that the euro had been possibly "somewhat overvalued" at the time of its debut in January 1999.

It was worth then $1.17 and has lost at times about a quarter of its dollar value. Yesterday, with British and US markets closed for public holidays, giving a clear run to European and Asian centres, the euro was barely changed, trading at around its Friday close of 0.62 against sterling and 0.93 against the dollar.

Other heavyweight support for the currency came from the French finance minister, Laurent Fabius, who, as a former ally of the late president François Mitterrand, was in at the birth of the project. He said the euro was "not Monopoly money" and said markets had failed to take into account the euro-zone's improving economic climate.

Across the Atlantic, William McDonough, president of the New York federal reserve bank, while describing the euro's introduction as a "success story", said that there was much to be done to make continental Europe more productive and more attractive to investors.

webTitle: President ousted as military takes over in Fiji

fields.headline: President ousted as military takes over in Fiji
fields.trailText: The Fijian military yesterday declared martial law, eased the president out of office and imposed a 24-hour curfew on the country's capital, Suva, in an   attempt to seize control of the constitutional crisis.
fields.byline: Rodney Joyce  in Pacific Harbour, Fiji, and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
The Fijian military yesterday declared martial law, eased the president out of office and imposed a 24-hour curfew on the country's capital, Suva, in an attempt to seize control of the constitutional crisis.

With nationalist gunmen still holding the ethnic-Indian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, hostage in the parliament, Commodore Frank Bainamarama, the head of the armed forces, said he had "with much reluctance assumed executive authority and declared martial law".

"The country, in the meantime, will be run by a military government. The primary objective of this government is to take the country towards peace and stability," he said.

Troops on leave and reservists were recalled to barracks. The president, Ratu Sir Kamisese Mara, was reported to have left office after being asked to resign. His private secretary, Joe Brown, said that military officials had told him the president had resigned to allow martial law to be enforced. The army said the president went "gladly", he added.

The parliament, where a Fijian businessman, George Speight, and a small group of gunmen on May 19 took the ethnic Indian prime minister and more than 30 members of his government hostage, was yesterday surrounded by troop reinforcements. Mr Speight had demanded the president's resignation, the appointment of an indigenous government, and a new constitution which would allow only indigenous Fijians to hold the posts of prime minister and president.

Mr Chaudhry was sacked by the president last week.

News of the army takeover heightened international concern. Britain warned that Fiji faced suspension from the Commonwealth if it turned its back on democracy.

Commonwealth foreign ministers are due to meet on June 6. However, the immediate focus of attention will be the intentions of the military.

John Battle, the Foreign Office minister, said: "If this situation goes badly wrong then there's got to be a question mark over the membership of the Commonwealth. If Fiji is to move out of the democratic community at this stage they would pay a very, very high price." Fiji was only readmitted to the Commonwealth three years ago, after two military coups in 1987.

The military took action after two soldiers and a journalist were injured by gunfire on Saturday and a policeman was killed on Sunday night when a mob ran through Suva and ransacked the state-owned television station.

On Saturday, Commodore Bainamarama said that 15 unarmed reservists who joined Mr Speight's men last Friday would be discharged.

Rodney Joyce is a Reuters correspondent.
