fields.headline: Isle of terror
fields.standfirst: As the army seizes power amid rising ethnic violence, Fiji's Indian population is living in fear
fields.trailText: The large slice of Fiji's population who are of Indian origin have been terrified since coup instigator George Speight's group, consisting of only a few soldiers from Fiji's elite counter-revolutionary warfare squadron, seized the small South Pacific island's parliament 10 days ago.
fields.body:
The large slice of Fiji's population who are of Indian origin have been terrified since coup instigator George Speight's group, consisting of only a few soldiers from Fiji's elite counter-revolutionary warfare squadron, seized the small South Pacific island's parliament 10 days ago.

On Sunday, Speight's supporters smashed up the local TV station, forcing it off the air, and besieged the Centra Hotel, where most foreign journalists covering the coup were staying. A policeman was shot dead.

Speight transformed his armed seizure of the parliamentary complex into a populist ethnic Fijian movement. Although the police and army at first backed Fiji's President Mara, the army commander moved to oust the president yesterday, and sparked an international crisis, with worried noises made by the UK.

The Indo-Fijian prime minister, Mahendra Chaudhry, and his cabinet, had been held under lock and key since the take-over of parliament. At the same time that Speight's group seized the parliament, rampaging Fijians in Suva's city centre smashed and looted mainly Indian shops. Indo-Fijian homesteads in rural areas have also been attacked.

Thirteen years ago, in 1987, a similar coup by the country's ethnic Fijian political leaders deprived Indo-Fijians of political rights for a decade. Speight's group now demands that the 1997 constitution, which gave Indo-Fijians greater political rights, be torn up. Fiji's great council of chiefs has already agreed that the position of prime minister be henceforth reserved for an ethnic Fijian.

The future looks bleak for the Fiji Indians. Many will probably now emigrate - as others did after the 1987 coup.

When Speight's group opened the parliament gates, at first only close kith and kin turned up. Then people from the provinces adjacent to Suva flocked from far and wide bearing root crops, chickens trussed in banana leaves and pigs tied, Asterix-style, to staves carried on tall Fijian shoulders.

They also bore large bundles of the gnarled roots of the kava plant, which, pounded into powder, mixed with water and squeezed through muslin handkerchiefs, makes a locally drunk stimulant called "yanqona". In Fiji, many a tale is told, and many political decisions are taken, around the kava bowl.

George Speight has now been turned into a modern-day Fijian folk hero. Buoyed by signs of growing support, Speight on Friday had swaggered down to the army blockades outside the besieged complex and demanded their removal.

The next day, his unarmed supporters marched straight into the armed road-blocks, physically grabbing the soldiers and throwing aside their makeshift wooden porcupine-blockades. That was when the shooting first started.

Gunshots proved the turning point in the crisis. Fiji is a small island country, 50% of whom are ethnic Fijian. Everyone knows everyone. Close links make violent conflict less acceptable.

So an armed assault on parliament had never been a realistic option for President Mara. The day after the first shooting, Mara backed off, ordering that the blockades around parliament be removed.

The president at first tried to steer a constitutional path through the crisis. Backed by Fiji's venerable great council of chiefs, he made compromises with Speight's group while trying to avoid abrogating the 1997 constitution.

The president also backed off from sending in the army to crush Speight's uprising. Frank Bainimarama, the army commander, originally declared support for the president, but there was always little sign that the army as a whole was willing to risk confrontation with members of the elite counter-revolutionary warfare squadron, who are behind Speight.

Ethnic divisions in Fiji are not like those in Northern Ireland or present-day Bosnia. Indians often go to the same schools as Fijians. The two communities play football together, although Indians rarely appear on the rugby field. Indians drink the traditional Fijian kava, and Fijians love spicy curry. Yet the two groups very rarely inter-marry, and the army is solidly Fijian.

Sociologists often say that urbanisation tends to whittle away parochial loyalties over time, or that class divisions in the towns will eventually displace the antiquated racial alignments of the countryside. Nothing could be more false for Fiji. Here, the sharp divisions are in the most urbanised areas.

The capital city Suva, and its environs, are the hotbeds of ethnic chauvinism in Fiji. The two communities lead a largely separate existence in this part of the country. Speight's coup was made in Suva.

In the island's more rural west, the economy rests on tourism, gold, timber and sugar.

But one reason for the strength of urban ethnic antagonism is government jobs. Speight's group not only want to replace Chaudhry with an ethnic Fijian prime minister: the nationalists also want more indigenous Fijians throughout the civil service.

 Jon Fraenkl is a lecturer in economic history at the University of the South Pacific in Fiji

Buoyed by signs of growing support, Speight on Friday had swaggered down to the army blockades outside the besieged complex and demanded their removal. The next day, his unarmed supporters marched straight into the armed road-blocks, physically grabbing the soldiers and throwing aside their makeshift wooden porcupine-blockades. That was when the shooting first started. Gunshots proved the turning point in the crisis. Fiji is a small island country, 50% of whom are ethnic Fijian. Everyone knows everyone. Close links make violent conflict less acceptable. So an armed assault on parliament had never been a realistic option for President Mara. The day after the first shooting, Mara backed off, ordering that the blockades around parliament be removed. The president at first tried to steer a constitutional path through the crisis. Backed by Fiji's venerable great council of chiefs, he made compromises with Speight's group while trying to avoid abrogating the 1997 constitution. The president also backed off from sending in the army to crush Speight's uprising. Frank Bainimarama, the army commander, originally declared support for the president, but there was always little sign that the army as a whole was willing to risk confrontation with members of the elite counter-revolutionary warfare squadron, who are behind Speight. Ethnic divisions in Fiji are not like those in Northern Ireland or present-day Bosnia. Indians often go to the same schools as Fijians. The two communities play football together, although Indians rarely appear on the rugby field. Indians drink the traditional Fijian kava, and Fijians love spicy curry. Yet the two groups very rarely inter-marry, and the army is solidly Fijian. Sociologists often say that urbanisation tends to whittle away parochial loyalties over time, or that class divisions in the towns will eventually displace the antiquated racial alignments of the countryside. Nothing could be more false for Fiji. Here, the sharp divisions are in the most urbanised areas. The capital city Suva, and its environs, are the hotbeds of ethnic chauvinism in Fiji. The two communities lead a largely separate existence in this part of the country. Speight's coup was made in Suva. In the island's more rural west, the economy rests on tourism, gold, timber and sugar. But one reason for the strength of urban ethnic antagonism is government jobs. Speight's group not only want to replace Chaudhry with an ethnic Fijian prime minister: the nationalists also want more indigenous Fijians throughout the civil service.  Jon Fraenkl is a lecturer in economic history at the University of the South Pacific in Fiji

webTitle: Granddaughter of LAPD chief shot dead

fields.headline: Granddaughter of LAPD chief shot dead
fields.trailText: The granddaughter of the chief of Los Angeles police has been shot dead, focusing fresh attention on fears of a resumption in gang violence and on the beleaguered police force.
fields.body:
The granddaughter of the chief of Los Angeles police has been shot dead, focusing fresh attention on fears of a resumption in gang violence and on the beleaguered police force.

Lori Gonzalez, 20, the granddaughter of Bernard Parks, head of the LAPD, was shot dead late on Sunday as she drove off after shopping in the city's Jefferson Park area. A lone gunman fired a sustained burst of shots into the car Ms Gonzalez was travelling in. She died from multiple wounds; her male companion survived.

Yesterday a spokesman for the LAPD said it was believed that Ms Gonzalez was not the intended victim but that no motive had been established. The murder is being investigated jointly by the homicide and robbery squads.

The murder comes amid fears that shootings may be on the increase again after a number of years in which they have dropped. Eight people were shot, one fatally, in a shootout in Long Beach at the weekend, the worst outbreak of violence in the area for eight years.

There is concern that with police facing their own problems, gang warfare on a large scale could resurface.

Mr Parks heads a force that is under investigation by the US justice department over the corrupt behaviour of a team of officers in the Rampart division of the city.

Officers have admitted to operating drug rings, shooting unarmed suspects, planting weapons and fabricating evidence. The city is anticipating having to pay tens of millions of dollars in compensation to those falsely imprisoned.

Last week it was announced that 75 convictions had been overturned and 70 officers of the 9,000-strong force were under investigation.

Thirty officers have already been suspended in an investigation that started when one Rampart division officer, Rafael Perez, agreed to give evidence against former colleagues in exchange for a shorter sentence on a drugs theft charge. He was jailed for five years for stealing cocaine that had been seized by police and recycling it.

Mr Parks has come under fire in the media over the scandal, although the worst offences occurred before he took over. Only the second African-American officer to head the force, Mr Parks enjoys the support of the mayor, Richard Riordan, but has been criticised for not taking action against rogue officers swiftly enough.

fields.headline: Advert for UK pork 'will backfire'
fields.trailText: Supermarkets have condemned a government backed advertisement for pork which relies on shock tactics to promote the British pig industry over foreign imports.
fields.body:
Supermarkets have condemned a government backed advertisement for pork which relies on shock tactics to promote the British pig industry over foreign imports.

Tesco and Asda warned that it could backfire and put consumers off meat altogether, a view shared by the Danish bacon industry, which supplies a quarter of the bacon sold in Britain.

One industry insider said the press advert, which appears on page 7 of the Guardian today, looked more like a campaign by vegetarians.

The advert is part of a six-month, £4.8m promotion by the meat and livestock commission and shows a sow suckling her piglets.

The message is: "After she's fed them, she could be fed to them." This is meant to portray the forced animal cannibalism still arranged in many countries, where pigs are fed meat products from other pigs. The practice is banned in Britain as an anti-BSE measure.

In smaller type is the exhortation: "Look after the farmers who look after their pigs."

Yesterday the MLC refused to name "guilty" countries among the main foreign suppliers, Denmark, Holland, Ireland, France, Hungary and Poland. A spokesman claimed that Denmark's statistics suggested only a third of the pork and bacon exported to Britain met the UK's welfare standards. He said: "If it is legal to use [pig meat for pigs] it is economically advantageous to do so."

Supermarkets complained after seeing the pre-released advert. Tesco said: "We had serious reservations about how this will be interpreted."

Asda said its imported bacon met UK standards, and British pork sales had risen because of price cuts - these might be jeopardised.

The Dutch meat board condemned it as "inflammatory, inaccurate and irresponsible".

John Howard, marketing director of the Danish Bacon and Meat Council, said: "Some British farmers will be delighted by this campaign, but if the overall market is damaged it will be a pyrrhic victory."

But Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said: "The advertisements are tough _ and they're absolutely right. The public demanded animal welfare legislation; it has been put in place. It is worth reminding people just how pigs are kept and what the recycling of meat actually means."

fields.headline: Haider's cheap petrol coup
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider, Austria's controversial far-right leader, yesterday shook his critics at home and abroad by announcing he had secured a deal for cheap petrol to be sold in the southern province of Carinthia.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider, Austria's controversial far-right leader, yesterday shook his critics at home and abroad by announcing he had secured a deal for cheap petrol to be sold in the southern province of Carinthia.

Mr Haider, who is governor of Carinthia and has used it as a powerbase from which his populist Freedom party (FPO) made the leap into government in February, said that petrol and diesel would be sold at 12% less than the average price elsewhere in Austria.

Last week it was confirmed that he had held business talks in Tripoli with Colonel Muammar Gadafy. Mr Haider is a friend of the Libyan leader's son.

The cut price fuel would go on sale at midnight last night, Mr Haider said, but refused to say where it had come from, how much had been secured and at what price. A local discount chain has been signed up to distribute the fuel.

After a general election in October last year Mr Haider threw Austria into chaos when the Freedom party entered a coalition government with the conservative People's party under the chancellorship of Wolfgang Schüssel. In protest the other 14 members of the EU imposed bilateral sanctions, which they have said will remain in place while the Freedom party is in government.

Mr Haider later resigned as leader of the FPO, following the deluge of criticism.

Opposition politicians and political analysts last night said the cheap fuel deal was yet another attempt by Austria's most controversial leader since world war two to strengthen the FPO's popularity ratings. His major trump card in the run up to the election last year was his pledge to provide a substantial monthly "children's cheque" to Austrian nationals. The petrol deal is seen in a similar light.

It is said to be a further example of Mr Haider's knack of tapping into the national psyche. Soaring petrol prices caused by higher global crude oil prices have led to widespread calls for politicians to intervene.

At a press conference in the Carinthian capital, Klagenfurt, yesterday, he remained cagey about the deal but said that he hoped the main petrol suppliers would match the low prices. If not, he said he would be forced to open petrol stations to the public that are normally used only by official vehicles, and which charge lower prices.

Earlier, Austria's economics minister, Martin Bartenstein, warned the major oil companies that unless they imposed price cuts by the end of May he would enforce price controls.

Mr Haider, known for his controversial remarks downplaying the crimes of Nazis, has drawn further international criticism recently by suggesting that Austrian politicians who criticise the government abroad should be put on trial.

The petrol deal comes after confirmed reports that Mr Haider held meetings earlier this month with Colonel Gadafy. The Libyan leader's son, Saifalislam, who became a close friend of Mr Haider while studying in Vienna, where the son graduated earlier this year, said the two men had come together to "discuss business". Their meeting, he said, focused on the timber and tourism industries.

"Jörg Haider is a very good friend of mine, my father's and of our country," the magazine News quoted Saifalislam as saying.

He insisted that Mr Haider had refused to accept political donations from Libya.

Although Mr Haider is no longer the FPO leader, he remains its de facto boss and the country's leading political personality, and he is still said to harbour desires to become Austrian chancellor. He is said to very much be at the helm of government and joins weekly coalition committee meetings in Vienna which include the chancellor, vice-chancellor and all the ministers.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
A contender steps forward to challenge defending champion David Winnick (of whom more below) for the title Stupidest MP 2000. He is David Wilshire. Best known until now for his outrage at the legendary Guardian cod fax, the Tory MP for Spelthorne threatens legal action against local Labour agent Harold Trace, who wrote to a paper accusing him of scaremongering about a hospital. What upset Mr Wilshire was being compared to "the Tory A-team in high places ... Archer, Aitken, Ashcroft and 'Amilton". Bright MPs ignore such attacks in papers like the Heathrow Villager, especially when made by someone being treated for cancer at the hospital in question. Mr Wilshire, on the other hand, forced the paper to apologise, and now attempts to compel Mr Trace to do so and to give £250 to a charity. If Mr Trace did make a rather wild comparison, though, you can see how hard Mr Wilshire would find it to empathise. During the cod fax debate, the worst thing to which he compared the Guardian was Nazi Germany, when warning: "that route lurks the jackboot and the lynch mob".

Speaking of David Winnick, the Labour MP writes to dispute the suggestion that Harold Wilson called him "the stupidest man in the House". (David thinks he irritated this column by not being an ardent Ken Livingstone fan: as if we had the remotest clue, bless his heart, of what he thinks of Ken or indeed anything else.) "I am not aware," he writes, "that Harold Wilson ever made such derogatory remarks about me (where in Hansard, please?)" David, surely you recall that the point of the original item was Hansard's failure to record the unreliable accurately (its reporter corrected your own inability, of course, to distinguish between Sierra Leone and Sri Lanka). The Walsall MP is off to a flier in defence of that title.

 The angel dust from Leo Blair spreads all the way to the Downing Street press office. When my colleague Richard Adams rings to ask how Cherie's mother spells her name - Gayle in the Express, Gail in the Times - a young man says: "hold on a moment, please." Please? Us? He returns with news that it is Gale. Richard also wanted to know why Gale appears on the certificate of her marriage to Tony Booth as Joyce Smith and later changed her name, but is too stunned by that "please" to push his luck.

 It is true that this is being written on a news-less bank holiday, and by a peculiarly bone idle hack, but even so I make no apology for treating those of you who missed it to a gem from Sunday's Observer. John Heilpern's reprinted record, in the style of a play, of a 1975 lunchtime chat between John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson, is a joy from start to finish, but especially so for one deadpan stage note. "RR: Pass the Paul Robeson," Heilpern records Sir Ralph saying after a Gielgud anecdote about bald actors wearing hats. "Gielgud passes over a large pepper mill." Magnificent.

 Concern mounts for clinical psychologist Raj Persaud. A friend, writing an article about how It-girls and ladettes always pose with their mouths wide open, rang for the mandatory quote, and found Raj unwilling to offer an opinion. "It's absolutely ridiculous that I should have a view on that," he thundered, in the manner of an extremely learned professor pestered with some imbecile inquiry about the Spice Girls. "Please leave me alone." Earlier last week, Raj treated Daily Mail readers to an analysis of the Blair family dynamic based entirely on a single photograph.

 In Australia, a retrial has been ordered of the case against a suspected bank robber. The judge in Adelaide believes the jury might have brought in a different verdict had the defendant used an alias instead of his real name, Rob Banks. For the retrial Mr Banks is thought to be considering the Danish sobriquet Stig Emup.

webTitle: Visitors flood to attractions on wet bank holiday

fields.headline: Visitors flood to attractions on wet bank holiday
fields.trailText: The bank holiday deluge failed to dampen Britain's new-found enthusiasm for modern art as visitors continued to flood in to Tate Modern in unprecedented numbers.
fields.body:
The bank holiday deluge failed to dampen Britain's new-found enthusiasm for modern art as visitors continued to flood in to Tate Modern in unprecedented numbers.

The remodelled Bankside power station on the south bank of the Thames in London was ringed by visitors queueing to get in to the world's largest display of modern art throughout the weekend.

On Sunday gallery staff handed out Tate umbrellas to visitors who braved occasional hail storms for the privilege of getting in to the much-praised Turbine Hall, where they had to queue again for access to the galleries themselves.

A spokeswoman for Tate Modern estimated that some 75,000 people had visited over the weekend, adding that they were "delighted" with the response.

Yesterday, with conditions considerably drier, visitors had to queue for 45 minutes outside the gallery before braving a further wait inside as staff attempted to control the flow of visitors into galleries that were close to capacity. One member of staff said: "It's incredible - we've had to operate a one-in one-out policy."

Management at rival Thameside attraction the Millennium Dome hoped to celebrate their second biggest day of admissions last night, with 27,600 visitors through the doors by 5pm.

The crowds were queueing on average between ten and fifteen minutes yesterday evening, with a wait of just under 30 minutes for the Home Planet Zone, which offers a virtual tour of the Earth. The Dome's capacity is 35,000.

A spokeswoman said: "Our record day was 32,000 last Bank Holiday Monday, when the TUC did a bulk buy.

"We expect there to be an influx of people through the evening when we have quite a few musical events on, and it will either top that or be the second biggest day.

"In the late 20s would be my ball-park figure because we don't have the advantage of a bulk buy today. It was in the early 20s on Sunday but today has been a real hit."

webTitle: IRA suspected of murder as powers devolved to Ulster

fields.headline: IRA suspected of murder as powers devolved to Ulster
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Detectives were last night investigating whether there was IRA involvement in the shooting dead of a suspected drugs dealer near Belfast, an execution exacerbating Ulster Unionist jitters as they again joined government with republicans. Powers were devolved to Northern Ireland at midnight.
fields.body:
Detectives were last night investigating whether there was IRA involvement in the shooting dead of a suspected drugs dealer near Belfast, an execution exacerbating Ulster Unionist jitters as they again joined government with republicans. Powers were devolved to Northern Ireland at midnight.

Edmund McCoy, 28, a Catholic, died at the Royal Victoria hospital in west Belfast yesterday, hours before the inclusive power-sharing executive took control from Westminster for the second time in seven months. He was shot in a pub in Dunmurry, just outside south Belfast, on Sunday evening.

Senior IRA figures are believed to have threatened Mr McCoy, a father-of-one, with assassination last year over his drug-dealing activities. He left his home, close to Dunmurry, soon afterwards, but is thought recently to have returned to the area, close to republican west Belfast.

Police, who rejected a sectarian motive, believed the murder was drugs-related. They were unable to say who was responsible, but refused to rule out terrorist involvement.

Hugh Lewsley, SDLP councillor in nearby Twinbrook, in west Belfast, said he was convinced that the IRA was responsible. So was Vincent McKenna, director of the Human Rights Bureau.

But the burned out car used in the attack was found in Derriaghy, a loyalist area, and police are also investigating whether Mr McCoy was a victim of a gangland feud.

The IRA is thought to have been been responsible for five other murders in Northern Ireland since the Good Friday agreement was sealed two years ago, three of them drugs-related. It is also suspected of five killings in the Irish Republic, all connected to the drugs trade.

As unionists, both supporters and opponents of the agreement, called on Sir Ronnie Flanagan, RUC chief constable, to clarify who was responsible, David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, was left in a difficult position. He said it was too early to comment.

Mr McCoy died 12 hours after he was shot in the Mott'n'Bailey bar. Two men, one disguised in a wig and false moustache, burst into the bar and singled him out.

Mr Trimble criticised the on-going loyalist feud yesterday. Ulster Volunteer Force members are suspected of firing about 30 shots at the home of an alleged Loyalist Volunteer Force member in Ballgowan, Co Down. Mr Trimble said: "This underlines the need for decommissioning and underlines the responsibility for mainstream loyalist paramilitaries to address that issue."

Yesterday's apprehension, more acute than in November, when the euphoria of a power-sharing executive for the first time in 25 years temporarily outweighed nagging doubts, was fuelled further as the Irish police held seven more republican dissidents. They have been gaining strength since the IRA's offer two weeks ago to put arms beyond use.

Gardai had earlier released eight members of the Real IRA held last week. They included the former IRA quartermaster, the leader of the Real IRA, the group behind the Omagh car bombing which killed 29 people in August 1998.

Mr Trimble was back at Parliament Buildings, Stormont, to begin restoring relations with Seamus Mallon, deputy first minister. He confirmed there would be talks soon on the controversial flags issue. The 12-member executive is due to meet on Thursday. It is understood Friday is a designated day for flying the Union Flag over government buildings.

Mr Trimble hoped the Rubicon had been crossed. If the IRA fulfilled its commitment and allowed weapons inspectors to look at some of its arms dumps, it would alleviate Ulster Unionist worries. The party's ruling council on Saturday backed a return to devolution by 53 to 47%.

Mr Mallon hoped General John de Chastelain, chairman of the decommissioning body, would be able to issue a positive statement by the end of June.
fields.bodyText: Detectives were last night investigating whether there was IRA involvement in the shooting dead of a suspected drugs dealer near Belfast, an execution exacerbating Ulster Unionist jitters as they again joined government with republicans. Powers were devolved to Northern Ireland at midnight. Edmund McCoy, 28, a Catholic, died at the Royal Victoria hospital in west Belfast yesterday, hours before the inclusive power-sharing executive took control from Westminster for the second time in seven months. He was shot in a pub in Dunmurry, just outside south Belfast, on Sunday evening. Senior IRA figures are believed to have threatened Mr McCoy, a father-of-one, with assassination last year over his drug-dealing activities. He left his home, close to Dunmurry, soon afterwards, but is thought recently to have returned to the area, close to republican west Belfast. Police, who rejected a sectarian motive, believed the murder was drugs-related. They were unable to say who was responsible, but refused to rule out terrorist involvement. Hugh Lewsley, SDLP councillor in nearby Twinbrook, in west Belfast, said he was convinced that the IRA was responsible. So was Vincent McKenna, director of the Human Rights Bureau. But the burned out car used in the attack was found in Derriaghy, a loyalist area, and police are also investigating whether Mr McCoy was a victim of a gangland feud. The IRA is thought to have been been responsible for five other murders in Northern Ireland since the Good Friday agreement was sealed two years ago, three of them drugs-related. It is also suspected of five killings in the Irish Republic, all connected to the drugs trade. As unionists, both supporters and opponents of the agreement, called on Sir Ronnie Flanagan, RUC chief constable, to clarify who was responsible, David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, was left in a difficult position. He said it was too early to comment. Mr McCoy died 12 hours after he was shot in the Mott'n'Bailey bar. Two men, one disguised in a wig and false moustache, burst into the bar and singled him out. Mr Trimble criticised the on-going loyalist feud yesterday. Ulster Volunteer Force members are suspected of firing about 30 shots at the home of an alleged Loyalist Volunteer Force member in Ballgowan, Co Down. Mr Trimble said: "This underlines the need for decommissioning and underlines the responsibility for mainstream loyalist paramilitaries to address that issue." Yesterday's apprehension, more acute than in November, when the euphoria of a power-sharing executive for the first time in 25 years temporarily outweighed nagging doubts, was fuelled further as the Irish police held seven more republican dissidents. They have been gaining strength since the IRA's offer two weeks ago to put arms beyond use. Gardai had earlier released eight members of the Real IRA held last week. They included the former IRA quartermaster, the leader of the Real IRA, the group behind the Omagh car bombing which killed 29 people in August 1998. Mr Trimble was back at Parliament Buildings, Stormont, to begin restoring relations with Seamus Mallon, deputy first minister. He confirmed there would be talks soon on the controversial flags issue. The 12-member executive is due to meet on Thursday. It is understood Friday is a designated day for flying the Union Flag over government buildings. Mr Trimble hoped the Rubicon had been crossed. If the IRA fulfilled its commitment and allowed weapons inspectors to look at some of its arms dumps, it would alleviate Ulster Unionist worries. The party's ruling council on Saturday backed a return to devolution by 53 to 47%. Mr Mallon hoped General John de Chastelain, chairman of the decommissioning body, would be able to issue a positive statement by the end of June.

fields.headline: Sex slaves trafficked to UK
fields.standfirst: Trafficking of sex slaves to UK grows
fields.trailText: More than 1,000 women may be trapped into sexual slavery in Britain each year amid a boom in the illegal trafficking of women from eastern Europe, ministers will be warned this week.
fields.body:
More than 1,000 women may be trapped into sexual slavery in Britain each year amid a boom in the illegal trafficking of women from eastern Europe, ministers will be warned this week.

A study commissioned by the Home Office on the trafficking of women into the UK for prostitution, the first attempt to assess the extent of the trade, is expected to argue that significant changes in police tactics and laws to punish criminal gangs profiting from the trade are needed to tackle the problem. Many police forces pay little attention to trafficking, unintentionally creating a "climate of toleration", ministers will be told.

Det Insp Paul Holmes, of the Metropolitan police clubs and vice squad, has warned that Britain is on course to suffer the same level of violence that has accompanied the trade in women in other western European countries. He said trafficking inevitably led to violent turf wars between organised gangs.

Police estimate that three-quarters of women in the Soho sex trade come from overseas, some working under coercion.

Ministers admit to deep concern over evidence that traf ficking is on the increase in cities and even smaller towns in the UK.

Women from the Balkan states and the former Soviet bloc, as well as south-east Asia and Africa, are charged thousands of pounds by criminal middlemen for visas or a smuggling arrangement to enter the country, often on the promise that they can pay off the balance of the fee in arrears by working for a few months in the sex industry or the "entertainment business".

On arrival in the UK, their documents are snatched and they find they are enslaved in prostitution in massage parlours or brothels while they pay off previously unmentioned "debts" amounting to further vast sums. They may be forced to have unprotected sex or engage in activities refused by other prostitutes.

Only a handful are prepared to report crimes against them for a variety of reasons: fear of the police because of experience of corruption in public authorities in their home countries, concern that they will be expelled from the UK or their families punished, and lack of language skills or the freedom to make a complaint.

For the traffickers, access to the multimillion-pound trade is highly lucrative, and the penalties are lower than for smuggling drugs or guns. A report by the European parliament's women's rights and equal opportunities committee highlights growing violence as the trade increases, and calls for a common European definition of trafficking and harmonised policy on tackling offenders and protecting victims.

The Home Office minister Barbara Roche last night said the growth in the trafficking of women, including illegal smuggling of people into Britain, was "deeply worrying and something I am really concerned about". She said: "This is a growing problem, and a very serious criminal activity. Very vulnerable people, including in some cases children, are being trafficked."

Addressing the problem required international cooperation and sharing of information, Ms Roche said. Recent UK legislation to tackle the "smuggling" of illegal immigrants would also help.

However, ministers are not yet prepared to commit to legal change specifically to tackle the trade in women, though they will consider recommendations in the Stopping Traffic study conducted on behalf of the Home Office by academics at the University of North London's child and women abuse studies unit (Cwasu), to be published on Friday.

The research, estimating that the numbers of women trafficked into the UK in 1998 alone could be up to 1,400, is expected to show that most police forces have limited knowledge of trafficking, and pay the problem little attention. While the study will praise the "pro- active approach" of the Met and acknowledge that other hard-pressed forces have limited resources, it will warn of the danger that sidelining the problem "unintentionally creates a climate of toleration for trafficking of women".

It will urge more intelligence gathering on off-street prostitution, particularly the numbers of foreign women, and recommends the creation of a new crime of sexual exploitation to help pin down traffickers. Other recommendations will include allowing trafficked women to sue their exploiters, and that the Department for International Development and the Foreign Office should focus on prevention campaigns in host countries.

Linda Egan, senior reseach officer at Cwasu and co-author of the report with the unit's director, Professor Liz Kelly, said: "There is no doubt that some women are being held in the UK in sexual slavery with no control over their lives. What you are talking about with some of these women is being raped day in, day out."

webTitle: Britain joins EU push on crime

fields.headline: Britain joins EU push on crime
fields.trailText: Britain's request to join a European-wide crime database with access to details on 14m stolen vehicles, firearms and fugitives was approved by EU partners yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain's request to join a European-wide crime database with access to details on 14m stolen vehicles, firearms and fugitives was approved by EU partners yesterday.

In another sign of increased cooperation with Europe over policing, UK immigration officials are to be allowed to operate in France to check Eurostar services for illegal immigrants and asylum seekers heading towards Britain.

Ministers also agreed that police could tap the telephones of suspects living in other member states.

But Britain continued its pick and mix approach to Europe by remaining outside the wider Schengen agreement which has loosened border controls between several states.

In another sign of increased cooperation with Europe over policing, UK immigration officials are to be allowed to operate in France to check Eurostar services for illegal immigrants and asylum seekers heading towards Britain. Ministers also agreed that police could tap the telephones of suspects living in other member states. But Britain continued its pick and mix approach to Europe by remaining outside the wider Schengen agreement which has loosened border controls between several states.

fields.headline: Dando murder suspect in court
fields.standfirst: More about the Jill Dando case
fields.trailText: The man accused of murdering the TV presenter Jill Dando on her doorstep last year made his first appearance in court yesterday.
fields.body:
The man accused of murdering the TV presenter Jill Dando on her doorstep last year made his first appearance in court yesterday.

Barry Michael George, 40, spoke in a firm voice to state his name and give his address as a housing association flat in Crookham Road, Fulham, south-west London.

George, also known as Bulsara, then sat in silence in the dock before west London magistrates in Hammersmith, his hands clasped in front of him.

He heard Alison Saunders, assistant chief crown prosecutor, ask for eight weeks to prepare papers to commit the case for trial at the Old Bailey.

Ms Saunders also asked for a court order to prevent publication of sketches that would clearly identify George. She said there had been a great deal of media interest in the case and warned that identification was a key issue for the prosecution.

An identity parade is to be conducted next month, the court heard.

Granting the order, Justin Phillips, stipendiary magistrate, said: "Mr George's right to a fair investigation and trial must never be compromised."

He said publication of photographs of George, which is not covered by the Magistrates Court Act, would undoubtedly lead to the intervention of the attorney general.

Maryan Syed, counsel for George, did not seek bail.

In court were Det Chief Insp Hamish Campbell, who is leading the investigation, and dozens of people in the public gallery. George, wearing a bright blue short-sleeved shirt and tan trousers, spoke once more during the 22-minute hearing.

Mr Phillips told him he was being remanded in custody. He said the charge he faced made this "a special case" that would be better dealt with by the chief magistrate at Bow Street court in central London.

He told George the case would be listed for mention at Bow Street on June 5 but that he would not have to attend the hearing unless he wanted to.

Asked if he understood the ruling, George, an unemployed musician, said: "Yes sir." He was then led to the cells by two security guards.

George was arrested last Thursday and questioned before being charged on Sunday afternoon.

Dando was shot in the head at point blank range at her Fulham home on April 26 last year after returning from a shopping trip.

webTitle: Answer me: Getting personal with... Maury Povich

fields.headline: Answer me: Getting personal with... Maury Povich
fields.trailText: How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Shy, retiring, private person searching for love in all the wrong places. No pets allowed.
fields.body:
Full Name: Maurice Richard Povich

Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? No, because the two things my mother would've been upset if I'd changed were my name and my nose.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? No, and unfortunately now I would like to, it's too late.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Shy, retiring, private person searching for love in all the wrong places. No pets allowed.

What was the last illegal thing you did? I'm sure I've ingested drugs illegally. I can't remember exactly when, but it was long enough ago that I'm comfortable admitting it now.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Dyed Easter eggs with my son.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? My wife (Connie Chung). I was fired soon after.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? VA

Has a critic ever made you cry? No, but they've made me angry. And, if they're still alive, I usually call them. I have no problem doing that because I respect what they do, but want to set them straight if they've erred.

What would you advertise without a fee? Adoption. And I've done a lot of non-profit work against drunk-driving.

What would you never advertise? I've never done a commercial for personal profit, nor would I ever.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? Dreams, or rather nightmares, about my golf game.

What takes you to a "happy place"? A good stiff scotch before dinner

Maury Povich appears every weekday on UK Living

webTitle: Passport control: Who's in town, and why

fields.headline: Passport control: Who's in town, and why
fields.trailText: It's not every day we greet someone who might have changed the world. But heading up to Oxford to do a talk at the Goodman Library, Oxford University (don't tell Gordon) is Shere Hite.
fields.body:
I'll have what she's having... It's not every day we greet someone who might have changed the world. But heading up to Oxford to do a talk at the Goodman Library, Oxford University (don't tell Gordon) is Shere Hite. Of course, you might be under the impression that Hite is just another one of those hairspray-addicted, self-promoting American feminists. But if you believe her supporters, it was 1976's The Hite Report On Female Sexuality that blew the myth of the vaginal orgasm. After which nothing was really the same again. A nation's women offer their thanks, and even a few of the men...

You the Don... A hearty welcome back to former London resident Donald Sutherland (pictured), appearing on the West End stage for the first time in 36 years. Big Donald left Canada for the Smoke in the 50s to learn his craft - getting a formal education as an actor and, more importantly, picking up guest villain slots on The Avengers, Man In A Suitcase and The Saint, vital training for the dodgy bad guy roles that have kept him in house and home for the last two decades. Still, for his early 70s films and accompanying political activism, he earned the right to make any number of lousy thrillers starring Charlie - sorry, Charles - Sheen. Or even Kate Bush videos. You can find him at the Savoy, starring in Eric-Emmanuel Schmitt's Enigma Variations, as adapted by Donald's son Roeg...

Punch the clock... Meanwhile, Public Enemy are back in our midst, playing at Homelands Scotland on Saturday the 3rd and the Stratford Rex on the 5th. But more to the point, Flavor Flav will be here in July doing solo shows. For those of us who've been entranced by the complex and often troubled figure of William Drayton for 14 years now, that merits a big "yeah, boyeeeeee" all round...

fields.headline: No: 1645 David Barber
fields.trailText: It might be my cataracts again, but I think you'll find that's a picture of a swan.
fields.body:
Age: 50.

It might be my cataracts again, but I think you'll find that's a picture of a swan. And not just any swan either, my friend. That swan, along with all other unmarked mute swans in open water in Great Britain, belongs to the Queen.

And it's called David Barber? Funny name for a swan. Now you're just being facetious. Barber, as every obsessive consumer of royal trivia knows, is the Queen's Swan Marker. (Unfortunately, he couldn't be with us for this Pass Notes, what with all the swan-marking and everything.)

Sounds to me like an increasingly absurd ceremonial position, shorn of all meaning and quite unsuited to the 21st century. Like I said, he is employed by the monarchy.

So what exactly does his job involve? Each year, Barber and his assistants don funny jackets, climb into rowing boats and make a five-day census of the swan population from London to Abingdon. Swans belonging by ancient right to the vintners' and dyers' livery companies are marked accordingly; the rest are Brenda's. Got that?

Just about. But why are you telling me this? Apparently, shops have been dumping unsold sandwiches into the Thames at Reading, and the bad diet is making them thin. Barber wants the illicit sarnie-dumpers prosecuted.

What use does the Queen have for swans anyway? Once, the poor dears were destined for the royal table. Now, Barber acts as an environmental watchdog - Ofswan, as it were.

And his is not the only such preposterously anachronistic royal sinecure either, I'll warrant. How right you are. Barber is unpaid, but Cedric Robinson, the Queen's Guide over Kent Sands, makes a cool £15 a year - and he has never even guided the Queen over Kent Sands.

Not to be confused with: The Washer of the Sovereign's Hands; The Lord High Admiral of the Wash; The Hereditary Bearer of the National Flag of Scotland; The Queen's Hereditary Falconer.

webTitle: Revealed: hidden art behind the gospel truth

fields.headline: Revealed: hidden art behind the gospel truth
fields.standfirst: Drawings throw new light on a prime sourcebook of English Christianity - and the Venerable Bede's role in it
fields.trailText: Sixty previously undetected drawings have been discovered in the Lindisfarne Gospels - nearly 1,300 years after the illuminated Latin manuscript was created as one of the world's greatest artistic treasures.
fields.body:
Sixty previously undetected drawings have been discovered in the Lindisfarne Gospels - nearly 1,300 years after the illuminated Latin manuscript was created as one of the world's greatest artistic treasures.

The discovery, made by a senior British Library scholar using a high-magnification binocular microscope, was said yesterday to show that the volume marked the birth of the first distinctively and proudly "English" culture.

Another key finding of the research is that the dating of the gospels - one of the prime sourcebooks of English Christianity - should be moved forward from the long-accepted AD698 to about AD720.

This means that the Venerable Bede, author of the first English history book, is now thought likely to have also been involved in producing the masterpiece.

The drawings have been identified by Michelle Brown, curator of illuminated manuscripts at the British Library. She disclosed this at the weekend in a 23-page lecture, with 130 footnotes, to an astonished audience of scholars in Bede's seventh century church at Jarrow, close to the site of the original Lindisfarne monastery on Holy Island, Northumberland.

Last night she said, "The audience all leapt up in their seats. It was the most incredible feeling".

Study of the drawings, discovered on the back of calf hide parchment, established them as by far the earliest known use of a metal-point pen, a forerunner of the pencil. No other metal-point drawings are known to have existed before 1100.

In many of the drawings, the artist also used paint that washed through to the front of the parchment. This can still be faintly seen. But the metal-point outlines are invisible to the naked eye.

Some traces of drawings were noted when the Lindisfarne Gospels were last closely examined at the British Museum in the 1950s. Ms Brown said they were not found then, partly because microscope technology was less advanced.

"I went looking for them. It was a bit like looking at an archaeological site."

She used steeply angled light. "Lo and behold, the drawings were there - like the plough marks you get in a field."

Invasions

What she had discovered was a series of practice sketches on every page of the manuscript. They were the doodle-pads used by a monk working in an era of recurrent invasions, when monasteries in remote, rocky places such as Lindisfarne were refuges of learning and art.

The artist is believed to be Eadfrith, bishop of Lindisfarne from 698 to 721. A note inserted in the manuscript two centuries later said he "originally wrote this book in honour of God and St Cuthbert and the whole company of saints whose relics are on the island".

He practised script letters, visible under the microscope as ridges and furrows in parchment. He also tried out preliminary versions of flowers, birds and other images. He did this preparatory work on the backs of parchments because calf hide was too expensive to be used as sketchpaper. The significance of the styles in which he drew will be the topic of scholarly analysis and theory for decades.

Ms Brown said these indicated that he was "consciously creating a new English culture". The sketches proved that he had begun by planning to write the gospels in a traditional Roman half-uncial script familiar from the culture of Lindisfarne's more civilised mother churches in Rome and the Mediterranean. But in his finished manuscript, he changed tack radically. He fused this style with Anglo-Saxon runic letters, some of them only seen before on pagan inscriptions.

"He was grafting these on to Mediterranean script," Ms Brown said. "He was having to make up his font as he went along. It was a conscious decision. It was the first time runic figures had been used in a book."

webTitle: Russia refuses to clear Stalin aide

fields.headline: Russia refuses to clear Stalin aide
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A request to rehabilitate the sinister figure of Lavrenty Beria, who as head of Josef Stalin's secret police was complicit in the deaths of millions of innocent Soviet citizens, was rejected yesterday by Russia's supreme court.
fields.body:
A request to rehabilitate the sinister figure of Lavrenty Beria, who as head of Josef Stalin's secret police was complicit in the deaths of millions of innocent Soviet citizens, was rejected yesterday by Russia's supreme court.

Human rights activists expressed relief at the conclusion to the case, which has threatened to undermine the work of the military prosecutor's rehabilitation department to salvage the reputations of Stalin's victims.

Beria's son has championed a campaign to pardon the former NKVD chief (the internal security organ which later became the KGB) on the grounds that most of the charges for which he was executed in 1953 were absurd concoctions.

Shortly after Stalin's death, Beria was arrested and accused of anti-state terrorism and high treason - charges which included the unlikely allegation that he was a British spy.

In the struggle for power that followed Stalin's death, Beria's rivals wanted to see him removed as quickly as possible and the ludicrous spying charge is thought to have been included to strengthen the case for his swift execution.

A detailed list of preliminary charges claimed that he had attempted to undermine the country's cattle-breeding and vegetable production programmes.

Many of the crimes for which he is remembered - including the deportation of ethnic groups from the Caucasus and the incarceration of thousands of anti-Soviet dissidents - were deemed too sensitive to mention on the charge sheet. Lawyers had argued that there might be a case for a review on strictly legal grounds - because although there was abundant evidence of Beria's general guilt there was little evidence that he was guilty of the key accusations against him.

According to the law on rehabilitation in Russia, if someone has been wrongly executed on false charges, they have the right to have their name cleared posthumously. However, the supreme court, made up of military judges, ruled yesterday that this could not apply to Beria or the several police officials shot alongside him.

The court concluded that the rules governing the rehabilitation of victims of repression should not be applied to senior officials who were themselves responsible for the repression.

Arseny Roginsky, president of the human rights group Memorial, which works to clear the names of victims of Soviet-era repressions, said any other outcome would have been unacceptable. "Beria was convicted of crimes that he was not guilty of, but he was nevertheless a guilty man."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two arrested over eggs
fields.body:
Two arrested over eggs

Two men from the north of England have been arrested in connection with the alleged possession of rare eggs from black-throated divers which are protected under law. They were arrested in the Sutherland area of the Scottish Highlands. There are only 156 pairs of the birds in Scotland.

Internet sex case remand

A man accused of underage sex with girls he met through internet chat rooms was remanded in custody by magistrates in High Wycombe, Buckinghamshire, yesterday. Patrick Green, 33, of Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, is accused of offences including unlawful sex and abduction.

Big cheese wins on a roll

Thousands watched the ancient sport of cheese rolling on a 300 yard slope on Cooper's Hill in Brockworth near Cheltenham yesterday. The winner was Craig Brown, 26, a pub landlord from Gloucester.

College offers for 12-year-olds

Promising 12-year-olds have been offered university places in an attempt to improve exam results in Hull, which is bottom of the national list for GCSE results. About 96% of the 360 students who attended classes where they were taught about skills required for higher education are expected to receive conditional offers to Hull University or the University of Humberside and Lincolnshire, six years before they are able to attend.

Seven Real IRA suspects held

Police in the Irish Republic yesterday arrested another seven suspected Real IRA activists under the offences against the state act. They were detained after raids in Dublin and Limerick. The group killed 29 people in the Omagh bombing.

Body found

The decapitated body of a man was found yesterday by a man walking his dog near a car park at Cofton Park, Rednal, Birmingham.

webTitle: US refuses to back down on export subsidies

fields.headline: US refuses to back down on export subsidies
fields.trailText: The United States said yesterday that it would press ahead with its plans for overhauling a multi-billion-dollar export programme despite objections from the European Union.
fields.body:
The United States said yesterday that it would press ahead with its plans for overhauling a multi-billion-dollar export programme despite objections from the European Union.

The EU rejected a US proposal aimed at bringing the foreign sales corporation programme - which offers tax breaks to American exporters - into line with global trade rules, saying that it did not meet basic World Trade Organisation requirements.

The WTO ruled in February that the FSC programme was an illegal export subsidy and gave the US until October 1 to revise it. The FSC covers hundreds of billions of dollars of exports and provides US companie with tax concessions which some estimates say could reach $4.1bn (£2.7bn) in 2001.

In response, President Clinton's administration said it would replace the FSC programme with special income tax rates for foreign sales by eligible manufacturers. The commission said that US companies would still have to export to benefit from the scheme - the very aspect of the original programme that had been condemned by the WTO.

Deputy US treasury secretary Stuart Eizenstat said Washington could challenge similar European tax schemes if Brussels dug in.

Mr Eizenstat warned that the dispute could lead to a backlash in Congress against the Geneva-based WTO. Congress will vote later this year on renewed US membership of the trade body, which sets global trading rules.

"We regret that the commission has chosen not to engage in serious negotiations based on our proposal," Mr Eizenstat said.

"It is our intention to work with the bipartisan leadership of Congress to pass legislation based on our approach, in the time frame set by the WTO ... While we are working with Congress, we hope the European commission will recon sider its position and demonstrate its willingness to commence serious negotiations."

Mr Eizenstat said Washington did not have time for drawn out negotiations with the EU because of elections due in November. Mr Eizenstat warned Brussels to back down or face an increase in friction on trade between the US and the EU.

webTitle: Lebanese detainees yet to smell freedom

fields.headline: Lebanese detainees yet to smell freedom
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A Lebanese guerrilla leader and a cleric - held by Israel as pawns to gain information on a missing aviator - were produced in open court yesterday for the first time since they were kidnapped in 1989 and 1994.
fields.body:
A Lebanese guerrilla leader and a cleric - held by Israel as pawns to gain information on a missing aviator - were produced in open court yesterday for the first time since they were kidnapped in 1989 and 1994.

Pale in their prison uniforms and guarded by four military policemen, the two men - Mustafa Dirani, the security chief of the Amal Shia militia, and Sheikh Abdel Karim Obeid, a Hizbullah spiritual leader, appeared unfazed by the legions of Israeli cameramen climbing over the seats of the Tel Aviv courtroom before proceedings began.

Sheikh Obeid, kidnapped in 1989, had a large bruise on his forehead - not uncommon among those who bow in Muslim prayer five times a day. Mr Dirani, kidnapped in 1994, spoke a few animated sentences to the packed courtroom before he was silenced.

After Israel's retreat from south Lebanon last week, the two men are the subject of growing international attention, with the argument that the two are a threat to the Jewish state becoming increasingly untenable.

"How much blood will there be until they can be released?" Zvi Rish, the prisoners' lawyer, asked reporters. "We should end this march of follies and open a new chapter."

Hizbullah guerrillas, the new rulers of the abandoned strip of Israel-occupied south Lebanon, have said they will continue to attack Israel until Sheikh Obeid, Mr Dirani and 15 other Lebanese are freed from Israeli jails.

The United Nations envoy Terje Roed-Larsen has also called on Israel to end their detention - which is in violation of international law - saying on Sunday that "their release would give an additional impetus to the restoration of international peace and security".

However, Judge Uri Goren, after hearing arguments about whether the two men pose a security threat to the Jewish state, yesterday reserved his decision until July 12.

The prime minister, Ehud Barak, is expected to roll over another in the series of three-month detention orders under which the two captives have been held.

Despite yesterday's events, the two men's liberty will be determined by Israeli public opinion, not legal argument, Mr Rish said. "The judge will see the situation. If there is quiet on the Lebanese border, then he will be ready to release them because the street will be in a position to accept it. But if there is violence there will be another decision."

The families of aviator Ron Arad and other Israelis missing in action were at yesterday's proceedings. For them and for the Israeli authorities the two diminutive men in the Tel Aviv court have become larger than life.

Thirteen fellow hostages were freed last month after supreme court judges ruled that the men were not a threat to state security, but merely human currency to buy information on missing soldiers. But Mr Dirani and Sheikh Obeid are bigger prizes.

Arad, who was shot down over Lebanon in 1986, was once in Mr Dirani's custody, and the government has been considering legislation to allow his indefinite detention.

"Should we return people who will become a symbol of a terrorist war against Israel?" asked Dvora Chen, the state attorney. "Do you really think they will go back to Lebanon and grow roses?"

The men have become heroes in Lebanon. In a brief statement permitted by the judge, Mr Dirani said that he had no intention of waging war, but he warned: "Unless we are freed, there will be attacks on Israel." His Hebrew translator failed to relay the threat to the courtroom.

Yesterday, authorities on both sides of the border moved to defuse tensions heightened on Sunday when Israeli troops fired on Lebanese protesters, injuring three people. Israel announced that it would move out veterans from the occupation zone who have been facing down crowds of taunting Lebanese.

Ron Arad: the missing airman

Ron Arad, an air force navigator, was shot down over Lebanon in 1986 and seized by Lebanese Shi'ite Muslim guerrillas.

He has not been seen for more than a decade. One report suggested he had been transferred to Iran after Israel attacked the Lebanese city of Maidoon, where the airman was being held captive.

His case has be come a cause celebre in Israel. Even the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, met his relatives during an official visit to Jerusalem.

Iran has always insisted it has no knowledge of the fate of Arad.

webTitle: Railtrack funding of Channel rail link in doubt again

fields.headline: Railtrack funding of Channel rail link in doubt again
fields.trailText: Railtrack's £3.5bn funding of the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link was in doubt last night as the company prepared to ask the government for more investment to help its capital projects.
fields.body:
Railtrack's £3.5bn funding of the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link was in doubt last night as the company prepared to ask the government for more investment to help its capital projects.

A final decision is not expected until the July meeting of Railtrack's board, but increasing problems with other big projects, notably the completion of the west coast main line between Glasgow and London, may force Railtrack to relinquish some projects to other companies.

Railtrack said yesterday that it was committed to the completion of the line, but industry sources believe that it cannot achieve its objective. Railtrack's main partner, Virgin Trains, is desperate for the project to be completed and would prefer not to become involved in a legal battle with Railtrack over possible compensation of £250m.

Ministers are becoming increasingly concerned that Railtrack will not be able to deliver the high profile projects to which it is commiited.

The big three are the west coast main line, the Channel tunnel link, and Thameslink 2000, the widening of north-south rail links across central London.

They believe that it might be better for Railtrack to split up into a project management company, keeping overall control of the infrastructure, but allowing individual companies to carry out the work.

Railtrack has not yet given the thumbs down to the second stage of the Channel tunnel rail link from just south of the M25 into St Pancras in central London. But it is the most difficult and most expensive section.

It will pass mainly in tunnels through heavily populated parts of south and east London before turning west at Stratford towards St Pancras. Infrastructure projects like these have an uncanny knack of becoming far more costly than originally planned.

Railtrack executives, having grossly underestimated the west coast main line costs which have more than doubled from £2.2bn to £5.4bn in less than two years, are just as anxious about the funding of the Channel tunnel rail link.

The final cost of the second stage is already expected to be more than the £3.5bn announced two years ago.

The first stage, from Folkestone, is well under way and is expected to be finished ahead of schedule.

It is on schedule to be opened by 2003 cutting the journey time between London and Paris by 20 minutes to two hours, 40 minutes.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, is due to open the tunnel which cuts through the North Downs in Kent next month.

Mr Prescott is interested in infrastucture companies taking over work which Railtrack is finding difficult to complete. He was pleased at the work done by the American company, Bechtel, which was called in by London Transport to help complete the Jubilee line extension to the Underground.

The same company is advising Govia, the group which runs Thameslink, on its bid to take over the south central rail franchise. It operates commuter services from Surrey and Sussex into central London.

Keith Ludeman, managing director of Govia's train division, says that Bechtel has given the group considerable assistance on its proposed £1.5bn investment programme for upgrading the network and providing new rolling stock.

webTitle: Israel grants rights to lesbian mothers

fields.headline: Israel grants rights to lesbian mothers
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's supreme court yesterday ignored dark mutterings about a modern-day Sodom and Gomorrah, granting a lesbian couple equal rights as mothers to their son.
fields.body:
Israel's supreme court yesterday ignored dark mutterings about a modern-day Sodom and Gomorrah, granting a lesbian couple equal rights as mothers to their son.

The ruling, which confirms Nicole Brener Kadish as the adoptive mother of her partner's biological son, Mattan, is the first of its kind in Israel. It also sets an international precedent by recognising an adoption by a lesbian couple that was formalised elsewhere.

"This means that the court has recognised that a child can have two mothers," said Hadas Tagari of the Association for Civil Rights in Israel. "The fact that both women are recognised as mothers to the same child means that there is indirectly recognition of the lesbian family."

For Nicole Brener Kadish and her partner Ruthy Brener Kadish, who had Mattan in California, before returning to Israel, the victory was the end of a year-long legal campaign.

Although Nicole had legally adopted the child in California, Israel's interior ministry refused to honour that ruling on the grounds that both parents were of the same sex.

Yesterday, the interior minister, Natan Sharansky, said he would order officials to honour the court's decision.

fields.headline: Orange chief plans global operation
fields.standfirst: £30bn deal with France Telecom paves way for flotation next year
fields.trailText: Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, and Graham Howe, his long-standing business partner, will today outline plans to turn the mobile phone network into a global brand through the pooling of its assets with France Telecom's Itineris mobile business and a flotation of the new group in London by early next year.
fields.body:
Hans Snook, chief executive of Orange, and Graham Howe, his long-standing business partner, will today outline plans to turn the mobile phone network into a global brand through the pooling of its assets with France Telecom's Itineris mobile business and a flotation of the new group in London by early next year.

After last minute negotiations which spanned the holiday weekend, Vodafone, Europe's leading mobile operator, is due to announce this morning that it has agreed to sell Orange to France Telecom for a total of £30bn - fulfilling the regulatory requirement to dispose of the business set down as a condition of the takeover of Germany's Mannesmann.

Vodafone is likely to receive just under £25bn in a mixture of cash and shares, with France Telecom taking on an additional £6bn of debt. The deal is believed to have been structured so that the British company is left with a non-voting stake of 10% in France Telecom, which both companies hope will be acceptable to Europe's competition authorities.

France Telecom has built a strong mobile phone franchise within France through Itineris, which is the market leader with over 10m subscribers. But, having so far struggled to develop the business internationally, it will now effectively hand over management control of the newly enlarged group to Mr Snook and his team, who had made it clear they would resign rather than see Orange go to a parent which did not share their vision of a wireless future.

Putting Itineris and Orange together will give the new group operations in eight European countries, including France and the UK, and also Hong Kong, Israel and Australia. While the Itineris name will not disappear immediately, it is envisaged that all new products, including the roll-out of so-called third generation services, will be branded as Orange.

The business will be demerged from France Telecom as soon as possible, although advisers do not expect a flota tion of a minority stake in the business on the London stock market before 2001.

The sale of Orange was expected to involve a protracted battle for control, with both Dutch carrier KPN Telecom and America's MCI WorldCom having expressed interest. At the same time, Mr Snook initially argued that the business should be floated off by Vodafone as an independent entity.

But Vodafone's thirst for cash, exacerbated by the costly British auction for third generation licences which is now likely to be copied across Europe, made a trade sale to a big competitor inevitable. Vodafone alone is estimated to be facing a £20bn bill to secure network rights and build its infrastructure across the continent.

fields.headline: In a state of cruelty
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: I was struck by two profound quotations from top people in Israel reacting to last week's historic retreat from the Lebanon. The first was from Ephraim Seh, head of Israel's armed forces. He was explaining his decision to allow soldiers from the defeated mercenary South Lebanon Army to enter and settle in Israel. He said he was initially reluctant to welcome his former allies because "it is very cruel to turn someone into a refugee".
fields.body:
I was struck by two profound quotations from top people in Israel reacting to last week's historic retreat from the Lebanon. The first was from Ephraim Seh, head of Israel's armed forces. He was explaining his decision to allow soldiers from the defeated mercenary South Lebanon Army to enter and settle in Israel. He said he was initially reluctant to welcome his former allies because "it is very cruel to turn someone into a refugee".

That's very true. It was, for instance, very cruel to throw hundreds of thousands of Palestinians out of their homes in 1948. The Palestinians were turned into refugees, many of them clutching the keys to their homes and bits of paper, bearing the official stamp of the forces of law and order guaranteed by the British mandate in Palestine, establishing their legal rights to their homes and land.

In the half century since, none of these legal titles were enforced by law. Instead, hundreds of thousands more Palestinians have been cruelly turned into refugees, for example after Israel invaded the West Bank of the Jordan in 1967 and illegally occupied yet more territory.

The second quotation came from Ehud Barak, the Israeli prime minister. He delared that any armed person who crossed the border from Lebanon into Israel would be committing "an act of war". This profound interpretation of international law seems to apply in one direction only. If armed forces cross the border from Lebanon into Israel they are committing an act of war.

But when armed forces crossed the border from Israel into Lebanon in 1982, bombing schools, hospitals, towns and villages, there was no talk from Israeli ministers of an act of war. In Beirut, the Israeli invaders unleashed the fascist Falange on the refugees camps of Sabra and Chatila. The Falange militia bravely slaughtered thousands of unarmed Palestinians, mainly women and children.

In his wonderful book about Lebanon, Pity the Nation (1990), Robert Fisk wondered what the dead of the Holocaust would have said had they witnessed the massacre at Chatila, as he had done. What would Anne Frank have said? She had written in disgust about how the Nazis planned to "cleanse" Utrecht of Jews, "as if they were cockroaches". In a committee of the Israeli parliament in 1983, General Rafael Eitan boasted of his triumphs on the West Bank. "All the Arabs will be able to do is scuttle around like drugged cockroaches in a bottle".

 A common mistake made by opponents of Israeli expansionist policies is to assume that everyone in Israel approves them. There are, however, lots of courageous Israelis who are angry and ashamed. I cite only one: Mordecai Vanunu, who committed the unforgivable crime of telling the truth about his government's nuclear policy.

Without Vanunu, we would not know that the butchers of Lebanon have access to nuclear weapons. For this disclosure, Vanunu was seduced in London by an Israeli agent and spirited away from the not-very-watchful eyes of the Sunday Times, whose editors used his story to great acclaim but did not protect their source. His consort took him to Rome. He was knocked out, drugged and whisked off to Askelon prison in Israel where he has spent 14 years, mostly in solitary confinement.

 Not that Israel is alone is wrongfully putting people in prison. In February I met Robert Fisk for the first time at the Savoy Hotel, where he was receiving his umpteenth award for outstanding coverage of international affairs. As we shook hands, he muttered: "I am still looking for Mograbi". Mograbi was the name given to the man who hired the car which was used to bomb the Israeli embassy and offices in Finchley in London in 1994. Jawad Botmeh, the young Palestinian Mograbi persuaded to help him hire the car (without disclosing his purpose), and his friend Samar Alami, were later convicted of conspiring to carry out the bombing.

They claimed from first to last that, as Palestinians campaigning against the Oslo accords for the future of Palestine, they had been set up by Mograbi. Both had cast-iron alibis for the bombing - Alami's emerged by chance and could not have been arranged by her. The prosecution triumphantly produced a document found in Alami's flat which, they alleged, was a map of the bombed buildings in Finchley. Oh dear. The map turned out to be of Sidon in the Lebanon.

In spite of a complete absence of any direct evidence to link them to the bombing (and the complete absence of Mograbi), the two young people were convicted and sent to prison for 20 years. Now that Lebanon is free at last, is it too much to hope for a powerful campaign to free Mordecai Vanunu, Samar Alami and Jawad Botmeh as well?

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: E-chiefs' pay leaps ahead
fields.body:
E-chiefs' pay leaps ahead

Heads of e-businesses are paid 40% more than their peers in traditional organisations, according to a survey published today by work consultancy Hay Management.

The average pay of an internet business boss - whether a start-up or a division within an established firm - is put at just under £141,000 a year, which includes a typical bonus of £24,300.

Average salary and benefits package of a person occupying a role of equivalent size and seniority in Britain's industrial and service sectors is put at just under £101,000, £12,000 of which is usually a bonus.

Iain Smith, managing consultant at Hay, reckons the recent falls in technology stocks, which have taken the shine off share options, have exacerbated the differential. "Top e-people will demand higher and higher salaries -giving them guaranteed remuneration now - in return for working in an increasingly risky environment," he said.

China telecom in £3.5bn IPO

China Unicom, China's second largest telecoms group, is planning to raise up to $5.2bn (£3.5bn) through a flotation on the New York and Hong Kong stock exchanges. The initial public offering will rank as the largest ever for an Asian company outside of Japan.

Unicom, which is an integrated telecoms provider, offering cellular, paging, long-distance and internet services, said it will also be offering stock to institutional investors in Europe and across the rest of Asia.

Launch of online distributor EO

EO, a planned European electronic share distribution service, is being launched on Thursday with John St John, the former head of equity capital markets at American investment bank Lehman Brothers, chief executive of the new venture.

The company aims to act as an on-line distribution platform, linking investment banks with investors ready to support private stock placements and flotations. It is also launching a specialist technology news service, EOnews.net.

Mercosur tie-in for car partners

French carmaker Renault and its Japanese partner Nissan are pursuing a broad operating agreement in South America's Mercosur trade bloc, linking manufacturing, sales, administration and purchasing operations.

They hope to gain 15% market share in the world's third largest trade bloc, comprising Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay and associate members Chile and Bolivia, in 10 years.

Renault is Nissan's largest shareholder with 37% of capital. Earlier this month, the two companies combined their European sales and marketing operations.

Dot.coms still a popular target

A volatile stock market and the wave of adverse publicity affecting internet shares have failed to dampen investor enthusiasm for the "new economy", according to a survey published today.

Carried out by business advisers Deloitte & Touche Corporate Finance, it found that 60% of venture capitalists expected their investments in new economy companies to increase in the next six months.

It also found that internet companies were still a favourite target for investment despite recent high profile failures such as the collapse of online fashion retailer boo.com.

Quinton Barry, head of private equity at Deloitte, said: "High profile dot.com difficulties do not seem to be dampening investment spirits."
