fields.headline: De Beers to abandon cartel
fields.standfirst: Aggressive marketing will replace diamond trade's price-fixing tradition
fields.trailText: De Beers, the diamond producer, is to abandon its 60-year policy of attempting to stabilise supply and demand in the world gemstone trade and concentrate instead on mining and marketing, the Guardian has learned.The move is to be announced on July 12.
fields.body:
De Beers, the diamond producer, is to abandon its 60-year policy of attempting to stabilise supply and demand in the world gemstone trade and concentrate instead on mining and marketing, the Guardian has learned. The move, which will send shock waves through the industry, is to be announced on July 12.

There will be fears of a re-run of the early 1930s, when gems flooded the market and prices collapsed, the event that led to the creation of the De Beers cartel. But the company believes aggressive marketing by the industry as a whole is a better way to boost demand and soak up supply than the operation of what has effectively been a private monopoly.

Henceforth, the company's London-based central selling organisation (CSO) will cease mopping up spare diamond supplies around the world in order to hold up prices, and De Beers generally will abandon its role as international policeman for the industry.

In years gone by, this has involved the use of secret agents, freelance spies and a private intelligence network spanning Europe and Africa.

Now De Beers - shaken by the colossal expense of trying to stabilise the market during the turbulent 1990s - is to put its own shareholders first and aim instead to be the industry's "preferred supplier" rather than buyer and seller of last resort.

To stave off what would otherwise be a glut of stones on the market, De Beers is proposing instead massive sat uration advertising and marketing around the world to beef up demand.

Recent research for the company by Bain, the management consultant, has shown that the advertising-to-sales ratio in the diamond business is just 1%, against 10% for most luxury products.

Managing director Gary Ralfe hopes to use De Beers' dominant position to persuade everyone in the industry to spend much more on marketing, and has confirmed the company is to continue its famous generic advertisements with the slogan "A diamond is forever".

The CSO - which makes no profit at all on its operations - will continue to function, but primarily as the marketing arm of De Beers, whose own mines produce about half the world's diamonds. The accredited brokers and other buyers who, 10 times a year, visit Hatton Garden for the "sights", or London auctions - are to learn on July 12 of "new oper ating measures", according to a De Beers source.

De Beers hit a high point in profit terms in the boom year 1989-90, but the following decade was to cost its shareholders billions of dollars. The break-up of the Soviet Union brought a flood of illicit diamonds on to the market, as did the civil war in Angola.

Meanwhile, demand collapsed in the far east with the slump in Japan and the meltdown of the "tiger" economies in 1997-98.

In 1996, Australia's Argyle mine - the world's largest in terms of quantity - walked out of the De Beers cartel, and by the end of the decade De Beers had effectively abandoned price support for the lowest-quality stones.

The consequence of the diamond glut was that, by 1997- 98, the CSO stockpile of diamonds taken off the market in mopping-up operations had topped $5bn (£3.4bn), from $2.5bn in 1989, equivalent to a year's worth of CSO sales.

It has since been reduced, but the net effect of CSO operations in the 1990s has been that De Beers shareholders made no more money by holding the company's stock than they would have done by opening an ordinary bank account.

Despite the changes, De Beers has ruled out becoming a major player in its own right in the polished diamond business, preferring instead to supply rough stones to the major cutting and polishing centres. The Bain review highlighted the fact that the biggest profit margins in the supply chain are earned at the rough-diamond mining stage.

Historical gems

 The first attempt at a diamond cartel was made by Cecil Rhodes, founder of De Beers, once it became clear the mechanised diamond-mining boom of the late 19th century was producing so many stones that their rarity value was threatened. Rhodes was central control of supply as essential to the manipulation of demand.

 During the great depression, Rhodes' rudimentary cartel broke up and prices sank. In 1934, De Beers chairman Sir Ernest Oppenheimer stopped the rot single handedly by effectively offering to buy all the diamonds in the world. This extraordinary gamble paid off, and the central selling organisation (CSO) was born.

 By the 1950s, diamond smuggling threatened to undermine the cartel as Soviet-bloc countries sought stones for industrial and military purposes and newly affluent western consumers provided a ready market for illicit gems. De Beers hired Sir Percy Sillitoe, head of MI5 from 1946 to 1952, to set up the International Diamond Security Network (IDSO).

 Ian Fleming, the thriller writer, is contacted by an IDSO agent whom he meets in Morocco. The result of their conversations is a series of newspaper articles about the "million carat network", a book,the Diamond Smugglers, and the James Bond novel Diamonds are Forever (1956).

 For much of the post-war period, De Beers was officially barred from contact with both major players in the cold war, the US and USSR. The Soviet Union, a major diamond producer, claimed to have no contact with what it alleged was an offshoot of the racist South African regime. The Americans objected to the CSO cartel on competition grounds.

 In reality, both countries continued to deal with De Beers and the CSO. The Soviet Union maintained the closest relations - out of the public spotlight - while the Americans permitted De Beers executives to travel unmolested in and out of the US provided they stated they were on holiday.

 From the 1950s until the 1970s, and possibly beyond, diamond smuggling was to prove a vicious and cut-throat business, from the Cape to the streets of Antwerp. De Beers is reluctant to discuss its own casualties in the battle to control illicit diamond trading.

 By the 1990s, smuggled gems were fuelling Africa's longest and bitterest civil war, that between Angola's legitimate government, the MPLA, and the rebel forces in the north of the country, Unita. With stones being routinely exchanged for weapons, De Beers felt obliged to amend its mopping-up policy to exclude what became known as "conflict gems".

 Today, the conflict in Sierra Leone is widely believed to involve smuggled diamonds exchanged by rebel forces for weapons. The exchanges take place largely off market, in Ukraine, Bulgaria and elsewhere, and De Beers is powerless to prevent them.

Despite the changes, De Beers has ruled out becoming a major player in its own right in the polished diamond business, preferring instead to supply rough stones to the major cutting and polishing centres. The Bain review highlighted the fact that the biggest profit margins in the supply chain are earned at the rough-diamond mining stage. Historical gems  The first attempt at a diamond cartel was made by Cecil Rhodes, founder of De Beers, once it became clear the mechanised diamond-mining boom of the late 19th century was producing so many stones that their rarity value was threatened. Rhodes was central control of supply as essential to the manipulation of demand.  During the great depression, Rhodes' rudimentary cartel broke up and prices sank. In 1934, De Beers chairman Sir Ernest Oppenheimer stopped the rot single handedly by effectively offering to buy all the diamonds in the world. This extraordinary gamble paid off, and the central selling organisation (CSO) was born.  By the 1950s, diamond smuggling threatened to undermine the cartel as Soviet-bloc countries sought stones for industrial and military purposes and newly affluent western consumers provided a ready market for illicit gems. De Beers hired Sir Percy Sillitoe, head of MI5 from 1946 to 1952, to set up the International Diamond Security Network (IDSO).  Ian Fleming, the thriller writer, is contacted by an IDSO agent whom he meets in Morocco. The result of their conversations is a series of newspaper articles about the "million carat network", a book,the Diamond Smugglers, and the James Bond novel Diamonds are Forever (1956).  For much of the post-war period, De Beers was officially barred from contact with both major players in the cold war, the US and USSR. The Soviet Union, a major diamond producer, claimed to have no contact with what it alleged was an offshoot of the racist South African regime. The Americans objected to the CSO cartel on competition grounds.  In reality, both countries continued to deal with De Beers and the CSO. The Soviet Union maintained the closest relations - out of the public spotlight - while the Americans permitted De Beers executives to travel unmolested in and out of the US provided they stated they were on holiday.  From the 1950s until the 1970s, and possibly beyond, diamond smuggling was to prove a vicious and cut-throat business, from the Cape to the streets of Antwerp. De Beers is reluctant to discuss its own casualties in the battle to control illicit diamond trading.  By the 1990s, smuggled gems were fuelling Africa's longest and bitterest civil war, that between Angola's legitimate government, the MPLA, and the rebel forces in the north of the country, Unita. With stones being routinely exchanged for weapons, De Beers felt obliged to amend its mopping-up policy to exclude what became known as "conflict gems".  Today, the conflict in Sierra Leone is widely believed to involve smuggled diamonds exchanged by rebel forces for weapons. The exchanges take place largely off market, in Ukraine, Bulgaria and elsewhere, and De Beers is powerless to prevent them.

webTitle: Labour in turmoil over candidate selection

fields.headline: Labour in turmoil over candidate selection
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's leadership is facing allegations of a series of stitch-ups in the selection of candidates for next year's expected general election.
fields.body:
Labour's leadership is facing allegations of a series of stitch-ups in the selection of candidates for next year's expected general election.

Unions have been accused of carving up constituencies to exploit the one member, one vote system. Armed with membership lists, they are organising postal votes ahead of hustings when candidates address the membership.

A fall in the number of women Labour MPs is also likely. Labour's goal is for 50-50 men/women representation at Westminster but no formal mechanism has been put in place since a "twinning" process in vacant safe seats was ruled unlawful four years ago.

One member, one vote was intended to clean up selections, which should be finished by July in plenty of time for the expected spring election.

But the current round has been marred by complaints, delays, suspensions and legal action. A rank and file reaction against Downing Street and Millbank has also led to prominent figures dropping out.

"The whole process is a complete mess, a total nightmare. We know it is not working," admitted a senior Labour figure.

Here the Guardian looks at four constituencies where selection has not been plain sailing.

webTitle: Benn aloof from fray as selection plan is 'by the book'

fields.headline: Benn aloof from fray as selection plan is 'by the book'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Benn, the veteran left-winger who is giving up his constituency, the safe Labour seat of Chesterfield, which he has held for the past 16 years, is staying loftily removed from the battle for his succession. "I have deliberately not interested myself in the selection, particularly after the skulduggery with the London mayor," Mr Benn said.
fields.body:
Tony Benn, the veteran left-winger who is giving up his constituency, the safe Labour seat of Chesterfield, which he has held for the past 16 years, is staying loftily removed from the battle for his succession. "I have deliberately not interested myself in the selection, particularly after the skulduggery with the London mayor," Mr Benn said.

Mr Benn will be spared, therefore, from a lengthy saga following the decision by the Labour party's regional director to postpone the Chesterfield selection contest in April.

Conspiracy theorists on the lookout for a Millbank plot to block another leftwing figure like Tony Benn will, however, be disappointed. Cockup rather than conspiracy appears to be the most plausible explanation.

The carefully laid preparations to select a successor to Mr Benn went awry at a meeting on April 29 of Chesterfield Labour party's general committee, called to select a shortlist. As the 15 candidates prepared to make their speeches, Labour's Midlands director, Roy Kennedy, abruptly called the meeting to a halt when it emerged that some of the local members were not eligible to vote. Under strict Labour party rules, the 15 branches in the Chesterfield Labour party were entitled to send one delegate to the general committee meeting for every 10 members.

One local Labour party source said: "It was all a bit of a mess. There's nothing political involved. The records were not up to date, but no one is blaming the local party officers because they are all volunteers."

In a letter to local party members, Mr Kennedy called for application forms to attend the meeting to be sent in by last Friday. The selection meeting is expected to be reconvened in June.

His intervention showed the extreme care with which the Labour party handles its selection contests. Wary of legal challenges from disgruntled activists, the party makes sure that everything is seen to be done by the book.

Whoever wins the selection is virtually guaranteed a seat in parliament. Mr Benn won the seat with a 5,775 majority at the last election, comfortably ahead of the Liberal Democrats in second place.

For such a safe seat, there is some surprise that none of the party's big guns has made a pitch for it. The hopeful candidates included Liz Kendall, a former aide to Harriet Harman; Reg Race, a former Labour MP and aide to Ken Livingstone at the GLC; and Terry Gilby, the mayor of Chesterfield.

webTitle: Boos and hisses greet selection of 'ambitious apparatchik'

fields.headline: Boos and hisses greet selection of 'ambitious apparatchik'
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: When John Mann won the Labour nomination for the solid seat of Bassetlaw in the old Nottinghamshire coalfield there were boos and hisses inside Ryton primary school at Worksop, where the result was announced.
fields.body:
When John Mann won the Labour nomination for the solid seat of Bassetlaw in the old Nottinghamshire coalfield there were boos and hisses inside Ryton primary school at Worksop, where the result was announced.

"They almost came to blows," one witness said later. Certainly the fight to succeed the veteran Joe Ashton, MP since 1968, aroused strong feelings in the constituency which Labour held with a majority of 17,460 in 1997.

Some who plumped for Mr Mann as the safest, most experienced candidate on offer said they feared the wrong choice would cost Labour the seat.

Before and since the ballot this month of the local party's 500 or so members, most of the blame for the row has been directed at Mr Mann, the former engineering union and TUC official who now works at Millbank as the Labour party trade union liaison officer.

Two weeks ago the Leeds-born Mr Mann was the front runner on an interesting shortlist.

He was up against Andrew Hood, a young Blairite who worked as a special adviser in Whitehall - first to the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and now to the defence secretary, Geoff Hoon; Yasmin Qureshi, 36, a government-employed barrister born and resident in Watford; and Lucy Ashton, 26, the MP's daughter, a journalist turned Labour official making a first-timer's bid "mainly for the experience".

Mr Mann is accused of devoting much of the past few months to a virtually full-time campaign for the seat and - by some critics - of overstepping the boundaries of party rule 4B13(e) which forbids candidates or their supporters from "interference in the process of applications for, or the issue and return of, postal votes".

Labour officials at Millbank and East Midlands regional HQ have vetted these complaints and found them groundless.

"It's an election, so you go out and get people to vote for you," Mr Mann said. "The reason people voted for me was that I was the first Labour party person they have ever seen."

In short, Mr Mann stands accused of winning. But whether he is an ambitious apparatchik who cunningly wooed most of Bassetlaw's 160 postal voters - a high number by normal standards - or an experienced union backed candidate facing "chattering class" opposition, there are lessons to be drawn.

Ambitious candidates, locals or outsiders, willing to get stuck in at grassroots with the membership list can get an unbeatable head start.

webTitle: Women claim they are not being invited to party meetings

fields.headline: Women claim they are not being invited to party meetings
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: What is it worth to pick the "right" candidate in one of Labour's safest seats? £200,000 if rumours in Dagenham are to be believed.
fields.body:
What is it worth to pick the "right" candidate in one of Labour's safest seats? £200,000 if rumours in Dagenham are to be believed.

A trade union is said to have offered to spend the six-figure sum refurbishing the local Labour offices if its favoured son is picked.

The story is doing the rounds as candidates - male as well as female - privately complain the party's rule book is not being enforced.

Ward parties are required to nominate at least one woman with rule 4B.10(c) stating: "Where party branches nominate they shall be obliged to submit the names of one man and one woman."

Yet the women hoping to be selected as Labour's prospective parliamentary candidate, of whom there are at least three, claim they have not been invited to meetings.

The chauvinism, in a seat famous for its Ford plant, is believed to stem from the decision more than a year ago of the sitting Labour MP, Judith Church, to step down.

Ms Church, who won Dagenham in a 1994 byelection after the death of leftwinger Joan Richardson, had been tipped for great things but is quitting after citing "personal reasons".

No Labour runner would speak out publicly yesterday and no formal complaints have been registered amid fears that such comments would scupper their chances.

But a Dagenham contender said: "Some, but not all, of the male members just remember that she was a woman and don't want another one. It's complete rubbish.

"We were not told about the meetings and, when a ward was warned it had to nominate a woman, one of the men said 'at least we don't have to listen to her as well'."

A 17,054 majority makes Dagenham a Labour stronghold yet the Commons seat is in the hands of only a couple of hundred people.

Membership has slumped from 500 to just 350 since the election and many local meetings are inquorate.

Labour hopefuls include Downing Street official Jon Cruddas, Bexley councillor Teresa Pearce, train driver Ray Parkin, Ms Richardson's former researcher Cameron Geddes, lawyer Emily Thornbury, and activist Sally Mulreddy.

Postal votes hold the key to selection, which gives a clear advantage to individuals or unions with the time and resources to organise.

The hustings on June 30 coincide with the close of the ballot when all postal votes must be in.

webTitle: Legal action over claims of harassment

fields.headline: Legal action over claims of harassment
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The Potteries seat of Newcastle-under-Lyme has been held by Labour for over 70 years; almost half of them under the steady stewardship of one couple, the Goldings.
fields.body:
The Potteries seat of Newcastle-under-Lyme has been held by Labour for over 70 years; almost half of them under the steady stewardship of one couple, the Goldings.

But the contest to replace Llin Golding, the tough Labour Mrs Fixit retiring 14 years after taking over the seat from her late husband John, has run into rockier waters, amid a legal wrangle and claims of over-enthusiastic canvassing amounting to "harassment" of electors.

The selection process was stopped earlier this month when two party members launched a high court challenge, alleging a rules breach by the leading contender.

On May 5, after Labour's poor showing in local elections, Sandra Hambleton and Bill Hughes appealed to the court to freeze the selection process, claiming that Paul Farrelly - city editor of the Observer, the Guardian's sister paper, and local constituency organiser - had contravened Labour's code of conduct by "harassing" members. Candidates are permitted to canvass prior to shortlisting, but only in a manner which does not "intimidate or offend".

Ms Hambleton and Mr Hughes, both Staffordshire county councillors, had already complained to the local party and the West Midlands region, but investigations had cleared Mr Farrelly who gained over 40 nominations for the shortlist as against two by the next contender, former MEP Mike Tappin.

An injunction was granted and the selection process put on hold for two weeks in the run-up to a high court hearing on May 19. The complainants, both supporters of Mr Tappin, hoped for a ruling which would either order the party to conduct an investigation, suspending the selection process, or compel it to restart the procedure.

Last week, however, Judge Richard Walker refused their application, ruling there was only weak evidence of a breach in rules and that other allegations were "far from persuasive". The two councillors were ordered to cover the party's £11,000 costs.

Following the hearing, shortlisting is now scheduled for June 6, with a final hustings on June 20. Mr Farrelly and Mr Tappin are certain to be shortlisted with at least two female candidates.

"Bill and Sandra effectively succeeded in creating a month's delay," said one party source. "It was a case of men and women behaving badly."

webTitle: Union call to compel voting at elections

fields.headline: Union call to compel voting at elections
fields.standfirst: Special report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: Voting at elections should be made compulsory, a Blairite trade union said yesterday. Not only would more citizens be forced to get involved, the measure would curb negative campaigning - personal attacks on candidates - and make parties concentrate on their policies.
fields.body:
Voting at elections should be made compulsory, a Blairite trade union said yesterday. Not only would more citizens be forced to get involved, the measure would curb negative campaigning - personal attacks on candidates - and make parties concentrate on their policies.

The engineering union, AEEU, in a document entitled Votes for All, written for the Fabian Society, says that despite objections on libertarian grounds, compulsion would push voting beyond 80% - compared with the 71% turnout of the 1997 election.

The pamphlet's authors, Tom Watson and Mark Tami, admit enforcement at local and Euro elections would be a huge problem, but say the solution is modest penalties, a £5 fine perhaps, "naming and shaming", or a demand for a written "absence" note.

Tony Benn MP yesterday warned that compulsion would take Britain further toward a "managed society", with people told what to do. He told Radio 4's Today programme that the prime minister was already creating a cross-party coalition to deny choice. "If you did it [compulsory voting] the next election would be won by the party promising to make it voluntary," he said.

The move comes at a time when the latest Representation of the Peoples Act has helped improve turnout; supermarket ballot places and Sunday voting had some impact in the May local elections. Mr Watson, who is the AEEU's political organiser, argued that one of Mr Benn's complaints - the loss of the right not to vote - could be resolved with the presence of the option, "none of the above", on ballot papers.

He and Mr Tami, who calls low turnout "a disaster for democracy", say there is a relationship between class and turnout; the most marginalised are most likely not to vote.

fields.headline: Trust failure over botched operations
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: An inquiry into the botched operations of gynaecologist Rodney Ledward is expected this week to be severely critical of doctors and managers who knew for years that he was unfit to be operating.
fields.body:
An inquiry into the botched operations of gynaecologist Rodney Ledward is expected this week to be severely critical of doctors and managers who knew for years that he was unfit to be operating.

The surgeon is also under investigation by Kent police, who are examining complaints of assault on an unspecified number of women, it has been disclosed. A spokesman said yesterday: "The inquiry is at a very early stage."

Jean Ritchie QC, who was asked by the then health secretary Frank Dobson to investigate Ledward's years of incompetence, will make her report public on Thursday. The investigation was supposed to last three months but has taken 15 months because of the enormous amount of evidence.

More than 400 women complained about their treatment after Mr Ledward was struck off the medical register in September 1998. Compensation cases date back to 1980.

The gynaecologist was not sacked by the William Harvey hospital in Ashford, Kent - where he did most of his NHS work - until December 1996, and kept his job at the private St Saviour's hospital for longer still. The General Medical Council, which debarred him in October 1998, looked at 14 cases of alleged botched surgery between 1989 and 1996, and proved 10 of them.

The Ritchie report will take a stern view of the management of what was then the South Kent Hospitals NHS Trust, which was responsible for the William Harvey hospital, and Ledward's colleagues who should all have realised that his work was far below standard, and his attitude to patients even worse. He notoriously described himself as "the fastest gynaecologist in the south-east" after performing seven hysterectomies in three hours and 40 minutes.

An inquiry at William Harvey after his sacking examined 150 operations and found a third ended with serious complications, of which 12 showed evidence of incompetence.

The report will strengthen the government's hand in pushing through medical reforms, including continuous audit of every hospital consultant's work and yearly appraisal. The GMC, whose role has been threatened by ministers, wants all doctors to have to prove their fitness to practice every five years. Whistle-blowing on colleagues whose performance does not come up to scratch is encouraged.

The Ritchie report will reinforce these changes and draw attention to the need for doctors to put the interests of patients ahead of loyalty to their friends and colleagues.

Ledward's victims describe a culture in which nobody would believe them. Maureen Goldingay, vice-chairwoman of the support group, said: "They kept telling us to go to the osteopath and the physiotherapist. We were told our problems stemmed from food allergies. We would wait nine months to a year to see yet another consultant."

The report will also highlight the problems that can arise from consultants practising both in the NHS and the lucrative private sector. Contracts allow consultants to be retained by the NHS on a good salary while spending as much time as they like on private work.

At the GMC hearings in October 1998, Ledward was found guilty of removing the ovaries of a 54-year-old magistrate from Kent without her permission and leaving her with serious bleeding and a damaged bladder. Five weeks before, he had told her that her ovaries were healthy. She suffered massive blood loss, but doctors were unable to contact Ledward for some time.

Eventually they got hold of him. Nine hours later, when he carried out a second operation on her, more than two litres of blood were found to have leaked into her stomach and abdomen. He was also found to have written a misleading account to her GP.

The patient told the GMC hearing: "I had been in hospital a month and I was unable to even walk up the steps to my house. My son had to carry me."

He notoriously described himself as "the fastest gynaecologist in the south-east" after performing seven hysterectomies in three hours and 40 minutes. An inquiry at William Harvey after his sacking examined 150 operations and found a third ended with serious complications, of which 12 showed evidence of incompetence. The report will strengthen the government's hand in pushing through medical reforms, including continuous audit of every hospital consultant's work and yearly appraisal. The GMC, whose role has been threatened by ministers, wants all doctors to have to prove their fitness to practice every five years. Whistle-blowing on colleagues whose performance does not come up to scratch is encouraged. The Ritchie report will reinforce these changes and draw attention to the need for doctors to put the interests of patients ahead of loyalty to their friends and colleagues. Ledward's victims describe a culture in which nobody would believe them. Maureen Goldingay, vice-chairwoman of the support group, said: "They kept telling us to go to the osteopath and the physiotherapist. We were told our problems stemmed from food allergies. We would wait nine months to a year to see yet another consultant." The report will also highlight the problems that can arise from consultants practising both in the NHS and the lucrative private sector. Contracts allow consultants to be retained by the NHS on a good salary while spending as much time as they like on private work. At the GMC hearings in October 1998, Ledward was found guilty of removing the ovaries of a 54-year-old magistrate from Kent without her permission and leaving her with serious bleeding and a damaged bladder. Five weeks before, he had told her that her ovaries were healthy. She suffered massive blood loss, but doctors were unable to contact Ledward for some time. Eventually they got hold of him. Nine hours later, when he carried out a second operation on her, more than two litres of blood were found to have leaked into her stomach and abdomen. He was also found to have written a misleading account to her GP. The patient told the GMC hearing: "I had been in hospital a month and I was unable to even walk up the steps to my house. My son had to carry me."

fields.headline: Can I have a word?
fields.trailText: The appalling news that Channel 4 was intending to broadcast A Brief History of the F-Word with celebrity contributions on the subject put me in mind of Sir Bob Geldof's contribution to the oeuvre.
fields.body:
The appalling news that Channel 4 was intending to broadcast A Brief History of the F-Word with celebrity contributions on the subject put me in mind of Sir Bob Geldof's contribution to the oeuvre. Last week, Bob Geldof was on the radio promoting a nationwide search for our favourite word. The purpose of this exercise, he told us, was to create a snapshot of the priorities and values of the nation. This presumption - that every word chosen would have some kind of cultural subtext - was Geldof's first mistake.

His second was to demand that the people choosing words gave some account of their selection. How can you say why you like a word? Geldof may know why he likes "fuck" ("because it's elastic, seductive, persuasive, sexy and flexible") but who's to say that the listener who called in to plump for "plinth" needed any similar justification? The lady said she chose "plinth" because famous people often stood on them.

Someone else suggested "modesty" without explaining why. "I hope we get some better ones than that," huffed Geldof. Like bollocks, I thought. Or arse, maybe. Were any non-swear words acceptable?

One child bravely offered "par allelogram". "What about that?" said John Humphrys. "I'd like to know why," huffed Geldof, resenting the whiff of the schoolroom. What self-respecting child would select a blackboard noun over the "could be an adjective, could be a verb, anything really" pleasure of fuck? One day, perhaps, that child will grow up to understand the full richness of our language.

* I don't like football and I won't be watching Euro 2000. Nor, if I can help it, will I be beating a path to the cinema to watch one of a brace of "female friendly" movies released to exploit football fatigue. Like many other women, I resent the implication that a lack of interest in sport necessarily means a passion for romantic comedies, with or without Ewan MacGregor. The insulting suggestion that women are more likely to watch this crap, when their more discerning partners are busy with lagers and scorecards, is even more upsetting than the idea that we're at a loss without them. Are boyfriendless hours really so hard to fill?

fields.headline: Holiday from hell
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV:  Rupert Smith
fields.trailText: Time was when the most sensational entertainment on offer over the spring bank holiday weekend was a trip to the local donkey derby and then, if you were lucky, an episode of Disney Time. Our senses deadened by years of such excitement, however, we now need stronger stuff to get through three days off work - or so the drama schedulers clearly think.
fields.body:
Time was when the most sensational entertainment on offer over the spring bank holiday weekend was a trip to the local donkey derby and then, if you were lucky, an episode of Disney Time. Our senses deadened by years of such excitement, however, we now need stronger stuff to get through three days off work - or so the drama schedulers clearly think.

While the BBC was given over to Music Live, ITV and Channel 4 treated us to a brace of ultra-violent offerings replete with guns and swearing in every frame. And thus, at 9.0pm, we had the stark holiday choice: Elton John on BBC1, Mozart on BBC2, guns and swearing on ITV and C4, and a Jack Nicholson sex-and-murder movie on Channel 5.

ITV's two-part Rough Treatment concluded in Jacobean mode, with doubly raped ex-soldier Eve (Daniela Nardini) carrying out inventive revenge on her assailants. On Sunday night no detail of the original attack had been spared by fellow officers in a sauna; Eve's father had also dropped dead of a heart attack for good measure. The episode ended with Eve faking her own death and retiring to Dungeness for some target practice, pursued only by an amorous physiotherapist with an inexplicable taste for psychotics.

A bump on the head left her with an alleged "personality change", which meant that Eve dressed in full terrorist drag for the entire second episode and said things like "I will move on - over their dead bodies!" As Nemesis she was brilliantly inventive, delivering one of her victims into the eager, rubber-gloved hands of an over-zealous Customs and Excise inspector, thus giving him a tiny taste of the anal intrusion which he forced upon her in part one. Later the same man was lured into a hotel room, robbed of his clothes and left blubbering in a wood after an ordeal at gunpoint.

This was all rollicking good stuff, except when one occasionally remembered that this was actually a drama about rape and its consequences. Entertaining as Nardini's exploits were, this was brutally depressing viewing. Perhaps the intention was to show what a dehumanising crime rape is - and yet, with the best will in the world, we wanted her to kill those bastards and be done with it.

The resolution - ruined lives for the rapists, and a big clinch with the amorous physio on Dungeness beach for Eve - added up in a crude, Old Testament kind of way, but it required a fantastical leap of the imagination to believe that Eve had been in any way redeemed by her experiences.

Over on Channel 4, guns were fired into stomachs, hands lopped off with meat cleavers and a small fat man with duct tape over his mouth was cut up into "chops" by men in butcher's aprons. But this was the loveable world of Lock, Stock , the spin-off TV series from the movie of nearly the same name, and therefore the violence and mayhem were only a bit of a laugh. It was all rather like the Monty Python sketch that imagined Salad Days directed by Sam Peckinpah - bright young things in blazers and boaters being riddled with bullets and bathed in gore.

The bright young things in Lock, Stock were an unfeasibly handsome foursome who embroiled themselves - the sillies! - in a caper involving a stolen racehorse, some hardcore animal porn (Old MacDonald Shags His Farm) and a missing watch with a penis instead of a big hand. The plotting was brilliant, worthy of the 30s screwball movies on which it seems, partially, to be based. The turns, particularly Ralph Brown as über-villain Miami Vice, were polished, and the dialogue occasionally sparkled ("Gun beats bottle", leered one of the hoods in a bar-room face-off). The series that follows will prove hugely popular with teenage boys, with actors who long to star in their own British gangland movie, and with anybody who fancies Scott Maslen (ringleader Jamie). That'll be millions, then.

Why we enjoy laughing at such realistic violence is a debate bigger than this column allows. Probably the same base motive that leads us to cheer a rape victim as she points the gun at her assailant's head. The fact that Channel 4 followed up Lock, Stock with a discussion about whether the word "fuck" still has the power to shock was so hilariously inappropriate in the context of all the preceding bloodshed that it lightened the gloom considerably.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Broadcast news
fields.body:
Broadcast News

(James L Brooks, 1987)

8.10pm, FilmFour

Sharply focused account of a love triangle which ends up complicating life behind the scenes of a US television station. Holly Hunter is the star producer, while Albert Brooks is a brilliant researcher who is unable to convey the news that he loves her. William Hurt (pictured) plays the dim glamour-boy reporter who's being groomed to step into the shoes of veteran anchorman Jack Nicholson. A watchable and satisfyingly jaundiced examination of the interface between media information and entertainment.

Postcards From The Edge (Mike Nichols,1990)

9pm, Living

Carrie Fisher's adaptation of her broadly autobiographical novel is an intelligent, snappy comedy. Meryl Streep plays a drug-addicted film star forced to go back to alcoholic mum Shirley MacLaine for safekeeping after an overdose. A caustic, loving campaign ensues, with witty sideswipes at Hollywood. The men - Hackman, Quaid, Dreyfuss - are left in the shade.

Blade

(Stephen Norrington, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

A flawed attempt to screen the Marvel Comics superpowered vampire slayer. There are some enjoyably modern-gothic set-pieces, but the limp story hardly grabs you by the throat. Wesley Snipes, though, is athletically efficient as the half-human, half-vampire hero, pitted against Stephen Dorff's would-be leader.

Lorenzo's Oil

(George Miller, 1992)

11.55pm, Sky Cinema

This is a change of tack for George "Mad Max" Miller - an emotional account of a couple who are doing battle with the medical profession in order to save their son. Five-year-old Lorenzo is given no chance by the doctors after contracting a rare brain disease, so parents Susan Sarandon and Nick Nolte set about finding their own cure. It sounds pure Hollywood, and while Miller works the sympathies in the best traditions of the tragic- illness genre, this is actually based on a true story.

fields.headline: Fighting chance
fields.standfirst: He became the world's greatest heavyweight when the title still meant something, humiliating the Nazi propaganda machine along the way. But, says Kirk Lake, the rise of Joe Louis owed as much to cynicism as guts and talent
fields.trailText: He became the world's greatest heavyweight when the title still meant something, humiliating the Nazi propaganda machine along the way. But, says Kirk Lake, the rise of Joe Louis owed as much to cynicism as guts and talent
fields.body:
When the flamboyant Muhammad Ali (then Cassius Clay) humbled the supposedly invincible Sonny Liston in 1964, boxing gained its first superstar and simultaneously moved inexorably down the sliproad that leads from sport into showbusiness. Fights became multi-million-dollar events, and the public's insatiable appetite for championship bouts - and more importantly their apparently inexhaustible wallets - eventually fractured the fight game into an alphabet soup of governing bodies, each with their own champions and contenders, and with smooth operators like Don King stirring the pot.

The bottom line is top dollar. And it always was. Every promoter needs an angle, every manager is looking for a gimmick. Without a British passport, Frank Bruno would've been making up the numbers in the ring records of better fighters, while Tyson's fall guy Julius Francis wouldn't even have had the opportunity to demean himself on They Think It's All Over. And let's not forget that ever-popular brand of horizontal heavyweights - the great, the white, and the hopeless.

In the modern age, when heavyweight boxing is about as exciting as watching two expensive wardrobes falling into each other and the title of Heavyweight Champion depends more on financial clout than fistic prowess, you could be forgiven for looking back longingly to a time when being the champion of the premier division of the purest sport of all actually meant something.

Jack Dempsey. Gene Tunney. Rocky Marciano. With names like comic-book superheroes, these giants of the 20s and 30s were untouchable. Symbolic supermen. You wouldn't catch any of these dropping their belts into the dustbin like Riddick Bowe. And perhaps the greatest heavyweight of this golden age was Joe Louis, the Brown Bomber.

Still the longest reigning champion of all time, there's little doubting Louis's awesome ability as a fighter. He was brave and he was brutal. Ernest Hemingway called his four-round destruction of Max Baer in 1935 the "most disgusting spectacle outside of a public hanging" he had ever witnessed. But, perhaps unjustly, Louis's reputation, as examined in tonight's The Boxer Who Beat Hitler (9pm, BBC 2), rests less on the 12 years he ruled the division, and more on one night in 1938 when the hopes of a nation were placed on his shoulders.

On the eve of war, Louis fought the German Max Schmeling for the Heavyweight Championship of the World. It was billed as "democracy versus fascism", and Louis delivered a monumental propaganda coup. But a look into the fight's background suggests that far from being a simple case of good versus evil, it was in fact a masterpiece of manipulation as cynical and calculated as anything Teflon Don could muster today.

Louis had already lost to Schmeling in a supposed title eliminator two years previously. In truth Schmeling was well past his prime, but he'd outthought Louis and, against all the odds, had knocked him out. Despite the result, a half-million-dollar deal saw reigning champ Jim Braddock sidestep the German and take on the Brown Bomber instead. As planned, Louis, the superior fighter and a virtual certainty to beat Schmeling in a rematch, emerged victorious.

Schmeling was promoted, on both sides of the Atlantic, as the pride of Nazi Germany, an Aryan warrior. Disingenuous to say the least. Schmeling was no Nazi. He had a Jewish manager (later he'd help numerous Jewish children flee Germany) and he was coming to the end of his career (after his defeat he'd win just four more fights). It was the desire to avenge the only loss on his record far more than any ideas of nationalist pride that spurred Louis to demolish Schmeling in a shade over two minutes. If anybody cried mismatch, it was lost in the patriotic roar.

The morale-boosting victory turned Louis into a national hero. In a segregated society, he united black and white and helped break apartheid in America. And when the war came, Louis became an integral part of the US Army's propaganda machine, a symbol of American resistance to fascist oppression.

But with Hitler safely dispatched, Louis was just another fighter, and by the late 40s his war effort was rewarded with a massive tax demand, ironically not for money he had personally received but for money generated for others in exhibition bouts. Like so many before and since, the champion was broke and forced out of retirement to face possible injury and inevitable humiliation.

Towards the end of his life Louis succumbed to paranoid delusions exacerbated by drug and alcohol abuse. He was convinced the mafia were trying to kill him with poisoned gas, and took to pasting over the air vents in his room and smearing mayonnaise over the cracks in the ceiling. Perhaps his descent could have been predicted - his father had been committed when Louis was two years old.

In boxing there's a fine line between guidance and exploitation. For every Bruno kept in cotton wool to be unwrapped on the big payday, there's a Tyson, spiralling unchecked and out of control. And whether the paymaster is a giant cable network or the allied war machine, the only certainty seems that no matter how great the fighter, nine times out of ten his career is a tragedy in waiting: with the final act played out to empty stalls.

fields.headline: Back on the rails
fields.standfirst: Elisabeth Mahoney is bowled over by Glasgow's revamped Tramway
fields.trailText: Some arts developments have had giddy amounts of cash poured into them (Tate Modern, the Lowry); others have had acres of media coverage (the Royal Opera House), but only one has a street named after it. On Friday, after almost two years of closure, Glasgow's Tramway reopens. And, from Friday, we can stroll along Tramway Street.
fields.body:
Some arts developments have had giddy amounts of cash poured into them (Tate Modern, the Lowry); others have had acres of media coverage (the Royal Opera House), but only one has a street named after it. On Friday, after almost two years of closure, Glasgow's Tramway reopens. And, from Friday, we can stroll along Tramway Street.

It is not a real street: it exists only within the vast old tramshed that was one of the UK's most ground-breaking arts spaces of the 90s. This place, with its roll call of celebrated associated artists (Peter Brook, Douglas Gordon, Robert Lepage, Les Furas del Baus, the Wooster Group, Lloyd Newson of DV8 and many others) has been given the thoroughfare by the Glasgow architects Zoo, the team behind the £3.6m redevelopment.

Tramway used to be about exhilarating experiences in evocative and forlorn spaces: dark, massive rooms with their previous functions, industrial and cultural, stamped into the rough walls, the uneven floors. Always a thrill to visit, it reeked of history. But cosy? No. Comfy? Never. Peter Brook once described Tramway as "an industrial cathedral" and he was right - going to Tramway was a bit like going to church: humbling, and not a tremendous amount to do with real life. At its best, visiting Tramway was dreamlike.

The challenge for the architects was to keep this quality, while at the same time opening up some of the unused parts of the extensive site and giving production companies the facilities they expect in a venue of this stature. The answer was the street.

A long, streak-of-light corridor leading from the new front entrance to a minimalist back garden (both designed by the Mimm Group, a multi-disciplinary group of Scottish artists), the street is a funky buffer zone between the main spaces. If Tramway were a body, the street would be its spine, with all the rooms leading off it. The emphasis throughout is on post-industrial, dressed-down chic, using reclaimed materials wherever possible and deliberately not covering up traces of the past.

The biggest change is beyond the revered spaces, however. Wisely, the two largest, Tramway 1 and 2 remain largely unchanged. But although more than half of the redevelopment budget was swallowed up by the costs of a new roof and getting the venue's heating and ventilation systems up to scratch, a whole new Tramway has been revealed.

Tramway was not only a tramshed a century ago, it was also home to Glasgow's 4,000 horses. So some of the site's most distinct features have a rather four-legged feel to them. Slowly graduating, wide staircases, once the horses' steps to their stables, have now been opened up for public use, and, on the upper floor, a series of the old stables have been converted into small, multi-function rooms. Some will be used as workshop and rehearsal spaces, others as teaching room. One is kitted out as a small dance studio, another as a larger project room for visiting artists. On Friday, after almost two years of closure, Glasgow's Tramway reopens. And, from Friday, we can stroll along Tramway Street. It is not a real street: it exists only within the vast old tramshed that was one of the UK's most ground-breaking arts spaces of the 90s. This place, with its roll call of celebrated associated artists (Peter Brook, Douglas Gordon, Robert Lepage, Les Furas del Baus, the Wooster Group, Lloyd Newson of DV8 and many others) has been given the thoroughfare by the Glasgow architects Zoo, the team behind the £3.6m redevelopment. Tramway used to be about exhilarating experiences in evocative and forlorn spaces: dark, massive rooms with their previous functions, industrial and cultural, stamped into the rough walls, the uneven floors. Always a thrill to visit, it reeked of history. But cosy? No. Comfy? Never. Peter Brook once described Tramway as "an industrial cathedral" and he was right - going to Tramway was a bit like going to church: humbling, and not a tremendous amount to do with real life. At its best, visiting Tramway was dreamlike. The challenge for the architects was to keep this quality, while at the same time opening up some of the unused parts of the extensive site and giving production companies the facilities they expect in a venue of this stature. fields.headline: Dracula reclaimed
fields.standfirst: Inside Story
fields.trailText: Ingrid Pitt, the first lady of Hammer Horror films, emerges pale-faced from the toilets of the Favorit nightclub, a seedy dive in the Romanian town of Poiana Brasov. "They're bloody disgusting and the paper's as scratchy as hell," she says. "Sorry," says a bouncer. "The cleaner doesn't come on Sundays."
fields.body:
Ingrid Pitt, the first lady of Hammer Horror films, emerges pale-faced from the toilets of the Favorit nightclub, a seedy dive in the Romanian town of Poiana Brasov. "They're bloody disgusting and the paper's as scratchy as hell," she says. "Sorry," says a bouncer. "The cleaner doesn't come on Sundays."

Other horrors have beset the delegates at this year's World Dracula Congress. Two have been mugged, and Arlene Russo, editor of the Glasgow-based vampire magazine Bite Me, is shocked at eastern Europe's lack of vegetarian food, and at having to walk back from the restaurant through the unlit pine forest after midnight.

In the bowels of the nightclub, lit with 20-watt lightbulbs and chilled to 10 degrees, gothic scholars, luvvies and Dracula fans (or "fangs") have just concluded a four-day gathering. This week they'll take the findings back to their Dracula clubs as far afield as the US, Australia, Israel, Serbia and Britain, having debated vampirism in Kosovo, Putin and Dracula, the divorce of Bram Stoker's Dracula and his historical namesake Vlad the Impaler, the correlation between wine-drinking countries and vampiric sightings, and even the supposition that Stoker was abused as a child.

"Why are you here?" delegates ask over glasses of vampire wine. "I always liked the moonlight and licking the blood off rare meat," says Flora Zbar from the University of Florida. For some, it has been a struggle to get here. "I sent off for an application form to join the London Dracula Society when I was in seventh grade," says 32-year old Nancy Hill from Washington state. "The mailman intercepted the form and gave it to my parents who tore it up."

Most are here to enjoy ghoulishly fascinating Transylvania, with its fog-filled mountain passes, horse-drawn carts, pot-holed roads and Gypsy settlements - three hours' drive from Bucharest and 100 years from modern Europe. The down-at-heel resort of Poiana Brasov, on the outskirts of medieval Brasov, was once where Romanians came to get a taste of what it was like in the west.

While farmers, earning around £30 a month, weed their potato fields in 30C heat, representatives from the world of gothic academia get down to business. Professor Elizabeth Miller, one of the world's foremost Dracula academics from the Memorial University of Newfoundland, is determined to set the record straight about the relationship between the title character of Bram Stoker's 1897 novel Dracula and Vlad "The Impaler" Tepes, the 15th century Wallachian prince who successfully fought off the Turks - impaling many in the process - and is viewed as something of a national hero in these parts.

Apart from pouring scorn on the belief that Stoker appropriated Vlad to create his fictional Dracula, she also dismisses the popular notion that a vampire bat sucks blood. "It laps it up like a cat laps milk," she insists. And Vlad, she claims, did not dip his bread into the blood of his victims and eat it, as has been rumoured.

Romanians are keen not to spoil what is clearly a good money-maker, but also a very western-dominated genre. Most Romanians hadn't heard of Stoker's Dracula until a decade ago. "We are debating a western myth in a place that eight out of 10 Americans believe doesn't exist," says Nicolae Paduraru, Transylvanian Society president.

"You could look at us as either the victims or the beneficiaries of a great book's success. But we cannot be passive about it, so we've identified a few Romanian scholars, historians, writers and philosophers who agreed with our viewpoint that we had to replace the commercially-motivated bullshit with some alternative - and to take a stand to redefine the Romanian culture."

It seems to be paying off. "Romanians are making room for Dracula, and now, slowly, he is even infiltrating our folktales," Paduraru claims. One academic to join the beanfeast is aristocrat philosopher Professor Constantin Balaceanu-Stolnici, the Impaler's last remaining descendant. Vice-president of Romania's Liberal Party, the 72-year old had interrupted a national election campaign to lecture on "the genesis of evil in the religious tradition".

"How," I ask, "does descending from Vlad Tepes affect how you consider good and evil?" "It affects your personality and it's an education, but nothing more," he says. A professor from Florida interjects: "You should show more respect! Vlad is to the Romanians what George Washington is to the Americans!"

If only, sighs David Drakula, the genealogy was so simple. The 33-year-old playwright - who works under the name Drake and whose film The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me had its premiere at the London Gay and Lesbian Film Festival last month - is here on a mission. So far he has traced his roots back to Macedonian Drakulas in the 1500s, but is hoping that the claim of Hungarian historians that he is related to Vlad Tepes will soon be proved.

"I really want to re-embrace my identity," he says. "But my family don't want to know. For them it's an embarrassment because it reeks of eastern Europe, which is considered murky geographically and a metaphor for unpleasant things."

Also present is German forensic scientist Mark Benecke, who has spent two years hanging out with New York's vampire youths based in the city's former meat-packing district. "They puncture their bodies and drink each other's blood and consider it as normal as you guys consider going to conferences on Dracula."

But Xenia Novi, a recent graduate from the University of Jerusalem and a "vampire in training", brings a sharper chill with her presentation on "the positive aspect of psychic vampirism". "We know that vampires exist," she says, "and some people become vampires to overcome depression. But becoming a vampire should be a conscious process; you need to work closely with a psychologist. You can't just wake up one day and be a cool, cute, sexy vampire and lose yourself."

She shows a video in which one of her female "case studies" explains what happens when she sucks the blood of a friend: "You see the pulsating energy in the neck, then you nibble it and lick it before the teeth go in. Then he passes out and sleeps for hours. On waking, he says he's never felt better."

Such descriptions of vampiric foreplay are too much for some academics, who march out. "What bilge water! I'd call that a personality disorder rather than vampirism," sniffs Jeremy Tudway, a clinical psychologist from Cardiff, who's on holiday with the London Vampyre Club.

Later Xenia is spotted in a nightclub with a Danish nurse. The president and vice-president of the London-based Ghost Club, founded by Charles Dickens, report back that an argument, involving knives, broke out between the two neck-romancers over "who was the better vampire".

Ingrid Pitt, signing copies of her Bedside Companion for Vampire Lovers in the Favorit lobby, thinks she would win that one. The 62-year-old Polish-born actress who lives in Richmond has just signed to star in the first Hammer Horror film for 25 years, called Dracula . . . Who? It's a revamp written by Pitt and husband Tony, due for release next summer. In it, Dracula turns vegetarian and tries to renounce his bloody ways despite his wife's ministrations. "Dracula is my raison d'etre ," says Pitt, who played Countess Dracula in the Hammer films. "When I go for the kill in a movie, I go into it with venom and viciousness. It's a bloody recommendable way of venting your anger."

fields.headline: Look now
fields.standfirst: Unlike some Hollywood stars who appear on the British stage, Donald Sutherland has no need to prove himself as an actor. So why is he here?  Tom Dewe Mathews investigates
fields.trailText: Unlike some Hollywood stars who appear on the British stage, Donald Sutherland has no need to prove himself as an actor. So why is he here? They keep on coming, the would-be thespians flying in from Tinseltown in an attempt to polish up their actorly credentials on the British stage.
fields.body:
They keep on coming, the would-be thespians flying in from Tinseltown in an attempt to polish up their actorly credentials on the British stage. The latest star to join the cavalcade is Donald Sutherland, appearing at London's Savoy Theatre this week in the French play Enigmatic Variations. But this isn't a Hollywood power-player seeking validation: apart from being a genuine actor, Sutherland is returning to his theatrical roots.

Sutherland learned his craft in Britain. He arrived in 1952, aged 18, to study at the London Academy of Dramatic Art before going on to do a seven-year apprenticeship on almost every stage in the country. Afterwards, to hone his "vocal technique", he added another year in Scotland at the Perth Repertory Theatre - a place of which he still holds fond memories. "It was wonderful," he says. "It was regular work. I was on eight quid a week, I had a wife, we lived near the Bells distillery and we woke up with frost on the bed."

But that was three wives ago. He is now married to the Canadian actress Francine Racette, who is the co- producer of Enigmatic Variations, while their eldest son, Roeg, translated the play from French. And there is the key to Sutherland's career, because if you add in the names of his other sons, Kiefer, Rossif and Angus Redford and wonder why he gave his children such odd handles, it's because they were all named after film directors.

For this is the gospel according to Donald Sutherland: "Everything must be subjected to the director. My job is to perform for him, to satisfy him. In simplistic terms, I am his concubine. Manipulated is what I want: I eagerly present myself to be manipulated."

That's fighting talk in Hollywood, where stars are often autocrats who run the show and directors more like their underlings. But Sutherland insists this is not the nature of the movie medium, and although he speaks softly, his words carry a big reputation. In the past 40 years he has made more than 100 films - 10 in the past two years alone. Most stars would give their Learjets to have worked with the directors he has, a collection that includes Federico Fellini, Bernardo Bertolucci, Louis Malle, Robert Aldrich, Robert Altman and Nicolas Roeg. In the process he has developed into an extremely versatile actor: as insidious as Anthony Hopkins, as winning as James Stewart, as chameleon-like as Alec Guinness, and capable of playing anything from comedy to grand guignol.

Louis Malle marvelled at Suther land's "melange of looseness and tension". That loose-limbed style was probably best expressed as Hawkeye, the oddball iconoclast in M*A*S*H, while his best buttoned-up performance was as the tough-yet-tender detective in Alan J Pakula's Klute. But Sutherland's special genius lies in his ability to plumb the depths of our behaviour and make us care, whether he is playing a foppish Casanova or the duped, starstruck Homer Simpson of The Day of the Locust. Although Sutherland's perceptive portrayals have won him both critical and popular acclaim, he has no illusions about the actor's role. "Actors," he says bluntly, "have no control in films."

But he didn't feel that way in 1970 when M*A*S*H catapulted him to stardom. Back then, fresh from his experience on the British stage, he naively believed actors were autonomous on a film set - "and that the director had to satisfy me . "I did that with Bob Altman on M*A*S*H," he admitted. "I had no idea how good he was. I saw the movie from my character's perspective, which was not broad enough."

Sutherland believes now that he was mistaken about every role he took on before 1973. But that year he went to work for Roeg on the eerie horror film, Don't Look Now. "With Nic, I said, 'I think the ending of the film is incorrect. It should be more optimistic, it should include spiritualism as a learning process.' 'That might be fine for you,' he said, 'but it's no good for me.' No one had ever said that to me before. Nic taught me to put my trust in a director. It wasn't easy for me because I don't trust easily. But Nic was so strong I had to make that decision."

Since then Sutherland has measured his success in terms of the directors he has performed for. He was so anxious to play Casanova for Fellini that he dropped his fee to £60,000 for almost a year's work. He had to "stand in line" for his part in Bertolucci's 1900 and he personally contacted Schlesinger to ask for the role of Homer Simpson in The Day of the Locust. But there is a downside to this flexible approach to directors: Sutherland has not built up a consistent image, and in Hollywood, where his name has been conspicuously absent at Oscar nominations, that can be seen as a lack of commercial consistency.

"I think it has hurt Donald not to be labelled," says the veteran producer Edward Lewis. "He may be known as a 'director's actor,' but at the box office he's not seen as a star with an identifiable following like Eastwood or Gibson. Because no two of his roles are alike, the audience doesn't know what to expect when he is cast, and Hollywood may feel it can't count on him."

Also film critics have charged that, in among the 100-plus roles, Sutherland has wasted his talents on throwaway parts. But, he insists, "I don't act characters I don't love, I don't do films that I don't morally believe in. I turned down Deliverance and Straw Dogs because I disagreed with the violence, although now I think I was wrong. I go to work to sustain my creative self. If you stop acting, you get old. It's like being in a marriage. When you stop fucking, the marriage dies."

That still doesn't explain some of the tat Sutherland has been in, like Revolution, or the Sylvester Stallone vehicle Lock Up or, maybe worst of all, the movie version of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. "Why not take a role like that?" says Sutherland about Buffy. "I liked the idea of that film. The only thing I had asked the director [Fran Rubel Kuzui] was that it seemed incorrect that my character would die, and she said to me, 'That's because you want to be in the sequel'. At that point, I realised I was in the wrong film."

By way of mitigation he adds, "Al Pacino and I sat on top of a hill once when we were doing Revolution and he said, 'I've never said this before in my life, but this one, really, I believe will be great.' And it wasn't. It's impossible to tell."

But whether or not he can spot a hit, there's no doubt Sutherland hasn't had much of a chance to deliver a big performance lately. Maybe it will happen on the Savoy stage tomorrow. But when it does take place, we'll know because it will unlike anything Sutherland has done before. and for that reason the studios in LA will be wary. But what do we care? That is how Sutherland chooses a role, and what Hollywood loses, we gain.

Enigmatic Variations is at the Savoy Theatre, London WC2 (020-7836 8888), from tomorrow till July 29.

"He may be known as a 'director's actor,' but at the box office he's not seen as a star with an identifiable following like Eastwood or Gibson. Because no two of his roles are alike, the audience doesn't know what to expect when he is cast, and Hollywood may feel it can't count on him." Also film critics have charged that, in among the 100-plus roles, Sutherland has wasted his talents on throwaway parts. But, he insists, "I don't act characters I don't love, I don't do films that I don't morally believe in. I turned down Deliverance and Straw Dogs because I disagreed with the violence, although now I think I was wrong. I go to work to sustain my creative self. If you stop acting, you get old. It's like being in a marriage. When you stop fucking, the marriage dies." That still doesn't explain some of the tat Sutherland has been in, like Revolution, or the Sylvester Stallone vehicle Lock Up or, maybe worst of all, the movie version of Buffy the Vampire Slayer. "Why not take a role like that?" says Sutherland about Buffy. "I liked the idea of that film. The only thing I had asked the director [Fran Rubel Kuzui] was that it seemed incorrect that my character would die, and she said to me, 'That's because you want to be in the sequel'. At that point, I realised I was in the wrong film." By way of mitigation he adds, "Al Pacino and I sat on top of a hill once when we were doing Revolution and he said, 'I've never said this before in my life, but this one, really, I believe will be great.' And it wasn't. It's impossible to tell." But whether or not he can spot a hit, there's no doubt Sutherland hasn't had much of a chance to deliver a big performance lately. Maybe it will happen on the Savoy stage tomorrow. But when it does take place, we'll know because it will unlike anything Sutherland has done before. and for that reason the studios in LA will be wary. But what do we care? That is how Sutherland chooses a role, and what Hollywood loses, we gain. Enigmatic Variations is at the Savoy Theatre, London WC2 (020-7836 8888), from tomorrow till July 29.

webTitle: Fair wind blows past Arctic tragedy

fields.headline: Fair wind blows past Arctic tragedy
fields.standfirst: 1897 explorers remembered as Briton balloons to north pole
fields.trailText: Adventurer David Hempleman-Adams yesterday passed over the southern extremity of the Arctic pack ice on his way to becoming the first man to fly to the north pole in a balloon - and becoming the first man to fly solo across the Atlantic in the process.
fields.body:
Adventurer David Hempleman-Adams yesterday passed over the southern extremity of the Arctic pack ice on his way to becoming the first man to fly to the north pole in a balloon - and becoming the first man to fly solo across the Atlantic in the process.

Flying with the aid of oxygen and exposed to sub-zero temperatures in a wicker basket slung below a helium and hot air balloon, Hempleman-Adams left Spitzbergen in Norway on Sunday and is predicted to reach the pole late tomorrow or early on Thursday.

In a radio message delivered from 7,000ft above the pack ice, Hempleman-Adams, who has previously flown the Andes and the Northern Passage in a balloon, said he was delighted to have left the open water behind him.

"If I'd have crashed into the Arctic ocean survival would have been difficult, so thank God that part of the voyage is behind me and I have the solid ice pack below," he said. "Now I can look forward to reaching the pole."

If he does reach the pole - and with conditions above the polar ice cap in summer relatively benign he has every chance - he will complete one of the last unconquered frontiers. Only one previous attempt has been made to reach the pole by balloon - over 100 years ago.

In 1897 three Swedish aeronauts led by Salomon Andree, an eminent scientist, left Spitzbergen aboard The Eagle, at the time the largest hydrogen balloon ever built. They did not return, and it was to be 33 years before the mystery of how they died became clear.

Andree owed his scientific reputation to his work with Alfred Nobel on the development of dynamite, but his true obsession lay beyond the laboratory.

He believed that Swedes were uniquely suited to polar exploration, and fired by national pride he enlisted two crew members, Nils Strindberg, 25, a student, and Knut Fraenkel, 27, an engineer.

Such was the clamour to join a venture that most observers felt would end in certain death that one of the hundreds of applicants offered to hang from a rope beneath the basket if there was not room on board. Fortunately for him his offer was rejected.

Andree's balloon was as primitive as Hempleman-Adams's is sophisticated. Constructed from some 3,000 sections of Chinese silk, the Eagle was fuelled by hydrogen, highly explosive and liable to leakage.

Hempleman-Adams's Britannic Challenge comes from the same stable as the Breitling Orbiter balloon which last year circumnavigated the globe. Where Hempleman-Adams has sophisticated navigation equipment and supplies of oxygen, Andree used carrier pigeons for communication and relied on a large supply of beer to boost spirits.

The Eagle was designed to carry enough hydrogen to fly for 30 days, ample time to cross the pole and land in Siberia or Alaska.

In the event, the flight of the Eagle lasted just 60 hours, crashing on to the ice little more than 400km from Spitzbergen, some 3,600km from the pole.

The Eagle never had a test flight, and within minutes of taking off the crew realised that the sail intended to steer the balloon was useless. As a result they headed north as a free floating balloon, entirely at the mercy of the winds. Andree himself had made just nine flights prior to his polar attempt; he was a novice flying into the unknown.

In adddition, Andree had failed to take into account the effects of weather. Shortly after take-off, the Eagle passed under low cloud, and the silk began to absorb water - when this froze, the Eagle's weight rose by more than a ton, throwing Andree's calculations into chaos.

The last 12 hours of the flight were spent bouncing across the ice before the inevitable decision to ditch was made. Symbolically, the beacon bearing the Swedish flag Andree had planned to toss out over the north pole was ditched on the first day in an effort to stay airborne.

Andree, Fraenkel and Strindberg were faced with a long march south over the ice and back to civilization. It was a journey they were ill-prepared to take, and they found themselves at the mercy of the drifting ice. While they headed south, the ice moved in unpredictable directions; they often found that after marching 15 miles they had ended up further north than when they started.

After two months on the ice and with winter drawing in, they had little choice but to pitch camp on White Island, north east of Spitzbergen. They were probably the first men ever to pitch camp on the icebound rock, and it was there that they died, not the victims of exposure but of infected polar bear meat.

Throughout their spell on the ice the men shot bears to supplement their tinned food supplies. Samples of bear meat were found with the perfectly preserved bodies of the team, and subsequent analysis revealed it was infected with the trichina parasite. Andree's diaries revealed they had eaten at least 20 meals from this meat. Trichinosis causes pneumonia and can lead to heart failure under exertion.

The bodies were discovered in 1930 by a Norwegian scientific expedition that passed White Island by chance, and they were taken back to Stockholm to a heroes' commemoration led by the king.

Brian Jones, flight director of the Britannic Challenge and a crew member, said the reason it had taken 103 years for someone else to try was the unique skills required for polar survival. "The type of person who can do this has to be far more than a balloon pilot. Arctic survival skills are far more important than balloon skills, and David has massive experience on the ice," he said.

And his Arctic experience includes walking to the north pole.
