fields.headline: Prostitutes imported into slavery
fields.standfirst: Home Office figures show 70% of Soho sex workers are foreigners, most here willingly but some smuggled in and forced to work
fields.trailText: The face is weary, the eyes flickering in both fear and curiosity. The woman is wearing a dressing gown, man-made fabric masquerading as silk, which she pulls over her underwear.
fields.body:
The face is weary, the eyes flickering in both fear and curiosity. The woman is wearing a dressing gown, man-made fabric masquerading as silk, which she pulls over her underwear.

The toilet door shuts and she loiters on the landing between two sex flats in Soho, central London. Suspicion, fear, panic make her shout: "What you want?" "Why" and "Busy now" in a heavily-accented voice, before slotting a key in the door with a notice advertising "The best sex in Soho". She disappears, her confusion echoed in the mutters to be heard inside the door.

The woman, young and quite beautiful, is just one of a growing number of eastern European women and other illegal immigrants working in the dark world that is the sex industry in London's West End. She is just one part of a worrying facet that has changed the sexual landscape of the flats, massage parlours and call services that offer sex in the capital. Today, many women are advertised as "young and fresh", "brand new", and "new in town" - all code words implying that the prostitute is foreign.

Kidnapped

According to a soon-to-be-published Home Office report, more than 70% per cent of all sex workers in Soho are foreign. Others will put it at between 75% and 80% in some areas. Some of the women are working willingly, but increasing evidence shows that many have been kidnapped and forced into the work; that they are, in fact, sex slaves. In London, according to one source, it has become a "multi multi million pound business".

The numbers are now so great that Home Office research and police intelligence reports show that the women and the traffickers and pimps are moving into suburbs all across Britain. Since the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989 sex workers from eastern Europe have crossed the borders but in the past five years they have moved across the Channel, to become commodities in the London sex trade. Now, as the UK seems less of a challenge, the sex workers are moving around.

For the majority of those five years police believe that most of the women knew they were coming to work in the sex industry but were duped about what they could earn and the type of sex they would have to perform. Now, though, intelligence reports suggests that a number of women are being smuggled into this country against their will.

Walk up the grubby stairwells of this Soho flat posted with cardboard signs advertising "models" and you can get an idea of just how many foreign women are working within this shady, often invisible trade. The sex workers themselves are not keen to talk, partly because they cannot speak English and partly because they are too scared. Often, there are pimps or traffickers who can be told quickly who is talking and what they are saying. Ask a woman where she is from and the reply is often "Eeengleesh" or, with the door closing, a smile and a simple "No honey, bye honey."

Some of the women work in the flats on their own, others have British maids who answer the door, greet the client, ask what kind of service he requires and communicates this to the prostitute in a kind of half verbal, half hand signal charade. The maids protect the ethnic origins of the girls within. They say the girls from eastern Europe are either Italian or Greek, no matter where they come from.

Eddie (not his real name) is a doorman who vets the punters for various Soho establishments. He has worked in the sex industry for 32 years, a scene, he says, which has changed over the last few years. "I wouldn't say every flat in Soho has a foreign girl in it, but in every other flat you will find a girl who comes from Kosovo, Albania, Romania. Before there used to be a lot of English and French girls but now the foreign girls are taking over. They don't hang around in the streets. They are always in the flats," he explains.

"Most of them are illegal immigrants. They make their way to England for a better life. Most of them don't speak English whatsoever, they can only say hello. I think the majority know what they are coming to. I think they come willingly to England. Maybe there's one or two cases where they force them to come."

Mafia links

Last year evidence emerged in court that women were indeed being forced into vice when three Lithuanian men were jailed for controlling four prostitutes they had trafficked. The men denied living off immoral earnings but were jailed for three years and recommended for deportation. In the four week trial, the jury heard how the break up of the Soviet Union led to mafia chiefs setting up organised vice rings in Britain. The jury was told that the women were handed fake documents and sent to London on false promises before being forced into brothels. One young mother from the Baltic told the jury she was "bought" by the gang for £2,400 and forced into prostitution. She said: "I had to work as a prostitute. I didn't want to do this but there was no choice. I was afraid, I was in a strange country and knew no one. There was always guards on the door of the brothel."

Such vice can be a difficult thing to police, especially since the women are more often than not the victims of crime. In the office that houses the 14-strong Metropolitan police vice squad in Charing Cross station near the square mile of Soho and its 75 brothels, Inspector Paul Holmes explains how difficult the situation has become.

He says that women working in effective imprisonment are too frightened to talk even if they could escape. Often, they have been told that the police here are in the pay of the criminal gangs or that if they report the crime they will be deported. The gangs always gather just enough information about the victim's family back home so that it can be used as a very serious threat of reprisal. In reality, the police are investigating a crime in which the victim cannot afford to talk.

"Up until recently we had not come across smuggled women. The majority of the women had travelled overtly on completely false documents or their own documents. But of late we are getting an increasing incidence of Balkan women being smuggled here," said Inspector Holmes. "The women are not deceived about what they will do but about the conditions they will have to do it in. What the women contract into is effectively debt bondage. She will agree to pay so much money to the traffickers in arrears for her travel documents, means of travel, accommodation here."

Inspector Holmes and his officers have found that the main regions of origin are central and south America, east and west Africa, south-east Asia, anywhere in the former Soviet bloc and the Balkan region. "Currently, Thai women are paying anywhere between £15,000 to £25,000. They are sold a package which is credible if it were true. Women are told 'we will get you in on a six month visa entitlement and you can pay that off in three months'. When she gets here reality kicks in. Immediately, her documents will be snatched. She will be taken to a safe house and from then it's all downhill. They say they must have forgot to mention it is £175 for the rent of the flat and £75 for the maid. So it's just loan-sharking. These women must be available for work and they must provide all services, including unprotected sex."

Ruthless

Last year the vice squad came across 284 foreign women working within Soho brothels. Inspector Holmes believes that in the sauna market the number of illegal women "could be as much as 80 to 90 per cent". He said: "We are investigating resourceful, ruthless individuals working entirely on their own through to highly organised gangs doing it on a wholesale basis.

"It's such an extremely profitable business. It's a multi multi million pound business in this city but the trafficking phenomena is not a London only problem. If you go to any location ranging from a market town to a big city that's got an off-street sex business, you are likely to find foreign women working there."

Inspector Holmes believes that the challenge for international law enforcement is to create the conditions in which the victims feel safe enough to testify. But he knows that each day the illegal trafficking of women gets bigger and bigger. And, like our European counterparts, Britain could see the beginnings of an extremely violent turf war for control of the business. He says: "We have not yet reached saturation point but we will. There is nothing to indicate that we are not going to get the violence that has gone with the spread of the trade across Europe."

fields.headline: Tories go a'courting
fields.standfirst:
Grey power takes the political stage

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: This could be the week future historians mark as the start of pensioner pulling power. For the second time within a week, the Tories have produced a package specially tailored to those over retirement age.
fields.body:
This could be the week future historians mark as the start of pensioner pulling power. For the second time within a week, the Tories have produced a package specially tailored to those over retirement age.

The latest offering, from a party which wants to cut taxation, includes six separate extra spending commitments. After decades of being ignored, with only tiny numbers of MPs present as earnings indices and other pension entitlements were whittled away, the pensioner lobby is not only being noticed but actively courted.

What is going on? After Labour's disastrous local election results in May, surveys suggested the one issue defeated candidates blamed was the tiny pension uprating this year - a mere 75p a week. Fundamental factors are also at work, the most important of them demographic. Retired people are increasing in number. The population bulge which created the youth culture of the 1960s is beginning to retire. There is nothing deferential about this generation; they are accustomed to asserting their rights. Unlike their predecessors, they do not feel particularly grateful for the welfare state. They have known nothing else. Moreover, private polling by the Tories suggests they resent Tony Blair's projecting the United Kingdom as a young country.

Of course the opposition is being opportunist. The same William Hague now promising to restore war widows' pensions to 2,500 women who lost it by re-marrying explicitly ruled this option out while he was a social security minister in 1995. Similar opportunities to introduce the new promises - extending invalid-care allowances to the over-60s, expanding breast screening to the over-65s, abolishing mixed-sex wards - were ignored by previous Tory administrations. But pensioners should ignore the opportunism and celebrate their coming of age. Indeed, cross-party peers have already amended the current pensions bill to give back war pensions to widows who remarry. What the pensioner lobby should examine is how they could make themselves more influential. Grey power has always been more successful in the United States through having a single association which caters for all needs of the retired from travel to politics. Hence its success in introducing an anti-age discrimination act 30 years ago, something for which the UK still awaits. It is time for Age Concern, Help the Aged and Saga to unite.

Indeed, cross-party peers have already amended the current pensions bill to give back war pensions to widows who remarry. What the pensioner lobby should examine is how they could make themselves more influential. Grey power has always been more successful in the United States through having a single association which caters for all needs of the retired from travel to politics. Hence its success in introducing an anti-age discrimination act 30 years ago, something for which the UK still awaits. It is time for Age Concern, Help the Aged and Saga to unite.

fields.headline: Terms of endearment
fields.trailText: Dear readers: how do I love thee? Let me count the ways... Your response to our request for least favourite word nominations has been a joy to behold. Aren't you funny? Aren't you clever? Is it time for a group hug yet?
fields.body:
Dear readers: how do I love thee? Let me count the ways... Your response to our request for least favourite word nominations has been a joy to behold. Aren't you funny? Aren't you clever? Is it time for a group hug yet?

As Voice of the Beehive originally sang, don't call us baby - or career woman, PR girl, housewife, spinster or It Girl. Inadvertent use of bitch, bubbly, stunning, totty, dolly-bird, and darling are similarly likely to incite random acts of violence.

And what about those They- Know-Who-They-Ares who remain oddly incapable of uttering the word woman? That's "wo-man", not "girl", and not 'lady'. "It is the year 2000 and the following exchange has just taken place," Gail Morrison tells us.

Me (in shop): 'I'd like to return this, please.'

Shop assistant (politely): 'Certainly, madam, can you remember who served you?'

Me (pointing her out): 'That woman over there.'

Shop assistant (now with raised eyebrow, atmosphere rather chilly): 'Do you mean the blonde lady ?'

I might as well have said, 'That slapper over there.' "

And terms of endearment ain't always received so: take "cute". "It's usually applied as a supposed compliment to a short woman (like me) or a woman who has some other amusing quality, like being elderly," notes Christy Karras.

Anna Statham suggests "empowerment" - "which means, in practice, to be blamed for something which used not to be my fault" - should also come in for a battering.

"Slut" and "slag" are universally loathed, but the worst offender is "cunt". As Flo Cairns eloquently puts it: "It's not the word itself but its use as a term of abuse which shocks most people. The usage proclaims a part of my anatomy as an insult and the offence is absolute. An old boyfriend liked it - his view was that how could the name of such a gorgeous organ be a bad thing? - and he tried to rehabilitate it by saying it with tenderness and love. It worked - almost."

Thanks to everyone who responded to our request for nominations. In the meantime, Sidelines' favourite word is "us".

fields.headline: Coming of age
fields.standfirst: The traditional lament of older women has been the loss of their sexual pulling power. But, says Clare Boylan, its demise brings surprising new rewards
fields.trailText: The traditional lament of older women has been the loss of their sexual pulling power. But, says Clare Boylan, its demise brings surprising new rewards
fields.body:
A friend of mine went to a fashionable restaurant for her 50th birthday. Her evening was not a success. What happened? Nothing! "As I walked into the restaurant no one looked up," she said. "Not one single man gave me a glance. I wouldn't have minded if they had raised their eyes and then looked away when they realised that it was a middle-aged woman. But how did they know, without even taking a first look, that I wasn't worth a second one?"

In Simone de Beauvoir's The Second Sex, there is a horrifying picture of the disillusion of the older woman as she watches the disintegration of all that gave her her power - her looks, her fertility, her sexual attraction. The surprise, according to de Beauvoir, is that this is not pre-eminent in the narcissistic beauty, the femme fatale, but in the ordinary woman who has unstintingly devoted herself to her family.

The femme fatale will have such intimate acquaintance with her mirror that she will have noted every line and slippage well in advance and will have made some adaptation. It is the virtuous and innocent woman to whom getting older comes as a blow. Suddenly, no one seems to notice her any more. No one seems to need her. The shock, says de Beauvoir, is almost as fatal as death itself.

The power to magnetise comes and goes, like a power supply in a storm, and then suddenly The Female Formerly Known as Babe thinks, "Hell, we're heading for a blackout." And it isn't, as women fear, due to an abrupt change from siren to hag. It is simply down to pheromonal slump. Men don't just look up when a young woman enters the room. They sniff the air. They are into the stud mode. As American journalist Jurate Jazickas put it: "At dinner parties they do not look at you and think, 'Well, she's old, but I'll bet she's led this really interesting life.' "

For most women, the invisibility of middle-age does come as a shock. Yet those who don't attempt to stage a desperate retreat back to adolescence are in for a heady decade. "Women become the sum of their experiences," one woman said. "They absorb and embody their lives. They grow into a rich and colourful tapestry. Men simply stack up experience. They use it for statistical purposes. In regard to emotions, they learn almost nothing."

"What's great about older women," said another friend, "is that they lose the giggle and develop a really dirty laugh. It is a particular sort of smoky music that is like good jazz. It is a mixture of wisdom and compassion and celebration of survival." This woman is an artist, 63 and still outstandingly attractive. She has been so delighted by the idea of dirty laughter that she has done a series of paintings on the theme, all showing women eating tremendous amounts of food, drinking wine and laughing so that their faces nearly come in half. She was recently approached by a man who asked her to do a similar series of paintings of laughing men. "I really wanted to do it," she said, "but men don't laugh in the same way. Men bark with laughter. It sometimes sounds like a cry of pain or anger. Women's laughter flows."

All through my youthful life, I was a placator of men. It was the price I paid for flattery and approval. It wasn't that I saw the opposite sex as my superiors. I simply had an archetypal case of hero complex. Men were strong and noble. Somewhere out there was the one who would mend my plumbing and my heart. When I was nine or ten, I remember my (then middle-aged) mother saying: "All men talk about integrity and all men are liars." While her statement seems a little strong even now (the duplicity between the sexes is mutual, even if a little heavy on the testosterone end), I find myself at that same sign post. What I want now is not flattery, but frankness; not resolution, but revelation. Being able to see men clearly, being able to divide what they say from what they mean, must give women the greatest freedom since the pill.

In her book Red Hot Mommas: Coming into our Own at Fifty, the American feminist Colette Dowling wrote of an epiphanic conversation with a group of women friends hitting 50 in the kitchen during a dinner party, in which they finally came to terms with their views on men and sex. "Returning to the men in the dining room felt a little like retreating to the back ranks after a brief, but exhilarating, moment on the revolutionary front."

There is something distinctly revolutionary about the mid-life female. In her fertile years, each new experience is seen, at some level, either as potential nest-building material, or as a threat to the nest. In the older woman, experience exists for itself alone and every event - the bad as well as the good - is held up to the light with interest and excitement. Even the rattiest bits go into their treasure box, for, although it may not bring love or wealth or reassurance, it is life and life itself is the treasure.

An obsession with the opposite sex is gradually replaced with a huge curiosity about the wider world. This does not mean that women lose interest in sex. They do, however, tend to lose patience. The newly outspoken woman has little tolerance with being groped in the wrong spot or being eased towards the bedroom with soulful chat lines. Nor do they want their pleasure as part of a 24-hour catering package. As one woman, quoted in Colette Dowling's book, said: "I certainly wouldn't rule out having another lover, but never again in my life will I cook dinner for a man."

All the same, it is not surprising that society considers women to be past their sell-by date when the womb packs up. This isn't merely a patriarchal put-down. Our own bodies feel exactly the same way. When a woman reaches the menopause, the brain hits the trip switch on follicle stimulating hormone, or FSH, which revs the system at high speed in a desperate (and futile) attempt to whip the ovaries back into production. It is this overheated engine that causes the insomnia, hot flushes and night sweats that plague some menopausal women. It seems astonishing that millennia of evolution have not educated our bodies into accepting their mature phase, but clearly the female body feels threatened by redundancy.

But far from being a punishment for the post-reproductive female, her new-found freedom and perception is a woman's reward for a job well done, for long years of service to the human race.

For the first time, the clear vista of the second half of her life becomes properly visible. No longer needing approval or fearing derision, no longer at the mercy of society's perceived view of physical attraction, no longer putting her family's interests first in everything, she can climb Mount Everest, take up line dancing, write a novel, get a degree. A surprising number of women do any or all of the above. Of course, the 30-year stretch from 50 to 80 isn't quite the same thing as that from 20 to 50. What about 60, for instance? Well, Kurt Vonnegut once said: "A woman of 60 is a volcano." One can only look forward to that.

 Clare Boylan's latest novel, Beloved Stranger, is published on June 1 by Abacus, price £6.99.

fields.headline: Inside Tate Modern
fields.standfirst: This week: An Encounter in the Calle Valentin Gomez Farias, Tijuana (1991), by Jeff Wall, in the temporary exhibition Between Cinema and a Hard Place
fields.trailText: This week: An Encounter in the Calle Valentin Gomez Farias, Tijuana (1991), by Jeff Wall, in the temporary exhibition Between Cinema and a Hard Place.
fields.body:
This photograph of an everyday encounter is burned into my memory. Whenever I recall it, I have the uncanny feeling that once I stood at the foot of this hill in this border town, watching a dog and a cockerel squaring up to one other.

The Calle Valentin Gomez Farias, named after a dead Mexican president, is more like a dried-up riverbed than a road. There is a guy climbing the hill, and maybe a couple further up, looking back as he climbs towards them. I am not sure, as I squint through the heat-haze, if they are truly there, although I feel certain I am there, beside the pick-up truck. The dog snarling, the cockerel rooted to the spot. The moment has the power and portentousness of allegory.

There is nothing to tell us how we ought to read this scene. The more I look, the more complex the image gets, the more suspect its reality. Canadian artist Jeff Wall's photographic tableaux are constructed, staged inventions. The photographic perspective of the image - the sharp foreground focus and progressive blurring - has been manipulated and intensified. The brow of the hill is in endless retreat, receding impossibly into a magnified distance. The world is tilted. There is too much space, too much distance, too much sharpness and clarity. It is a fierce image, in a fierce light.

Wall calls his works "prose poems". His large-scale, back-lit transparencies have a cinematographic quality. However physically transparent they appear to be, they contain multiple layers of meaning. What at first appears as a plain record of an ordinary moment shows itself to be misleading. It is also a kind of sublime spectacle. How else to explain the terrible grandeur of this urban hinterland, the way it transfixes me, like a chicken looking into the open jaws of a snarling dog?

A second, even larger work by Wall hangs nearby. A Sudden Gust of Wind (After Hokusai) is an updated, photographic transcription of one of Hokusai's woodblock prints. It is a grand pictorial machine, ripe with incident and wit. Fascinating though it is, it cannot compare to the power and subtlety of this encounter on a border hillside. Wall takes us to a contested region - between photography and film, a tart parody of utopian 19th-century paintings of a New World sublime. And what, we ask ourselves, happens next?

fields.headline: Let there be light...
fields.standfirst: ...and patchwork and photographs and video.  Jonathan Jones sees what happens when Tracey Emin and Damien Hirst go to church
fields.trailText: ...and patchwork and photographs and video. Jonathan Jones sees what happens when Tracey Emin and Damien Hirst go to church.
fields.body:
Driving hail battered the church in which performance artist Bobby Baker opened Art in Sacred Spaces, an exhibition of contemporary art in working religious buildings across London. Baker delivered the Sunday sermon at the church she regularly attends wearing a white smock smeared with tomato ketchup to illustrate the sin of anger. She told us that what she does about stains is wash them out in her wonderful washing machine. After a quick change she paraded up and down the aisle to the strains of Abba, showing off her smock, which was now a dazzling white. So the church is like a washing machine? Or it isn't? Should Dawn French tire of playing The Vicar of Dibley, Baker would make a perfect replacement.

Once the hail might have been taken as a critical judgment, in the days when a church was imagined as a place that was literally sacred, the house of God. The duty of the artist was to make that sacredness visible in the paintings and carvings that decorated God's house. What we now call site-specific art began with a painting like Titian's altarpiece of the Assumption (1516-18) in the church of the Frari in Venice, a seven-metre tall canvas whose action leads up, up and away from gloomy earth into a realm of light as the Virgin floats towards the blazing gold of paradise. If this painting were to be placed in a museum we would miss one the most astonishing coups de theatre in art as Titian's painted light fuses with the real gold evening sky in the huge windows above.

There are good reasons why we do not, and would not want to, live in a world where art and religion are so gorgeously one. But do modern churches have to be quite so aesthetically impoverished? Most of the spaces where this exhibition took place felt as sacred as waiting rooms. The church where Bobby Baker delivered her sermon was your bog- standard neogothic C of E church with an uneasy mixture of pointy arches and bright, friendly décor. Baker's ser mon displayed the same pinched timidity behind its bluster. Come on, give us some fire and brimstone.

Art in Sacred Spaces is organised by "a board of religious leaders and arts professionals with a consultant arts project manager" and feels like it. There is Millennium Fund money, a mix of famous artists willing to show something they knocked up earlier and less famous ones glad of the commission, an enthusiastic art public willing to give up their Sundays traipsing to obscure churches, chapels and synagogues in search of that special site-specific frisson. But there seems to be no courage about asking hard questions of art or religion. What does it mean that our very idea of art was born in a religious context?

Art in Sacred Spaces is less about rethinking the relationship between art and religion than letting the glamorous limelight of art pour through dusty 19th-century stained glass windows. Suffer the little children to come unto me, said Tracey Emin, and the result is a patchworked blanket on which pupils from Ecclestone Primary School name things they find beautiful. "The children's interest was quickly aroused when they were told that a famous artist called Tracey Emin would be working with them," salivates a leaflet in St Mary's Church. The blanket is laid out in front of the altar. Things the children find beautiful include rabbits, cats, the sea, Spain, their mums. Aw, innit lovely.

This artwork at least has a certain bravery. Emin is not afraid of being thought sentimental or tacky; in coming on like a charity-shop Matisse, worshipping beauty with cut-up rags just like he did in the chapel he decorated near Cannes, she acknowledges the celebratory, incantatory function of art. You leave thanking the Lord that she has found a subject other than herself.

The critic Walter Benjamin argued that the symbiosis of art, architecture and history in a venerable religious space creates an "aura" that art has lost in the modern world as it separated itself from such places. The photographer Catherine Yass has made a career of misunderstanding Benjamin. She takes pictures of places saturated in history and atmosphere, then adds a blue ectoplasmic aura to the image. Here she shows photographs in a synagogue, the Congregation of Jacob in Whitechapel. This 1921 building, which feels as if it has been here since 1721, with its delicate blue walls and skylight, is the one building on the trail which feels sacred. Yass has taken pictures of this and other East End synagogues that hijack their atmosphere and turn them into images of decay.

Art in Sacred Spaces avoids the hard and rocky road for the primrose path. The religious bodies involved seem embarrassingly eager to suck up to the gods of Britart. Some artists have simply allowed the use of existing works, displayed like relics. Rachel Whiteread shows some old screenprints in a Hackney synagogue. Mark Wallinger's well-known video Angel, in which the artist plays a blind man reciting the opening of St John's gospel at the bottom of the escalator of Angel tube station, Islington, is screened with what seems pointless literalness at St John the Evangelist Roman Catholic church round the corner from the Angel tube station.

Only one artist has the brazen gall to state what is really happening here. Damien Hirst worships himself at St Stephen's, whose vicar says he feels "bold" for showing Hirst's The Last Supper. Hirst's Last Supper consists of prints in the manner of pharmaceuti cal labels advertising sausage and mash and steak pie hygienically sealed and sold by the company Damien & Hirst. You think of the transubstantiation of matter into commodity. You think of the other Last Supper, Leonardo's, kept behind several plated glass doors and vacuum-sealed corridors, a monument to the moment when artists became bigger than Jesus.

Art in Sacred Spaces is in locations around north and east London, till June 11. Details: 020-7690 4809.

The blanket is laid out in front of the altar. Things the children find beautiful include rabbits, cats, the sea, Spain, their mums. Aw, innit lovely. This artwork at least has a certain bravery. Emin is not afraid of being thought sentimental or tacky; in coming on like a charity-shop Matisse, worshipping beauty with cut-up rags just like he did in the chapel he decorated near Cannes, she acknowledges the celebratory, incantatory function of art. You leave thanking the Lord that she has found a subject other than herself. The critic Walter Benjamin argued that the symbiosis of art, architecture and history in a venerable religious space creates an "aura" that art has lost in the modern world as it separated itself from such places. The photographer Catherine Yass has made a career of misunderstanding Benjamin. She takes pictures of places saturated in history and atmosphere, then adds a blue ectoplasmic aura to the image. Here she shows photographs in a synagogue, the Congregation of Jacob in Whitechapel. This 1921 building, which feels as if it has been here since 1721, with its delicate blue walls and skylight, is the one building on the trail which feels sacred. Yass has taken pictures of this and other East End synagogues that hijack their atmosphere and turn them into images of decay. Art in Sacred Spaces avoids the hard and rocky road for the primrose path. The religious bodies involved seem embarrassingly eager to suck up to the gods of Britart. Some artists have simply allowed the use of existing works, displayed like relics. Rachel Whiteread shows some old screenprints in a Hackney synagogue. Mark Wallinger's well-known video Angel, in which the artist plays a blind man reciting the opening of St John's gospel at the bottom of the escalator of Angel tube station, Islington, is screened with what seems pointless literalness at St John the Evangelist Roman Catholic church round the corner from the Angel tube station. Only one artist has the brazen gall to state what is really happening here. Damien Hirst worships himself at St Stephen's, whose vicar says he feels "bold" for showing Hirst's The Last Supper. Hirst's Last Supper consists of prints in the manner of pharmaceuti cal labels advertising sausage and mash and steak pie hygienically sealed and sold by the company Damien & Hirst. You think of the transubstantiation of matter into commodity. You think of the other Last Supper, Leonardo's, kept behind several plated glass doors and vacuum-sealed corridors, a monument to the moment when artists became bigger than Jesus. Art in Sacred Spaces is in locations around north and east London, till June 11. Details: 020-7690 4809.

fields.headline: From bed to worse
fields.trailText: Kate Clanchy: Ultrasoundings: The trouble is, this is not a soothing subject. It's fraught, fought over, and for all the pally language used in the self-help books, highly ideological.
fields.body:
The trouble is, this is not a soothing subject. It's fraught, fought over, and for all the pally language used in the self-help books, highly ideological. The National Childbirth Trust Book of Sleep, for instance, advocates sleeping with your baby until it is more or less an adolescent. That is it strongly implies - though it pretends not to - that your baby will stop breathing/suffer cot death/endure psychological damage through separation anxiety if you don't. The only women it quotes who put their babies in cots are either work-obsessed harpies or those in the grip of primitively sexist relationships with men who won't even let them breast-feed. Proper NCT men, on the other hand, sleep on their fronts to protect their privates from the baby's kicking feet, or, in one melancholy case, have been on the sofa in a sleeping bag for three years.

This is not why I got married. It took me 30 years to find someone I wanted to share my bed with, and I don't want to split it. Even having the cat at my feet for an hour gives me backache, and I'm allowed to kick him off. Nor am I reassured by books like The Continuum Concept or Three in a Bed, with their constant citing of "other cultures" where babies are carried around day and night and are always happy. I don't believe that hardworking rural families have ever allowed their children to wake them up four or five times a night. Anyway, the cultures seem to have one thing in common: they treat women as beasts of burden.

Besides, there seems to be an entirely opposite set of sleep books dedicated to teaching your baby to get out of your bed and into his cot for long, solo sleeps. There is even a new American verb, to Ferber-ise, which means to put your child through a nail-biting programme of controlled wailing in order to achieve this. "Ferber" is Dr Richard, a fully paid-up Harvard sleep-scientist.

His best-seller, Solve Your Child's Sleep Problems is firmly against co-sleeping and stuffed with information about REM sleep patterns but not entirely soothing in the depths of the night. It offers just one too many case studies of children who wake up at 5am until they're four years old, have "detached naps", or bed-wet till they're ten. And all their parents started off as kind, reasonable people, just like me.

The book I actually find most soothing was passed to me with the urgency of a samizdat pamphlet by my cousin. She's got two children and swears by it. It's called The Contented Little Baby Book, is by a maternity nurse, Gina Ford, and is an extremely subversive and entertaining document. Gina advocates getting your baby into a routine from birth. She draws up timetables for swaddling, feeding and napping in dark rooms, and promises, providing "my routines are followed to the letter", a night's sleep by the time the child is six weeks old. She is outrageously priggish and bossy, in short, and does not believe in colic.

But she also does something the other books don't: she acknowledges, consistently, on every page, the effect of tiredness on the mother, and suggests ways to avoid it. Sometimes, while reading Gina on the importance of blackout blinds, I even drop off myself.

fields.headline: The art of office life
fields.standfirst: The Guardian is to have an artist-in-residence.  Dan Glaister reports
fields.trailText: Today the Guardian becomes part of the Year of the Artist, a £4m scheme to place 1,000 artists in residence in 1,000 different places. The Guardian will in fact have two residencies: it will continue its support for Streets Alive, a theatre company whose productions are created and performed by homeless people, and it will appoint an artist-in-residence to work in its London offices.
fields.body:
Ooh, it's a giggle. Barnsley Football Club had a poet, and so did the law firm Mishcon de Reya. Better still, London Zoo, lurching from crisis to crisis, hit on the idea of a poet-in-residence, hoping that verse would "help to interpret the lives of the animals". And then there was good old Marks & Spencer. Not only did it have its own poet, it also invested in sessions with Adventures in Motion Pictures. The ballet company, a spokesperson said, demonstrated its rehearsal technique and its development of characterisation to M&S staff. No sooner had the shelf stackers recovered from that, than in came Bulgarian-born wrap artist Christo to share his thoughts on the creative use of fabrics with the staff. How we laughed.

And then there was the Today Programme. The stuffy shirts of Radio 4's early morning shift were to have a sound artist in the studio with them, subverting matters of national interest with a series of ultra-low frequencies. Presenter John Humphrys was not amused. "If anybody wants to mess about with our interviews, I think we might have something to say about it." Absolutely. It could never happen here.

But now it has. Today the Guardian becomes part of the Year of the Artist, a £4m scheme to place 1,000 artists in residence in 1,000 different places. The Guardian will in fact have two residencies: it will continue its support for Streets Alive, a theatre company whose productions are created and performed by homeless people, and it will appoint an artist-in-residence to work in its London offices.

"Artists are not there simply to illustrate or depict," wrote Sian Ede of the Gulbenkian Foundation, one of the first organisations to become involved with residencies in this country. The idea of artists in residence stems from the work of 60s artist-theoreticians such as John Latham, who helped to set up the Artists' Placement Group, dedicated to the placing of artists in government departments. The group saw the artist as an idiot savant who could comment on issues from the outside, bringing an artistic sensibility to decision-making.

An artist-in-residence can help an organisation to make sense of itself, providing a different perspective and possibly a new insight into the daily working routine. Whether being involved in the big picture - the daily editorial conference at which the paper's treatment of the day's stories is thrashed out - or the minutiae of daily office life, we hope that an artist-in-residence will tell us things about our organisation and our workplace.

Unusually for a newspaper, there is no programme and no deadline. The fewer preconceptions, the fewer requests that are made of the artist, the better. Almost the only limitation we are placing on the artist-in-residence is the medium. We have decided to invite applications from digital artists. The Guardian has a substantial IT department, a huge resource that is used in just one way, to help publish a newspaper. It is a resource that could promise much to an artist working with new technologies. And it is through technology that most of the people working at the Guardian communicate: our common asset, from commercial departments to the paper's website, is the computer - we all work with it, and we all work through it. A digital artist will have the opportunity to reach all of us, and possibly all of our readers, whether they be consumers of the newspaper or its online incarnation.

fields.headline: Catapult casualty
fields.standfirst: Woman hurt in bounce from safety net
fields.trailText: Dangerous Sports Club member Stella Young was stable in hospital yesterday after being catapulted 120ft and bouncing out of a net supposed to catch her.
fields.body:
Dangerous Sports Club member Stella Young was stable in hospital yesterday after being catapulted 120ft and bouncing out of a net supposed to catch her.

Ms Young, 44, a Citizens' Advice Bureau manager, fell 30ft, breaking her pelvis when the "flight" went wrong in a garden at Stogursey, Somerset, on Sunday. Her boyfriend, Richard Wicks, encouraged her to become the third person to try the human catapult based on the medieval trebuchet. He helped build it and was the first person to try it.

Bill Fryer, a friend of Ms Young, said: "She is lucky to be alive. It was an horrendous accident."

fields.headline: The French take the reins
fields.standfirst:
But Paris may funk its European moment

The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The French start their turn as presidents of the European Union this week on the back foot. The German foreign minister's appeal for a swift move to pan-European voting, constitution and all, caught them unawares.
fields.body:
The French start their turn as presidents of the European Union this week on the back foot. The German foreign minister's appeal for a swift move to pan-European voting, constitution and all, caught them unawares.

On the other hand they do not warm to Tony Blair's neo-liberal vision of a "flexible" Europe - which carried the day at the Lisbon summit (though they must wonder how far France's success in adapting to the internet age comes despite not because of French state practice and socialist policy). On security and defence, it is French unwillingness, which the United Kingdom shares, to give up the trappings and pretensions of great power status that helps explain the lack of movement since Xavier de Solana was appointed special commissioner last year.

But it is the issue of enlarging the EU that exposes the French most cruelly. Inside the next six months, prior to the summit planned for year's end in Nice, they have either to tell the candidates from east-central Europe effectively to forget it or else accelerate the process of redrafting Europe's constitution to breakneck speed. So far Paris has shown no aptitude for either.

Joschka Fischer said his enthusiasm for a great European leap forward was personal, but he carries a chunk of the German political class with him. Paris was nonplussed. After all, it used to be the French - Giscard, Delors, Mitterrand - who decided when and where the engine moved. Neither prime minister Lionel Jospin nor President Chirac are conviction "Europeans". Both have lately been discomfited by restless natives - Charles Pasqua and former followers of the Front National at Mr Chirac's shoulder, the left-wing nationalist, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, blowing raspberries at Mr Jospin's cabinet table.

Now their discomfort becomes internationally visible, sandwiched as they are between German willingness to consider a profound shift in political power and the scepticism of London and the Scandinavians. (Political instability in Rome means the Italians bring nothing to the party; it is possible the French may have to contend with Silvio Berlusconi as head of an emphatically right-wing coalition.) Paris exhibits a similar discomfort in global affairs. French left and right toy with anti-Americanism but know that constructing a European alternative - one with its own version of market capitalism, with its own defence and security interests, for which it is prepared to fight - means submerging French sovereignty, including opposition to UK beef imports.

Paris must now stage-manage an intergovernmental conference leading to a new treaty. Its main subject is how the EU operates if enlargement goes ahead. Mr Fischer has as good as said: formalise a Europe that moves in its different blocs at different speeds. Admit the Poles, Hungarians and others to an outer dimension, while a streamlined federal entity is created at Europe's (Franco-German) core. The logic says: either slow enlargement to a pace compatible with the EU's present governance, or allow expansion eastwards to happen on condition there are huge changes to the way Europe works.

The first of these would require the French to tell the Poles to wait for full accession. The second demands from Paris outward-looking imagination of a kind that the Chirac-Jospin cohabitation has so far lacked. Perhaps there was a time of continental lassitude when Tony Blair might have seized the EU's leadership. If so, the moment has passed. The French now have the reins, even if they are unlikely to jerk the beast into new life.

fields.headline: Early to bed
fields.standfirst: MPs spend more time with their familiesParliament: special report
fields.trailText: The House of Commons is in recess this week, timed happily to coincide with school half-term. Slowly parliament is recognising that its members have responsibilities as parents. But not quickly enough.
fields.body:
The House of Commons is in recess this week, timed happily to coincide with school half-term. Slowly parliament is recognising that its members have responsibilities as parents. But not quickly enough.

The groundswell of complaint is fuelled by the large number of restless Labour backbenchers. Many have found the MP's role frustrating and unrewarding. Tess Kingham is retiring at the next election, saying the Commons is "a 19th-century gentleman's club", where most that goes on is a waste of time. Liberal Democrat Mark Oaten makes a similar complaint about debates that drag on with little said of any consequence. All this must press hard on young parents - who have to justify by the value of their work tough decisions about whether they are there for their children's bedtime, birthday parties or doctors' appointments .

For the truth is that very little of the real business of politics happens in the House of Commons any more. In his cynical way Austin Mitchell made the point in observing that chasing MPs was hardly worth lobbyists' time, so little did they have to offer. Power has shifted to Number 10, the cabinet room, to television and radio studios. Which leaves the 1997 influx of younger ambitious MPs champing at the bit.

Hopes of reform were pinned on the Commons' specialist select committees. But their bid for more resources and an independent panel to appoint members has now been rebuffed by a government reluctant to see MPs acquire more independence. There is even a possibility that the House of Lords may pip the Commons to the post in reforming procedures. Its leader, Lady Jay, recently advocated daytime sittings and practical changes to let members plan their lives. It is about time Labour brought its own rhetoric about a better balance between life and work to bear on its parliamentary supporters.

fields.headline: Villagers bypassed on computer highway
fields.trailText: Rural communities are falling behind in online buying despite hopes that the internet could compensate for the decline in village shops, a study reveals.
fields.body:
Rural communities are falling behind in online buying despite hopes that the internet could compensate for the decline in village shops, a study reveals.

One in 10 Britons shop online with well-heeled urban commuter types being, as ever, the most sought-after customer while older people living in out of the way places are more likely to be unfamiliar with buying on the net.

The research, compiled by market analysts CACI using 30m lifestyle records, shows that Reading is the online consumer capital with nearly 18% of adults regularly surfing the web for holidays, books, CDs and other goods and services. London and Cambridge follow close behind.

In these and other online boom towns such as Chester, Southampton and Brighton, internet shopping poses a real threat to those businesses with little or no web presence.

But wide swaths have been left almost untouched. In the north of England, Scotland and Wales only 16% of adults are online and less than 6% are frequent online buyers while rural and remote counties such as Cornwall or Orkney show the greatest reluctance to take up shopping on the web.

Lower computer literacy was partly to blame for the slow uptake of internet shopping in rural areas, the authors suggest. "A lot of people have access to the internet at work, and those kinds of white-collar jobs tend to be more concentrated in urban areas," said Paul Winters, head of market analysis at CACI.

The study notes the irony that the lowest profile in e-commerce is in rural communities, "one of the catchment types with potentially most to gain from the internet" because of the decline in transport and shops.

Mr Winters said: "For someone in a rural community to be able to go online and order everything from groceries to clothing and CDs and have them delivered to their door would seem more advantageous than for someone like me who can get on the tube and be in the West End in minutes."

The urban centres at the bottom end of the scale are predominantly in poorer northern areas, with Liverpool having only 16.6% of the population online and just 5% as frequent online purchasers.

The report highlights not only a clear north-south divide, but also a sharp distinction between rich and poor despite the lower prices online.

The north has concentrations of online shoppers in areas like Wilmslow, Manchester's wealthy commuter suburb, while Edinburgh is among the exceptions to the rule in Scotland. However, digital TV could change the scale of online buying in the next 10 years.

The report's authors say their analysis would give a better guide to the real worth of internet businesses than the present system based on the number of customer hits or registered members.

webTitle: Witnesses sue police for 'nine years of hell'

fields.headline: Witnesses sue police for 'nine years of hell'
fields.trailText: The Metropolitan police is being sued by two murder trial witnesses who claim that a secret special operations unit at Scotland Yard failed to take care of them after they were promised new identities and a new life under the witness protection programme.
fields.body:
The Metropolitan police is being sued by two murder trial witnesses who claim that a secret special operations unit at Scotland Yard failed to take care of them after they were promised new identities and a new life under the witness protection programme.

The unprecedented legal action, which accuses the unit, SO10, of breach of contract, negligence and misrepresentation, could be highly embarrassing to the police, who rely on the reputation of the programme to secure testimony in gangland and terrorism cases.

If they win the case it could spark a flood of similar complaints from other people who believe they have been badly treated under the programme.

The two women, who cannot be named, say they were promised a fresh start with new names and a carefully crafted background after agreeing to testify in the murder trial of a known drug dealer. Instead, they claim, they have endured nine years of hell, during which the police have failed to provide them with adequate housing, protection or peace of mind.

Speaking to the Guardian through an intermediary, the women said they felt that the police had treated them with contempt and effectively ruined their lives. "They believe the police just thought that as they were drug addicts they would be dead pretty quickly, and they would not have to worry about them anymore," the intermediary said.

The saga began in 1991 when a local drug dealer bragged to one of the women that he had killed an acquaintance.

At first they thought he was joking, but after he was arrested the women went to the police to tell them what they knew. They were told their testimony would be crucial to the case and were asked to sign witness statements and agree to give evidence at the trial.

On the east London housing estate where they lived, being a prosecution witness was considered equivalent to being a grass. But they were promised protection, and after being given 24 hours to decide the two agreed to take the stand.

A team from SO10, which runs the witness protection programme, came to the east London police station. The women were promised new identities with a "background" cover story.

They claimed that officers told them they would be rehoused in a two bedroom house with a garden, similar to the one they lived in already, when it was safe to do so. They also claimed that they expressed a desire to receive drug rehabilitation treatment, but the police told them they could not have counselling until after the trial, because it might prejudice their evidence.

Officers arrived at their house at dawn the next morning. They were told they could take whatever they could load into their car, while the rest would be put in storage. They were taken to a caravan park on the outskirts of Dover, Kent. A local doctor prescribed them sleeping tablets and the heroin substitute diamorphine.

After five months they moved into rundown premises in Dover. There was no cooker, curtains or carpet, and the walls were damp, they said. The police delivered their belongings from storage in boxes marked Metropolitan police.

SO10 insisted that, though they were lesbians, they should pretend to be sisters. They were given national insurance cards, but they had been filled out incorrectly and the mistakes whited out.

Rather than getting a new identity they each effectively had two names: one for receiving drugs from the doctor and another for collecting benefit. They could not open bank accounts or obtain passports or driving licences.

They testified at the trial of the accused man, but he was acquitted. Afterwards, they claimed, they did not hear from SO10 for almost three years. During this time they became reclusive and unwell. They were not referred to a psychiatrist or anybody else who could help them to overcome their addiction and other psychological problems, because the police had told their doctor it would be a breach of security.

The neighbours became suspicious, and at one point local police were planning to raid the house as a suspected IRA safe house after a tip-off, but at the last minute an officer recognised the address.

It was only after a newspaper wrote a story on their plight that SO10 got back in touch, they said. A senior officer promised to sort out the situation, but a psychiatrist who was sent to see them reported that the only problem they had was drug dependency.

The neighbours became more hostile. The women's car was vandalised, and some grass and a fake bullet were put through the letterbox.

In 1995 S010 finally arranged for them to be seen by a drugs clinic and formalised their new identity as sisters. They moved back to "temporary" accommodation in London, but the flat had no heating and was barely furnished. From then on communication with SO10 virtually ceased.

The women say they are bringing the case, to be heard by a judge at the central London county court in autumn, to try to make the police tighten up the witness protection rules and ensure that nobody has to go through what they have. If they lose they threaten to take the case to the European court of human rights.

webTitle: University prepares to demote the bard

fields.headline: University prepares to demote the bard
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: The dons of Cambridge University  are considering scrapping their exam paper on Shakespeare to make way for more modern literature.
fields.body:
For John Keats, one-time medic turned Romantic poet, the works of William Shakespeare were, quite simply, "enough".

It was a view shared by the majority of his contemporaries and successors but not, it would appear, by the dons of Cambridge University who are considering scrapping their exam paper on the bard to make way for more modern literature.

The highly controversial move - which is set to draw accusations of "dumbing down" - would mean the playwright would no longer be given privileged status but would be studied alongside his contemporaries as part of a paper spanning works from 1550 to 1700.

In addition, there would be a compulsory Shakespeare question in a separate paper on tragedies. But there would be no requirement to answer any more than the two questions on his entire canon, comprising 37 plays, two narrative poems and 148 sonnets.

The proposal, which is unlikely to come into force for three years, is being considered because the university wants to make more room for Victorian and 20th century authors, currently crammed into a single paper covering literature from 1830 to the present day.

"Every year that paper becomes more of a monstrosity because it becomes longer, and something has to be done about it," said Anne Barton, a fellow of Trinity College.

In addition, the faculty believes that few students read the entire canon and that many of them merely regurgitate their A-level texts in the exam room.

"If the Shakespeare paper is made a compulsory part of the renaissance paper, it's not the end of the world," said Professor Barton. "In fact, I think there's a good deal to be said for putting him in the context of contemporary literature, both dramatic and non-dramatic."

She added: "There's no question of scrapping Shakespeare as a compulsory part of the degree and to accuse us of 'dumbing down' is ridiculous."

But the recommendation, which follows Oxford University's recent move to make its Anglo Saxon course optional, has drawn strong criticism from academics outside the university.

"Of course I think it's absolutely necessary to study Shakespeare", said Frank Kermode, the university's former King Edward VII professor of English, who added he would be "very surprised" if the proposal succeeded.

"The whole of our literature has to be estimated in relation to him. This seems to me a foolishness. It would certainly change the whole balance of the course and would be a net loss to put it mildly."

John Carey, Merton professor of English literature at Oxford University, said: "I'm personally in favour of a compulsory paper because Shakespeare seems to be the one writer who everyone who comes afterwards has read.

"All the writers after him have read, learned, allude to, react against him. So, unless you know your Shakespeare, you don't read post-Shakespeare literature properly.

"I do think you have to read the whole canon if you are reading Shakespeare - and if it's just an option on a renaissance paper, people won't do it."

"Keats in his letters said 'Shakespeare is enough for us' and I think that if you had to choose one author, he'd be the one. Is he enough? Well, he's a start."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Tonight's live transmission from the Grand Theatre in Leeds is certainly one for connoisseurs.
fields.body:
Tonight's live transmission from the Grand Theatre in Leeds is certainly one for connoisseurs.

Performance On 3 (7.10pm, Radio 3) offers a rare production of Handel's ground-breaking opera Radamisto. The work, performed tonight by Opera North, was written in 1720 for the newly formed Royal Academy of Music, which hired Handel (pictured) as its musical director. The impact of Radamisto turned London into the operatic centre of Europe for years afterwards.

Harold Arlen never achieved the same public recognition as his contemporaries, yet his talents matched those of Irving Berlin or Cole Porter. His most famous song was Somewhere Over The Rainbow, but Don Black has picked the title of an earlier hit for his series about Arlen.

The World On A String (10.0pm, Radio 2) was written for the Cotton Club, where Arlen made his reputation back in the 1930s. This first programme airs other Arlen successes of that period, including Stormy Weather and That Old Black Magic.

webTitle: Scottish marriage à la mode offers Celt safety hatch

fields.headline: Scottish marriage à la mode offers Celt safety hatch
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: It was, for centuries, the perfect marriage. Couples were bound together in a simple ceremony and, if after a year they could not get on together, there was a built-in get-out clause. Handfasting used to be the only way for respectable Scots to marry.
fields.body:
It was, for centuries, the perfect marriage. Couples were bound together in a simple ceremony and, if after a year they could not get on together, there was a built-in get-out clause. Handfasting used to be the only way for respectable Scots to marry.

Nowadays, as more couples want to wed according to Celtic tradition, William Mackie, a bishop of the obscure Celtic Church in Scotland, wants the handfasting ceremony given legal recognition once again.

Following the Braveheart film, he has performed an increasing number of such weddings - only, to abide by the law, his rite omits the offer to part after 365 days. "I plan to lobby MSPs to get it reinstated in its entirety: a lot of people make a mistake and, as long as there are no children involved, the one year opt-out would save a lot of hassle," he said.

Handfasting was suppressed following the Synod of Whitby in 664AD when Celtic Christianity was abandoned for the Catholic Church. But changes in Scots law catering for a variety of ceremonies have allowed the custom to return.

Last year there were 19 Celtic ceremonies and Mr Mackie believed the trend was gathering steam - in no small part due to the scene in Braveheart where Mel Gibson, playing William Wallace, married his sweetheart, Murron.

"I am Scottish through and through, and this is how I always wanted it," said Tracey Sutherland, who married Norman Porter in a Celtic ceremony in Aberdeen.

Historically, a clergyman placed a cord across the couple's hands held crossed, an allusion to the infinity symbol. The cord was left untied, but, should they wish to remain together until death, after a year and a day they would come before the clergyman again. As the couple made their vows afresh, he would tie both ends of the cord over the hands: the couple "tied the knot".

Ms Sutherland and Mr Porter used a modified rite, handing each other gifts of bread (an earnest of food for their home) and a dagger and a bible (for their union's physical and spiritual defence).

In the authentic ceremony the couple did not utter "I do", but exchanged rings and, at the close, each jumped over a broomstick, symbolising their preparedness for the hard work that marriage could be.

webTitle: More rain likely in flood areas

fields.headline: More rain likely in flood areas
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Areas hit by torrential rain over the bank holiday weekend could face fresh flooding with more rain forecast for today - followed by heavy rain during tomorrow evening and night.
fields.body:
Areas hit by torrential rain over the bank holiday weekend could face fresh flooding with more rain forecast for today - followed by heavy rain during tomorrow evening and night.

The forecast means this May is heading for the record books as one of the wettest. During the weekend up to three inches fell in eastern Scotland, and southern, central and eastern England.

Tony Conlan, forecaster with PA WeatherCentre, said more rain was expected today over southern England, south Wales, the south Midlands and East Anglia.

Rain was expected to hit Wales and western England by tomorrow afternoon and was due to cross the whole of the country during the night.

"The heavy rainfall on Wednesday night means that we are looking at what is likely to be one of the wettest Mays on record," Mr Conlan added.

The environment agency said 25 amber flood warnings were still in place in south-east England yesterday. "River levels are taking a lot longer to recede than was expected - this is due to tidal pressures," a spokesman said.

A spokeswoman for AA Roadwatch said the only major road still closed by flooding yesterday was the A127/A129 underpass at Rayleigh Weir in Essex.

A man was in hospital yesterday after falling 30ft into a hole caused by subsidence in the road at Epple Bay, near Birchington, Kent. The 25-year-old man, from Margate, Kent, suffered head and leg injuries. He was trapped for nearly an hour before firefighters freed him.

Updated flood warnings are available from the environment agency floodline on 0845 988 1188. Press Association

fields.headline: Quack's pact to take flak
fields.trailText: A Brazilian engineer who claims to embody the spirit of a first world war German doctor will emerge from hiding to face a murder charge if judges lift a court order against him, his lawyers said yesterday.
fields.body:
A Brazilian engineer who claims to embody the spirit of a first world war German doctor will emerge from hiding to face a murder charge if judges lift a court order against him, his lawyers said yesterday.

Rubens de Faria, who operates without charge on the poor in makeshift surgeries and says he is the reincarnation of "Dr Adolph Fritz" is accused of causing the death of a Sao Paulo student in 1998 and of illegally practising medicine.

Mr Faria, 46, claims to have treated 500,000 people in the past 10 years for diseases ranging from cataracts and arthritis to cancer and brain tumours.

Last week a court in Sao Paulo, where the student died of leukaemia days after allegedly taking Mr Faria's advice to stop medical treatment, ordered him held to await trial, saying he had no fixed address and qualified as a "fugitive".

"We are going to ask the judge to repeal that prison decree. If he doesn't agree, we will still try to file [a writ of] habeas corpus to have it overturned," said Roberto Podval, one of his two lawyers.

Although branded a quack, Mr Faria commands a huge following in Brazil for his "miracle cures". In 1997 he performed a spine operation on a former military dictator, Joao Figueiredo.

fields.headline: Invasion of the part-time villagers
fields.standfirst:
Assembly members urge action to curb growth in number of second homes as rural Welsh communities face decline

Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Trefdraeth is well used to invaders. The imposing remains of the hilltop Norman castle are a constant reminder to those in the community below of a centuries-old incursion which stamped its mark on the "town on the beach" forever.
fields.body:
Trefdraeth is well used to invaders. The imposing remains of the hilltop Norman castle are a constant reminder to those in the community below of a centuries-old incursion which stamped its mark on the "town on the beach" forever.

Today the invaders come armed not with chain mail and swords but with bank balances that most locals can only dream of.

Like many communities in rural Wales, this ancient Pembrokeshire town - Newport as it known in English - has long felt the economic fallout of successive housing booms in more affluent parts of Britain. Young families on low earnings have watched, powerless, as property prices have been forced upwards beyond their reach by rich incomers, mostly English, seeking second homes.

At Cwm-yr-Eglwys, a coastal hamlet a few miles away, just four of the 24 houses are occupied all year round. Some are used only for three weeks during the summer.

"Come October it will be dead and you won't see a light in any of those houses," said Norman Thomas, the only Welsh speaker among the two dozen householders. "I feel it's tearing the heart out of the community."

Newport's experience reflects that of many communities throughout rural Wales. Arson attacks on empty properties may, thankfully, be a relic of an angrier past, but pressure is mounting for action from the country's new democratic institutions to curb purchases that have been blamed for depopulating communities and threatening the Welsh language.

The Welsh national assembly is being urged to investigate whether planning regulations could be changed to allow local authorities to deal with the issue.

In Newport, where around 30% of residential properties have become holiday cottages, there is strong support for a punitive rate of council tax for second home owners.

The town - population 1,100, with two banks, shops, cafes and a post office - appears to be flourishing. But Tony Lewis, a town councillor who ran the town's bookshop until his retirement last year, claims that places like Newport are living on a knife edge.

"Any community can stand a certain percentage of second homes," he said. "But once it becomes a majority the community begins to die because you can't support local shops just on the tourist trade.

"Already a lot of businesses are not finding it easy and if you get many more second homes it could tip the balance and finish them off. You can't blame people for wanting to come here - it's a fabulous, unspoilt area. But we have reached saturation point and I really feel that planning controls should allow a veto by local planning authorities on the number of second, holiday homes."

Glyn Rees, a Pembrokeshire county councillor and Newport's mayor, shares the view that curbs need to be introduced .

"This is not anti-English. We want people to come down here, but we want them to live here and be part of the community," he said. "Five years ago a new primary school was built for 120 pupils, but there are only about half that number there because local people can't afford to buy properties in Newport and move outside the catchment area."

Perhaps the strongest support for controls on second home ownership comes from the Welsh language pressure group Cymdeithas yr Iaith Gymraeg, which regards the influx of non Welsh speakers as the principal cause of the decline in the language since the 1960s.

Dylan Phillips, a spokesman for the society, said that while the number of Welsh speakers is on the increase in the industrial south-east and the north-east of the country the language continues to decline in traditional rural heartlands.

"A number of villages are being left empty for a long period of the year," he said. "It is breaking up community life because young people can't afford to buy the houses and are having to migrate for economic reasons.

"Ideally I would like to see the number of second homes being restricted to only 5% of the housing stock within any community."

Planning restrictions on second home ownership are among a host of suggestions that have been put to the Welsh assembly as part of the national housing strategy consultation process. They are likely to receive strong support.

The government line in Cardiff is that there are no plans for subordinate legislation of this kind. But a spokesman for the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, said it would be surprising if the national housing strategy currently being prepared did not address "the problem of second homes".

Plaid Cymru believes that if a property is to be sold as a second home it should be treated as "a change of use", forcing the buyer to seek planning permission.

Elin Jones, Plaid Cymru AM for Ceredigion, which is said to have the fastest rate of inward migration of any county in Wales, said the policy did not mean that second home purchase had to be denied. But it would allow local authorities to have a planning role.

The Liberal Democrat housing and local government spokesman, Peter Black AM, said there was a need to introduce measures to help people stay in their communities. He called for restrictions to be put on second homes by taking away council tax incentives and tightening up the planning process.

"This is not just a language issue," he said. "It is an issue about the sustainability of rural communities in the face of depopulation and the break up of community life from the lack of affordable housing for local people."

But the proposed measures met with opposition from Welsh Conservatives. The party's local government spokesman, David Davies AM, said they would discriminate against non-Welsh speakers and fuel anti-Welsh language sentiment.

Damning the proposals as "hare-brained", he said policies to prevent second homes in Wales would harm the language in the long run.
