The imposing remains of the hilltop Norman castle are a constant reminder to those in the community below of a centuries-old incursion which stamped its mark on the "town on the beach" forever. Today the invaders come armed not with chain mail and swords but with bank balances that most locals can only dream of. Like many communities in rural Wales, this ancient Pembrokeshire town - Newport as it known in English - has long felt the economic fallout of successive housing booms in more affluent parts of Britain. Young families on low earnings have watched, powerless, as property prices have been forced upwards beyond their reach by rich incomers, mostly English, seeking second homes. At Cwm-yr-Eglwys, a coastal hamlet a few miles away, just four of the 24 houses are occupied all year round. Some are used only for three weeks during the summer. "Come October it will be dead and you won't see a light in any of those houses," said Norman Thomas, the only Welsh speaker among the two dozen householders. "I feel it's tearing the heart out of the community." Newport's experience reflects that of many communities throughout rural Wales. Arson attacks on empty properties may, thankfully, be a relic of an angrier past, but pressure is mounting for action from the country's new democratic institutions to curb purchases that have been blamed for depopulating communities and threatening the Welsh language. The Welsh national assembly is being urged to investigate whether planning regulations could be changed to allow local authorities to deal with the issue. In Newport, where around 30% of residential properties have become holiday cottages, there is strong support for a punitive rate of council tax for second home owners. The town - population 1,100, with two banks, shops, cafes and a post office - appears to be flourishing. But Tony Lewis, a town councillor who ran the town's bookshop until his retirement last year, claims that places like Newport are living on a knife edge. "Any community can stand a certain percentage of second homes," he said. "But once it becomes a majority the community begins to die because you can't support local shops just on the tourist trade. "Already a lot of businesses are not finding it easy and if you get many more second homes it could tip the balance and finish them off. You can't blame people for wanting to come here - it's a fabulous, unspoilt area. But we have reached saturation point and I really feel that planning controls should allow a veto by local planning authorities on the number of second, holiday homes." Glyn Rees, a Pembrokeshire county councillor and Newport's mayor, shares the view that curbs need to be introduced . "This is not anti-English. We want people to come down here, but we want them to live here and be part of the community," he said. "Five years ago a new primary school was built for 120 pupils, but there are only about half that number there because local people can't afford to buy properties in Newport and move outside the catchment area." Perhaps the strongest support for controls on second home ownership comes from the Welsh language pressure group Cymdeithas yr Iaith Gymraeg, which regards the influx of non Welsh speakers as the principal cause of the decline in the language since the 1960s. Dylan Phillips, a spokesman for the society, said that while the number of Welsh speakers is on the increase in the industrial south-east and the north-east of the country the language continues to decline in traditional rural heartlands. "A number of villages are being left empty for a long period of the year," he said. "It is breaking up community life because young people can't afford to buy the houses and are having to migrate for economic reasons. "Ideally I would like to see the number of second homes being restricted to only 5% of the housing stock within any community." Planning restrictions on second home ownership are among a host of suggestions that have been put to the Welsh assembly as part of the national housing strategy consultation process. They are likely to receive strong support. The government line in Cardiff is that there are no plans for subordinate legislation of this kind. But a spokesman for the first secretary, Rhodri Morgan, said it would be surprising if the national housing strategy currently being prepared did not address "the problem of second homes". Plaid Cymru believes that if a property is to be sold as a second home it should be treated as "a change of use", forcing the buyer to seek planning permission. Elin Jones, Plaid Cymru AM for Ceredigion, which is said to have the fastest rate of inward migration of any county in Wales, said the policy did not mean that second home purchase had to be denied. But it would allow local authorities to have a planning role. The Liberal Democrat housing and local government spokesman, Peter Black AM, said there was a need to introduce measures to help people stay in their communities. He called for restrictions to be put on second homes by taking away council tax incentives and tightening up the planning process. "This is not just a language issue," he said. "It is an issue about the sustainability of rural communities in the face of depopulation and the break up of community life from the lack of affordable housing for local people." But the proposed measures met with opposition from Welsh Conservatives. The party's local government spokesman, David Davies AM, said they would discriminate against non-Welsh speakers and fuel anti-Welsh language sentiment. Damning the proposals as "hare-brained", he said policies to prevent second homes in Wales would harm the language in the long run.

webTitle: Ethiopian planes bomb Eritrean capital as refugee crisis grows

fields.headline: Ethiopian planes bomb Eritrean capital as refugee crisis grows
fields.standfirst: Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: The Ethiopian government made a mockery of diplomatic efforts to settle its border war with Eritrea yesterday by carrying out air raids on the Eritrean capital Asmara just as delegates from both sides were due to begin peace talks in Algeria.
fields.body:
The Ethiopian government made a mockery of diplomatic efforts to settle its border war with Eritrea yesterday by carrying out air raids on the Eritrean capital Asmara just as delegates from both sides were due to begin peace talks in Algeria.

When the Ethiopian delegation failed to arrive, the talks were put back to today.

Ethiopian fighter planes attacked Asmara's military and civilian airports in the late morning with rockets and cluster bombs. There were no reports of casualties.

A government spokesman said Ethiopia was still keen to settle the dispute by negotiation, but by launching a direct attack on Asmara for the first time since June 1998 it reiterated its belief that action speaks louder than words.

At least one building at the military airbase three miles from the city centre was totally destroyed, but Eritrean officials said the airstrip had not been damaged.

An Eritrean government spokesman called it a cowardly act. "You cannot bomb Asmara without hitting civilian areas," he said.

In response to the attack two Eritrean MiGs immediately took to the sky, screaming above the city in pursuit of the attackers, and remained airborne for the rest of the day.

The road leading to the airport was in chaos after the attack as thousands of civilians rushed to the scene.

Eritrean soldiers and police set up road blocks to keep people from the site of the attack. Larger groups of women stood alongside the street wailing and chanting anti-Ethiopian slogans.

"Four Ethiopian planes flew in very low over my head," said Esayas Gebru, a security policeman at the civilian airport. "I was very scared. There was so much noise."

Minutes after the attack a Red Cross plane delivering emergency supplies to people displaced by the war made a hasty evacuation in fear of repeated attacks.

Hundreds of thousands of Eritrean civilians have been displaced by the Ethiopian offensive, which began two weeks ago and has gained it thousands of square miles of southern Eritrea. The number displaced grows daily.

Despite Eritrea's promise to withdraw from contested border areas, the Ethiopian advance continues, with heavy fighting reported on Sunday on the central front deep inside undisputed Eritrean territory and an aerial attack on a power station near the Red Sea port of Massawa.

The UN World Food Programme (WFP) appealed for emergency aid for more than 300,000 people yesterday.

It said it had decided to continue airlifting food into Asmara to feed the displaced despite yesterday's attack, but described the situation as "very uncertain".

The Sudanese government said it was struggling to cope with the needs of the tens of thousands of Eritrean refugees who have fled across their common border in the past two weeks.

In Dbwara, 25 miles south of Asmara, an emergency camp has been set up for internally displaced people, centred on the secondary school. One truckload after another arrived at the camp yesterday, bringing the number of people sheltering there to 30,000. Two days ago the compound was empty.

Most of the people displaced come from Eritrea's agricultural heartland. The rainy season will end in July and unless crops are planted in the next 3-4 weeks the consequences for the whole country will be dire.

"Unless the war ends soon and these people can go home then this will develop into a very severe humanitarian crisis," the WFP said.

Desks and chairs have been thrown out of the school buildings to make way for bags of flour, blankets and whatever emergency supplies can be made available. Most of the refugees fled with only the clothes on their backs. A few people have managed to find shelter in the school buildings, but most are left to sleep outside on a bed of stones, with no shelter from the rains which have just begun to fall.

Solomon Embaye, a director of the Eritrean Relief and Refugee Commission, himself displaced, who is coordinating the aid effort at Dbwara, said there was no shelter, and little food and medical supplies.

"At the moment we are depending to a great extent on local people bringing food, blankets and whatever help they can. But this is little more than a gesture."

Mulu Tesfankiel arrived at the camp on Sunday night with her five children. She said that her village near the town of Adi Quala had been repeatedly shelled by the Ethiopians.

webTitle: Ex-president loses gay sex case appeal

fields.headline: Ex-president loses gay sex case appeal
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The former Zimbabwean president Canaan Banana yesterday lost an appeal against his convictions for sexual assault and gay sex offences and was ordered to serve a year in jail.
fields.body:
The former Zimbabwean president Canaan Banana yesterday lost an appeal against his convictions for sexual assault and gay sex offences and was ordered to serve a year in jail.

Banana, 64, was not in court to hear the ruling but was expected to report to prison later yesterday, said his lawyer, Josephine Bennett.

The former president was convicted last year on 11 counts of sodomy and abusing his power to sexually assault and carry out "unnatural acts" with men, most of whom were on his presidential staff. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison, but with nine years suspended.

The supreme court ordered him to serve a year in jail, with a second year suspended. Homosexual acts are illegal in Zimbabwe.

Ms Bennett said Banana could make a last-ditch appeal for clemency from President Robert Mugabe. Mr Mugabe has referred to homosexuals as "lower than pigs and dogs".

Banana, who is married with four adult children, is a former Methodist minister and was president for seven years until 1987.

Last year's convictions followed a sensational trial in which one of his former aides, Jefta Dube, said he was forced into a homosexual relationship with Banana.

Banana was arrested after Mr Dube shot dead a police colleague who taunted him as "Banana's wife". Mr Dube was jailed for 10 years for that murder. During the trial, Mr Dube described how Banana drank, danced and played cards with him before drugging and raping him in the presidential State House library.

He also said he had sex with Banana many times in the State House grounds during regular evening walks, and in a sports changing room on the estate.

The supreme court also upheld a previous court order that Banana must pay Mr Dube Z$250,000 (£4,400) in restitution.

Banana, who had claimed that the convictions violated privacy rights, insists the case against him was influenced by political opponents.

fields.headline: Mike Roberts
fields.standfirst: World-renowned cameraman who captured film masterpieces for Attenborough, Zinnemann, Joffé and Spielberg
fields.trailText: Last week, while on location in Bath for Lasse Hallström's new film, Chocolat, Mike Roberts, for the first time in his career, failed to make the morning bus that takes the crew to the film set. He had died peacefully in his sleep, aged 60.
fields.body:
Last week, while on location in Bath for Lasse Hallström's new film, Chocolat, Mike Roberts, for the first time in his career, failed to make the morning bus that takes the crew to the film set. He had died peacefully in his sleep, aged 60.

Roberts was one of the finest camera operators in the world, and probably the greatest British film cameraman ever. Working for more than 40 years with directors like Neil Jordan, Richard Attenborough, Roland Joffé, Fred Zinnemann and Steven Spielberg, he elevated his art and craft to new levels, being an essential part of four films that won Academy awards for cinematography and four further nominations. In 1997, he was awarded the Michael Balcon Award by Bafta for his outstanding contribution to British cinema, the first technician to be so honoured.

As a director, I made eight films with Mike as my camera operator, and the thought of filming without him, frankly, fills me with dread. Like many directors, I will miss him terribly. He was our eyes; his understanding and "know- ingness" of a scene were consummate. Although he had no formal arts training, his perception of composition and light was instinctive and intuitive, as was his mastery of how subtle and artful camera movement could add power and energy to a shot.

Born in Woking, Surrey, Mike started out as a runner in Fleet Street, catching the bug for film at Southall studios while working for Pearl and Dean. He moved to ABPC Elstree studios as a central camera loader, and after six years went freelance, working his way up from clapper loader on films like School For Scoundrels to focus puller on A Man For All Seasons. One day when the camera operator had flu, he moved up to the seat on the dolly, which he occupied for 65 films.

A wiry, slender man, his face craggy and leathery from the wind and sun of a thousand locations, he had a gracefulness and agility that made him the acknowledged master of his craft. As the camera swooped and dipped across a set, balanced on a small platform, Mike would twist and pivot, gently shifting his balance from one leg to the next, his face glued to the eyepiece.

Liam Neeson once said: "It's incredible to see him at work, bent over the camera, be it 60ft high or racing along a track. It's as if the camera is an extension of his body."

Mike was also extremely brave. No matter if he was filming a Khmer Rouge explosion in The Killing Fields, hanging from a tank on Empire Of The Sun, braving the Iguazú falls on a raft on The Mission, or facing the collapsing walls of a burning church in Mississippi Burning, he never moved away from the camera eyepiece for one second.

Receiving his Balcon award, he generously thanked his long-time camera grip, Colin Manning, who, he said, "has probably pushed me halfway round the world to get me here tonight." And all around the world was where Mike filmed, as he relentlessly and passionately worked on one film after another, often without a break, first choice as he was of directors worldwide.

The producer, David Puttnam, remarked: "If ever there was proof that film is a collaborative art form, then Mike is it." On every shot, he would interact with almost every member of the crew, and always with grace and calm professionalism.

He also had an extraordinary rapport with actors - being, as he was very often, the closest person to them on a film set. His gentle manner and unselfish technique (he never needed to ask for repeat takes because of the camera's imperfections, such was his skill) put great actors at ease, allowing them the freedom to be of their best.

Last week in the bars of Pinewood and Shepperton studios, the conversations were all about Mike, touching, as he had, the lives of three generations of film people. The sad news of his passing was attached to the call-sheets of the films in production. In many cases, filming literally stopped in Britain and abroad because crews were just too shocked and devastated to be able to work.

That a camera technician should have had this effect - not a movie star, director or producer, but an unpretentious, self-effacing brilliant man, who was never once known to raise his voice - is testament to the respect everyone had for Mike.

He is survived by his wife Eileen, his two daughters, Danielle and Georgina, and his mother and sister.

On the set with a great operator

Neil Jordan writes:
I first met Mike Roberts on the set of The Company Of Wolves. He was then in the middle of an extraordinary career as a camera operator, having worked with directors out of the mists of the past, like Henry Hathaway and Fred Zinnemann.

But I didn't know that. What I did know was a lined, gypsy face, a pair of steady blue eyes and a thin, sinewy hand that guided his camera effortlessly to that magical place where the scene, the setting and the actor's face begin to make sense.

The film I was making - with its unreal settings, its stories within stories, transformations and leaps of fancy - made very little sense to anyone else on the crew, but that didn't trouble Mike. What he saw was what he saw, and if a crane shot, for example, that travelled through a forest, beginning in summer and ending in winter, allowed him a smile at the absurdity of the conception, it was executed beautifully.

In fact, as he executed shots and gave them as gifts to the director, he collected stories as a kind of payment. And between shots, he would tell these stories, of past set-ups, past movies, hilarious stories, always pivoting on the absurdity of the film-making process.

Over the years, I came to work with many great cameramen, but somehow always with the same operator, and that was Mike. He would come off a Steven Spielberg film, an Alan Parker film, a Roland Joffé film to whatever small obsession I had made for myself and step immediately into its world.

He would tell his stories as the tracks were being laid, the shot lit, about whatever absurdities he'd encountered since I last met him, then suddenly click into action when the cameras rolled.

He loved first takes, unrehearsed shots, impossible set-ups. With what Chris Menges called his "Cartier- Bresson thing", the moment was what he valued, the sense of unique happening, and, for Mike, whatever happened always happened through the actor.

Technically, he was extraordinary. He did a shot on a hothead once, with a crane that moved through 180 degrees, and, during the second take, his video monitor blew. He executed it blind - and that take made it to the finished film.

I thought he would abandon operating, as most operators do, and light his own films, but for some reason that never interested him. What did interest him was his seat on the dolly that Colin pushed, the actors in front of him - and maybe even the director behind him.

While I was shooting the death of Michael Collins in the hills of Wicklow, with Liam Neeson in the foreground and a line of silhouetted extras in the hills beyond, one of the extras fell into a fissure in the mountain. We found out that he was uninjured, and, while waiting for a helicopter to arrive and winch him out, I set up another shot.

Sarah, my daughter and my assistant on the film, berated me for my heartlessness. I tried to explain that keeping a crew down here waiting idle wouldn't help the rescue process up there. Mike said he fully expected to die on a dolly one day - and be hoisted off it and replaced as quickly as possible.

Over the past few years, as Pinewood and Shepperton filled up with gizmo-driven movies, and as the camera became subsumed beneath a wealth of digital effects, his enthusiasm for some of the films he worked on waned a little. For him, nothing could replace an actor's face.

But his repertoire of absurdities gained immeasurably. I always hoped that he would one day write them down - Mike Roberts: The Collected Absurdities Of A Life In Film. And now he has been tragically denied that opportunity. So maybe those of us who remember them should write them down for him. But I doubt if we could ever tell them as well.

 Mike Roberts, film cameraman, born July 20 1939; died May 24 2000

fields.headline: Natasha Tatarova
fields.standfirst: Roma refugee whose flight from persecution to asylum in Britain ended in tragedy
fields.trailText: Natasha Tatarova, who has died aged 31 in a fire, probably caused by a gas leak, was an outstanding figure among the Slovak Roma refugee diaspora. Her family was one of the first Slovak asylum cases to gain leave- to-remain status from a British court - a decision against which the Home Office has appealed.
fields.body:
Natasha Tatarova, who has died aged 31 in a fire, probably caused by a gas leak, was an outstanding figure among the Slovak Roma refugee diaspora. Her family was one of the first Slovak asylum cases to gain leave- to-remain status from a British court - a decision against which the Home Office has appealed.

She was born into a family of musicians. Her aunt was choreographer of the Romathan theatre in Kosice, and, as a child, Natasha performed as a singer and dancer with her father, the clarinettist Jozef Badzo. Strikingly beautiful, she had a dancer's poise and self-discipline, a compelling presence and awesome elegance.

The Badzos toured former Czechoslovakia and Germany until Natasha's early marriage to Milan Tatar ended her performing career. She became the backbone of an extended family, but events in 1997 channelled her driving will into bringing her relatives out of danger.

The Tatar family, like most of the Romany exodus which reached Britain that summer, came from Michalovce in eastern Slovakia. During the 1990s, this remote region near the Ukrainian border became a site of terror against the Roma population.

Michalovce itself became notorious for spearheading the eviction of Roma families from their housing alongside other Slovaks into a ghetto estate outside the town. These moves were enforced by skinhead gangs, using rape and murderous beatings. Today, Michalovce is a byword for gangsterism, but more than 80% of the Slovak asylum seekers have been sent back there from Britain.

Natasha's husband managed to keep a skilled job when most of the Roma were being thrown out of newly privatised companies. But the family's car and well-furnished flat aroused hostility from their neighbours. Milan was subjected to knife attacks, during the last of which he recognised the local police chief's son. Reporting incidents to the authorities, always unsuccessful, was now impossible. The Tatars moved to another village, where they suffered the final gang attack which drove them to Britain.

What was done to Natasha in Slovakia - in front of her husband and children - left her with permanent injuries. She was obliged to have a hysterectomy and suffered recurrent kidney problems for the rest of her life. Milan was beaten so badly that a broken rib pierced his lung, which had to be removed.

In this condition, they arrived at Dover. They were later housed in a single bed-and-breakfast room in Deal, where they asked for a work permit as soon as legally possible. After the National Front march on Dover in autumn 1997, they were so terrified that they asked English friends to find them a flat.

The atrocities the couple had suffered meant that - pending the Home Secretary's planned readjustment of the 1951 UN Refugee Convention - any British court which heard the facts accurately was bound to grant Natasha and her family leave to remain. But the Home Office appeal left the Tatars in limbo.

Early in 1998, they relocated to south London. Natasha, who had by now learned English, was working as a part-time interpreter for the Refugee Arrivals Project. She was determined to achieve permanent refugee status by avoiding the "shame" of requesting state assistance.

The gates closed on Slovak immigration in the summer of 1998. The Home Secretary imposed visas and arranged to post British immigration officials in Slovak airports. Natasha tried every avenue to secure visas for her stranded family members, but the tide had turned. Her parents, brother and sister were refused asylum and "voluntarily" went back in despair. In March, her brother, Marek Badzo, was nearly murdered by hooded Slovak police officers.

Overwork and insecurity had by then broken Natasha's marriage. Now, as a separated woman, she had to start her asylum application all over again. She and her children moved to a bleak, third-floor flat in Penge.

It was there that she died, trying to save two teenage cousins. She had dropped her three young children to the safety of mattresses spread by neighbours, while a third cousin fell from the window and sustained a broken spine. Natasha leapt, landed on a wall and was almost certainly injured, when the screams of Lucie and Kolody led her to run back upstairs. They were not seen alive again.

Natasha failed to locate her family in a safe country. She did unite a wide and disparate group of those who knew and cared about her. She is survived by her daughters Natashka and Marcella. Her son Martin and cousin Rastik remain in hospital.

 Natasha Tatarova, child performer, asylum seeker, born June 7 1968; died May 23 2000

fields.headline: Letter: Barry MacSweeney
fields.standfirst: Daniel James writes:
fields.trailText: Daniel James writes: I met Barry MacSweeney (Obituary, May 18) only on a couple of occasions, but his disarming honesty made me feel like an old friend within minutes. His life and works were embarrassingly raw, neither allowing space for ceremony.
fields.body:
I met Barry MacSweeney (Obituary, May 18) only on a couple of occasions, but his disarming honesty made me feel like an old friend within minutes. His life and works were embarrassingly raw, neither allowing space for ceremony. Throughout his Book Of Demons, which he referred to as a book of experience, there is a dwelling on the negative and the pain that he had suffered. Despite this, I find the poems highly moving, revealing and beautiful.

I met him last at a literary festival in April. In contrast to the man who had brought tears to my eyes the year before, with readings from Pearl and The Book Of Demons, he had returned to the drink and often verged on the self-obsessed. This was heart-breaking, but worst of all was to see him dozing off in mid-talk, and waking intermittently in fits of coughing; symptoms that indicated even he had lost hope.

Perhaps consistent with a man reflecting on approaching death, he returned constantly to images of purity that radiated from his childhood - the borage, the tumblestones, the argent stars and ox-cheek tea. He was a true character, definable only by his work - a creative genius whose life defined his poems and whose poems ultimately defined his life.

In a life where work originates in experience, and experience is generally bad, the figure of Pearl, a mute Northumbrian girl, still held an enchanting power over MacSweeney 50 years on.

He talked of not wanting "to lose the magnetic attraction of the past", and for me the poem, Rediscovered Pearl, was not only a way of coming to terms with his death, but a chance to do as he had always done - holding on to the good that is hidden in the bad.

His death came as a peace and silence, as a return to the innocence of childhood and an escape from the tyranny of words and experience. You could believe that this man passed his days talking in poetry. You could believe that this man was the victim. You could believe from reading his poems that you knew him well.

Barry's life was about believing, his death was about ceasing to believe. I believe we are old friends, though he wouldn't know my name.

fields.headline: Kim Borg
fields.standfirst: Singer with a broad view of musicianship
fields.trailText: The Finnish bass-baritone Kim Borg, who has died aged 80, was a well- regarded singer in opera and song from the mid-1950s to the mid-1970s, with a wide repertory but a natural preference for the music of Scandinavia and Russia.
fields.body:
The Finnish bass-baritone Kim Borg, who has died aged 80, was a well- regarded singer in opera and song from the mid-1950s to the mid-1970s, with a wide repertory but a natural preference for the music of Scandinavia and Russia. He was a specialist in the songs of his fellow Finns Sibelius and Kilpinen, many of which he recorded. He appeared in many opera roles internationally, his gifts as an actor much to the fore.

Britain saw him on stage all too seldom. He appeared at Glyndebourne in 1956 as an imposing, if slightly too rough-hewn, Don Giovanni. He returned to the festival as, more appropriately, Don Pizarro, in Fidelio in 1959.

At about this time, Sir John Barbirolli took a liking to Borg's voice, and afterwards frequently asked him to sing the roles of the Priest and the Angel of the Agony in The Dream Of Gerontius. When Barbirolli recorded the work in 1964, a version some consider the best of all, Borg was chosen for those bass-baritone roles. His self-evident sincerity of interpretation overcame the drawback of rather a thick accent.

He appeared for the first time in recital in London in 1959, when his interpretations, and wholehearted powers of expression, were greatly admired. This was also the year of his debut as Count Almaviva (Le nozze di Figaro) at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York, where he appeared for the following three seasons.

Borg was born into a musical family in Helsinki, and was first taught at home by his mother; she told him to sing from the chest, not the throat. Notwithstanding this support, he chose to study chemistry rather than music.

With the war between Finland and the Soviet Union breaking out in 1939, he was recruited to the Finnish army and served as a photographer in his platoon (photography then being his hobby). In 1945, he turned to music and studied composition at the Sibelius Academy in Helsinki, and voice with teachers in Copenhagen, where he was later to make his home. He gave his debut recitals in those two cities in 1947.

Borg's opera debut followed in 1952, not in his home city - where his talents were, at first, under-appreciated - but in Aarhus, in Denmark, as Colline in La Bohème. This led to his breakthrough, when he was invited to take the short, but plum, bass role of Prince Gremin in Yevgeny Onegin at the Royal Opera, Copenhagen, where he was immediately engaged on a regular basis.

It was at this point that Borg's international career took wing. He was engaged to sing the oily monk Rangoni to Christoff's Boris Godunov in Issay Dobrowen's ground-breaking recording of Mussorgsky's opera for EMI in 1952. Soon, Deutsche Grammophon was on his trail, and he made a number of recordings of opera, oratorio and song for the company during the following 10 years.

Borg was much admired in Germany and, from 1965 to 1968, was a member of the Hamburg State Opera. But he was always welcome in his native Scandinavia, and from 1960 was a member of the Stockholm Opera, where his Scarpia was much praised in 1963. In 1971, he sang Fafner and Hagen in the company's performances of Wagner's Ring. A year earlier, he sang Osmin at the Drottningholm festival, another histrionic triumph.

He appeared in concerts at the Salzburg festival from 1956, singing Mozart, and in 1965-66 sang Pimen in Karajan's staging of Boris Godunov. His Mussorgskian credentials were also confirmed by a fine recording of Songs and Dances of Death.

In 1972 he became professor of singing at the music academy in Copenhagen, though he had equivocal views on the art of teaching singers. He was also much in demand as an adjudicator at singing competitions. A wise and intelligent man and singer, he appreciated that musicianship was as important as voice in his art. His career confirmed that.

He married Ebon Karin Ingeborg Ringblom in 1950; they had two children.

 Kim Borg, bass-baritone, born August 7 1919; died April 28 2000

fields.headline: The view from the quad
fields.standfirst: The Laura Spence affair
fields.trailText: Your leader (May 27) missed the point about Oxbridge admissions. Cambridge colleges admit state and private pupils in the same proportions as applications received. Performance in university examinations shows no difference between the two groups - and therefore no discrimination in favour of weaker private school applicants. So the real problem is to persuade able applicants from the state sector to apply.
fields.body:
Your leader (May 27) missed the point about Oxbridge admissions. Cambridge colleges admit state and private pupils in the same proportions as applications received. Performance in university examinations shows no difference between the two groups - and therefore no discrimination in favour of weaker private school applicants. So the real problem is to persuade able applicants from the state sector to apply.

If Blair, Blunkett and Brown really want to be radical, may I suggest they move to abolish private sector education and work ceaselessly to provide a uniformly excellent state system for all? The elitism that allows the rich to buy a better future for their children is the real scandal and I can absolutely guarantee that state school admissions to Oxbridge would rise to 100% immediately such a policy was implemented. Instead all we have is spineless fudging on selection, barmy privatisation schemes for "failing" schools, and further attacks on the integrity and morale of the teaching profession. As a Labour party member, school governor and parent, I despair of this goverment's education policy.
Dr Nick Gay
Christ's College, Cambridge
njg11@mole.bio.cam.ac.uk

 Over the last 15 years about two-thirds of the students I have admitted to study computer sciences have been from state schools. I did not have to fight my colleagues to be able to do this. But I did have to work hard trying to convince talented potential students from state schools that I had no prejudice against them.

The real scandal is that teachers in state schools are undervalued, underpaid, and made the scapegoats for social ills beyond their control - and this with the connivance of the secretary of state and his chief inspector of schools. I am a governor of a state school. I have seen talented and dedicated teachers give up the struggle to provide a first-class education for all and migrate to the private sector. Is it any wonder that the distribution of talent between sectors is skewed?

I will listen to lectures on fairness from Messrs Blunkett, Brown et al when they have provided sufficient resources and support for the state sector to provide an education for all which rivals the elite education for the rich.
Bernard Sufrin
Worcester College, Oxford

 Brown and Blunkett can't be that "furious" about the advantages private education offers - else they'd stop bellyaching, go to the root and abolish fee-paying schools. (You know, forces of conservatism.) Having considered Oxford's admissions problems for 10 years, including stints on the target schools scheme and arguing at governing bodies, I'm staggered by the feebleness of their response. Cabinet ministers can do a lot more than any scheme or admissions tutor: free universal access to higher education from an equitable schooling system is in their gift. It isn't in anyone else's.
Alan Hamilton
Wadham College, Oxford

 Instead of criticising the Magdalen interviewer's assertion that comprehensive school pupils have lower self-confidence, Malcolm Wicks et al might more usefully wonder exactly why it is that the toffee-nosed public school kids who infest this town have the confidence to treat everyone else like dirt - an attitude they doubtless carry over when they pass into business and government.
Rob Wheaton Oxford

fields.headline: Thinking on their feet
fields.trailText: My daughter, educated at an independent girls' day school, had 10 A*s at GCSE and was predicted 4 A grades at A-level. She was rejected by Nottingham University to read medicine without an interview.
fields.body:
My daughter, educated at an independent girls' day school, had 10 A*s at GCSE and was predicted 4 A grades at A-level. She was rejected by Nottingham University to read medicine without an interview. Is this prejudice, or simply the university's right to choose whichever candidates it feels will benefit most from the course it offers?
Angela Howard
London

 Gordon Brown might take a closer look at his alma mater, Edinburgh University. Although more egalitarian than the Scottish parliament (an even tinier proportion from the working class than the Commons), Edinburgh is a much-favoured destination for the social elite of Britain, more so than Oxford or Cambridge. A Scottish politician once again blinded by the "democratic intellect" myth.
Dr Stephen Cullen
Eton, Berks

 There is a disturbing similarity between the tactics of the chancellor and those of Robert Mugabe. How long before we see TV pictures of nervous admissions tutors standing behind the gilded gates of their colleges, whilst crowds of disappointed supporters of New Labour gather outside demanding their education "plots"?
Michael Stanhope
Lutterworth, Leicester
stanhope@dial.pipex.com

 If Gordon Brown means what he says, will he reinstate the financial assistance to Ruskin College, vindictively terminated by Mrs Thatcher 10 years ago? It provided over 90 places a year for working-class students.
Bill Purdie
Marlow, Bucks

 According to the leaked memo, Laura Spence was "... able to manifestly think on her feet". At least Ms Spence is now going to an establishment where she will be learned how to write proper.
Dr Donald Sharp
Beverley, E Yorks

webTitle: How to make an offer that can't be refused

fields.headline: How to make an offer that can't be refused
fields.trailText: Laura Spence's rejection, despite meeting all objective criteria, shows why rigorous equal opportunities procedures should be used by everyone responsible for selection. This means stating explicitly the selection criteria which are required, checking off those criteria, and sticking by the candidates that process throws up, even if they are not quite the type of individuals the selectors pictured.
fields.body:
Laura Spence's rejection, despite meeting all objective criteria, shows why rigorous equal opportunities procedures should be used by everyone responsible for selection. This means stating explicitly the selection criteria which are required, checking off those criteria, and sticking by the candidates that process throws up, even if they are not quite the type of individuals the selectors pictured.

If a highly subjective quality such as "how they would fit in" is required, then include that in the criteria, state it in the course description and be prepared to defend it publicly if challenged. Liberal organisations need not look smug because a bastion of the establishment has been caught in the act. How many of them have a recruitment policy which basically says those recruited should be mirror images of those already in post?
David Turner
Bradford

 I graduated from the LSE by way of a Sunderland council housing estate to a professorship at Anglia Polytechnic University. Colleagues in what is known locally as the Posh People's University seem entirely oblivious of the whole social exclusion process in which they are centrally involved. It echoes the Metropolitan police's opposition to institutional racism.
Prof David Brandon

fields.headline: Advert for UK pork 'will backfire'
fields.trailText: Supermarkets have condemned a government-backed advertisement for pork which relies on shock tactics to promote the British pig industry over foreign imports.
fields.body:
Supermarkets have condemned a government-backed advertisement for pork which relies on shock tactics to promote the British pig industry over foreign imports.

Tesco and Asda warned it could backfire and put consumers off meat altogether, a view shared by the Danish bacon industry which supplies a quarter of all bacon sold in Britain. One industry insider said the press advert, which appears on page 7 of the Guardian today, looked more like a campaign by vegetarians.

The advert is part of a six-month, £4.8m promotion by the Meat and Livestock Commission and shows a sow suckling her piglets. The message is: "After she's fed them, she could be fed to them." This is meant to portray the forced animal cannibalism still arranged in many countries where pigs are fed meat products from other pigs. The practice is banned in Britain as an anti-BSE measure. On the advert, in smaller type, is the exhortation: "Look after the farmers who look after their pigs."

Yesterday, the MLC refused to name "guilty" countries among the main foreign suppliers, Denmark, Holland, Ireland, France, Hungary and Poland. A spokesman claimed Denmark's statistics suggested only a third of the pork and bacon exported to Britain met the UK's welfare standards. He said: "If it is legal to use [pig meat for pigs] it is economically advantageous to do so."

Supermarkets complained after seeing the pre-released advert. Tesco said: "We had serious reservations about how this will be interpreted."

Asda said the advert might "turn people off buying meat". Its imported bacon, a spokesperson said, met UK standards, and British pork sales had increased because of price cuts - these might be jeopardised.

The Dutch meat board condemned it as "inflammatory, inaccurate and irresponsible".

John Howard, marketing director of the Danish Bacon and Meat Council, said: "Some British farmers will be delighted by this campaign but if the overall market is damaged it will be a pyrrhic victory."

But Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, said: "The advertisements are tough ... and they're absolutely right. The public demanded animal welfare legislation, it has been put in place. It is worth reminding people just how pigs are kept and what the recycling of meat actually means."

webTitle: Africans urge UN to toughen mandate

fields.headline: Africans urge UN to toughen mandate
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive guide
fields.trailText: West African governments have agreed to send an extra 3,000 troops to bolster United Nations forces in Sierra Leone amid government claims of significant new military successes against the Revolutionary United Front.
fields.body:
West African governments have agreed to send an extra 3,000 troops to bolster United Nations forces in Sierra Leone amid government claims of significant new military successes against the Revolutionary United Front.

They also said that they plan to fly the captured rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, out of the country to "guarantee his security".

The Sierra Leone army yesterday said it had captured the strategic town of Lunsar, about 30 miles from the RUF headquarters at Makeni. UN aid workers reported several thousand civilians fleeing the city ahead of the advancing government forces.

A communique from a summit of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States asked that the mandate of the UN mission in Sierra Leone be toughened from "peacekeeping" to "peace enforcement" and that its command be given to a West African officer.

Both requests appeared in line with the wishes of the regional superpower Nigeria, which is expected to provide the bulk of the extra regional troops, bringing its force in Sierra Leone close to 6,000 and making up the largest single contingent of foreign soldiers.

Many in Sierra Leone hope the Nigerians will use their considerable experience of fighting in the country to push the RUF out of the diamond fields which fund the rebels' war. But at the moment the UN's mandate technically prevents its troops from going on the offensive against the rebels except as a means of defence. Instead, they are used to secure territory captured by government forces.

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, was quoted yesterday as saying that the organisation should abandon outdated concepts of neutral peacekeeping and replace them with a more muscular form of peace enforcement.

The Nigerians will, in any case, take on the greater responsibility for defending Freetown as British forces are whittled down next month.

The UN force commander, Major General Vijay Jetley, said yesterday that the release of a final batch of peacekeepers held hostage by the rebels frees his force to take a more robust approach to the rebels.

"We are going to consolidate and move forward," he said. "The RUF are demoralised. They never imagined they were going to get what they've been getting. We've given so many casualties to the RUF that they're still licking their wounds."

Gen Jetley portrays the rebels as a divided force with many fighters ready to give up and some commanders prepared to negotiate. But recent RUF counter-attacks suggest that, while the rebels are suffering setbacks, many are willing to fight on.

For now, the government and the British military, which is providing strategy and logistics, are relying on a disparate collection of forces to break the rebels. But it is a marriage of convenience that has the potential to end in a nasty divorce.

The new Sierra Leone army, which was created after the peace accords last July, barely exists except as a collection of fresh recruits and inexperienced officers.

The backbone of the government forces is provided by members of the old army which has seized power twice over the past decade before being ousted two years ago.

Much of the old army then allied itself with its former enemy, the RUF, and followed the rebels' lead in committing widespread atrocities against civilians. When the two forces jointly seized Freetown at the beginning of last year, it was difficult to distinguish between them when it came to murder, rape and mutilation.

Many of those soldiers are now fighting for the government against their former rebel allies, but they remain loyal to ex-military ruler Johnny Paul Koroma, who has barely hidden his ambition for greater power.

Perhaps least predictable of the forces aligned with President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah is the Kamajor militia, whose members rely as much on the charms and amulets which they believe provide magic protection from bullets as the British rifles they have managed to purloin.

Their leader, Samuel Hinga Norman, is also Sierra Leone's deputy defence minister. He insists that his forces will stay loyal to the government, but it is not clear that he has complete control over his men.

webTitle: Abused elderly let down by apathy

fields.headline: Abused elderly let down by apathy
fields.trailText: Social workers are failing to deal with abuse of elderly people because there is a wide-spread belief that little can be done, a study today suggests.
fields.body:
Social workers are failing to deal with abuse of elderly people because there is a wide-spread belief that little can be done, a study today suggests.

An "air of despondency" hangs over those who should be responsible for protecting such abuse victims and meeting their long-term needs, according to the study.

The finding comes as the government remains on the back foot over the welfare of older people. Ministers stand accused of paying lip service to "grey" issues because of the focus on young Britain.

The study, funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, claims to be one of the first to go beyond the definition of elder abuse and assessment of its prevalence, to look at how victims are treated.

Jacki Pritchard, a researcher, carried out the study in three local authorities in northern England. She interviewed 27 women victims of abuse, as well as social workers and other social care staff, and consulted more than 300 elderly people in focus groups.

Interviewees were as old as 98-year-old Gwen, who had been abused by a stepdaughter through money matters. The abusers were male in almost all cases, as old as 90 and as young as nine.

Irene, 80, described how her grandson was systematically robbing her to pay for drugs. "He took my camera, purse and keys. The week my husband died, he took £80 and £20 from my purse," she said.

Emma, also 80, spoke of how her husband had inflicted mental cruelty on her: "Every day he was suggesting that I wasn't right in my head, that I had forgotten to do something, and I knew I had not."

When Ms Pritchard talked to welfare workers, however, she found their attitudes towards such abuse were "predominantly negative" because of an assumption, often erroneous, that little could be done.

This belief was based on a view that victims might not recognise they were being abused, that they usually did not want outside intervention, and that there was no legislative framework to protect adults in the same way as at-risk children. One worker said: "We have no legislation, whereas in child care you have got the various acts. We cannot do that ... and that makes our work even more difficult really, when you know abuse is going on and you just cannot do anything."

Another worker, talking about the difficulty of helping an elderly person being abused by their own family through finance, said: "We are toothless tigers."

Ms Pritchard said many professionals were "unduly pessimistic" in their approach to the problem of elders' abuse. Evidence showed that when help was available, victims would take advantage of it and leave, and stay away from, their abusers.

"These research findings confirm that older victims of abuse need practical help and emotional support from workers in a wide range of agencies, but that the necessary resources are not always made available," Ms Pritchard said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Siemens in CDU cash inquiry
fields.body:
Siemens in CDU cash inquiry

German MPs are investigating the electronics and computer giant Siemens on suspicion that it illegally donated millions to the former chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats in return for setting up trade deals with East Germany in the late 1980s.

Volker Neumann, the MP leading the Kohl slush fund inquiry, told the business magazine Capital: "We are trying to find out whether Siemens donated cash as a gesture of thanks for the massive profits it made in East Germany." Siemens was suspected of bank-rolling the CDU through Swiss bank accounts, he said. Tony Paterson, Berlin

Victory for Kuwaiti women

A Kuwaiti woman yesterday won permission to take her fight for the right to vote and stand for election to the country's constitutional court.

"This is a great victory ... This is what we wanted," said Rola Dashti

A year ago, Kuwait's ruler, Emir Sheikh Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, issued a decree granting women the right to vote and stand in elections in 2003. But Kuwait's parliament rejected the decree in November. Reuters, Kuwait

UN in control of Congo city

Rwandan and Ugandan troops yesterday started withdrawing from Kisangani, clearing the way for creation of the first demilitarised city in warring Congo under the control of the UN.

Twenty unarmed UN military observers escorted Rwandan and Ugandan soldiers away from the main airport at Bangoka, 12 miles north-east of Kisangani, where they have clashed repeatedly despite being nominal allies. AP, Kigali

Serbs killed in street shooting

Three Serbs, including a four-year-old child, were killed in a drive-by shooting in Kosovo thought to have been carried out by an ethnic Albanian, international officials said yesterday.

Two people were seriously injured in the incident, which occurred around 8:30pm local time on Sunday in the eastern village of Crnica, according to the Nato-led K-For peacekeeping force. Reuters, Pristina

Cult charged for amazing feet

Tokyo prosecutors yesterday indicted the founder of a religious cult who claimed to cure diseases by inspecting feet, accusing him of defrauding believers of more than £150,000, Japanese media reported.

Hogen Fukunaga and seven other leaders of the Ho-no-Hana Sampogyo cult were charged with swindling five followers out of 25m yen between 1994 and 1996, according to Kyodo news agency. AP, Tokyo

Hong Kong warns refugees

Security officials in Hong Kong yesterday warned they will kick out Vietnamese refugees who refuse to leave their camp when it is shut down this week.

The camp at Pillar Point will close at midnight tomorrow, putting an official end to the Vietnamese boat people saga, a remnant of the Vietnam war.

The government had decided in February to offer permanent Hong Kong residency to the refugees and close the camp. But some refugees say they cannot afford to live anywhere in the notoriously expensive territory. AP, Hong Kong

webTitle: OJ case follows US dramas to the small screen

fields.headline: OJ case follows US dramas to the small screen
fields.standfirst: Plans for a TV series about the murder trial of the former football star are set to provoke outrage
fields.trailText: Controversy about the OJ Simpson case has been reignited by a decision to turn his trial into a television mini-series with a script by Norman Mailer that will "force America to confront its racism".
fields.body:
Controversy about the OJ Simpson case has been reignited by a decision to turn his trial into a television mini-series with a script by Norman Mailer that will "force America to confront its racism".

The OJ Simpson series is another example of the new trend for turning real life drama into television. The story of six-year-old Cuban Elian Gonzalez is also soon to be filmed as a mini-series.

In the OJ film, award-winning actor Ving Rhames, who stars in the new film Mission: Impossible 2, will play Johnnie Cochran, the lawyer who successfully defended Simpson against the charges that he had murdered his wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald Goldman at his wife's home in Los Angeles in 1994. Mr Cochran suggested that Simpson had been framed by racist police officers.

The series will be produced by Tom Fontana and Barry Levinson, whose films include the acclaimed Rainman and Diner. It is to be directed by Lawrence Schiller whose recent film about the unsolved murder of child beauty contestant JonBenet Ramsey was a ratings success.

It is believed that the success of the film about Ramsey persuaded CBS, which will screen the series, to weather the inevitable criticism of the Simpson project.

Mr Rhames said that his reason for taking on the project, called An American Tragedy, was his experience of life in the US as an African-American man.

"What I find in America is that an unarmed man in New York can be shot 41 times and it's called an accident and everybody goes free, another man is assaulted with a toilet plunger ... and other incidents which make me think that, as an African-American male, I'm in trouble," he told the entertainment daily, Variety.

"It colours how you look at someone like Johnnie and how the media and the world in general dealt with the OJ case and how he was perceived by minorities."

webTitle: President of Peru beats absent rival

fields.headline: President of Peru beats absent rival
fields.trailText: Police clashed with hundreds of youths on the streets of Lima early yesterday morning protesting at President Alberto Fujimori's re-election for a third term of office.
fields.body:
Police clashed with hundreds of youths on the streets of Lima early yesterday morning protesting at President Alberto Fujimori's re-election for a third term of office.

After winning 50.3% of the preferences in Sunday's runoff, Mr Fujimori did not appear in public and his planned victory rally attracted only about 3,000 people, most of them bussed in from shantytowns.

The opposition candidate, Alejandro Toledo, who had asked his supporters to boycott the poll because of suspected electoral fraud, addressed an estimated 70,000 supporters in Lima's main square. They promised a sustained campaign of civil disobedience. "The streets belong to the people, not to the dictator," they chanted.

"The third round of the election begins here," Mr Toledo said, announcing plans for a series of rallies throughout the country this week. He took 16% of the vote. Spoiled ballots accounted for 32%, indicating the widespread dissatisfaction at the electoral process.

Lima was quiet yesterday morning and Mr Fujimori is hoping to sit tight and wait for the national and international outcry to blow over.

The question mark over the legality of the elections dates back to 1992, when Mr Fujimori closed the congress and supreme court and relaunched state institutions under his own control. The opposition said his bid for a third consecutive term was a blatant violation of the constitution.

A new constitution permitting the one-off re-election of the president allowed him to stand for office in 1995. His defeat of the Shining Path insurgency and control of inflation made him a popular figure, and international financial institutions approved his privatisation programme.

The following year he amended the constitution by the Law of Authentic Interpretation, which opened the way for a third term.

His campaign workers falsified a million signatures to register the Peru 2000 alliance last year. The national intelligence service harassed opposition candidates and television stations refused to broadcast even the opposition's paid advertisements.

The final count for the first round of voting recorded a million more votes than voters. In the congressional vote the National Election Processes Office shaved 10,000 votes from an opposition party, depriving Heriberto Benitez, a human rights lawyer who has brought cases against the armed forces, of a seat.

Mr Toledo, who took 40% of the first round vote, demanded changes in the electoral machinery to ensure a more even playing field.

fields.headline: A cruiser down memory lane
fields.trailText: It is only an underpowered truck with a minivan engine, but the eccentric little buggy with 30s styling has become America's hippest car for nearly 40 years. The Chrysler PT Cruiser sold 8,322 in its first month on the market, nearly twice as many as the Volkswagen New Beetle when it was launched two years ago.
fields.body:
It is only an underpowered truck with a minivan engine, but the eccentric little buggy with 30s styling has become America's hippest car for nearly 40 years. The Chrysler PT Cruiser sold 8,322 in its first month on the market, nearly twice as many as the Volkswagen New Beetle when it was launched two years ago.

Order one now and you will probably not see it until next year, and even then it will probably cost you more than the $16,000-$20,995 (£10,700-£14,000) list price.

The cruiser and rivals such as the New Beetle and the Ford Focus are evidence of Americans overcoming their historic revulsion for small cars, seduced by nostalgia-inducing retro design, reasonable prices and a national psyche rattled by petrol going beyond $1.50 (£1) a gallon.

There are reports of some dealers asking $9,000 over the list price. DaimlerChrysler, which had banked on selling 50,000 a year in the US, has responded to the cult status of the PT (personal transportation) by gearing its Mexican factory to build closer to 200,000. An Austrian plant is being set up for the overseas market.

People are buying Cruisers without taking a test drive, sometimes without seeing it.

"It's like some kind of giant toy," said Jim Filomena, from the Bronx in New York, whose wife took delivery of a silver PT last week. "It's such a joy to see guys in Mercedes and Jaguars craning their necks to see it."

"Some people inside our company are saying there hasn't been anything like it since the original [1964] Mustang," said James Holden, DaimlerChrysler's president.

fields.headline: Flying colours
fields.trailText: The 80 children and 15 staff at the Cedars School in Gateshead have been awarded Sport England's Sportsmark Gold award - the first special school to win the award
fields.body:
Liz Neale is over the moon. And she's not the only one. The lads have done well - as have the girls.

The 80 children and 15 staff at the Cedars School in Gateshead have been awarded Sport England's Sportsmark Gold award - the first special school to win the award.

"Physical education is important for body image and self-confidence," says Neale. "At the Cedars we make it fun." Everybody at the school does PE, regardless of their disability. Games include wheelchair basketball, soccer and sitting volleyball. "We try to play games where we can integrate children in wheelchairs with children who are ambulant. We do gymnastics, trampolining and hockey."

To win the award, Neale proved that the school met national curriculum standards that many mainstream schools fail to reach. Cedars children do at least two hours of PE each week and there are after-school sports clubs three days a week. The clubs are open to any child in the Gateshead area and disabled children in mainstream schools are given the opportunity to mix and compete on a more equal footing.

The Cedars' sports facilities consist of one all-purpose hall and PE involves travelling, both to venues in Gateshead and to seek competition with other schools. Neale uses the structures set up by Disability Sport England to play competitions.

"Children get a chance to meet other competitors who can demonstrate real skill," Neale says. "That motivates them even more." And the trips are often residential, giving the children the kind of social contact that is often denied them in everyday life.

But the competition is real. "We develop each of the children's physi cal abilities to their peak as much as we can," says Neale. The school has had internationals within disability sport and some pupils have gone on to take coaching qualifications.

Neale is the only PE specialist in the school, a job she landed "almost by chance" 18 years ago. She sees the award as an opportunity to raise the profile of disability sport and as a reward for the children.

"They're absolutely thrilled to bits," Neale says. "I'm proud of them because they do reach extremely high standards. A lot of them work hard and train hard just like any other sports person and this is recognition for those efforts."

More pragmatically, Neale is also hoping that the award may be the catalyst that leads to improved sports provision at the school.

"I'm hoping that the award may help pull in some funding for better facilities," she says. "We really do need a sports hall."

fields.headline: Homing in
fields.standfirst: Should you teach your children yourself?  Pippa Crerar  talks to two mothers who were home educated and had to decide whether to delegate education to an institution
fields.trailText: Should you teach your children yourself? Pippa Crerar talks to two mothers who were home educated and had to decide whether to delegate education to an institution
fields.body:
"Do fish have eyelids?" asks seven-year-old Gareth Henderson. "And do they sleep?" his older sister, Rebecca, pitches in. Their mother Jessica, not a marine expert, makes a mental note to look out her book on fish so she can answer their questions.

Gareth and Rebecca are inquisitive children, perhaps because they have their own teacher 24 hours a day to answer anything they might want to know. For the Hendersons are one of thousands of families in the UK who home educate.

Jessica is a second generation home educator; she decided to teach her children at home because of her own happy experiences as a child on a small island off the coast of Queensland, Australia, where she and her sister took correspondence classes and were taught by their mother.

"We spent half an hour a day on written work, which we would then post back," Jessica says. "The rest of the time we played and learnt to think about our natural environment. Being taught at home gave me great confidence. I got used to the fact that my ideas would be taken seriously. We were very free, it was an idyllic childhood."

The other children on the island faced a long ferry trip to school each morning. Jessica joined them for one year only, when she was seven. "At school I learnt about injustice," she says. "The headteacher would victimise some kids, especially the aborigines."

Jessica moved to England in the early eighties and trained to become an electrician. She has known all along that she would like to teach her children at home. "I've never seen the need for learning to take place in an institution."

The children have formal lessons a couple of mornings a week with plenty of time devoted to play and other activities. Jessica has a plan for each day, although she admits it often changes. "What we do depends on the day. We are surrounded by beautiful countryside so we go on lots of outings."

The children also have lots of friends. "Some friends who go to school tell my kids they're very lucky!" Jessica says. She has no plans to send them to school in the future but stresses that the decision is theirs. "I check now and again if they're happy and they say they are."

Rebecca, 10, already has her future mapped out; she wants to become a writer. Gareth doesn't know yet, but he loves creating complicated Lego designs and Jessica thinks he might like to be an engineer. But could the children's career ambitions be thwarted by their unconventional education? "Universities take the enthusiasm and initiative of potential students into account," Jessica says. "They need people who can think differently. I'm quite confident that whatever they decide to do there will be a place for them."

Jessica can reel off the benefits of home schooling, but many parents can't decide so readily. Priscilla Park-Weir, who lives in Surrey with her army husband Iain, was also home educated, but sent her children to school after a spell teaching them herself. "I didn't think I wanted to educate my own children at home," Priscilla says. "Not at all."

"My own memories of being taught at home are fairly neutral ones," she says. "I never had that high a view of my own home education. It wasn't the concept of home schooling or the teaching, but the feeling of being cut off. But I suspect that I would have had that anyway, it was my personality."

She and her brothers were taught at home in a small village in the north of Scotland. The local school did not seem to be an option for her parents. "My mother had us at home through snobbishness," she says. "If we'd been better off we would have been sent to a private school." Later on, she was sent to boarding school in Berkshire.

Despite earlier reservations, in the end Priscilla did teach her children, Helen and Gavin, at home for several years. "There were different threads leading to my children's home education," she says. "We were living in Aberdeen and it was a combination of the schooling there at that time and seeing other home-educated children so content in themselves. So many people don't realise home schooling is a legal option all the way through."

Because of her own childhood, she had felt that home schooling created isolation. "But my children were very confident and out-going, home schooling worked well for them. They would wait for their friends to finish school and then rush out and play," she says.

Iain Park-Weir was posted to Belize soon after. Had he not been, Helen and Gavin would have returned to school. "My husband had a conven tional attitude to education and he thought it would disadvantage them," Priscilla says. "Luckily we went to Belize, which gave me a good reason to continue."

Helen and Gavin, like the Henderson children, had formal lessons in the morning and sports in the afternoon. Helen, now 24, remembers the playground that Belize provided for them. "We had a chemistry set and the best thing was the magnifying glass, we used it to burn palm leaves and make fires."

When the family returned to Britain, the children went to school. Helen was keen. "I liked the idea of boarding school and thought it would be a bit like Malory Towers, with lots of friends running around. New was exciting," she says. When Gavin heard his sister was going to school, he wanted to join her.

Although enthusiastic about her years of home schooling, Helen can also see the advantages of conventional education. "There were more facilities at school than at home. At A level we did lots of brainstorming; I really enjoyed the team work and I would not have had that if I'd stayed at home."

Both the Park-Weir children did three A levels and went on to university. Helen now works in the investment management division of HSBC and Gavin, 22, is working for an internet start-up company. Priscilla believes her children's confidence and success is grounded in their early years.

"From an early age Mum encouraged us to ask questions," Helen says. "We always asked why? Why don't stars fall out of the sky? At school I remember thinking some of my teachers were stupid because they couldn't answer all my questions."

But when Helen has children of her own, would she consider teaching them at home? "I don't know if I'm the right kind of person to teach, but you never know, it's not something I definitely wouldn't do," she says.

In case she does decide to follow the home schooling path, here's a tip. Most fish don't have eyelids (only sharks, and theirs close from the bottom up). Also, although fish spend time resting, they don't really sleep as they have to keep moving to get water (and thus oxygen) through their gills.

fields.headline: Heads down
fields.standfirst: Too many headteachers are leaving; if the government wants to keep them it must act now, argues  David Hart
fields.trailText: Too many headteachers are leaving; if the government wants to keep them it must act now, argues David Hart
fields.body:
The annual conference of the National Association of Head Teachers opens today at a time when heads and deputies feel "punch drunk" from a stream of government reforms designed to drive up standards. Many do not doubt the government's priorities, nor do they oppose a large proportion of the initiatives. But the "change programme" is working to an unrealistic timetable. The balance between pressure and support has not yet been reached.

Decent funding is a major priority. This may seem strange when £19bn has been promised over three years. Nonetheless, school budgets have not been increased to the degree hoped for by school leaders. This is exacerbated by funding disparities that make a mockery of the existence of a national curriculum, a national inspection system, national league tables, national tests and a national pay structure. A move to a national funding formula, enhanced by a decent comprehensive spending review settlement, is well overdue.

The funding debate, together with Ofsted inspections, bring the role of the local education authority into sharp relief. Local authorities have an important function to perform but they have to be relevant to the 21st century. They must accommodate school self-management. Separate funding streams to support the responsibilities of schools and the functions of local education authorities should be established.

Although the government answer at the moment is semi-privatisation, the long-term solution lies in the recommendations of the Better Regulation Task Force. Its belief in a redefinition of lines of accountability, simplified funding allocations and a redistribution of powers strikes a chord.

The current workload on heads and deputies is causing too much stress. Bureaucracy and red tape have not been reduced. They have merely been "recycled". This is doubly damaging at a time when the resources to support school management are "coming on stream" too slowly to counteract the demands of central and local government. Prescription and control by government produce bureaucracy. They have to be relaxed.

The Green Paper is being "rolled out". Threshold assessment was always going to be a serious challenge in 2000, the year of the "big bang". "Brownie points" have been lost by government over the variable quality of the training programmes. A performance management system for 25,000 schools and 400,000 or more teachers should be in place by spring 2001. But the timetable is too ambitious. The Green Paper will deliver real benefit in the long term. It is the short-term pressures that are soaking up a great deal of management energy.

Other issues will also dominate debate. Ofsted's new framework was introduced with no consultation, bordering on arrogance. The impact of Ofsted's inspections of local education authorities on the heads in the failing authorities cannot be underestimated. The government's policy on exclusions is placing great pressure on heads and their staff. It is simply not feasible to argue that only real violence justifies permanent exclusion. The Human Rights Act will soon change this stance when it comes to bullying. Artificial targets, and not pupil needs, are driving this agenda.

I have no doubt that David Blunkett, when he addresses our conference this week, will want to reassure heads that plans are in hand to respond to their very real concerns. The government is heavily dependent on school leaders for the delivery of its programme. Too many heads are leaving. Too many schools are having difficulty replacing them. The next 12 months are absolutely crucial if heads and deputies are to feel that they are properly supported by a government many welcomed back in 1997.

 David Hart is general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers.

fields.headline: A seismic exchange
fields.standfirst: A fruitful friendship has sprung up between pupils in a London school and Turkish children involved in last year's earthquake.  Eileen Fursland reports
fields.trailText: A fruitful friendship has sprung up between pupils in a London school and Turkish children involved in last year's earthquake. Eileen Fursland reports
fields.body:
Goodwill between English and Turkish football fans may be in short supply at the moment, but in one west London primary school it's a very different story.

Two boys from West Drayton Primary School recently went to Turkey as "goodwill ambassadors" to attend the opening of a new school, built to replace one destroyed in last August's earthquake. There they met some of the young victims of the disaster who have lost their homes, their school and, in some cases, their parents.

"We asked the children 'how did it feel to be in the earthquake?' and they said they were scared and upset and wanted to get away from it. Some of them got separated from their parents and they really missed them," says Richard Davis, 10.

The opening of the school was a high-profile event in Turkey and the two boys were mobbed by reporters, photographers and cameramen.

Richard from year 5 and his best friend, Dale Thomas, from year 4, went to Turkey with Dale's mother Karen, who is a governor at West Drayton Primary, and Val Ross, head of community affairs at the nearby toy and games manufacturer Hasbro. Hasbro funded the £70,000 cost of building the new school in Izmit in response to a request for help from staff in its Turkish office.

Some of the 250 children whose school was destroyed have not attended school at all since the earthquake, while others have been taught in tents or have temporarily joined another school, making for classes of 60 in its overcrowded classrooms.

When the new term starts in September, they will have their own school again, a prefabricated building with eight classrooms and a playground with play equipment - and it will be twinned with West Drayton Primary. When Val Ross suggested that West Drayton Primary might like to become involved, says headteacher Adrian Ingham, he found it an unusual and deserving initiative.

"We will exchange writing between our pupils and the Turkish pupils - descriptions of their lives and so on. Eventually we would like to think that some of the children from Turkey could come here and some of our children could go there. There could certainly be an exchange of teachers as well - we are ambitious in that respect," says Ingham.

"It has the dimension of the children and all that they can learn about one another and from one another. For teachers, too, it is an opportunity for them to extend the children's learning and to develop themselves. We also have a small number of Turkish children in the school and if, through links like this, we can help them see that we understand something of their cultural background, that is very useful," he concludes. Fundraising for the school is another possibility. Val Ross has given an assembly at West Drayton Primary about the earthquake and told the pupils of the appalling conditions in Izmit when she first visited in October last year.

Redevelopment has begun, but even so, linking with a school in an area that has suffered such a disaster will present particular challenges. Does Ingham think the parents of his pupils will be keen on the idea of exchange trips? "We would have to work at this over a period of time, but why not?

If it happens in mainland Europe, why shouldn't it happen in Turkey? It's just that it's going to have a very different flavour to it. We will need to work with our children to educate them about what the children there have been through."

With the demands of the curriculum and the drive to improve standards, caring and compassion are sometimes forgotten - but in spite of the time pressures it is important to keep the broader view, he says.

"We're not just exam machines," he says, "we're involved in developing complete human beings, as far as possible, with a view on life that goes beyond the next set of results.

"We serve an internationally mixed community here and many teachers believe it is our job to open the children's eyes to that. With younger children it is hard but unless we start, some of the attitudes that tend to develop - suspicion of the world abroad - will continue. And it's our job to break down some of those preconceptions."

Richard and Dale are already sold on the child-friendly Turks. "The people really like you - they pat you on the head and are kind to you and give you presents. One of the girls gave me a kiss on the cheek," says Richard.

In fact, Karen, Dale and Richard loved the country so much that the two families have booked a Christmas and New Year holiday there.
