fields.headline: Head aches
fields.trailText: Appointing a new head is the single most important responsibility of any governor. Matthew Rees offers a few words of wisdom to those about to take the plunge
fields.body:
The single most important factor in a school's performance is the head. Therefore, appointing a new one is the most important thing we do as governors. There follow a few simple rules on how to do this.

Your local education authority may urge you to act quickly, but take your time. The deputy who gives you such cause for concern will do less damage in the short term than an inappropriate head can wreak in the long term.

Once you are relaxed about the process, you will have time to think. Do a lot of this. The head dictates the school's character, so in writing the job specification you are defining what you want the school to be like. Consider this carefully, use small workshops to bounce ideas around, get agreement from the whole governing body and then ensure that the key points are in the job spec. This also helps the candidates, as they will get a meaningful description of what is wanted at your school.

My final rule would be to spend your interview time wisely. We ran three interviews of 20 minutes in parallel to reach a shortlist, then asked each remaining candidate to present for 20 minutes and answer questions for 10. That adds up to one-and-a-half hours with each candidate upon which to base this vital decision. Focus on talking about things that matter to your school, such as the school development plan or the relationship with parents.

If you get the process right, you will get a competent head who is appropriate for your school. You can then justifiably claim some of the credit for progress.

 Matthew Rees is chair of governors at a primary in Kingston Upon Thames.

fields.headline: Those early days
fields.standfirst: Parents fret about how much they should push their infants. There is new research that suggests they should just relax.  Tony Mooney explains
fields.trailText: Parents fret about how much they should push their infants. There is new research that suggests they should just relax. Tony Mooney explains
fields.body:
Amid a burst of baby- mania in the UK following the birth of Leo Blair, many parents are increasingly anxious about the amount of stimulation they are giving their children in the early years. It is an undisputed fact that in the first three years of its life a baby's brain is involved in what has been termed a fit of "biological exuberance" when it produces trillions more connections between the nerve cells (synapses) than it does in the adult brain.

Armed with this fact, there are those who argue for earlier state intervention in education in the belief that very young children need to be stimulated in the right way while their brains are developing most rapidly.

Some prominent voices argue that early stimulation increases the connections between synapses and increased connectivity means enhanced brainpower. The science writer Ron Kotulak, of the Chicago Tribune newspaper, has even suggested that children exposed to inner-city environments in their first three years may be having their brains permanently wired in ways that could direct them towards violence and crime. In his Pulitzer Prize-winning series in 1993, Kotulak wrote:

"What research can now tell us with increasing certainty is just how abuse, poverty, neglect or sensory deprivation can reset the brain's chemistry in ways that make some genetically vulnerable children more prone to violence."

If parents are not able to provide the stimulation that influences early synapse and brain circuit formation by providing the right kind of early experiences for their children, then is it not incumbent upon the state to intervene so that the children do not suffer?

Such a stance might be defensible if the science that supported it was valid. But in a recently published book, the American expert Dr John T. Bruer claims that the argument about influencing early brain development is without scientific foundation and "ensnares parents, particularly mothers, in a web of conflict and guilt" about the opportunities they are providing for their children.

Bruer cites some famous studies to undermine the "first years last forever" enthusiasts. For example, some parents in villages in Guatemala were found to have raised their children in dark huts for their first year of life. The children were rarely spoken to or played with in an attempt to protect them from evil spirits. Yet despite this treatment, by adolescence the children were found to be as socialised and as intellectually capable as most middle-class American teenagers.

Perhaps Bruer's most telling example of young brains not being permanently wired in childhood comes from the study of some families in the Dominican Republic. These families are deficient in an enzyme that helps to build the penis and scrotum in the foetus. This is due to a defective gene, and boys affected by it have a stunted penis resembling a clitoris. These boys are brought up as girls until puberty, when male hormones transfer the girlish frames into mannish bodies. As soon as this happens the children switch genders, wear male clothes, pursue females and grow into normal males. This syndrome is named "quevedoces" (eggs at 12) by the locals. Despite their early experiences, there appears to be no problem in switching from girl to man, showing, according to Bruer, that "early experience had not permanently wired female gender roles into the brains" of those changing to males at 12.

The advice to the parents of young children throughout Bruer's book is that they need to be relaxed about the stimulation they provide. He draws on all the very latest research in neuroscience to debunk the idea that infant brains are "growing and connecting in direct response to the actions of watchful, singing, reading and talking parents".

There is absolutely no relationship between the rate of synapse formation or synapse density and the quantity of stimulation, either to deprivation or to over-stimulation. The evidence points to early rapid synapse formation being under genetic, not environmental, control. In addition, there is no neuroscience evidence to suggest that stimulating babies saves or strengthens those synapses that have already formed.

For those parents resisting the political pressure to push their children into schools before the age of five, Dr Bruer has more reassuring thoughts. Apparently there are no critical brain periods for learning. There are no windows of opportunity that slam shut for learning the culturally transmitted skills that children learn at school. So although children in our culture normally learn to read, write and become numerate by certain ages, there is no reason to believe that there is the existence of critical periods for these skills. What is culturally normal is not biologically determined, a principle that ought to silence the critics of Summerhill School.

One final point made by Bruer is that the brain is a highly tuned learning instrument nearly all its life and a large body of research evidence suggests that, throughout life, experiences "have a profound effect on personality, character and mental health and that these effects swamp the impact of early childhood experience". So parents can talk, sing and read to their babies because it can't hurt, but neither does it lead to better brains in infants. Parents should realise that children thrive in a wide variety of physical and cultural environments and that the best thing they can do for their children is to be highly sceptical of any claims to the contrary.

 The Myth of the First Three Years: John T. Bruer, (Free Press, New York 1999). J. Kagan, The Infant; Ready and Able to Learn, Children Today (1985). Sex on the Brain: Deborah Blum (Viking, New York 1997).

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: We have just received information about the work-experience fortnight that our son's school runs. What exactly should we tell him to expect and what can he hope to get out of it?
fields.body:
We have just received information about the work-experience fortnight that our son's school runs. What exactly should we tell him to expect and what can he hope to get out of it? We didn't do work experience in our day and feel we are as much in the dark as he is.

Lindsay Thomas is careers co-ordinator at a school in Richmond upon Thames.

Work experience is as it sounds: your son is placed within a workplace, and carries out the same tasks - more or less - as an employee. It's intended to give pupils the chance to learn about a specific area of employment, to meet new people, to work in an adult environment, to see work routines and to learn new skills.

Not all placements for pupils are directly related to the career they hope to pursue, although there will be opportunities to use what they've learned from the experience in various ways. Most pupils, regardless of the type of job they do, get a great deal out of it. They often develop more maturity, motivation, self-confidence and interpersonal skills.

To make this experience as successful as possible, a school should give parents information about the placement beforehand. At our school, we do this via a parents meeting dedicated to explaining the whole process and our expectations of it. We reassure parents about issues that might concern them and explain whom to contact with problems.

Some schools use their own database of jobs to place pupils, or ask pupils to arrange their own placements. In Richmond upon Thames we use an organisation called the Trident Trust, a registered charity: it used a database of 1,200 jobs, and will contact all employers to confirm placements and provide certification that pupils have done the placement.

Perhaps their most important role, from a parental point of view, is that they do all the health and safety checks for the school - this is also the case for those pupils who have arranged their own work placement. Staff from the school endeavour to visit all pupils to check that everything is going well, from both the employer's and the pupil's point of view.

In terms of how you can help your child when they go on work experience, I would advise parents to make every effort to attend any meetings about the process and to ensure that you have read any related literature your child has on it. This will help you to reinforce the school's expectations about pupil behaviour whilst on work experience, and what the purpose and aim of work experience is as far as the school is concerned.

We ask pupils to complete a diary, which includes their daily routine, interviews with other employees and their employer, what the health and safety regulations are at their place of work, etc. This can be followed up at school, and could be used when pupils put together their Records of Achievement in year 11.

Stress to your son that the expectations of employers may not be the same as those of teachers, and that he needs to be mindful of punctuality, courtesy and the dress code. It's a valuable insight into the world of work, but is only really a taster. There may be limits on what pupils are realistically be able to do.

The most successful work experience placements tend to be where the pupil is prepared to get fully involved and is determined to get the most out of the opportunity, regardless of whether or not it's a career she or he wants to pursue in the future.

Next week's query

I am a classroom assistant at a local school, and am working with a new teacher from South Africa who seems to be struggling with the delivery of the literacy and numeracy hour. The more able are not being challenged, while some other activities are far too complex for the less able.

My dilemma is do I whistle-blow and speak to the head or a senior teacher, and run the risk of being seen to be questioning the professionalism of a staff member?

 We will also be offering advice to parents/carers on how to approach the school if you feel your child is not getting sufficiently challenging work.

 Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about your school? Can you help other readers from your experience? In our interactive advice column, we pose a reader's problem and publish answers from the public along with an expert view. Please send your queries and answers (no more than 100 words and marked "If you ask me") to the address at the end of Letters.

My dilemma is do I whistle-blow and speak to the head or a senior teacher, and run the risk of being seen to be questioning the professionalism of a staff member?  We will also be offering advice to parents/carers on how to approach the school if you feel your child is not getting sufficiently challenging work.  Do you have a problem with your child's education? Is something bothering you about your school? Can you help other readers from your experience? In our interactive advice column, we pose a reader's problem and publish answers from the public along with an expert view. Please send your queries and answers (no more than 100 words and marked "If you ask me") to the address at the end of Letters.

fields.headline: Alphabet of woes
fields.trailText: Nearly a century ago, in a more or less idle remark, the essayist GK Chesterton claimed that those who spell a word wrong will always be saddled with the temptation to think it wrong too. In New Zealand classrooms, where Chesterton used to be taught, the same sentiment has long held sway -with the "right" spelling invariably being in accordance with the version of the written language bequeathed to the country by its erstwhile colonial British overlords.
fields.body:
Nearly a century ago, in a more or less idle remark, the essayist GK Chesterton claimed that those who spell a word wrong will always be saddled with the temptation to think it wrong too. In New Zealand classrooms, where Chesterton used to be taught, the same sentiment has long held sway -with the "right" spelling invariably being in accordance with the version of the written language bequeathed to the country by its erstwhile colonial British overlords.

Chesterton might not have been very impressed at the proposals now before English teachers in New Zealand to allow their students to pick and choose from the language's American and British orthographies: color or colour, programme or program, and so on. Alternatively - the argument is about nothing if not alternatives - the conventional British variants of the words could be dropped altogether and the local version of the language as it is taught switched to the American flag.

The suggestion has been made at the behest of the New Zealand Association of English Teachers, whose president, Phil Coogan, is impressed by the "phonetic logic" of American spelling and, thanks to the Internet, its global ubiquity.

The issue, he believes, "is going to become increasingly important, especially with the widespread use of electronic language."

Opinions were recently canvassed in the organisation's newsletter, sent to hundreds of teachers and departmental heads in New Zealand. The subsequent debate spilled over into the national news media and even onto the website of Britain's Simplified Spelling Society, which has long campaigned against what it calls the public nuisance of non-American spellings.

Many of the New Zealand teachers surveyed said that English spelling in any form was a poor cousin to imagination and creative thought on the part of students, although some remained unsure whether the time is yet right for the Kiwis to bid farewell to British English.

In a syndicated column on English usage, the local writer Frank Haden, who styles himself as a sub-Chestertonian curmudgeon, predicted mayhem in the local classrooms if either of the proposals are ever adopted.

"Take a deep breath," he wrote, "introduce American spellings, declare them the correct ones, deduct marks from any pupil who tries to smuggle through an English spelling, then stand back. Chaos will naturally follow."

In Haden's view, many of the stateside variants introduced to the language only ever happened because the Americans "didn't know any better". New Zealanders, he feels, do.

The call for change comes at a time when local-language educators are grappling with both an upsurge of general interest in American language themes and a general decline in the overall popularity of English as a subject. According to figures released this year by the country's education ministry, the number of senior secondary school pupils studying English has fallen over the past decade from nearly 100% to slightly more than 92%.

At university entrance level, the number stands at 60%, down from 70% in 1990. At the post-secondary level, the country's eight universities and 35 polytechnics are increasingly concerned about the literacy levels and communication skills of incoming students, according to Frances Kelly, a policy manager with the ministry.

The decline parallels New Zealand's overall national literacy rate, which, as measured by international agencies, has decreased over the past 10 years from a perfect 100% to today's 98%.

On a slightly more light-hearted note, the New Zealand Performing Arts School, a government-funded tertiary institution, recently inaugurated a programme designed to Americanise the local accent, with its famously broad vowels, clenched consonants, and oddly rising inflections to the end of each spoken sentence.

"The course covers pronounciation [sic]," says a brochure, "the use of cadence and stylistic elements, which will help students achieve a mid-Atlantic feel or accent." Not even the New Zealand Association of English Teachers, however, would be happy with the brochure's spelling of pronunciation, regardless of where the debate initiated among its members leads in terms of policy change.

Coogan, who believes his association will indeed ratify one of the proposed changes later this year - a move that would then need to be endorsed by the country's governing qualifications authority - insists that standards of communication are not at issue, and that there will never be room among his colleagues for an anything-goes attitude to teaching English.

"A mistake in written English is still a mistake," he says. "This is not about lowering standards, nor is it about issues of national identity. I think it would be a shame if the subject gets clouded over in either of these ways."

For others, though, the clouds will surely arrive if the country puts through/thru the idea for enroled/enrolled students being permitted/permited to favour/favor the spellings they deem most colourful/colorful.

fields.headline: Size matters
fields.standfirst: The future of the smallest sixth forms looks increasingly shakey, reports  Peter Kingston
fields.trailText: The future of the smallest sixth forms looks increasingly shakey, reports Peter Kingston
fields.body:
Areas of the country with clusters of small sixth forms may be subjected to early scrutiny by Ofsted, its new head of post-16 operations has hinted.

Stephen Grix, Ofsted's director of post-compulsory education, was responding to MPs' concern about new figures from the Department for Education and Employment showing that nearly half of sixth forms have 150 or fewer pupils.

Out of 1,834 sixth forms in England, 115 have up to 50 pupils, 319 have between 51 and 100, and 409 have 101 to 150, according to statistics in a written answer from schools minister Estelle Morris and based on figures supplied by schools in January.

David Chaytor, MP, joint-chair of the Commons all-party further education group, said the imminent arrival of Curriculum 2000, with its heavier demands, redoubled existing concern about the quality and adequacy of provision in small sixth forms.

How could a sixth form with just 25 pupils in each year do justice to the expanded numbers of subjects and combinations of subjects? Would Ofsted be prioritising local education authorities with large numbers of small sixth forms for area inspection, he asked Grix. Inspection is the first step specified in schedule 7 of the Learning and Skills bill, which is nearly through the Commons committee stage, for tackling "inadequate" sixth forms.

That was down to ministers, Grix stressed. "But I expect this is one of the criteria they'll be looking at."

Chaytor, who is Labour member for Bury North, said he would now be asking ministers to identify areas with heavier concentrations of small sixth forms, and to supply details of small sixth forms' exam performance.

Ministers have privately made it clear that long-running concerns about unviable sixth forms will be addressed, but such a politically sensitive issue takes time. A single uniform inspection regime, capable of irrefutably exposing any glaring anomalies, is a crucial precondition.

MPs and representatives from the Association of Colleges and the lecturers' union Natfhe were largely reassured by Grix's briefing on the emerging shape of the inspection regime, one of the thornier parts of the government's reforms for post-16 education and training.

But there was concern, particularly from Natfhe, at his expectation that inspections will probably focus less heavily than at present on governors and much more on quality of teaching and learning. Poor governance had after all been partly blamed in a number of high-profile college scandals.

"We'll still look at governance, but we think it's a bit heavy to go so hard on people who are volunteers," Grix said.

Colleges will be subjected to single inspections rather than duplicate arrangements, which many in the sector have been concerned about since last summer's announcement of Ofsted's new role in post-16 inspection, he confirmed.

To bring consistency to their operation, teams will be led by HMIs (her majesty's inspectors), ie full-time officials, rather than freelances. These will include 21 or so existing Ofsted HMIs plus a dozen or so new HMIs, who will be appointed from inspectors brought over from the Further Education Funding Council inspectorate, which is to be scrapped.

Ofsted will take the leading role in most college inspections. In colleges where more than 90% of full-time students are over 19 - a small minority of institutions - inspections will be led by the new Adult Learning Inspectorate (ALI).

fields.headline: Basically brill!
fields.standfirst: Only one college has managed to win top rating for teaching basic skills.  Angelique Chrisafis went to find out the secret of its success
fields.trailText: Only one college has managed to win top rating for teaching basic skills. Angelique Chrisafis went to find out the secret of its success
fields.body:
Former hospital porter Alan McDonald puts the lid on his fountain pen and surveys his immaculate page of Pythagorus theorem. Five years ago, McDonald, who is 50, was one of the 7m adults in Britain who couldn't find a plumber in the alphabetical index of the Yellow Pages.

"I didn't know that many words and I couldn't fill in forms. I didn't have the confidence to talk to people because I thought I'd get laughed at for making mistakes." Having worked as a refuse collector, he did a drop-in course in basic English and maths at Liverpool Community College and is now practising for stage three exams. "I don't feel stupid anymore," he says.

Liverpool Community College is a rare success story in basic skills teaching. The Further Education Funding Council has just awarded it the only top Grade 1 assessment in the country since inspections began in January. Given that there are more than 400 further education colleges teaching basic reading, writing and maths in England and Wales, this is quite an accolade. Britain has one of the poorest records of functional illiteracy in Europe. At least 20% of adults cannot calculate the change from £2 for a loaf of bread and two cans of beans. One in 16 cannot properly read posters, find an address or choose a meal in a restaurant. This is twice the level of functional illiteracy in Germany.

Against this background, the funding council's chief inspector, Jim Donaldson, praised Liverpool college's high expectations of students, its method of marking and tracking success, its outstanding teacher training, retention rates and curriculum management. He said that the college would be a beacon for all other colleges. But what is interesting about the college's success is that the majority of its 3,000 basic skills students come from Liverpool 8, the most deprived postcode in Britain. Literacy rates in Liverpool are 5-10% lower than the national average and only 30% of school leavers achieve five GCSEs grades A to C. So how does the college get such success rate?

At the Colquitt Street drop-in centre, one of the college's 11 centres across Liverpool, Jason Lunt is chewing his pencil. Lunt, 30, left school with no qualifications and hasn't worked for 10 years because of illness. He is doing a pre-GCSE comprehension exercise which challenges him to understand and follow instructions in English. "I love it," he says. Across the room, Mohammed Nasser Ali, 21, is "scanning" a text for familiar words and looking others up in a dictionary. Gina, 18, who was excluded from school and used to work packing magazines that she could not fully read, is studying basic English vocabulary and maths to prepare her for a child-care course.

There are 15 students in the room, aged between 16 and 60, all working on their own assignments at their own pace. Three teachers approach individuals in turn and tutor them.

"The drop-in centre is open from 10am till 3pm and students have individual work plans. They come in and take breaks as they want to," says Gale Jones, the centre manager. "We offer individual programmes for each student. Students can start on any day of the year. Most people who come here can read a basic tabloid story. They come when they find they can't help their children with homework or are unable to write letters. They have gone through jobs by hiding their inadequacies and the last thing they need is group teaching where they are forced to compete with others."

The college's success comes from a break with the norm, says Leelee Yates, Basic Skills manager. First, the college writes its own materials and markets them outside. English exercises and comprehensions are refreshed and re-written on almost an individual basis.

"One year, we had a lot of Liverpool football fans, so I wrote player profiles," says teacher Kathie Highton.

But all teaching and materials at the 11 drop-in centres and community projects at Liverpool College is standardised. The funding council report noted that communication between the 36 full-time and 32 part-time teachers was excellent.

The college has also rethought teacher training in basic skills. The college demands not only the national teaching certificate in basic skills, it has developed its own accredited training qualification based on practical assessment of the time management skills needed to individually tutor a room full of different students.

"Almost all our staff have over five years' experience and even the drop-in centre receptionists are trained in basic skills, so that applicants are interviewed within a week and avoid the bureaucracy that has caused them problems elsewhere," says Jones.

Liverpool Community College principal, Wally Brown, says the college has removed the pointless stigma attached to basic skills teaching.

"Twenty years ago, lecturers' pay was defined by subject, and basic skills was at the bottom of the pile. Even now, there is a hierarchy in many colleges. There is an assumption that any teacher who can read and write can teach others to read and write," he says. "Basic skills have been a priority in Liverpool for the last 15 years, and we have learnt that it takes time to see results from students. The govern ment is taking literacy seriously and I'm pleased about that. But the idea of quick-fix 10-week literacy summer schools is absolute nonsense."

The majority of the college's intake for basic skills comes by word of mouth, says Yates. "Retention rates are high because our atmosphere is relaxed." Highton refers to students as her family. "If you teach in an inner-city centre like this, you have to be good at dealing sensitively with the emotional baggage students bring to class. If someone has had a bad night, we let them take it easy."

The college is also realistic. "Our only weakness in the inspection was low numbers of students achieving full awards," says Yates. "But that is because we treat progress on an individual basis and don't think purely in terms of exams."

Last year, the college advised Brookside scriptwriters when character Barbara Dennon failed to be promoted because she couldn't read.

"I think the writers wanted Barbara to learn to write a postcard in the first episode and sit a degree eight weeks later, we had to put a break on that one," laughs Yates.

"Our staff aren't good at blowing their own trumpets," says Brown. "They just used these techniques because they worked. The Grade 1 rating should inspire other colleges to prioritise basic skills."

fields.headline: Up for grabs
fields.standfirst: Hurrah! More money for widening participation, but how easy is it to get your hands on, asks  John Crace
fields.trailText: Hurrah! More money for widening participation, but how easy is it to get your hands on, asks John Crace
fields.body:
Last week's surprise announcement of an extra £100m of funding for further education was greeted with both incredulity and relief in colleges across the country. Of this money, £20m is to be allocated generally, £10m is to be spent on IT, £10m on basic skills and a massive £60m on widening participation.

It has long been recognised that the true costs of teaching widening participation students have not been recognised by government. But after colleges have recovered from the initial shock of this unexpected generosity, a few sceptics may stop to wonder just how easy it will be for them to lay their hands on the cash.

The Further Education Funding Council regulations were initially straightforward. Any student who lived in a postcode area that fell within the top 15% of relatively deprived wards automatically qualified the college for a 6% uplift in funding. This remains the primary requirement, but last year the funding council introduced several extra funding benchmarks to pick up those who might have fallen through the postcode safety net. So, in came uplifts for the homeless, travellers, people with mental health difficulties, care leavers, those who have had their statutory education interrupted, asylum seekers and refugees, ex-offenders, alcoholics and drug abusers. This is where the problems started.

It's all very well creating funding categories, but it's another matter getting people to admit they fall into them. Much of the information that a college would need to assess its financial entitlements is of a highly sensitive, if not confidential, nature and eliciting that data requires tact and diplomacy. A college can ask its students to fill in an application form on enrolment, but there are no guarantees that the information supplied will be accurate, or indeed, that a student will have the literacy skills to understand the questions and supply the answers. Many students would rather keep learning difficulties to themselves. Similarly there are few people willing to own up to having had alcohol or drug problems or criminal convictions.

Short of asking direct questions, such as: "Have you done bird, you drunk?" there is no way anyone can be sure that all the bases have been covered. And even then you're just as likely to get a thump as an honest answer. Small wonder then that colleges, such as Lewisham, with large numbers of widening participation students on their books, are not receiving anything like the funding that is technically owed.

"About 75% of widening participation students are picked up automatically through the postcode system," says Gravatt. "Of the other 25%, we reckon we only manage to identify about half."

Part of the problem is that at present there are no national protocols for colleges to assist in identifying students' needs and difficulties. However, this may soon change if Rosemary Clark, quality manager for the Quality Information and Advice Service, has anything to do with it. "We have been approached by five or six colleges who have expressed concern about this issue," she says, "and we are keen for as many colleges as possible to pool their experience with a view to possibly drawing up some guidelines."

In the meantime most colleges will continue to work to their own policies. For Lewisham this entails a prolonged induction period in which lecturers try to get to know their students and find out what they can and can't do. Ruth Silver, Lewisham's principal, admits that it is somewhat hit and miss, and remains philosophical about the missed funding. Her greatest bugbear is the government's attitude to widening participation. "You can't have the same achievement expectations of a 25-year-old who has been out of mainstream education for 10 years as of a 16-year-old," she says. "We are now taking on students with problems we've never even seen before; some can't even sit down through an entire lesson and we are having to provide a whole range of support service we have never had to in the past." Which means, come to think of it, that the funding would be quite handy after all.

This is where the problems started. It's all very well creating funding categories, but it's another matter getting people to admit they fall into them. Much of the information that a college would need to assess its financial entitlements is of a highly sensitive, if not confidential, nature and eliciting that data requires tact and diplomacy. A college can ask its students to fill in an application form on enrolment, but there are no guarantees that the information supplied will be accurate, or indeed, that a student will have the literacy skills to understand the questions and supply the answers. Many students would rather keep learning difficulties to themselves. Similarly there are few people willing to own up to having had alcohol or drug problems or criminal convictions. Short of asking direct questions, such as: "Have you done bird, you drunk?" there is no way anyone can be sure that all the bases have been covered. And even then you're just as likely to get a thump as an honest answer. Small wonder then that colleges, such as Lewisham, with large numbers of widening participation students on their books, are not receiving anything like the funding that is technically owed. "About 75% of widening participation students are picked up automatically through the postcode system," says Gravatt. "Of the other 25%, we reckon we only manage to identify about half." Part of the problem is that at present there are no national protocols for colleges to assist in identifying students' needs and difficulties. However, this may soon change if Rosemary Clark, quality manager for the Quality Information and Advice Service, has anything to do with it. "We have been approached by five or six colleges who have expressed concern about this issue," she says, "and we are keen for as many colleges as possible to pool their experience with a view to possibly drawing up some guidelines." In the meantime most colleges will continue to work to their own policies. For Lewisham this entails a prolonged induction period in which lecturers try to get to know their students and find out what they can and can't do. Ruth Silver, Lewisham's principal, admits that it is somewhat hit and miss, and remains philosophical about the missed funding. Her greatest bugbear is the government's attitude to widening participation. "You can't have the same achievement expectations of a 25-year-old who has been out of mainstream education for 10 years as of a 16-year-old," she says. "We are now taking on students with problems we've never even seen before; some can't even sit down through an entire lesson and we are having to provide a whole range of support service we have never had to in the past." Which means, come to think of it, that the funding would be quite handy after all.

fields.headline: Keeping the freedom to learn
fields.standfirst: Ron Dearing  is leaving Ufi, but his faith in its mission is as firm as ever
fields.trailText: Ron Dearing is leaving Ufi, but his faith in its mission is as firm as ever
fields.body:
A couple of years ago, I was sitting at lunch next to the Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore. "How are you going to compete against China?," I asked, "as it thrusts massively into the world economy with wage rates a fraction of yours?" Without a moment's thought he replied, "By being 10 years up the learning curve and staying there." He was right of course.

We have a prime minister who has set a target of 50% participation in higher education, albeit with much of the expansion, at least initially, below degree level. The motivation is to underpin national competitiveness. We must play the same game as Singapore. People and nations need to renew their intellectual and skills capital, again and again.

If we must create a society committed to the practice of lifelong learning, what can we say in reply to those at work, who increasingly say stress, pressure and long hours are their lot? How can they be expected to find the energy to continue in learning?

Part of that energy will come from the realisation that it is a necessity. But there is a limit. It must therefore be a central issue of national policy to offer maximum effectiveness in learning and maximum convenience to learners. It must be a policy committed not just to the service of the successful, but even more to those who fared least well at school, who are least equipped to engage in further learning; and who, by virtue of their school experience, have the least appetite for it.

The traditional sources of continuing education will remain the major players. But if we are to lift individual engagement in learning throughout life on the scale required, we need a major new player and a new approach. The government's vision of a university for industry, now taking shape as the Ufi, is a major part of that response. The Ufi, in full operation this autumn, is being fashioned with an especial emphasis on the needs of millions lacking basic skills; on making learning a practical proposition for busy, small firms, too, and on creating an adult society at home with new technology.

To succeed, the Ufi must make learning readily accessible wherever, whenever, and in whatever quantity the learner wants. To that end, from the outset, 80% of its learning will be web-based. It will provide learning at 1,000 learning centres staffed to help the new learners. Learning will be structured in bite-sized units so that learners can fit their learning into life. For small firms it will offer a just in time approach to learning; the ability to call down information and know-how when it is required. By providing this directly into the workplace it can take away the unacceptable cost of staff leaving the workplace to learn.

But what about the support that comes from engagement with other learners and the excitement that comes from engaging in debate? The Ufi's intention to provide interaction with tutors and fellow students through the internet is a recognition of that. The opportunity to learn in the workplace offers another social context. The thousand learning centres will be another.

We need to create a society in which, for every citizen, there is a freedom to learn and a freedom to enter into learning without barriers. It must be as available to those in prison as much to those in a board room. And, incidentally, I can think of no two places where it can do more good. Typically, the prisoner's lack of basic literacy and numeracy means that 49 out of 50 jobs are closed to him. At the other end of the spectrum, in the boardroom, we need no less a revolution in attitudes to engagement in lifelong learning. Bosses can learn too!

As to government, I have no doubt about its commitment. But I am talking of something more than commitment. Think of China and India with 40% of the world's population, energetic, entrepreneurial and clever, coming into the world market. Can Britain settle for anything less than the revolution needed to get us all into learning for life?

 Sir Ron Dearing is the retiring chairman of Ufi.

fields.headline: No copying!
fields.standfirst: Plagiarism was never much of an issue in colleges, but the internet is changing all that, reports  Simon Midgley
fields.trailText: Plagiarism was never much of an issue in colleges, but the internet is changing all that, reports Simon Midgley
fields.body:
New technology, it seems, has brought further education a new headache. The advent of the internet means they are having to be much more alert to the danger that their students could be plagiarising words and images from other's work.

In the past this has been considered a problem for universities, but the arrival of near universal access to the internet now means that computer literate students of any age can now download material from the web.

This poses a whole new set of prob lems for colleges. They must now teach all students, entry level, level 1 and level 2, not just the academic A-level students, about the importance of acknowledging sources, using quote marks and providing bibliographies.

"Students at level 1 and 2 were previously unlikely to copy great chunks out of books, but now they can get them via the internet. We have got to be much clearer about making sure they have the academic skills of acknowledging and referencing," says Peter Glasgow, assistant director at Waltham Forest College.

Concern is such that colleges have been ringing the Association of Colleges advice line asking for guidance on how to establish college-wide plagiarism policies. In response, the association has just published a model policy on academic misconduct, which embraces everything from plagiarism to cheating, collusion and any other attempt to obtain unfair academic advantage.

This defines plagiarism as the presentation of someone else's work, words, ideas, opinions or discoveries, whether published or not, as one's own. It also defines plagiarism as appropriating the artwork, images or computer-generated work of others without properly acknowledging the source, with or without their permission. While plagiarism can occur in exams, the model policy says it is most likely to occur in course work, assignments, portfolios and dissertations.

Maggie Scott, the association's quality adviser, who helped prepare the model policy, said that as IT becomes more extensively used in colleges it will be increasingly important to get the proper protocols governing its usage into place.

Colleges need to look at their disciplinary processes again in the light of the new technologies. They also need to examine how they oversee the use of computers in open learning workshops and how they configure their networks to ensure it is not easy for information to be passed from student to student.

Ms Scott added that colleges have to educate their students as to what is acceptable and what is not. "Everyone is transferring information at such an enormous rate that what colleges have to do is make sure that the proper protocols of acknowledging source material are observed.

"Whatever course they do, even something as practical as motor vehicle maintenance, all students should be aware of the fact that they need to own their own work and that they cannot use other people's work under any circumstances."

webTitle: La cuisine au Ritz, c'est très chic

fields.headline: La cuisine au Ritz, c'est très chic
fields.standfirst: The basement of the exclusive Ritz in Paris is home to a well-kept secret... a cookery school.  Zoé Eisenstein went to find out more
fields.trailText: The basement of the exclusive Ritz in Paris is home to a well-kept secret... a cookery school. Zoé Eisenstein went to find out more
fields.body:
Dans les sous-sols du célèbre htel Ritz à Paris, une merveille peu connue vous attend. On y pénètre par une petite porte discrète à l'arrière de l'htel. Il suffit maintenant de descendre quelques marches, de prendre un couloir étroit et on se retrouve bientt devant la pancarte qui révèle le secret : École Ritz Escoffier .

Derrière la porte à votre gauche, vous découvrez une cuisine de r ve, avec son assortiment de fouets, de casseroles et de couteaux brillants. Enfilez votre tablier et votre toque, et suivez les conseils culinaires du chef Gilles Maisonneuve, professeur de ce cours de grande cuisine. Voilà, il ne vous reste plus qu'à plonger les mains dans la farine !

Je suis allée apprendre à faire une ptisserie délicieuse, le Paris-Brest, avec Gilles et mes collègues apprentis, Vincent, Julien, Chase, Laurence et Natan.

Comment se déroulent les cours ?

Gilles Maisonneuve (chef) : On peut faire une entrée, un plat, un dessert : par exemple des tomates en salade, une escalope de veau à la crème, du riz pilaf. Ensuite en dessert, on peut avoir des melons en surprise, des ananas, des mousses de fruits. Aujourd'hui, c'est un cours de ptisserie. Je trouve ça très agréable d'apprendre la cuisine aux enfants, de les voir très passionnés de venir ici pour apprendre. Ce qui est important c'est de voir qu'à la fin du cours, l'enfant est ravi de déguster le produit qu'il a réalisé.

C'est ton premier cours ?

Vincent (15 ans) : Je suis des cours ici régulièrement, parce que je voudrais devenir cuisinier plus tard. Un jour, j'aimerais ouvrir mon restaurant, servir de la cuisine française, un peu gastronomique.

Julien (12 ans) : C'est mon premier cours, ma grand-mère m'y a inscrit. Je trouve qu'il est bien fait, bien organisé. Aujourd'hui on apprend à faire le Paris-Brest et comme demain c'est l'anniversaire de ma soeur, je me suis dit que je vais pouvoir lui faire un gteau.

Chase (7 ans) : C'est souvent les m mes enfants qui viennent. Mes parents m'ont envoyé ici pour que j'apprenne à faire la cuisine. Ma maman m'aide à faire la cuisine à la maison. Elle m'a appris à faire des cr pes.

Laurence (13 ans) : Je suis déjà venue une fois. J'avais appris à faire les terrines de saumon et d'aubergine. Comme on a les recettes, on peut facilement les refaire chez soi.

Natan (10 ans) : Je viens tous les mois depuis trois ans. J'aime ça, je trouve que les cours sont très bien présentés, qu'on fait des très bonnes choses et que c'est super.

Tu fais la cuisine à la maison ?

Vincent : Le dimanche, oui. Les plats varient selon la saison et ce que j'ai envie de faire. Par exemple, si je veux faire un fraisier un jour, je ne peux pas le faire en hiver parce qu'il n'y a pas de fraises.

Chase : J'ai déjà appris à faire des gteaux. J'aime faire les gteaux, en particulier le gteau à la vanille. Je sais cuisiner des salades de crabe mais je ne me souviens plus comment.

Laurence : Je fais beaucoup la cuisine chez moi. Mais apprendre au Ritz, c'est pas la m me chose. L'htel est réputé pour sa cuisine, donc ça donne plus envie que d'apprendre avec la famille.

Natan : J'aime cuisiner les pizzas tomate mozzarella, j'en fais souvent pour ma famille. Ils pensent que c'est très bon. Il y a plus de garçons que de filles ici.

Vincent : C'est vrai. Je pense que la cuisine est un métier qui est assez masculin dans l'ensemble.

Julien : Peut- tre que les filles ne sont pas motivées.

Laurence : C'est pas normal. Il y a trois filles et sept garçons. La cuisine c'est un métier fait pour les deux. Mais moi, plus tard je veut tre avocat.

Natan : La cuisine c'est très bien pour les filles et les garçons. Aujourd'hui il y a plus de garçons mais en général c'est moitié-moitié.

Que penses-tu des cours ?

Laurence : Chaque mois, ils sont de mieux en mieux. Ce que j'aime, c'est quand on rentre à la maison pour déguster avec les parents - c'est super sympa. Le mois prochain, on va apprendre la boulangerie, les croissants et tout ça.

Natan : Aujourd'hui, je trouve le cour très bien sauf qu'il y a un peu trop d'enfants. Normalement on est moins nombreux. Mon cours préféré, c'était tout au début quand on a fait de la pomme arlequin, c'est une pomme où on met un toast au caramel et c'est vraiment très bon.

Vincent : C'est une bonne école. J'ai cherché des cours de cuisine dans Paris, j'ai trouvé le Ritz, je suis venu une fois et j'ai trouvé ça bien donc je reviens.

un (e) avocat (e) lawyer

tre cuisinier to be a cook

tre ravi to be delighted

un fouet whisk

un fraisier strawberry cake

fields.headline: The registration game
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones  in support of the insupportable
fields.trailText: Janet Jones in support of the insupportable
fields.body:
I wonder if you would believe me if I told you this was the true story of a Thursday.

On Thursdays, I try to give Learning Support to students who are believed to need Learning Support.

At five to nine I was ready to teach Roderigo and six others. Three men were climbing in and out of the ceiling with wires, but never mind them. I was sitting there. The register was there. Roderigo's work was there. Roderigo, however, was not there. The six others were not there either, but that was to be expected as I have not seen them for weeks.

I had found Roderigo and spoken to him the day before. Was there any chance he would be there on Thursday? There was. I had found Roderigo's tutor, too. There was no reason for Roderigo not to be there in the morning.

But he was not. The three men continued climbing in and out of the ceiling with wires. I continued sitting there with the register and Roderigo's work.

At a quarter to ten, I thought I should do something more useful. At five to eleven, I was ready to teach Fred and about eight others. Fred was not in any of the rooms he is often in on a Thursday morning. I inquired here and there. Fred, I was told, was in The Workshop. That is kind code for No Chance Today. I wandered away with the register. In my wanderings, I met Roderigo:

"What happened?" I asked.

"It was not me," he said. "It was the train."

At 12 o'clock, I was ready for Ahmed and Hamid and about 16 more. The 16 more have not been seen of late, but Ahmed and Hamid have been appearing every now and then. At 12.30, the door opened at the speed of a stone rolling up a hill. It was Ahmed:

"Just me," he said, with what can only be called dismay.

"That doesn't matter." I try to be sensitive.

"It's not good . . . just me . . ."

He manages 15 minutes with me.

By one o'clock, I am back at my desk reading a note: "Victor is unable to manage his two o'clock class with you today." I had sought out Victor the day before, too:

"Yes," he had said.

"Two o'clock?" I'd said.

"Yes," he'd repeated.

That was a bad Thursday. Those sorts of Thursdays are one of our biggest problems. Even the inspectors spotted them:

"Attendance," they said, "punctuality," they said. "Yes," we said, "we know," we said. But we cannot give Learning Support to people who are not there. And people will not be charmed or bullied or bribed (politely known as The New Deal) into coming to classes unless they are willing to be.

The seven ages of man have got themselves muddled up in further education. Roderigo and Fred and Ahmed and Hamid and Victor are, in many ways, "the whining schoolboy, with his satchel . . . creeping like a snail unwillingly to school." But the schoolboy's "shining morning face" is no longer there. It is long gone. I see instead the lover and the soldier and the justice and the occasional "ean and slipper'd pantaloon" who find it hard to act the schoolboy.

At least, if they are on my registers, it means they did come to Learning Support once.

Fred was not in any of the rooms he is often in on a Thursday morning. I inquired here and there. Fred, I was told, was in The Workshop. That is kind code for No Chance Today. I wandered away with the register. In my wanderings, I met Roderigo: "What happened?" I asked. "It was not me," he said. "It was the train." At 12 o'clock, I was ready for Ahmed and Hamid and about 16 more. The 16 more have not been seen of late, but Ahmed and Hamid have been appearing every now and then. At 12.30, the door opened at the speed of a stone rolling up a hill. It was Ahmed: "Just me," he said, with what can only be called dismay. "That doesn't matter." I try to be sensitive. "It's not good . . . just me . . ." He manages 15 minutes with me. By one o'clock, I am back at my desk reading a note: "Victor is unable to manage his two o'clock class with you today." I had sought out Victor the day before, too: "Yes," he had said. "Two o'clock?" I'd said. "Yes," he'd repeated. That was a bad Thursday. Those sorts of Thursdays are one of our biggest problems. Even the inspectors spotted them: "Attendance," they said, "punctuality," they said. "Yes," we said, "we know," we said. But we cannot give Learning Support to people who are not there. And people will not be charmed or bullied or bribed (politely known as The New Deal) into coming to classes unless they are willing to be. The seven ages of man have got themselves muddled up in further education. Roderigo and Fred and Ahmed and Hamid and Victor are, in many ways, "the whining schoolboy, with his satchel . . . creeping like a snail unwillingly to school." But the schoolboy's "shining morning face" is no longer there. It is long gone. I see instead the lover and the soldier and the justice and the occasional "ean and slipper'd pantaloon" who find it hard to act the schoolboy. At least, if they are on my registers, it means they did come to Learning Support once.

fields.headline: Air cabin crew
fields.standfirst: A weekly guide for lifelong learners
fields.trailText: Air cabin crew
fields.body:
Excuse me. Do your seat belt up please, sir.

Oh, right . Would you mind answering a few questions? I'll try my best, but we've got rather a restless lot on board this flight and I'm very busy.

That's what I wanted to know. What?

Well, what do you do? Apart from the little mime show and passing round those funny plastic trays, all you have to do is keep the drink flowing, isn't it? That's an outrageous simplification. And we certainly don't keep the drink flowing.

So I've noticed. Another drinkie when you've got a sec would slip down nicely. But first, what does your job entail? We air cabin crew are responsible for the care and safety of airline passengers in normal and emergency situations. That work can include welcoming passengers aboard the aircraft, demonstrating and explaining emergency equipments and procedures, as you quaintly described it, serving food and drinks, selling duty-free goods.

Ah, yes. Duty free. Do you have any of those pink spotted headscarves with Imperial Airlines stamped all over them? No, we're sold out of them, I fear.

You amaze me. People actually buy them? Altitude does funny things to people. But if I can continue. We give first aid and complete flight reports.

But it has such a glamorous reputation. You can see the confined spaces we work in, and the time we spend on our feet. It's exhausting. Time zones and climate changes cause tiredness. And the job means spending frequent periods away from home.

How many of you are there whizzing about the skies? There are currently around 25,000 air cabin crew employed in the UK.

What skills are required? Air cabin crew should be confident, polite and tactful. They need friendly personalities and ought to be able to enjoy working with a wide range of people. They need to be capable of working under pressure and to be physically fit.

And slobs need not apply, I suppose. You've got it. Applicants should be neat and well groomed with no visible tattoos, as well as having a clear speaking voice.

Any entry requirements? It varies. Some airlines want four or five GCSEs, grades A-C, including maths and English. Minimum entry ages range from 19 to 21 years of age. Minimum height varies between 1.58m and 1.60m and some set a maximum height ranging from 1.82m to 1.87m. Applicants should have weight in proportion to their height. Some airlines have upper age limits, eg Virgin Atlantic, which is 28. And some insist that applicants can swim at least 25 metres.

How comforting. Most airlines prefer applicants to have knowledge of a second language. For British Airways conversational ability in a second language is essential.

Are there courses? Some colleges offer courses to prepare for application to work as cabin air crew. The Aviation Training Association advises caution about one- or two-day courses entitled "How to Become Cabin Crew".

Do the airlines train you? Yes. Each has its own training school. Training lasts between four to six weeks and continues in-flight under supervision.

fields.headline: Keep your cool
fields.standfirst: Exam time is fast approaching but don't panic - try some of  Jerome Monahan's confidence-boosting remedies below
fields.trailText: Exam time is fast approaching but don't panic - try some of Jerome Monahan's confidence-boosting remedies below
fields.body:
It's happened. That comfortable cushion of time you always thought lay between you and GCSEs has gone. But it's not too late to get a firm grip on things. Try taking the following steps, both traditional and alternative, to do yourself justice in revision and exam hall.

Conventional wisdom

 Be positive. You cannot afford to think negatively. Banish all thoughts about retaking subjects next year before you have even tried to get things right first time round. You can still do a lot.

 Set yourself a realistic revision schedule and stick to it. Allow yourself time for short, five-minute breaks every half-hour or so.

 Turn your revision notes into spider diagrams in which chunks of information are summed up by single words. Your memory is better than you think.

 Ensure you are familiar with the format of the exam papers you are taking. How are they divided up? How many questions will you have to answer and what marks do they carry? What demands will they make of you - multiple choice or longer essays?

 Tidy your room and organise your notes. If you surround yourself with chaos, you are far more likely to feel chaotic.

 Leave early for exams.

 Be self-sufficient. You do not need the additional pressure of discovering too late that your calculator batteries have died or your ruler is covered in jam. You will also need a see-through pencil case or container for your bits and pieces. And don't forget to take set texts or your English anthology with you for the open-book papers.

Alternative wisdom

You are not just a mind, however. Your body and spirit must be in harmony at this demanding time. So why not try the following:

 Music can boost your mental powers but don't play any music. Some people say plants that have pop or rock played at them will grow less quickly than others of the same species that are exposed to Baroque music dating roughly from 1700-1750.

In one experiment plants in the first group grew away from the sound source while the others actually wound around the speakers. Some believers in accelerated learning are convinced that listening to composers such as Mozart, Scarlatti or Hadyn encourages the best thought waves for intellectual achievement.

 According to the eastern spiritual belief feng shui, "chi" is the life force that runs through everything. Simply changing your position in relation to the shape of your home is believed to improve your energy and health. For example, sitting with your back to a door or a bookcase is considered very bad for your spirit. But keeping a pet goldfish in your room during the day when you are not there is very positive - ensuring a good balance of cool Yin and hot Yang energies for your return.

 Try to get a good night's sleep before every exam.

 If you are feeling hyped-up, put five drops of camomile aromatherapy oil in your bath. If you bathe in the morning, use a few drops of grapefruit and lavender oil as stimulation. And to keep you going during the day, drip five spots of rosemary oil into a handkerchief for you to sniff. "... rosemary, that's for remembrance," says Ophelia in Hamlet. And she's quite right - it is good for energising and refreshing the mind.

 In those tense moments lining up to go into the exam hall, take a tip from reflexology and massage your hands. This will release tension in the rest of your body.

 If you are very anxious on the day, consider a five-drop dose on your tongue of the flower-based Bach Rescue Remedy. It is very important not to take more than this and if you are using other medicines, seek advice.

 Diet is important. Pasta or milk will give you long-term energy. Just before the exam eat a banana or drink unsweetened fruit juice to raise your blood sugar and get you buzzing. Above all else - eat breakfast.

 And last but not least, there is always the power of prayer.

 Further information: for more tips about learning visit: www. happychild.org.uk and click on the accelerated learning link. Also visit the Guardian's on-line GCSE revision site or the BBC resources

fields.headline: Encyclopaedias
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor guides you through the online encyclopedias
fields.body:
The new 32-volume edition of Encyclopaedia Britannica is out next year. It will cost at least £700 - if, that is, you have a bookcase in the library or living room that can hold it. Anyone with a DVD player can already buy it for a tenth of the price, and if you have a CD-Rom drive it costs less than £50.

Does that still seem rather dear? Actually, it's free. The CD-Rom is normally faster to access and the DVD "embraces the medium to its fullest extent", according to a Britannica spokeswoman - which means, for example, that searching for information on giraffes will return video of the mammals and all sorts of other interactive temptations - but visiting www.britannica.com produces a perfectly decent encyclopaedia entry, pictures and links.

Britannica had first aimed to launch a British version of the site with appropriate spelling and a UK emphasis, but visitors seemed to appreciate the US effort so much that, for the time being, they have decided not to bother. Britannica has deals with newspapers and magazines (including the Guardian) which allow visitors to find articles on particular entries.

For all its virtues, Britannica.com could still do with more updating. Choosing Tony Blair as the search term, I found an informed, analytical entry that nonetheless stopped in April 1998 with the Good Friday Agreement.

Britannica's main rival is Microsoft's Encarta, which also has a team of writers and researchers in Britain. (Certain parts of the site are only available to software subscribers.) Again, however, we learn nothing of the past two years. The result is an entry that concludes, somewhat oddly, with Blair's efforts to make the royal family more responsive to public opinion - something of a minor triumph for the man responsible for the wholesale reform of the Lords and the devolution of power from Westminster. Encarta does have better multimedia content, though: a short, fuzzy video shows the birth of a six-foot baby giraffe.

The popular www.infoplease. notes Blair's 1997 win but has nothing more recent to offer. (Labour's spin-doctors might want to dispute the claim that the party has "eschewed a concern for welfare" since he took charge). It's a better option than www.encyclopedia.com, however, which believes John Major is living in Downing Street.

Younger children may like to try eyewitness.dk.com It reproduces all Dorling Kindersley's children's encyclopaedias onscreen and, although the format is rather cumbersome to navigate, the pictures and lively text make them a delight to browse.

fields.headline: History
fields.trailText: The best historical sites on the web, rounded up by Ros Taylor
fields.body:
Castles of Wales
***** Aimed at: everyone

Shamefully, this outstanding site was produced by an American! He has collected a vast amount of information, photos and plans of Welsh medieval castles. Ideal for key stage 2-3.

Guardian Century
*** Aimed at: everyone

Published in the run-up to New Year, the Guardian Century has articles from every year of the 20th century to enhance key stage 4 history lessons.

Guardian Millennium
**** Aimed at: everyone

In 1998-99, the Guardian's former foreign correspondent Derek Brown wrote a 500-day online history of the last millennium. The result, which includes extensive links, is searchable by date and makes an entertaining, if necessarily concise, illustrated resource.

Spartacus International
***** Aimed at: teachers (and older pupils)

It has extensive cross-referenced sections on the US (1840-1960), the medieval world, the first world war, slavery, Vietnam, women's emancipation, the trade union movement, development of railways and parliamentary reform. Resources vary from archive footage, sketches and photos to first-person accounts.

Public Records Office
**** Aimed at: teachers

With classroom resources for key stages 2-4 (and further education), it draws on extensive archives to provide worksheets. Useful, though more material could be put online.

BBC Online History
**** Aimed at: everyone

The BBC's site tends to concentrate on point-and-click interactivity and multimedia rather than classroom materials, but the result is highly entertaining. The Battle of Hastings and Waterloo games, in particular, are fun with great sound effects.

Internet Sourcebooks
*** Aimed at: everyone

A useful bank of primary sources and a good research tool for older students. The site focuses on ancient, medieval, modern, scientific, Jewish and women's history.

Recollections of war
**** Aimed at: everyone

Excerpts from the Imperial War Museum's first world war sound archive. The mix of photos, posters, paintings and audio should help to evoke the social history of the period for key stage 4 students. The vast World War One Documentary Archive also has some invaluable pictorial and written material, but it needs careful sifting by teachers.

Original sources/texts
*** Aimed at: everyone

The online Britannia is designed with US teachers in mind. But the documents, which range from a contemporary account of Boadicea's rebellion in 61AD to a Churchill speech, are useful for history students at any level.

Holocaust Cybrary
*** Aimed at: teachers

Its education section is intended to support teachers tackling the subject with their classes. Only a few pieces are suitable for use in class without adaptation.

 You can find more history sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or email Ros Taylor with your favourite sites.

fields.headline: In the garden of Eden
fields.standfirst: John Crace  tours the rainforest growing in the Cornish countryside
fields.trailText: John Crace tours the rainforest growing in the Cornish countryside
fields.body:
Earlier this month the first phase of the Eden Project, a collection of living plants from all over the world, opened to the general public. The aim of the project is to illustrate our relationship with and dependence on plants. Without plants there would be no life on earth and by the end of each day, most of us will have come into contact with plants from every continent. For instance, some newspapers are made from Scandinavian wood pulp and the wood for most hardwood doors is imported from south-east Asia. The whole project is expected to be open in late spring next year.

Background

The first designs for the Eden Project date back to 1995 when a team of architects and horticulturalists was brought together to create the ideal showcase for the plants, but it was not until 1997, when the £74.3m project was given a Millennium Commission grant of £37.15m and became one of the UK's top Landmark Millennium Projects, that construction work began in earnest. Cornwall was the ideal location for the Eden Project, due to its mild climate, clean air, ample water supplies and southerly location. The site finally chosen was the former china clay pit at Bodelva, near St Austell. The pit is a 14-hectare bowl, 60 metres deep, with steep south-facing walls that catch the sun even in winter.

Planting

The global garden, the size of 30 football pitches, is now being built in the natural theatre created by the clayworks. The 60-metre crater will become home to thousands of important plants. Three of the world's climate zones (biomes) are being recreated. The humid tropics (rainforests and Oceania) and the warm temperate regions (the Mediterranean, South African cape and California) will be contained in two giant conservatories that will recreate the required heat and humidity. The third, roofless, biome is our own temperate zone that thrives on the climatic advantages Cornwall has to offer. Here plants from the Himalayas, Chile and Australasia will grow alongside our own native flora.

Education

The Eden Project is an educational resource designed to inspire, inform and involve the public. Participative education programmes are being designed for all ages and abilities. The project aims to promote education for sustainability and will work closely with the scientific and botanical communities, and will support and showcase research programmes that can sustain the diversity of plants and our relationships with them.

fields.headline: Otpor: rage of innocents
fields.standfirst: The dramatic rise of Serbia's anti-government student movement
fields.trailText: The dramatic rise of Serbia's anti-government student movement
fields.body:
Fears of a student uprising against Serbia's increasingly unpopular regime brought an abrupt, and early, end to all university classes last week. With students now the focus of Slobodan Milosevic's venom, authorities also banned all gatherings on Serbian campuses, effectively turning them into forbidden zones.

Otpor, which means Resistance, has been a long time in the making. But the student movement of disaffected graduates and university attendees is beginning to do what no other force has yet done. It is uniting a war-weary population against the man most blamed for dragging the Balkans into anarchy.

For supporters, who say Otpor is "a state of mind, a way of thinking", the omens have never looked better. This month alone Otpor-orchestrated protests, street happenings and university take-overs have plunged the regime into panic. Suddenly analysts think the movement could be the kind of kindling that will spark the revolution the country so badly needs.

They see them as squabbling power-seekers who are vain and immature," says Milan Nicolic, director of the Belgrade-based Centre for Policy Studies. "Otpor, by contrast, is viewed as incorrupt, bold, well-organised and aggressive. The students don't have any skeletons to hide, they have never done deals with Milosevic and their demands for change sound very legitimate in the ears of the people."

Serb-watchers - a cynical bunch at the best of times - say the youth factor is what could rid the pariah state's political compass of moral imperfections.

"They've got nothing to lose," says Nicolic. "The regime knows that, and that's what has frightened it."

Serbs of all ages and political persuasions have been appalled by scenes of fresh-faced students being arbitrarily arrested and bundled into police buses in towns nationwide. Reports of the maltreatment of Otpor members in custody have further infuriated a population exhausted by years of isolation and poverty.

The government's decision, last week, to brand the youngsters as "fascist hooligans" and "western-paid terrorists" has also increased the movement's appeal. "Otpor is as much about an idea, the idea of resistance, as anything else," says Vukasin Petrovic, one of the movement's ever-changing spokesmen. "The regime can beat us, but it can't beat or control ideas, and that is the key to Otpor's success."

Serbia has a student population, on paper at least, of around 250,000, although far fewer have bothered turning up to classes since the regime passed legislation in May 1998 stripping universities of their autonomy. As tenured professors, deans and de partmental heads have been ousted by government-approved replacements, thousands of students have enrolled in Belgrade's two alternative universities, which are run as underground establishments by those who lost their jobs.

Otpor, say its founders, was the direct result of the restrictive measures. "We started as a small protest movement in faculties and high schools," says Petrovic, a 23-year-old political science student at Belgrade Univer sity. "Now we have 27,000 signed-up members and eight million activists, because Otpor is now in the minds of most of the population. People realise we are not like opposition politicians - we are not in this to promote ourselves, we just want change."

Milosevic has feared student-power since hundreds of thousands of demonstrating undergraduates forced him to concede electoral fraud, and overturn the results of a municipal vote, in 1996. Now that they have re-emerged to inject a new lease of life into the opposition, he has begun to fear them even more. And experience has taught Otpor how to outwit the authorities: the movement is a network of loosely organised groups, without apparent leadership, to prevent penetration and arrests.

"Our [four] universities have always been overpopulated precisely because Milosevic has wanted to keep young, unemployed urban people off the streets," says Nicolic. "The regime has always tried to manipulate students by appointing professors who refused to grant them credits, or pass their exams, if they took part in campus protests."

Otpor's most significant weapon, so far, has been its symbol: a clenched fist that now graces more than 400,000 posters, 500,000 T-shirts and two million leaflets, match boxes and badges throughout Serbia. In some of Belgrade's recent mass demonstrations opposition leaders, including Zoran Djindjic, who heads the Democratic Party, have worn Otpor T-shirts in recognition of the movement's growing popularity.

"We are getting financial support from Serbs who live abroad," says Petrovic. Exiled youngsters, who are part of the country's growing brain-drain, have thrown their weight behind Otpor. They see it as the best vehicle to bring about political change that will allow them to return home.

Antagonism between the activists and the authorities has been exemplified by an almost-laughable war of posters now being fought on Belgrade's streets. Anxiety over the group is such that police have often forced people in Otpor t-shirts to take them off. Activists say that despite the threat of laws to end their "terrorist activities", the next step will be an increasing campaign of civil disobedience.

The regime's decision to close universities, after students threats of a mass walk-out this week, appears to have hardened the resolve of protestors fighting for democracy. Otpor activists said the measures were the clearest sign yet of the panic gripping the authorities.

"I don't think anything can stop us now," said Petrovic. "In fact, all these measures just make us much better protestors. Over the past five years the government has destroyed a generation of students by stopping exams and classes whenever it gets afraid and frankly, we've had enough."
