fields.headline: Street-wise teenagers fight youth crime
fields.standfirst: We know what gangs get up to, say youngsters masterminding estate projects
fields.trailText: An effective antidote to youth crime is given in a report on recruiting teenagers to turn round localities blighted by their contemporaries' vandalism, violence and theft.
fields.body:
An effective antidote to youth crime is given in a report on recruiting teenagers to turn round localities blighted by their contemporaries' vandalism, violence and theft.

Two years of pilot schemes have found that local young people, unemployed and many without school qualifications, can reach disaffected gangs and broker deals with adult authorities on their behalf.

Crime and fear of crime have dropped in districts ranging from Swansea to Bradford, according to the independent Local Government Information Unit, after the formation of youth action groups, funded by a range of charities and other agencies but run by under-25s. On a vandalised Bradford estate, emergency calls have dropped from more than 10 a week to nil after a youth team spent six months working with a gang that had targeted a parade of shops.

"We understand where they [gang members] are coming from," says Julie Rhodes, 19, a recruit on the Yorkshire city's project, organised by local voluntary groups with £400,000 of single regeneration budget funding. "We know what they get up to," adds Gavin Sunderland, 18, getting ready to go out on patrol. "We probably like the same music they do too, which helps."

The key to success has been recruiting such streetwise young people and genuinely taking their advice and acting on it, said the report, Taking Part, published by the information unit and the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders.

"The central complaint of most children and young people who have had difficult experiences is that they were not listened to or involved," said the report. Chris Bosley, the youth worker heading the Bradford project, called the five young women and seven youths in her team "incredibly clear headed and effective". She said: "We adults have a habit of saying 'God, I don't believe that goes on', but these kids are out there and they know that it does, and why it does. And that's a start in dealing with it."

The findings are the first national response to the 1997 Crime and Disorder Act, encouraging "young people and children to take part in deciding how to tackle crime at local, community and neighbourhood level".

Hilary Kitchin of the information unit toured experiments where teenagers had become policymakers and an informal community police force. "These examples show how you can bring about a change in attitude if you listen to what young people have to say. They set out guidelines that are the opposite of the old idea young people should be seen but not heard."

In Wolverhampton there are "primary school parliaments" and in Swansea there is a teenage "action against crime squad". Common to schemes, said the report, was a recognition young people knew about street life and were much more credible as problem solvers to their contemporaries.

The report, sent to all local councils, pointed out young people were far more likely to experience violent crime - affecting 21% of 16 to 24-year-olds in 1997, compared with 5% of the general population, but the public persistently focused on youth involvement in crime, possibly deterring policy-makers from consulting young people in finding solutions. "Adults appear to make strong connections between crime, young people and the disintegration of the community," it said. "It is important to be clear on the facts of youth crime, and to avoid these assumptions which feed negative views of young people and what they have to offer."

The report highlighted the hidden ingredient of such youth schemes which emerged when word had spread on the streets that young people played more than a token role, and that trust was genuinely devolved from adults.

Team members also benefited themselves, with nine of the 13 members of Bradford's first group taking university degrees in social work or specialist teaching after doing A-levels on the two year project.

Ms Bosley said: "Kadir came to us without any qualifications after hating school; he is now back at that same school as a full time mentor on 16 grand a year. He's worth it. He knows what it's like for the kids, because that's where he comes from. That's the heart of this project."

Taking Part, LGIU, 22 Upper Woburn Place, London WC1H 0TB; £15

fields.headline: The best bridge scene: The girl on the bridge
fields.trailText: Paris. Adele (Vanessa Paradis) stands on a bridge over the Seine, edging forward, preparing to jump.
fields.body: Paris. Adele (Vanessa Paradis) stands on a bridge over the Seine, edging forward, preparing to jump. A middle-aged man, Gabor (Daniel Auteuil), approaches. Adele doesn't notice. "I'd say you're about to screw up." Adele glances up. "I'm OK, thanks." "I mean it. You look desperate." "You think so?" "What are you playing at? Heads or tails? Who are you out to impress?" Adele stares down at the water. "Nobody. I never impressed anyone. I'm not starting now." "You're too young to be so sad. Are you terminally ill? Short of a kidney? A liver? A leg?" "No, I'm just short of_ a little guts. I'm scared. It's cold." Gabor laughs mirthlessly. " It's cold ! Do you think they heat it?" "I should blank it out." "Right. Think happy thoughts. They'll give you a push." "That'll be hard. Happy thoughts aren't my speciality. That's why I'm here, see?" "You know what I see? I see a waste ahead. And I hate waste." "Waste of what?" "You don't trash a good lightbulb." "This one burned out long ago." Gabor exhales. "You're depressing me." "So bug off! I'm at the end of my rope, OK?" "What rope? Look at you. Your rope's barely begun. This is just a bad patch." Adele takes a step forward. "My whole life's a bad patch." fields.headline: Back to work at Stormont
fields.trailText: David Trimble went back to his day job this morning. But as the Northern  Ireland executive got back to work, there were rumbles of continuing dissent  - and an even more ominous crackling of gunfire in the background.
fields.body:
David Trimble went back to his day job this morning. But as the Northern Ireland executive got back to work, there were rumbles of continuing dissent - and an even more ominous crackling of gunfire in the background.

The resumption of devolved government has come as a relief to most of the main parties in Ulster, and no doubt to its long-suffering people. But one of the most important power-brokers in the province, Ian Paisley, is refusing to give his blessing to the latest attempt to make the Good Friday peace accords work.

Two leading members of his Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) were absent from their government departments this morning. Peter Robinson, the minister for regional development, and Nigel Dodds, minister for social development, are said to be keen to resume their ministerial careers - though they are still refusing to attend cabinet meetings which include members of Sinn Fein.

But Mr Paisley has apparently set his mind against further power-sharing. His party council meets tonight to take a final decision. If the vote goes against participation, the two seats will be allocated to Mr Trimble's Ulster Unionist party, and to the moderate Alliance party.

The latest phase of power-sharing will no doubt survive a boycott by the DUP, though the new government will dismiss the Paisleyite faction at its peril.

Mr Trimble was on mischievous form on this morning's Radio Four Today programme, when he compared the DUP to an autocratic East European party, conducting its business behind closed doors. "We wait to see whether there's a puff of white smoke coming out from wherever they go into conference," he said - a throwaway gibe calculated to enrage Mr Paisley, who loathes all things papal.

Northern Ireland's First Minister has already bitterly offended his Sinn Fein colleagues, by remarking that the republican party has still be politically "house-trained".

With political nerves still scraped raw by the disputes of recent weeks, Mr Trimble would be well advised to suppress his predilection for cheap taunts, and instead brace himself for the coming storms. For it is clear that the Northern Ireland executive cannot expect plain sailing.

Its most immediate problem, as it returns to the bread-and-butter business of running the province, is to put behind it the corrosive row over IRA disarmament. But with the first weapons inspections due in a matter of days, the issue will remain at the forefront of public and political attention.

Then there is the continuing mutual recrimination between the Unionists and Sinn Fein over the vexed issues of police reform, and the flying of national flags over public buildings. The Unionists want to retain the name of the Royal Ulster Constabulary and the right to fly the Union flag - symbols of British rule vehemently rejected by republicans and for that matter the moderate nationalists of the Social Democratic and Labour Party.

John Taylor, the Ulster Unionist deputy leader, has raised the political temperature over the weekend by hinting that Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson has offered concessions to the party, to entice it back into power-sharing. If that is so, we could see yet another breakdown of the fragile devolution experiment.

A threat literally more deadly than any of the political shadow boxing, lurks on the streets of Northern Ireland. Recent days have brought a spate of shooting incidents in the murderous feud between two of the most ruthless loyalist paramilitary gangs, the Ulster Volunteer Force and a breakaway faction, the Loyalist Volunteer Force. A third group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, is said to be getting involved in the brutal dispute.

Even more chilling, the IRA has offered grim evidence that it too is still in business. It is hotly suspected of murdering a leading loyalist over the weekend. Eddie McCoy, gunned down in a Belfast suburban bar, was targeted not for his paramilitary activity, but for his alleged involvement in drug dealing.

The IRA long ago declared war on drug dealers; a war which has claimed at least 11 lives during the organisation's so-called ceasefire. There could be no clearer evidence that the republican group remains armed and belligerent.
